title: DroughtHit Corn Crop in Georgia Is Infested by Carcinogenic Toxin
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 29James Short had a wry smile on his face as he told of the drought that had cut his corn crop to an average of 34 bushels each on the 400 acres he planted, less than a third of a normal harvest.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% Municipal tax.)

title: BUILTIN OVERTIME ON BUSES ASSAILED
description: The Transit Authority's practice of paying nearly S60 million a year in overtime much of it built inwas severely criticized yesterday in a report by Sidney Schwartz, the state's Special Deputy Comptroller for New York City.

title: 4,650 HURT BY IMPORTS CERTIFIED FOR U.S. HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)The Labor Department today certified 4,650 workers in the steel and electronics industries as eligible for special Federal assistance on the ground that import competition eliminated their jobs.

title: Joffrey shows Off New Tarantella
description: Robert Joffrey's admiration for George Balanchine is unstinted, and from the beginning Mr. Balanchine has generously assisted his young colleague and competitor. In the past, the Joffrey Ballet has had Scotch Symphony, Donizetti Variations and, more recently, Square Dance in its repertory. Now, however, the Joffrey list of Balanchiniana seems to be reduced to simply the Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux. This received a welcome reinforcement at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Sunday night when the Joffrey Ballet presented the premiere of its new production of another Balanchine duet, Tarantella. Square Dance in its repertory. Now, however, the Joffrey list of Balanchiniana seems to be reduced to simply the Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux. This received a welcome reinforcement at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Sunday night when the Joffrey Ballet presented the premiere of its new production of another Balanchine duet, Tarantella.

title: D.V. McNamee Jr., Founder and Head Of Banking Concern
description: Daniel V. McNamee Jr., chairman of the First Albany Corporation, an investment banking concern that he founded in 1952 and that now has offices in 11 upstate and New England cities, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Loudonville, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: MANILA, Oct. 31The news that the World Bridge Federation intends to suspend Italy, announced here last week, has produced angry reaction ??om some Italians.

title: Israeli Rights and Wrongs
description: What else is new? Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations, Chaim Herzog, asked after last week's 131to1 vote in the General Assembly censuring Israel for establishing settlements in the territories it has occupied since 1967. What is new is that virtually all Israel's friends, including all the West European governments, joined in the vote of censure. The Israelis could take little comfort from the United States abstention. Washington has often denounced the settlements as obstacles peace; it abstained purportedly because its cochairmanship of the forthcoming Geneva conference dictated a neutral posture.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Justice Agency Holds Rights Act Does Not Apply to the Bakke Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Department of Justice is drafting a second brief in the Bakke case to assert to the Supreme Court that Congress did not intend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to prohibit preferential treatment for minorities even if whites were penalized as a result.

title: HELMS, EXC.I.A, CHIEF, PLEADS NO CONTEST TO 2 MISDEMEANOK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, pleaded nolo contenders, or n?? contest, today to a criminal information charging him with two misdemeanol counts of failing to testify fully, comepletely and accurately before a Sen?? committee.

title: CLOTHING WORKERS UNION SEEKS IMPORT PENALTIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)A major clothing workers union asked the Carter Administration today to impose penalties on imports of apparel and textiles from eight South American and Far Eastern countries.

title: Nets Come Up With $320,000 Owed to Knicks
description: The Nets met the deadline yesterday for paying $320,000 they owed the Knicks. The money was the second payment of the 20year, $4 million territorial indemnification due the Knicks when they allowed the Nets to join the National Basketball Association for the 197677 season and play in the same area.

title: Met Approves Paid President, Subordinate Artistic Director
description: A controversial new form of top management for the Metropolitan Museum of Arta fulltime paid president and a subordinate artistic director was approved yesterday by the museum corporation's members, who voted, 480 to 186, for the plan at their annual meeting.

title: A Long Career In Intelligence Richard McGarrah Helms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31To some who had watched Richard McGarrah Helms over the years, it was ironic that he pleaded no contest today to a misdemeanor charge of failing to give a Senate committee full answers in 1973 about the role of the Central Intelligence Agency in Chile. It was ironic because cause in his many years in dealing with Congressional committees on highly sensitive issues, the 64yearold Mr. Helms had managed to acquire a reputation as an official who told the straight facts while avoiding the political fights that often surrounded those facts.

title: Maine Gets $426,000 Grant
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 31 (UPI)The Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has awarded a $426,000 grant to the Maine Criminal Justice Planning and Assistance Agency, the Maine Congressional delegation announced today. The grant is to be used for the operation of the planning agency, which is also responsible for the development of a comprehensive plan intended to identify Maine's most pressing criminal justice needs.

title: Kidnappers of Dutch Businessman Silent
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The kidnappers of Maurits Caransa, the Dutch businessman, remained silent today after an appeal by the family to make contact.

title: Procter & Gamble Net Rises 11.5% On Recovery in Profits for Coffee
description: Some recovery in profit margins on coffee products contributed to the 11.5 percent increase in earnings reported yesterday by the Proctor & Gamble Company for its first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: Carey Urges Revised Aid Formula For Working Family in Relief Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Governor Carey described the Carter Administration's new welfarerevision bill here today as sound in general concept but requiring a major change in the aid formula for the working poor to avoid disastrous effects for New York State.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Blanche Gaines, 87, Literary Agent And a Former Music Reviewer
description: Blanche F. Gaines, a leading literary agent from the early years of television drama to her retirement in 1967, died yesterday in a Stratford, Conn., nursing home. She was 87 years old and the widow of Charles Gaines, a radio producer.

title: Lifting of Pro Age Barrier Roils CanadaU.S. Hockey
description: Ken Linseman, a gifted center for a Kingston, Ontario, junior team, saw no point in playing another amateur season when he knew he could be playing in the professional leagues. Over the weekend the 19yearold Linseman scored a goal in each of his first two games for the Birmingham Bulls of the World Hockey Association. That was after a Federal district court in Hartford granted an injunction Friday against the W.H.A.'s preventing the underaged player from competing.

title: Article 3  No Title
Conferees Ease the Deadlock on Medicaid Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31House and Senate conferees took their first major step today toward breaking a fourmonth deadlock on abortions financed by Medicaid by reaching tentative agreement on treatment for victims of rape and incest.

title: Advertising
description: Centsoff coupons continue to grow as a method of promoting product sales, and growing right along with them as a delivery vehicle to consumers is the freestanding newspaper insert.

title: Joan Tetzel, Actress, Is Dead at 56; Played Leading Roles in Many Hits
description: Joan Tetzel, whose acting career embraced outstanding roles on Broadway, Off Broadway and in motion pictures. died yesterday at her home in England. She was 56 years old.

title: Indian, Starting Job as Aide to Interior Secretary, Sees Backlash in Congress Over Tribal Land Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Forrest J. Gerard, a Blackfoot Indian from Montana, has taken over as Assistant Secretary of Interior for Indian Affairs at a time when his people are as embattled, he says, as his ancestors were when whites tried to take valuable reservation land in the 1880's.

title: Steel Production for the Week Shows an Increase of 0.1%
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 29 was up 0.1 percent to 2.4 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.3 million tons in the preceding week.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The jailed president of Lakeland's striking teachers said last night that he was willing to accept Governor Carey's call and enter into binding arbitration in a bid to end the 35day teachers strike, the longest in the state's history.

title: 3 Times Speedy JazzRock
description: Jazzrock concerts have become savage rites at which speed of execution is worshiped, often in a manner that would be appropriate for a Saturdaynight wrestling match. The Beacon Theater's Sunday evening program, with the Larry CoryellAlphonse Mouzon Band, Brand X, and David Sancious and Tone, ran true to form, though there were signs that jazzrock musicians are becoming increasingly restive at their listeners' demands for lightningfast runs and little else.

title: Ford Lifting Base Price of Fiesta By 3.2%, to $3,799, a $119 Rise
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP)The base sticker price of the new Ford Fiesta went up 3.2 percent as of today, the Ford Motor Company announced. Ford said the average price of the new Germanassembled import, after options are taken into account, would rise by 3.7 percent, or $161.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Lambros D. Callimahos, a Musician And Authority on Military Codes
description: Lambros D. Callimahos, an authority on military codes and a concert musician, died Friday of cancer at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 66 years old and lived in New Carrollton, Md.

title: WILLIAM F. CALLAHAN JR., PUBLISHING EXECUTIVE, 62
description: William Francis Callahan Jr., who retired in 1968 as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Dell Publishing Company, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street.

title: Article 1  No Title
JESSE J. LOESER
description: Jesse J. Loeser, who retired in 1965 after serving 20 years as a civil engineer for the New York City Housing Authority, died Sunday in Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.3. He was 78 years old and lived at 88 Heck Avenue, Ocean Grove, N.J.

title: Helms Accord: Balancing Security and Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Very little of official Washington has ever been comfortable with the criminal investigation of Richard Helms. Many, professional Central Intelligence Agency officers, military men and others, believe that if Mr. Helms lied to Congress he did so because he felt that doing so served a higher cause, the national security of the country. They have speculated that he may have had secret orders to lie from Presidents or, in the case involved, from Henry A. Kissinger, who was Secretary of State.

title: Records of College Football Teams and the Schedules of Their Remaining Games
description: *Night game

title: U.S Officials Still Unsure Whether Geneva Parley Can Be Convened in 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Government officials said today that they expected to know in a week or 10 days whether a Middle East peace conference could be convened in Geneva by the end of the year.

title: Torrez Opts for FreeAgent Status
description: Mike Torrez, the pitcher who gained two of the Yankees four World Series victories, declared himself a free agent yesterday and instantly became the most attractive starting pitcher available in Friday's pitchingpoor freeagent reentry draft.

title: Berkowitz's Father Is Designated To Manage Killer Suspect's Estate
description: The 68yearold father of David R. Berkowitz, the man suspected of being the 44caliber killer, was officially designated to manage his adopted son's estate after a 30minute hearing yesterday at which the suspect testified that he had no right to control his own affairs.

title: Toronto Gunman Yields Hostages When Given a Bottle of Whisky
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31 (UPI)A gunman who traded 29 hostages he was holding at gunpoint in a bank for a bottle of Scotch whisky was charged today with two counts of robbery and one count of conspiracy to commit robbery.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that Heinrich Himmler ran Auschwitz. The commandant of the World War II German prison camp was Rudolph Hss.

title: Races in Westchester Could Shift Control of Board to the Democrats
description: WHITE PLAINSWestchester County Democrats, once an ineffectual minority in a county known nationally as a Republican stronghold, are striving this year to extend their political base and perhaps become the county's dominant party.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1977

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: SquatterThieves May Force South Bronx Businesses to Leave
description: Young thieves living as squatters in a cluster of vacant, cityowned buildings in the South Bronx have been burglarizing local businesses so brazenly that some merchants think they may have to move their companies and several hundred jobs out of New York.

title: 15 N.F.L. Teams in Contention For 8 Postseason Playoff Berths
description: Walter Payton stopped running because he had no interest in breaking Gale Sayers's record. O. J. Simpson appealed to management not to discharge the coach, Jim Ringo, but Simpson may be ready to quit. The Colts took their revenge or the Steelers, who About were so angry Dwight (Mad Dog) White smashed his Pro helmet. Joe Theismain Football proved again that a quarterback who can move is more effective than one who cannot, and the Raiders exposed the Broncos as a team with a questionable future.

title: Legal Services Staff to Strike
description: Members of the Legal Services Staff Association, who represent indigent New Yorkers in LandlordTenant Court, voted last night to strike on this morning.

title: DISSIDENT CATHOLICS WIN A CASE IN COURT
description: MINEOLA, LI., Oct. 31A dissident Roman Catholic group, the Society of Saint Pius X, won court permission today to hold a special dedication mass this Sunday at its new United States headquartersbut with only 25 persons in attendance.

title: D'ArcyMacManus Gets Bally Account
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company, the Chicagobased maker of such things as slot and pinball machines, has decided to take a chance on D'ArcyMacManus & Masius.

title: 3 WESTERN POWERS VETO MOVES IN U.N. TO CURB SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31The United States, Britain and France used their vetoes in the Security Council today to block three Africansponsored resolutions that would have imposed stringent economic penalties on South Africa because of its repressive racial practices against blacks.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A former Bergen Country jail guard and an inmate pleaded guilty yesterday in Superior Court in Hackensack to charges of conspiring to smuggle cocaine into the minimumsecurity Jail annex.

title: ?? Drown as Greek Ship Sinks
description: BREST, France, Oct. 31 (UPI)Ten of??he 21 crew members of the Greek freight??r Tina drowned when the vessel sank today in the Bay of Biscay, the coast ??uard radio station said. Six other crew members are missing.

title: Deaths
description: ATKINSONJoseph P., on October 30, 1977, devoted husband of the late Della (nee Curtin) and Grace nee Cox), beloved lather of George, Joseph Jr. and Mary Rush, also survived by eight grandchildren and five loving great grandchildren. Reposing from 25 and 79PM at RiverdaleonHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. at west 261 street. Mass of christian burial St. Margaret's Church, Wednesday 11AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery

title: People and Business
description: In a move described as a major restructuring of top management, the Minnesota Power and Light Company created four new senior vice presidencies, one new vice presidency and the position to director of planning, all effective Jan. 1.

title: Court Lets Stand A Ruling Favoring Doctor in Sex Case
description: The Supreme Court yesterday let stand a ruling that a policeman's eyewitness account of how a doctor in Dutchess County, N. Y., allegedly sexually assaulted an anesthetized female patient could not he used as evidence in a trial.

title: Creedmoor's Open Cates at Center of Controversy
description: Insanity was his defense. And the verdict was not guilty by reason of insanity for the murder of his 25yearold wife and his 17monthold son.

title: Chiefs Discharge Wiggin
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31  In the wake of a 447 defeat laid on his team by the Cleveland Browns, Paul Wiggin was dismissed today as head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Strikes at Lockheed and Boeing Are Expected to Be Prolonged
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31Prospects appear to be growing for prolonged strikes against the Lockheed and Boeing companies by more than 40,000 aerospace workers in California and four other states.

title: Opera: Met's New Rigoletto Employs a Unit Set
description: The Metropolitan Opera staged a new production of an old opera last night. With sets and costumes by Tanya Moiseiwitsch, produced by John Dexter, Verdi's Rigoletto, one of the alltime favorites, was revealed to an anticipatory audience. Well might anticipation have run high, with such singers as Placido Domingo, Ileana Cortrubas, Sherrill Milnes and Justino Diaz in leading roles.

title: ENERGY TAX MEASURE IS PASSED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31After weeks of dismantling, amending and restoring, the Senate tonight passed an energy tax bill 52 to 35, but the provisions differed greatly from the President's original proposal.

title: Expected Rise in Foreign Demand Increases Soybean Futures Prices
description: Soybean futures prices jumped 14 to 17 cents a bushel yesterday, with the three nearest deliveries showing the best gains on expectations that the weekly export figures would show increased foreign demand.

title: DAVID REGOSIN
description: David Regosin, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Regosin, Edwards, Freeman & Stone, died Friday in Nassau Community Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 103 Muirfield Road in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Marijuana Suspect Held
description: RUNNEMEDE, N.J., Oct. 31 (UPI)Smoel Hamdi, 40 years old, of Hallandale, Fla., was held today on a charge of transporting $110,000 worth of mrijuana on the New Jersey Turnpike. The police said he had 230 pounds of it in the trunk of his car.

title: Lavish Apartment Is Said to Cost Bonwit Teller Chairman His Job
description: A Park Avenue triplex apartment built and decorated for John Schumacher over a year's period was the issue over which he lost his $200,000ayear post as chairman of Bonwit Teller last Friday, trade sources indicated yesterday.

title: About New York
description: Beyond the stage downtown, beyond the one free place for celebrating being human and black, four young actors whose talent has been forged in tragedy imposed on a vast tribal scale have no place to go but home.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Champion, Beat Thy Typewriter
description: They were calling him an old man now. Henry James could take that. He was old, old in the bone, old in the spirit. All those years of brooding about the significance of the American heiress in Europe had taken it out of him. But, by George!, he was still Henry James. The Master. And he could still raise a lump on the jaw of any writer who stepped into the same patty with him.

title: Dan Horn Scores
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 31In a blanket finish, Dan Horn, the 125pound highweight, closed strongly in the stretch tonight to win the $53,650 Cliff Hanger Handicap for New Jersey breds on grass at the Meadowlands.

title: JOSEPH ZERILLI, 79; DETROIT MAFIA BOSS
description: GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Oct. 31 (UPI) Joseph Zerilli, the Mafia boss in Detroit and last of the Prohibitionera gang war veterans, died yesterday in a suburban Detroit hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Flood Threat Closes Coast Park
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Oct. 31 (UPI)Big Sur State Park has been closed indefinitely to prevent damage from possible major floods of storm water over ground denuded by last summer's 156,000acre fire. The fire in the Ventana wilderness area burned off ground cover that usually slows down runoff from storms. Park officials said the closing of the popular 800acre camping site might last as long as five years.

title: U.S. Court Orders Improvements In Medical Careat Women's Prison
description: Medical procedures at the state prison for women in Bedford Hills, N. Y., were criticized yesterday by a Federal appeals court, which cited interminable delays and outright denials of medical care to suffering inmates.

title: GEM BROKER ACCUSED OF PLOTTING ROBBERY
description: A 30yearold diamond broker from Brooklyn has been arrested and accused of plotting to rob gem merchants and of intending to fence the stolen diamonds for part of the proceeds.

title: Koch Says He'd Build Westway If Carey Persists in Backing It
description: Representative Edward I. Koch yesterday reiterated his opposition to the Westway even as he seemed to shift his emphasis once again by reaffirming his willingness to build the $1.16 billion highway if he failed to persuade Governor Carey to oppose it.

title: U.S. REPORTED READY TO LEAVE THE I.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  President Carter plans to announce tomorrow that the United States will withdraw from the International Labor Organization on Wednesday, Administration sources said today.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter ustands for new annual high and dindicates new low.

title: RATE MOVES BY FED CUT PRICES ON BONDS
description: In a move that surprised the credit markets, the Federal Reserve yesterday pushed interest rates higher, presumably in anticipation of an unacceptably large increase in the money market supply to be made public Thursday.

title: Muskie Has Severe Back Pains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Senator Edmund S. Muskie entered Bethesda Medical Center today for treatment of severe back pains, his office announced. A spokesman for the 63yearold Maine Democrat said that it was not known how long he would remain in thehospital.

title: Times to Raise Rates
description: Come the New Year, The New York Times will be increasing its ad rates. When it raised them last January it said the average increase was 7 percent. This time, however, it makes the point that because there are so many sections and classifications an average percentage would be meaningless. Fred D. Thompson, vice president of advertising, did say that had the new rates been in effect for the 12 months ending Sept. 30 it would have increased ad revenues by $21.6 million. That represents a 9.6 percent increase over actual ad revenues for that year.

title: Last Direct Travel Link Is Lost Between Tanzania and Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 31 (UPI)The last direct travel link between Kenya and Tanzania were severed today, underscoring the deep political and economic differences between the two East African neighbors.

title: France Is Under Public Pressure To Free 8 Kidnapped in the Sahara
description: PARIS, Oct. 31The French Government is coming under increasing public pressure to do something to free eight French technicians being held prisoner by guerrillas fighting for the independence of the former Spanish Sahara, now divided between Morocco and Mauritania.

title: HIGH COURT AGREES TO REVIEW DECISION ON INSURANCE SALES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether insurance companies can be sued for violation of the antitrust laws when they join together and refuse to sell a certain kind of policy to anyone seeking such protection.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: Time1:14 2/5. ScratchedAncient Rock, Cocktail Hour, Flowing Free, Second Effort, Marys Pride.

title: Soviet Star Radio Announcer Recalls Great Moments in History
description: MOSCOW, Oct, 31Yuri B. Levitan speaks in a deep, orotund baritone and for radio listeners here, his might as well be the voice of history itself.

title: Conference Standings
description: Pro Transactions

title: That Raider Punter's Rocky Mt. High
description: DENVER, Oct. 31Hardly anybody was wearing orange here today. Blue was the more appropriate color now that the Denver Broncos have been broken. The firmest foot in the Oakland Raiders' stirrups belonged to Ray Guy, the punter in the Super Bowl champions' 2414 victory. After six consecutive triumphs, including a 307 ambush of the Raiders in Oakland two weeks earlier, the success of the Broncos had inspired Orange Sunday for the rematch. Just about all of the 75,007 loyalists in Mile High Stadium were wearing something that was orange. Particularly popular were Orange Crush Tshirts sold by the softdrink firm that inspired the nickname for the Broncos' defensive units. And about 75,000 orange placards proclaiming Go Broncos were handed out free. The assembly at Mile High Stadium resembled a college crowd at other orangeflavored institutionsTexas or Tennessee or Syracuse. In pro football's version of a Rocky Mountain High for followers of a team that has never made the playoffs, one banner proclaimed, Next Year Is Here! Stomp the Snake, and Rattle the Snake. But the Bronco boosters were worrying about an arm when they should have been concerned with a legRay Guy's punting leg.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Companies List Reports Covering Their Sales and Earnings Figures
Rhodesian Blacks And Briton Confer But Only for Hour
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Talks between black Rhodesian guerrilla leaders and a top British military official, scheduled to last two days, broke up today after one hour.

title: Westchester Bus Talks Go On Past Deadline
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y., Tuesday, Nov. 1 (AP)Negotiators trying to avert a strike against three Westchester County bus lines stopped the clock just before midnight last night to continue their talks past the strike deadline.

title: HELMS, EXC.I.A. CHIEF, PLEADS NO CONTEST TO 2 MISDEMEANORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, pleaded nolo contendere, or no contest, today to a criminal information charging him with two misdemeanor counts of failing to testify fully, completely and accurately before a Senate committee.

title: Glick and Argent Cited in Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange commission yesterday charged Allen R. Glick, a controversial Las Vegas casino operator and the largest borrower from the Teamster Pension Fund, and his wholly owned Argent Corporation, with fraud in connection with Argent debentures.

title: San Francisco Voters' Interest Centers on Airport Bond Issue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31Ballot issues are generating more interest among the electorate here than are the 115 candidates who are vying for 10 local seats in next week's elections. And of the 22 propositions, which include oroposals to ban billboards and buy a hotel, the most controversial is a $90 million airport bond issue that opponents say could drive the city broke.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: SUIT CHARGING GULF WITH FRAUD IN SALE OF URANIUM OPENS
description: SANTA FE, New Mxico, Oct. 31Opening arguments began today in a billiondollar uranium suit, with the United Nuclear Corporation charging that the Gulf Oil Corporation knew that prices would rise steadily when United Nuclear signed contracts to supply Gulf with iranium at relatively low prices.

title: Columbia Hall Honors Hogan
description: A new residence hail at Columbia University was dedicated yesterday in memory of the late Frank S. Hogan, a Columbia alumnus, who served as Manhattan District Attorney for 32 years. The Frank Smithwick Hogan Residence Hall on the southeast corner of Broadway and 114th Street, formerly St. Luke's Nursing Home, provides 26 four and fiveroom apartments for 114 residents and space for the university's comptroller's office.

title: BBDO International Gains
description: BBDO International's thirdquarter revenues were up over the same period last year by 9.8 percent to $22.5 million while net income showed an 11.8 percent growth to $1.9 million, or 76 cents a share, compared to 69 cents.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Article 2  No Title
The Contest for Queens District Attorney Is Fired Up by NadjariSantucci Debates
description: Standees lined the walls and with their backs to the doors of the auditorium of Public School 99 in Kew Gardens, Queens. The men and women had bolted their dinners after work and rushed to the school for a political debate. They did not leave until it ended after 10 P.M.

title: Safe Airlines and Unsafe Airports
description: Each time an American airline sells a ticket, it assumes a responsibility for the traveler that goes beyond the proper maintenance of its equipment. Today, airport searches and luggage checks represent a commitment to every passenger's protection against hijackers. A traveler should be able to board a United States carrier with confidence that American security standards are being observed at every stop along the route.

title: CATHERINE L. O'BRIEN, 81, LEADER IN HOME PRODUCTS
description: Catherine L. O'Brien, honorary chair man of Stanley Home Products Inc., which she cofounded in 1931, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 81 years old.

title: U.S. REPORTED READY TO LEAVE THE I. L. O.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  President Carter plans to announce tomorrow that the United States will withdraw from the rInternational Labor Organization on Wednesday, Administration sources said today.

title: Carborundum Gets A Takeover Offer; Plan Being Studied
description: The Carborundum Company, a leading upstate manufacturer of abrasive products, disclosed yesterday that it had received a formal takeover bid, but it declined to identify the bidder.

title: Giscard Assures Algerians
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 31 (Reuters)President Valry Giscard d'Estaing has assured the Algerian Government that France is not pinning a commando raid to rescue the eight technicins who are believed held by Polisario guerrillas in Mauritania, informed French sources said here today.

title: Lexington House Changes
description: Charles Mandel, 43yearold president of Lexington House, publishers of Madison Avenue magazine and Client/ Media News, said yesterday that he is resigning from that post but will remain a stockholder, a director and a member of the editorial board. During the three years he was at the helm of Madison Avenue, the publication made a dramatic economic turnaround.

title: Israeli Jobs Paling to Win Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31A fiveyear study of attitudes toward Israel among 1,000 Arabs from occupied areas with steady jobs in Israeli enterprises has shown no significant decrease in hostility, a university psychology professor reports.

title: Shaping Policy: A Military Role
description: With Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in the van, the military has recently been taking great pains to define and explain its role in the Presidential decisionmaking process on defense issues.

title: House, in 4070 Vote, Urges Seoul To Cooperate in Scandal Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The House of Representatives voted today 407 to 0 to call on the South Korean Government to cooperate fully and without reservation in the investigation of the Korean influence buying scandal.

title: 3 WESTERN POWERS VETO MOVES IN U.N. TO CURB SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31The United States, Britain and France used their vetoes in the Security Council today to block three Africansponsored resolutions that would have imposed stringent economic penalties on South Africa because of its repressive racial practices against blacks.

title: School for Circus Arts Is the Only Show in Town
description: New York City's only circus school opens today.

title: South Florida U. Names Head
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP)The state Board of Regents today named John Mott Brown, director of the Center for Visual Science at the University of Rochester, to head the University of South Florida in Tampa. Dr. Brown, who is 52 years old, has a Ph.D. in psychology and has taught at various universities since 1954. He is expected to take over as president of the university in January.

title: Patti Labelle's Debut as Solo Reveals Exciting Performer
description: It's not surprising that of the three members of Labelle, which broke up last year, the one who would make the strongest initial impact on her own was the group's lead singer, Patti Labelle. On Sunday Miss Labelle gave the first of two almost soldout concerts at Avery Fisher Hall(the second was last night.) These were her first solo appearances in this city, and despite some technical and musical problems, she was a great success.

title: Randy Weston's Ellingtonia
description: Randy Weston, making his first appearance in New York in more than two years at the opening of this year's series of Heavenly Jazz Concerts, a benefit for the dayschool scholarship fund of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, on Sunday afternoon, was the dominant figure of the program as both pianist and composer. But the spirit of Duke Ellington was constantly present in the church.

title: Dow Declines by 4.33 to 818.35, Ending 3Day, 21Point Advance
description: The stock market's threeday advance ended yesterday as investor uncertainty over the economy and interest rates sent prices moderately lower.

title: Fume Fear Halts Graffiti Work
description: New York City's Transit Authority has suspended four procedures for cleaning graffiti from subway cars because of a growing concern among transit workers and riders about the possible harmful effects of the cleaning fluid.

title: High Court Backs Drug Hunt OfJersey LongHair Drivers
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 31The United States Supreme Court left standing today a ruling that the New Jersey state police cannot be barred from stopping longhaired drivers on the state's highways and searching their cars for what plaintiffs said was the hope of finding marijuana or other illicit drugs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that Heinrich Himmler ran Auschwitz. The commandant of the World War II German prison camp was Rudolph Hss.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI Kenya, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Somali guerrillas smashed the Ethiopian Army's first offensive against them in the mountains of eastern Ethiopia over the weekend, the Mogadishu radio said today.

title: Carey Tells of Surplus, Says It Will Aid Tax Refund
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced projections of a substantial budget surplus for the state for this fiscal year. He said most of it would he used to speed tax refundsa move that will both discourage Republican calls for an immediate tax cut and bolster the chances that one will be enacted before next year's state elections.

title: KOCH WINS BACKING OF SANITATION UNION
description: Representative Edward I. Koch, who in his campaign for Mayor of New York has sharply attacked the performance of some municipal workers, yesterday won the endorsement of the 8,000member Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

title: URBS EASED BY MARCOS IN ADVANCE OF POLLING
description: MANILA, Oct. 31 (UPI)President Ferinand E. Marcos eased martial law retrictions today to allow free debate on ??he referendum scheduled for Dec. 17 on whether his fiveyearold authoritarian ??ule should continue.

title: GiantsCardinals Scoring
description: SECOND QUARTER

title: Net Savings Inflows Fell in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Net inflows into Federally insured savings and loan institutions fell sharply in September to $1.65 billion from $2.63 billion in August, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. The board attributed the decline to the recent rise in openmarket interest rates, which has probably diverted funds from savings accounts.

title: Pound Up 6c to $1.84 as Britain, Fearing Inflation, Lifts Money Rein
description: LONDON, Oct. 31The Government relaxed its tight grip on the pound today and the newly liberated currency soared by more than 6 cents to $1.84.

title: College, Anyone? It's a Student's Market
description: Joann wants to study nursing at a college within a hundred miles of New York City that is neither too big nor too small. She has straight A's.

title: Virginia Man Found Guilty
description: A jury in Manhattan convicted Augu?? tine Paris Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va.,?? Federal charges of tax evasion and co?? spiracy to receive 70 pounds of heroi?? The prosectors Lawrence B. Pedowitz al?? Betty Santangelo said evidence at t?? eightday trial showed that Mr. Paris h?? received heroin imported from Hot?? Kong by way of Vancouver, B.C. Jud?? Gerard L. Goettel will sentence the d?? fendant on Dec. 16 in the Federal Distil?? Court at Foley Square.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANK SUES WATERHOUSE
description: The International Bank, a financial holding company, yesterday sued the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Company for $9 million in connection with the collapse of a Bahamian bank the company controls.

title: Farmers Receive 1% Price Increase, First for 5 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Prices farmers get for raw products rose 1 perI cent between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15, the first increase in five months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: ENERGY TAX MEASURE IS PASSED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31After weeks of dismantling, amending and restoring, the Senate tonight passed an energy tax bill 52 to 35, but the provisions differed greatly from the President's original proposal.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A new United States corporation, known as Iveco Trucks of North America, has been organized to market mediumduty Dieselpowered trucks in this country, Umberto Agnelli, chairman of Iveco B.V. and vice chairman of Fiat, announced yesterday in Amsterdam.

title: Dobler Stars In 280 Rout Of the Giants
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31The Giants were rudely awakened tonight to the possibility that, no, they will not be in the National Football League playoffs this season.

title: Senate Confirms Pierre N. Leval
description: The United States Senate has confirmed the nomination of Pierre N. Leval, to a judgeship in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Leval, who is now chief assistant to District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan will take over the Southern District bench of Judge Dudley B. Bonsai, who has retired.

title: Flu Forces Duran Out of Garden Bout
description: Roberto Duran of Panama has pulled out of his nontitle, 10round bout against Wilfredo Benitez at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 18 and will be replaced by Bruce Curry of Los Angeles.

title: Study Finds Dispute With Israel Would Hurt the Carter Race in 1980
description: A confrontation with Israel over peace in the Middle East would draw politica opposition against the Carter Administration not only from American Jews, but also from a significant cross section of American society, according to a study published in Commentary magazine. The seudy added that this opposition would have a devastating effect on President Carter's chances for reelection.

title: Unveilings
description: MARMORUnvellin0 of a monument tothe memory of Fannie Marmor of Norwayne Court, Brooklyn, NY at Mount Carmel Cemetery Cypress Ave, Brooklyn, November 1, 1977 122PM.

title: Oregon Owner Suspended
description: Oregon's own horseracing scandal became official last night when the ownerbreeder of two horses, which proved to be older than the ages claimed for them, was suspended for five years and ordered to return almost $30,000 in prize money they earned in their careers.

title: William Kaiser, Chief Engineer Of the Superliner United States
description: William Kaiser, chief engineer of the superliner United States from her maiden voyage in 1952 to his retirement in 1967, died of cancer on Sunday in St. Rose's Home. He was 75 years old and lived at 511 East 20th Street.

title: REMOVAL OF JUDGE ASKED IN WALLACE DIVORCE CASE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 31 (UPI)Attorneys for Cornelia Wallace asked an appellate court today to remove Circuit Judge John W. Davis 3d from hearing the divorce petitions filed by her and Gov: George C. Wallace.

title: Completing the Mental Care Revolution
description: Thousands of former state mental patients wander the streets of New York City. More are on the way. They fill perhaps a third of the rooms of the welfare hotels, mostly on the West Side. They wander Times Square and Broadway, usually not dangerous, but often offending scaring people with their unpredictable and unconventional behavior.

title: Diamond Broker Accused Of Plotting to Rob Others
description: A 30yearold diamond broker from Brooklyn has been arrested and accused of plotting the robbery of gem merchants arid of intending to fence the stolen diamonds for part of the proceeds.

title: Steelworkers Avert Strike in an Accord With Can Concerns
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 3 (UPI)  The United Steelworkers of America ratified a new contract with the nation's four major can companies today, averting a scheduled midnight strike by 30,000 union workers in the United States and Canada.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOOD FOR THOUGHT The Lunch & Learn series so popular with workers in the financial district of Manhattan have resumed at Pace University, one block east of City Hall.

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Rise
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the wekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Women Defying SalesTax Edict
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, Oct. 31Women volunteers for the Burdette Tomlin Memorial Hospital Auxiliary said today they would stop collecting the state sales tax in a nonprofit gift shop tomorrow and that they were prepared to go to jail for their action.

title: Oil Spilled in Galveston Collision
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Oct. 31 (UPI)Two barge tows collided before dawn today at a threeway channel junction, dumping 42,000 gallons of thick black oil into Galveston Bay. No one was hurt in the 4 A.M. accident, but Lieut. Jack Hardin of the Coast Guard said a slick several thousand yards long lapped at Bolivar Peninsula and threatened wildlife on Pelican Island.

title: Government Overlapping Studied
description: AUGUSTA, Me. (UPI)A gubernatorial group was named to se if county and regional planing commisions and Federal administrative districts in Maine were coordinating their efforts efficiently. The Task Force on Regional and District Organizations was set up to minimize areas of jurisdiction and duplication of effort among the organizations, Gov. James B. Longley said.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31A new state commission designed to study breaches of personal privacy was organized today, but was unable to agree on what it should investigate.

title: Beame Asks State Help for Budget
description: In one of his last budget presentations as he neared the end of his term of office, Mayor Beame yesterday called on Governor Carey and the State Legislature to enact $350 million worth of items he said would help close New York City's deficit in the next fiscal year.

title: Six Good Buys
description: It may take some looking, but you can still find relatively inexpensive boots that are stylish as well as long lasting. Above are six examples.

title: Horse Show Program
description: 9:00Model green conformation hunter.

title: 3d Ohio Episcopal Church Studies Secession Over Ordaining Women
description: COSHOCTON, Ohio, Oct. 31 (AP)A third Ohio Episcopal congregation is discussing secession from the national church because women priests are being ordained.

title: Yale and Princeton Set For a 100th Encounter
description: Yale and Princeton will meet for the 100th time in a football game Saturday at Princeton. By the reaction of the two teams, it is just another of those old YalePrinceton thingsnothing special other than life or death in the Big Three.

title: Offering of Detroit Edison Stock Set
description: An offering of 4 million shares of the common stock of the Detroit Edison Company will be made today, according to Morgan Stanley & Company and the E. F. Hutton & Company underwriters. The tentative price, set by the underwriters last night, was $16 a share, the same price at which the stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. This would make the total offering worth about $64 million.

title: Machine Tool Orders Up in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31United States machine tool orders rose to 253.8 million in September from $250.7 million in August, the National Machine Tool Builders Association said. Shipments also rose in the month, to $211.8 million from about $145 million, while the order backlog increased to $2 bilion from $1.96 billion. So far this year, new orders have totaled $2.15 billion, a 42 percent increase over the yearearlier level.

title: Christian Church Joins a Boycott Against Stevens Textile Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The 1.3millionmembers Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) said today that it had joined the national boycott of the J. P. Stevens textile company.

title: Creedmoor's Open Gates at Center of Controversy
description: Insanity was his defense. And the verdict was not guilty by reason of insanity for the murder of his 25yearold wife and his 17monthold son.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The Internal Revenue Service, in its first major policy move since Jerome Kurtz became commissioner, yesterday issued nine important rulings that greatly inhibit the use of tax shelters.

title: Callaghan Makes a Comeback but Pares Program
description: LONDON, Oct. 31In one of the final royal pageants of Jubilee Year, Queen Elizabeth II will open the new session of Parliament on Thursday with her annual speech from the thronea speech that will outline an unusually modest legislative program.

title: DESCRIPTIONS VARY FOR ROBBERRAPIST
description: ALLENDALE, Oct. 31A marauding robber and suspected rapist who broke into at least three suburban homes here Friday night and held five hostages briefly at gunpoint before eluding an allnight police search in thick, swampy woods was portrayed in paradoxical terms today by investigators.

title: When the Govern or Became Brendino Byrne
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31Governor Byrne and the Housing. Education and Welfare Secretary, Joseph A. Califano Jr., became Brendino Byrne and Giuseppe Califano today as they toured Newark's predominantly Italian North Ward.

title: Aides in U.S. Feel Saudis Lack Skills To Use New Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Saudi Arabia is running into difficulty handling the military supplies purchased from the United States, raising questions about the Saudis' ability to absorb advanced arms over the next few years, according to Pentagon and Congressional sources.

title: Economic Changes Upset Israelis But There Is No Rush for Dollars
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Israelis continued to react turbulently today to the Begin Government's drastic economic changes. but an expected rush to buy dollars failed to materialize.

title: Jazz Get a Choice
description: O'Brien also ruled yesterday that the New Orleans Jazz has the choice of accepting Wesley Cox or a 1978 firstround draft choice as compensation for the Golden State Warriors' signing of E. C. Coleman, a free agent.

title: House Votes Condemnation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to denounce the South African Government for repressing dissidents and urged President Carter to take effective measures against it.

title: CARTER BACKS COMPROMISE ON CONSUMER AGENCY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP)President Carter today endorsed compromise legislation designed to create a longdiscussed consumer protection agency, but Congressional leaders said there still might not be enough votes to pass it.

title: Woman Steps In for Solti, Wins Carnegie Hall Ovation
description: What an improbable scenario. Even a militant feminist editor might reject it as just too much. One of the world's most lionized conductors, scheduled to lead one of the great orchestras in a Carnegie Hall performance of Mahler's most complex and philosophically ambitious symphony, injures an arm and is forced to withdraw at the last moment. His place is taken by his woman assistant, and she conducts a triumphant performance that wins her a standing ovation.,

title: Tourists Gain New Insights On Vietnamese
description: HANOI, Vietnam (Reuters)Vietnam is opening up to tourists with a kindness typical of the Vietnamese but with about as much comprehension of the West as Westerners have of Vietnam.

title: Fed Interest Rate Raised
description: In a move that surprised the credit markets, the Federal Reserve yesterday pushed interest rates higher, presumably in anticipation of an unacceptably large increase in the money supply to be made public Thursday. Page 53.

title: LEGISLATOR INDICTED ON NOSHOW HIRING
description: Assemblyman Thomas R. Fortune of Brooklyn was indicted yesterday o?? charges that he had hired a clerk fo?? his Albany office who was paid $500 every though he knew she would never show up for work.

title: Crewman Killed on British Tanker
description: GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 (UPI)The Coast Guard disclosed today that a crewman was killed Saturday night in a boiler room explosion aboard a British tanker. th7: Nordic Aurora. A speakesman for the Coast Guard said the accident occurred as the tanker was about 75 miles off the New Jersey coast,

title: German Court Bombed in Apparent Terrorist Action
description: BONN, Oct. 31A homemade bomb, believed to have been planted by terrorists, exploded at the back entrance of a court building in Zweibrilcken in the Rhineland early this morning and caused extensive damage. No one was hurt.

title: Around the Nation
description: Representatives of the North Atlantic shipping companies and members of the 125man wage scale committee of the striking longshoremen are scheduled to gather in New York tomorrow for a possible resumption of bargaining talks if sufficient progress on local issues has been made in the individual ports.

title: 87 Guerrillas Reported Killed
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 31 (AP)The South African and Rhodesian Governments reported today the killing of 87 black guerrillas in two border battles.

title: New Legionnaires' Disease Case Brings Total in Vermont to 26
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Oct. 31 (UPI)Another case of legionnaires' disease in Vermont was reported today, bringing the total of confirmed cases in the state to 26 in the past three months.

title: Woman Steps In for Solti, Wins Carnegie Hall Ovation
description: What an improbable scenario. Even a militant feminist editor might reject it as just too much. One of the world's most lionized conductors, scheduled to lead one of the great orchestras in a Carnegie Hall performance of Mahler's most complex and philosophically ambitious symphony, injures an arm and is forced to withdraw at the last moment. His place is taken by his woman assistant, and she conducts a triumphant performance that wins her a standing ovation.

title: Jets Now Lose Like Winners
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 31A halfseason over, the Jets show two victories and five losses, including three in a row. They should be despondent, gnashing their teeth and blaming the officials for their bad luck.

title: High Court Bars Hearing Appeals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The Supreme Court today refused to hear appeals by two company officials convicted of defrauding a mutual fund in transactions involving oil and gas rights in the Canadian Arctic.

title: Article 4  No Title
Ottawa Legislator Tells of Finding Bugging Device in His Office Chair
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31An opposition member of the Canadian House of Commons said today that a bugging device had been found in his chair in his parliamentary office by an electronics expert.

title: Leapin' Lipizzans!! It's Horse Show Time
description: It turns out that the Tempel Lipizzans, the magnificent white stallions that do caprioles, levades, courbettes and other exotic maneuvers in midair, are also workhorses. A halfdozen of them turned up yesterday in the chilly precincts of Central Park to earn their daily grain.

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONAnna. Happy birthday In heaven, Mom, with Dad and sisters Jewel and Geraldine.

title: Notes on People
description: In the city of Oviedo, in northern Spain, 9yearold Felipe de Sorbn y Grecia, who right now is more interested in riding his motorbike than in monarchy, will be formally invested today as heir to the Spanisit throne. The blond, moonfaced boy will be pinned with the venera, or badge, that labels him Prince of Asturias, in simple religious and civil ceremonies attended by his parents, King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia, who is Greek born. Sources at the royal palace in Madrid reported that Felipe is aware that he will one day be king, but his interests run more to playing games and his motorbike, whose horsepower his father has had cut down for safety's sake.

title: TV: Speed of Production Marks Fine CBS Documentary on Panama
description: This evening at 8, the CBS Reports' documentary called The Battle Over Panama is almost as significant for its production schedule as for its valuably clarifying content. With Bill D. Moyers as chief correspondent on the project, the program goes to Panama and Washington, among other places, to investigate the highly emotional issue of the Panama Canala narrow body of water surrounded by controversy.

title: EnergyPolicy Flaws
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa.Two distressing aspects of public discussion of the current energy debate are the uncritical acceptance President Carter's proposals have received and the dismissal of his critics as mere interest groups.

title: Carter May Delay His Trip Abroad To Lobby for Energy Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31White House officials were giving serious consideration today to the postponement of President Carter's scheduled foreign trip later this month as a symbol of his commitment to energy legislation over other immediate concerns, including foreign policy.

title: World War I Ship Revisited 350 Feet Down
description: Sixtyone years ago she was one of the survivors of His Majesty's Hospital Ship Britannic, the sistership of the Titanic, when the Britannic was blown up during World War I and sank in the Aegean Sea.

title: First Black Anglican Bishop Returns to Uneasy SouthWest Africa
description: NOW abroad 12 years, the Kev. James uluma sat in his modest bookcrowdapartment in Manhattan's Stuyves??t Town and talked about going home on to become the first black Anglican shop of the territory known as ??mibia or SouthWest Africa.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is so much intelligence and awareness in Hortense Calisher's new novel, so many eyes and fingers and abstractions, such a pile of images, that the prose itself is pressed upon. It must bear an awful weight of knowing. Words look nervously for a place to hide, but they are pinned by mind, driven to conclusions. A rough poetry results, a poetry with rivets, as if the book were working up to a scream.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Accuses Press
description: OMAHA, Oct. 31 (AP)Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn said today that the press had not told the public the full truth about the Allan Bakke case because it was controlled by white males.

title: An Executive's Reactions To Washington: Negative
description: In view of his involvement withthree previous Democratic Administrations in Washington, John T. Connor was asked in a recent interview whether he approved the economic policies of President Carter and how receptive he would be if this Administration asked him to return to Government service. On both counts, the longtime member of the prestigious, Republicanoriented Business Council indicated his reactions were negative.

title: Seoul Proposes More Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 31 (UPI)South Korea proposed to the United States today that negotiations be resumed at the diplomatic level to find a solution to the Tongsun Park issue that has strained relations between Washington and Seoul.

title: Money
description: Monday, October 31, 1977

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1977

title: Racing's Mystery Deepens
description: While a State Supreme Court judge reserved decision yesterday whether Dr. Mark Gerard's suspension should be lifted, confusion mounted over the veterinarian's role in an alleged racetrack fraud.

title: Carter to Oppose End to Income Limit for Social Security Recipients
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Carter Administration said today that it would oppose legislation to end all income limitations on Social Security recipients, but it restated its support for attempts to liberalize the current restrictions.

title: SquatterThieves May Force South Bronx Businesses to Leave
description: Young thieves living as squatters in a cluster of vacant, cityowned buildings in the South Bronx have been burglarizing local businesses so brazenly that some merchants think they may have to move their companies and several hundred jobs out of New York.

title: REVENUE SERVICE CLOSES SEVERAL TAX SHELTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service today ended a number of tax shelters for wealthy Americans by curbing certain partnerships, leasing operations and other investments and promotions.

title: LONGHAIRED DRIVERS LOSE HIGH COURT PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States Supreme Court left standing today a ruling that the New Jersey state police cannot be barred from stopping longhaired drivers on the state's highways and searching their cars for what plaintiffs said was the hope of finding marijuana or other illicit drues.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Supreme Court turned aside today an opportunity to decide whether a reporter could refuse to identify a confidential news source when he was called as a witness in a civil lawsuit.

title: Married to a Life of Pratfalls, Floppy Shoes and SleightofHand
description: PARISAnnie Fratellini is shy, selfconscious and serious. She is also the female half of France's bestknown clown duo and the only woman clown in Europe in the big time under the big top.

title: Pound Up 6c to $1.84 as Britain, Fearing Inflation, Lifts Money Rein
description: LONDON, Oct. 31The Government relaxed its tight grip on the pound today and the newly liberated currency soared by more than 6 cents to $1.84.

title: Market Place
description: When James Townsend, president of the Rockwood National Corporation, calls debenture holders of the predecessor company, the LevinTownsend Computer Corporation, offering money, he does not always get the holder to take it.

title: Carter Can Use Time Out
description: President Carter's decision to delay the introduction of his tax reform proposals makes political, economic, legislative and personal sense. He has enough trouble already on all these fronts and needs a breathing spelltime for regroupingmore than anything else.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1977

title: Enquirer's Growth Plans
description: The National Enquirer yesterday began a threeday series of luncheons in the Rainbow Room to let advertisers and agencies in on its growth plans. While its last audit shows its circulation at 5 million, it is setting 10 million as its target. The publication, which began to test TV advertising as a circulation promoter last July, expects to do a lot of that promotion next year. Grey Advertising is its agency.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Body of Maryland Boy, 9. Found
description: SALISBURY, Md., Oct. 31 (AP)The body of William Russell Marine Jr., 9 years old, was found today in a shallow grave in a field near this Eastern Shore community during a search for another missing youngster, the state police reported. He had been stabbed several times, the police said. State police said a neighbor, Elwood Leushner, 45, was charged with firstdegree murder.

title: Putting the Best Boot Forward (and How to Take Care of It)
description: THE YOUNG woman looked as if she lived on an office worker's salary, which, in fact, she does, and for a moment one wondered if she'd walked into one of the city's most expensive shoe stores, The Chelsea Cobbler on East 55th Street, by mistake. Then, one of the salesmen recognized her and brought out the glossy cordovan boots she's tried on a dozen times before. She told him she's finally saved enough money to buy them and paid the $265 bill, more than she pays each month for her West Side apartment.

title: Cleveland Quartet: Early Rachmaninoff
description: Most artists would prefer to burn and forget the first halting efforts of their student days, but the more important the artist the more we may be forgiven for refusing to honor such modesty. Not much damage can be done to Rachmaninoff's reputation, for instance, by the exhumation of his two partly finished string quartets, which he himself did not list among his works.

title: The U.N. Today
CHANGE IN HIRING IRKS CAPE COD PARK CREW
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., Oct. 31More than 100 seasonal employees of the Cape Cod National Seashore have organized to fight a new job evaluation system that could cost many of them their summer employment. National Park Service officials in Washington say this is the first organized protest they know of over the new policy in the nation's parks.

title: Easy Radar
description: It may be the era of small is beautiful, but technology marches on. Students at Central Washington University in Ellensburg, Wash., like their contemporaries elsewhere, have turned to bicycles for campus transportation and, with the bicycles, have come abuses. First, speeding. Now, hit and run. Three pedestrians have recently been struck and injured by bicyclists. The last culprit kept on pedaling into the darkness. Perturbed, the campus police are now experimenting with a solution adapted from the highway: radar.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Blazer in Latvian Songs
description: The program of traditional Latvian folk songs offered Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall may not have been a monument to ethnomusicological authenticity. Aldis Lagzdins, normally an organist, had arranged the material very freely for voice and piano, and the singer, Judith Blazer, is of ItalianJewishAmerican extraction. But the program was still an enormously delightful, moving experience.

title: Court Weighs Opening Hearings On Deportation of Suspected Nazi
description: A lawyer for the New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday appealed to a Federal District Court judge to open to the public a deportation hearing of an alleged Nazi war criminal.

title: A Victim of The C.I.A.
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J.In August, Adm. Stansfield Turner, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, testified before a Congressional committee that the C.I.A. has covertly sponsored research conducted by some 80 institutions, including 44 colleges and universities. This has been widely reported and continues to occasion concern and speculation as to who and what was involved.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)President Carter signed a $6.7 billion foreign assistance appropriations bill today that cuts off aid to some countries considered guilty of abusing human rights.

title: Extensive Rate Reform Is Backed For Utility Industry in a Study
description: The project director of a major utility industry study on rate design strongly endorses the call for extensive rate reform in the study's firstyear report, according to this week's Electrical Week. The newsletter said it obtained an early copy of the report, which is scheduled to be mailed out today.

title: GIUSEPPE MORANDI
description: BRESCIA, Italy, Nov. 1 (UPI)Giuseppe Morandi, who teamed with Nando Minaia to win Italy's first Mille Miglia auto rac in 1927, died today in a Brescia clinic. He was 83 years old.

title: Drama: BullyTalks Softly...
description: SUCCESS IN RECREATING an eminent figure onstage from his or her words depends heavily upon the subject chosen. It should be a man or woman of words, or at least one who used words well.

title: Carter Signs Minimum Wage Bill, Giving Raises of 45 Percent by 81
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)President Carter today signed legislation increasing the paychecks of many of America's lowest paid workers 45 percent by 1981. He called it a step in the right direction and said it would pump an additional $9 billion into the economy.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: The Labor Scene
description: A. H. Raskin reports that arbitration techniques developed to keep the peace in labormanagement relations are findir.g a widening role in the settlement of disputes in other fields. However, in industrial relations, arbitration's role may be waning. Page D5.

title: It's Called Repentance
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.Three Federal prisoners, John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, are now eligible for parole by virtue of the recent sentencereduction decision of Federal District Judge John J. Sirica. Central to Judge Sirica's decision, and to the forthcoming parole decisions for these three Watergate defendants as well, is the newly perceived attitudes of repentance conspicuously displayed by the defendants.

title: Upstate Farmers Tell of Crops and Hopes Washed Out by Rain
description: FLINT, N.Y.The rains came on Sept. 13 and for the next six weeks the sun was a stranger in central and western New York State. By some measurements, the rain reached 18 inches in that period. about four times normal.

title: A Chinese Cook's
description: HILLSBORO, ORE.

title: Kidnappers Free Wealthy Dutchman; $4 Million Is Paid
description: AMSTERDAM, Wednesday, Nov. 2A Dutch multimillionaire who was kidnapped here last Friday has been released unharmed by his kidnappers in exchange for about $4 million in ransom, the police said early today.

title: Experts Say Congress Can Extend Ratification of Rights Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Justice Department and private legal experts held today that Congress has the authority to grant states an additional seven years in which to ratify the equal rights amendment.

title: Young Says PolicyOf U. S. on MideastIs Bolstering Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. IAndrew Young defended President Carter's role as an honest broker in the Middle East today, expressing confidence in a speech to the World Jewish Congress that the Administration's policies would bolster Israel's security.

title: Carter Signs Minimum Wage Bill, Giving Raises of 45 Percent by 81
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)President Carter today signed legislation increasing the paychecks of many of America's lowest paid workers 45 percent by 1981. He called it a step in the right direction and said it would pump an additional $9 billion into the economy.

title: Arbitration: Growing Role, Possibly a Waning One Too
description: Techniques developed to keep the peace in labormanagement relations are being adapted to the settlement of conflicts ranging from the location of offshore oil drills to commercial claims arising out of trade with the Soviet Union and China. By ironic ing of peacemaking horizons by the American Arbitration Association comes amid warnings by some top  flight arbitrators of an imminent end to the golden age of arbitration as a court of last resort in industrial relations, the field where it has had principal application until now.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Indianapolis 6, Houston 3. New England 6, Queber.

title: Koch, Cuomo or Goodman?
description: Edward Koch, Mario Cuomo and Roy Goodman are able and worthy candidates for Mayor of New York City. Indeed, it is surprising that a barren political system and generally rowdy political campaign should end up producing three realistic nominees on the lines of the Democratic, Liberal and Republican Parties. Even before they g to the polls, the voters can rest easy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a book review of Daniel Schorr's Clearing the Air in The Times on Oct. 24, it was incorrectly suggested that The Village Voice paid money to the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press in exchange for the, Pike Committee report on the Central Intelligence Agency. Although Mr. Schorr had recommended such a transaction it did not take place.

title: N. F. L. Keeping a Closer Eye on Violence
description: During a game between Cincinnati and Pitts burgh last month, John Stallworth, the tall, swift Steeler wide receiver, caught a pass in the middle of the defensive secondary and kept running for what was going to be a big gain. Melvin Morgan, playing safety for the Bengals, closed in on Stallworth, but the receiver cut to his left and was about to go by the Cincinnati player.

title: Wine Talk
description: PARIS

title: Consumer Agency Bills Dead in Congress Now
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)Lastditch legislation to create a new agency to defend consumers rights in the Federal Government died today after House leaders decided the proposal did not have enough support.

title: Professional Football
description: National Conference

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: AT FIRST, there were only the suitcases, the cardboard boxes and the shopping bags, all of which he had carried over himself, and then placed neatly in the closets. He was moving into an empty apartment, and the move had brought on him those curiously mixed feelings of exhilaration and despair that New Yorkers always feel when they move into empty apartments. The exhilaration comes from having a sense of the possibility of all things when they move into an empty apartment: the despair comes from this, too. Only the very brave, the very young and the very dumb do not mind it. This is because they are better equipped at handling failures than other people. Also, the very chic do not mind empty apartments because they think that a few plants, a couple of candles and some inflatable furniture make a home. Other people know better.

title: CITY'S ILLS STRESSED IN MAYORAL DEBATE
description: In a debate that repeatedly underscored New York City's serious problems, the four major mayoral candidates yesterday favored maintenance of the 50cent transit fare, but all declined to pledge its continuation.

title: House Inquiry Looking Into Network Responsibility
description: THE HOUSE Communications subcommittee that today begins two days of hearings on television practices in sports is seeking to determine whether the networks, in their competitive zeal, have manipulated certain events and deliberately deceived the viewing public.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, said yesterday that he had ruled that local boards of education had the power to conduct sexeducation classes in the public schools. He made the ruling in a case of the parents of two girls who objected to such a class given by the Board of Education of Dumont.

title: Glossary for Horse Show
description: JumpersBest known division in show. They are scored by the number of faults they commit. When a jumper knocks a fence down, it. is charged with four faults. iff the horse refuses to try to jump a fence, it is charged with three faults. The horse with the lowest number of faults is declared the winner of the event.

title: Dollar Declines To Record Lows As Pound Gains
description: The dollar fell to record lows in West Germany, Switzerland and Japan in hectic foreign exchange trading yesterday, The Associated Press reported. The British pound, meanwhile, gained slightly on its second day of freedom from Bank of England restraints.

title: Setting Rules for Nuclear Exports
description: A comprehensive bill to control the spread of nuclear materials and technology that could be used by other nations to make weapons has been languishing in the Senate. It has the endorsement of the Carter Administration and the unanimous approval of the House. It cleared three Senate committees but then was blocked because a few senators refused to consent to the ground rules for floor debate. It now appears that the roadblock will be lifted to allow a vote this weekthe last chance for passage before Congress is swamped by the onrush energy legislation. The measure offers valuable and timely assistance to President Carter's effort to control nuclear proliferation. It should be brought to a vote and passed.

title: Survey Finds Fewer Think Carter Can Restore Trust in Government
description: The American people appear to be losing confidence in President Carter's ability to restore trust in government, according to the latest quarterly New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The U.N. Today
About Real Estate
description: The pace of activity in industrial real estate in the city has begun to pick up with the help of industrial revenue development bonds.

title: Dow Off by 11.44 to 806.91 As Fears on Fed Heighten
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping more than 11 points, following apparent confirmation that the Federal Reserve was permitting shortterm interest rates to move higher.

title: HALLIBURTON'S NET UP 13% FOR QUARTER
description: Gains in highmargin oilfield services and products lifted thirdquarter net income of the Halliburton Company by 13 percent to a record of $103.1 million, or $1.76 a share, from $91.3 million, or $1.56 a share, in the similar three months last year, the Dallasbased company reported yesterday.

title: Ensemble Studio Doing New Pinero Play
description: Eulogy of a Small Time Thief, a new play by Miguel Piero, author of Short Eyes, will be the second production of the season at the Ensemble Studio Theater, 549 West 52d Street, it was announced by Curt Dempster, artistic director of the theater.

title: Gard of Thanks
description: MulchroneVincent: Louie, Martin, Patrick and Michael, family of the late Vincent Muichrone wish to express their gratitude for the kindness and sympathy they have received. It Is comforting to know one has so many loyal and sincere friends.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1977

title: About Education
description: There has always been an uneasy, unfulfilled relationship between the schools and television.

title: Between the Law and the Secrets
description: When, in Senate testimony, Richard Helms was caught between his duty to obey the law and his duty to protect secrets, he chose the secrets. And so the Government was caughtbetween the need to enforce the laws against lying to Congress and the continuing need to keep secrets. The Carter Administration has now succeeded in paying homage to both law and secrets.

title: Pentagon Aides Insist Cruise Missile Can Breach Soviet Defenses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Defense Department contends that the Soviet Union's $100 billion air defense system is vulnerable to the American cruise missile and that Moscow would have to undertake a multibilliondollar program to offset development of the new weapon.

title: Cosmos Defend Signing Of Two Undergraduates
description: While a number of college coaches are furious about the recent signing by the Cosmos of two undergraduates from the University of Santa Clara and St. Louis University, the president of the North American Soccer League champions and the two players said yesterday they had no guilty feelings.

title: Miss Hillis Carries Her Baton Lightly
description: ALL I DID was my job.

title: Technology
description: American manufacturers of ultraminiature electronic circuits are struggling, by such steps as infusions of capital from abroad and major reorganizations, to meet the pressures of rapid expansion, both present and anticipated.

title: A Very Fine Line Divides Floral Park From Floral Park
description: Where 261st Street crosses 87th Avenue in Floral Park is where Bryant Avenue crosses Whitney Avenue in Floral Park.

title: U.S. Quits I.L.O. And Touches Off A Furor in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1President Carter withdrew the United States from the International Labor Organization today, touching off bitter criticism of the action here.

title: Appeals Unit Questions Challenge To Carey's Proposed Bond Issue
description: The New York State Court of Appeals heard arguments yesterday on the constitutional challenge to Governor Carey's proposed $750 million bond issue, with several judges expressing doubt that they should find unconstitutional an act that technically would not take effect unless the voters approved it next Tuesday.

title: Goodman to Relive 38 Carnegie Jazz
description: THE 40TH ANNIVERSARY of the first jazz concert ever held at Carnegie Haltthe now legendary concert by Benny Goodman and his orchestra on Jan. 16, 1938will be celebrated by Mr. Goodman with a concert there next Jan. 17.

title: Tribesmen in Pakistan Thrive On Making Weapons by Hand
description: DARRA, PakistanLike hundreds of other market towns scattered across India and Pakistan, this little crossroads 25 miles south of the Khyber Pass bustles every morning with shoppers from the surrounding countryside. But here, instead of mangoes or wicker bags or blankets, they are buying rifles, pistols and machine guns.

title: Bellamy and Goldin
description: Whoever becomes Mayor, the only sustained and loyal opposition will have to come from the other two city officials elected by a citywide constituency: the President of the City. Council and the Comptroller.

title: City Betterment Unit Assigned to Y. & R.
description: Young & Rubicam, New York, has got itself a rough assignment. It asked for it.

title: Soybean Futures Continue to Rise
