title: Leonard Silk
description: ROME The economic and political situation in Italy remains precarious despite some slowing in the inflation rate and the narrowing of the balanceofpayments gap. That theme emerged from the talks conducted here this week

title: Menken and Ellen March Play
description: IN THE CURRENT cabaret world, a piano accompanist is no longer expected to merely play piano for a singer. More and more, pianists can be heard joining in vocally, harmonizing with the singer, creating a background of shouts and exclamations or even doing brief passages of solo singing.

title: Gulf and Western Reports Disclosing Further Activities
description: A number of disclosures about the private investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into certain activities of Gulf and Western Industries are contained in the company's 10K filing for its fiscal year ended last July 31.

title: Struggle Over I.L.O. Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2President Carter's decision to pull the United States out of the International Labor Organization is viewed by union and industry leaders as as an exercise in shock therapy that will discourage the use of United Nations bodies as antiAmerican American forums.

title: 55 Nations Are Charged With Repressing Writers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2Writers who express dissident opinions have become the targets of repressive government action, including imprisonment, in 55 countries, according to a worldwide study made by the writers organization P.E.N.

title: Kummerfeld Now Says City Deficit May Reach as Much as $468 Million
description: First Deputy Mayor Donald D. Kummerfeld said yesterday that New York City's deficit for the next fiscal year could be as large as $468 million, more than $100 million higher than previous estimates and by far the highest prospective deficit city officials have yet acknowledged.

title: Dance: Ageless Pauline Koner
description: ONE would never dare to think of Pauline Koner as a pioneer of modern danceshe looks so indomitably young, even youthfully fragile. Yet her looks must be confusing, because she claims in the program book for her Dance Umbrella performances, which opened at the Entermedia Theater on Tuesday night, to be celebrating her 50th year in the professional dance world.

title: CALLAGHAN ASSAILED IN CROSSMAN DIARIES
description: LONDON, Nov. 2  Prime Minister James Callaghan is bitterly criticized in the final volume of the diaries of his onetime Cabinet colleague, Richard Crossman, which was published this week.

title: U. N. COUNCIL AGREES ON ARMSBAN TERMS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2The 15 members of the Security Council agreed at a private meeting today on the terms of a revised proposal for a mandatory embargo on arms sales to South Africa to induce it to change its repressive racial practices.

title: Alone (but Besieged) In the North Woods
description: THE ISOLATION and peace she found in the wilderness of the Adirondack mountains so intrigues the outside world that Anne LaBastille may have to move to another wilderness to keep the world from beating too much of a path to her door.

title: BREZHNEV, IN A SHIFT, SAYS HE WOULD HALT CIVIL NUCLEAR TESTS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2The Soviet Union moved a step closer to accepting a suspension of all nuclear explosions today by dropping its insistence that any halt exclude blasts for peaceful purposes.

title: The Kindly Clock
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Remember, back in August, how Mr. Carter's Justice Department assured us that the Bert Lance case would be investigated vigorously and without a hint of favoritism for the President's best friend?

title: Dutchman Says He Negotiated His Own Release
description: AMSTERDAM, Nov. 2 (AP)Maurits Caransa, the Dutch millionaire who was freed early today by kidnappers after five days in captivity, said he negotiated his own ransom for $4.16 million with his four abductors, whom he described as just criminals and not political terrorists.

title: BRAZIL BUS CRASH KILLS 2 IN AMERICAN TOUR GROUP
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 2 (AP)One of three buses plunged off a mountain road tonight while returning American tourists from a visit to the Christ the Redeemer statute overlooking Rio, killing two persons and injuring 17 others, including the driver, the police said.

title: Accused Murderer Presents an Enigma To Illinois Courts
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (Reuters)Unable to speak, hear, read or write, Donald Lang is an accused murderer whose case falls somewhere outside the law.

title: Woodsman's Skill in Tracking Led To RapeRobbery Suspect in Jersey
description: ALLENDALE, N.J., Nov. 2A 27yearold woodsman and naturalist who has roamed and studied New Jersey's vast and desolate Pine Barrens since childhood was cited today by the Bergen County police as having played a key role in the capture of a man suspected of being the robberrapist who has caused deep fear in dozens of suburban communities after three nighttime assaults since March.

title: New York Jobless Rate Down
description: ALBANY, Nov. 2 (UPI)Both the unemployment rate and the number of persons with jobs dropped off in New York during September, the State Labor Department reported. The number of people with jobs went down 76,400 from August, with 7,007,600 employed. Those out of work totaled 590,700, down 33,600 from August.

title: CARTER MAKES PLEA TO JEWS ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  President Carter told a group of Jewish leaders tonight, that intemperance or partisanship should not be allowed to thwart what he said might be the best opportunity for a permanent Middle East peace settlement in our lifetime.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Boston Man Is Jailed Under Consumer Law
description: BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP)The Massachusetts consumer protection law netthe its first imprisonment when a Boston contractor was jailed for failing to complete new homes for which he had accepted about $85,000 in deposits.

title: Dow Drops 6.06 to a 2Year Low On Fears of Rise in Interest Rates
description: The threat of higher interest rates depressed stock market prices again yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average hit a twoyear low just above the 800 level.

title: Saudi Buys Wildenstein Furniture
description: PARIS. Nov. 2 (UPI)Akram Ojjeh, a Saudi Arabian millionaire, who bought the mothballed luxury liner France last week, has sparked renewed attention by buying the vast Wildenstein collection of antique French furniture.

title: Books of The Times
description: TOWARD THE END of his psychobiopsy on 1920's RoseRoomers at the Algonquin Hotel in New York, James R. Gainesas if he were being nagged, as if afraid someone might rain on his parade of generalizationsis moved to demur: It could be argued (and no doubt will be) that the writers of the Round Table did precisely what they were capable of doingno more, no less. Still, it is hard to think that the group had no effect on their capabilities, and easy to see how the group's will helped some of its members succumb to currents in the time that they might successfully have resisted individuals.

title: The Useful Rear Stairs Deserve a Pat on the Back
description: Before it vanishes completely from the domestic scene and nobody knows what I'm talking about, I'd like to get on paper a few wellchosen adjectives in honor of that universal friend, the oldfashioned back staircase. Time was, in our grandparents day, when every dwelling bigger than a doghouse came equipped with both a front and a back staircase. But builders are no longer such a considerate lot as they once were, and the back staircase has gone the way of the window seat, the wisteriacovered veranda and other lastcentury aids to pleasant living.

title: A Loft That Looks Lived In
description: MOST PEOPLE have to go outdoors to jog. Neils Diffrient and his wife, Helena Hernmark, do their jogging in their loft, running past her looms and his drawing board, around the PingPong table, the open kitchen area, the freestanding fireplace and the open bedroom, while Thomas, the ginger cat, gets out of the way by bedding down on a table full of yarn. The Diffrients haven't measured the jogging laps, but with 3,300 square feet in SoHo, they get plenty of exercise.

title: U.S. May Sell Shells to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters)The Defense Department today notified Congress it intended to sell Israel nearly 190,000 rounds of mortar ammunition worth an estimated $11.8 million. Con press has 30 days in which it can disapprove of the sale.

title: White House Explains Carter Comment on Helms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2A White House spokesman denied today that President Carter had intended to mislead news representatives and the public when he said in September that he had not discussed the case of the former Director of Central Intelligence, Richard Helms, with Attorney General Griffin B. Bell.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Two years ago we put flocked wallpaper in our bathrooms. Within six months mold started to grow. I washed the paper with a mild Clorox solution, hut within a short time the mold was growing again. We installed exhaust fans to rid the bathrooms of humidity, without success. I want to replace the paper, hilt am afraid the same thing will happen again. Do you have any suggestions? P.G. Rockaway, N. J.

title: The Horse Show: A Ritual of Pomp and Primping

title: BONDS REFERENDUM IS UPHELD IN ALBANY
description: New York State's highest court, reversing two lowercourt decisions, ruled yesterday thta it could not remove Governor Carey's proposed $750 million bond issue from next week's ballot.

title: Norwalk Police Battle in Court Over Racial Hiring Issue
description: NORWALK, Conn.Connie Carney and Rowena McFadden, both 22 years old, want to become police officers here. Both talk of wanting to work with people.

title: In Memoriam
description: SOMMERIda. We miss your remarkable love surpassing everything. Rose & Leonard.

title: DROUGHT STUDY GIVES GOOD NEWS AND BAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2The First Boston Corporation of New York City held a news conference here today on the twoyearold drought in the West and gave out good news for investors and bad news for consumers.

title: About Newyork
description: Reddish brown, with the glistening strong look of mahogany, the thoroughbred knew he had a visitor and looked up from nuzzling the earth. He had such a direct and gentle gaze that the visitor felt compelled to say Hello, out loud or seem rude.

title: Accrediting Agency to Investigate Charges That Medical Salesman Had Role in Operation at L.I. Hospital
description: The country's main hospitalaccrediting agency said yesterday that it would immediately investigate allegations that Smithtown General Hospital on Long Island had allowed a medicalsupply salesman to perform crucial parts of a bone operation.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev's proposal for a moratorium on all underground nuclear detonations  for peaceful uses as well as weapons testsmarked a major step forward toward a comprehensive test ban, but that differences persisted on the duration of such an accord.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Although the Carter Administration's strategy on steel imports is apparently yielding some results, its primary tacticenforcement of a controversial antidumping provision of the 1974 Trade Actis denounced abroad as

title: ByrneBateman Contest Is Suddenly a Real Race
description: It's neck and neck in New Jersey. With five days to go, Brendan T. Byrne, the Democrat they called OneTerm Byrne not so very long ago, has pulled dead even in the polls with Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican Mister Nice Guy from the State Legislature who, just as recently, seemed shooin to be the Garden State's next chief executive.

title: RISE IN STEEL ORDERS LINKED TO FINDINGS ON JAPANS DUMP1N
description: Orders for plate steel have picked up at several American mills and there are signs that at least some of the increase has been due to a Government finding that five major Japanese steel companies had dumped that product in the United States market.

title: BREZHNEV, IN A SHIFT, SAYS HE WOULD HALT CIVIL NUCLEAR TESTS

title: SOVIET SHORTFALL IN GRAIN FORESEEN, WENTHER IS BLAMED
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 2The Soviet Union's grain harvest, falling nearly 20 million tons below expectations, will total only 194 million metric tons this year, President Leonid I. Brezhnev disclosed in a speech today.

title: New Series On TV Fail Faster Than Previously
description: OF THE 22 NEW SERIES that were introduced by the television networks in September, only twoLove Boat and Soap, both on ABChave been consistently successful in the ratings. This means that new programs are failing at a faster rate this season than the industry considers normal. In a typical season in the past, three new shows failed for every two that became popular.

title: INVENTORIES OF CRUDE OIL UP BY 7.4 MILLION BARRELS
description: Inventories of crude oil for the week ending Oct. 28 rose 7.4 million barrels to 344.8 million barrels from 337.4 million barrels the week before, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Deaths
description: ALTMANEdith. The Rachel Group of Hillcrest Hadassah deeply mourn the passing of our beloved past President, Edith Altman. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family.

title: Energy Follies and Energy Drama
description: Act One began as serious national drama. A new President, confronted with a foreign stranglehold on America's energy lifeline, called for a spirit of sacrifice from the public and a complex National Energy Plan from Congress. The House enacted the program with dispatch. In Act Two, which ended this week, the Senate left the drama looking more like the Energy Follies.

title: Master PIan to Aid Gambling in Atlantic City Urges Razing of Slum Area and the Closing of Airport
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 2A Washington consulting firm, hired seven months ago by this resort community for $500,000 to study how the city might best accommodate gambling casinos, recommended tonight that an airport be moved and rundown residential neighborhoods be cleared.

title: Jets Coach Hospitalized; Rasmussen Gets His Job
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L. Nov. 2With Bob Fry, the offensive line coach, in Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip with phlebitis, Randy Rasmussen was given added duties by the Jets. The veteran guard will serve as a playercoach as the team prepares for its rematch on Sunday with the Miami Dolphins at Shea Stadium.

title: Control Battle for Carborundum Emerges as Eaton Enters Picture
description: A $400 million battle for control of the Carborundum Companyreminiscent of the threeway fight over the Babcock & Wilcox Companyemerged yesterday.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Nov. 2, 1977

title: CONVICTION IS UPHELD IN MISS HEARST CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2Patricia Hearst's conviction for robbing a bank in company with a group of terrorists who had kidnapped her was upheld here today by a threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth I Circuit.

title: Miami Beach Adds Beefcake Posters
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov, 2Photographs of scantily clad models romping in the surf have been a staple in the promotion of Miami Beach for 40 years, but this year beefcake will be served up with the cheesecake.

title: FRANCE REINFORCES GARRISON IN SENEGAt
description: PARIS, Nov. 2The Government of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing has reinforced the French garrison in Senegal in West Africa in an attempt to bolster France's diplomatic efforts to win the release of eight of its citizens kidnapped by guerrillas in neighboring Mauritania.

title: G.O.P. CHIEFS SAY CARTER RENEGED ON PANEL CHOICE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)Republican oCngressional leaders said today that President Carter had violated an agreement to nominate a Republican for the Federal Election Commission from a list submitted by them.

title: North Stars Foil Rally And Top Islanders, 32

description: DESPITE respectful notices and towering performances in the lead roles by Colleen Dewhurst and the late Michael Dunn. Edward Albee's adaptation of Carson McCullers's novella The Ballad of the Sad Cafe had only an abbreviated run en Broadway in 1963.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The troubled Delaware & Hudson Railway will delay a request for S25 million In Federal funds until the new president, Charles H. Bertrand, has time to review it, the D. & H.'s parent company said yesterday.

title: Bergland Says Soviet Might Buy 9 Million More Tons of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that the Soviet Union might buy at least nine million additional tons of American wheat and corn to offset a 10 percent reduction in the Russian crop.

title: October BigStore Sales Rose 4.5%
description: October sales among six of New York City's biggest retailers rose only moderately over the month a year ago, the gains, averaging 4.5 percent, just about matching the inflation rate in departmentstore merchandise.

title: Record Number Collect Back Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)  The Labor Department recovered back wages totaling $112 million for a record 628,000 victims of wage and hour violations in the year that ended Sept. 30. Labor Secretary Ray Marshall reported that enforcement of wage and hour laws benefited more workers in that period than in any year since the law was enacted 39 years ago.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Chard Powers Smith, a Writer, 83
description: Chard Powers Smith, writer of fiction, history and poetry mostly about New England, died Monday night in the Sweetbrook Nursing home, Williamstown, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: People and Business
description: The Jos. Schiitz Brewing Company, which has slipped from the No. 2 spot in the brewing industry to third, and recently reported a 60.9 percent decline in thirdquarter earnings, has a new president.

title: Union Chief Disputes Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the teamsters union, said today that former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst did not tell the truth when he testified that he worked through Mr. Fitzsimmons to help an insurance executive accused in a swindle of getting a lucrative teamster contract.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONAfter much delay, the Carter Administration has promised it will announce by next Tuesday at the latest the long awaited quotas or import taxes or both that it will impose to increase the price of sugar.

title: Letters
description: The RentControl Issue

title: Shipping/Mails
description: INCOMING

title: Norman D. Watkins
description: JAMESTOWN, R.I., Nov. 2 (AP)Norman D. Watkins, an earth scientist at the University of Rhode Island, died today at his Jamestown home. He was 43 years old.

title: Hasidic Feat: Simple as Aleph, Beth, Gimel
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2This was not one of your garden variety historic events at Independence Hall, such as a meeting of the Continental Congress or the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Home Improvement
description: AS LABOR costs continue to rise, and as competent repahmen and remodeling contractors get harder to find in many communities, more people are learning how to do things for themselves. In response to their evergrowing demand for information about how to maintain or improve their homes, many new howto books have been published in recent months.

title: AARON HARRIS GOLDBLATT
description: Aaron Harris Goldblatt, a member of the staff of The New York Times information bureau until he resigned in 1961 to devote himself to his interest in theatrical projects, died Oct. 29 in the Times Square Motor Hotel, where he lived. He was 55 years old.

title: PHILIP GOODMAN
description: Philip Goodman, who retired in 1964 as business agent of the Newark branch of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died yesterday in Marlboro (N.J.) Hospital alter a lingering illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Matawan. N.J.

title: West Germany Jails Spy for 5 Years
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Nov. 2 (Reuters)A woman who admitted having spied for East Germany while working as a secretary in the West German Foreign Ministry was sentenced to a fiveyear prison term today. Helge Berger, 36 years old, admitted having passed government secrets to East Germany during the 10 years she was employed in West Germany's trade mission in Warsaw, its embassy in Paris and in the Foreign Ministry in Bonn.

title: Money
description: Wednesday, November 2, 1977

title: Canadian Dollar Is Continuing to Decline Despite Efforts to Bolster It
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 2Canada spent $641.3 million in United States funds from its dwindling foreign currency reserves last month to prop the ailing Canadian dollar, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: CocaCola's Net in Third Quarter Rose 11.5% to Record $93.3 Million
description: Profits of the CocaCola Company were up more than 11.5 percent for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30. the Atlanta soft drink company reported yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A New Jersey Brief by United Press International printed in The Times Wednesday incorrectly identified Lucille Puryear as one of three Newark executives of an antipoverty agency who were indicted on charges of attempting to rig an election for her to become a vice president of a national lobbying organization. Those indicted were John Bugg. William Perry and Clarence Swann. Mrs. Puryear was not charged with any wrongdoing.

title: Arbritrator Rules for Player
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)An arbitrator ruled today that the Miami Dolphins did not have the right to order an injured guard, Bill Stanfill, to play and that Stanfill must be paid under the terns of his guaranteed twoyear contract, Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association. announced the decision that was reached by an arbitrator, James Scearce.

title: Two Scientists at Field Station in Panama Study MalariaBearing Lizards Unharmed by Disease
description: BARRO COLORADO ISLAND, Canal Zone  The rain forests of Panama are a reservoir of malaria  but no longer the kind that infects human beings, which has been largely eradicated by mosquito control. For reasons still stubbornly mysterious, the type of malaria that virtually saturates the forest infects lizards.

title: Article 3  No Title
Television
description: Morning

title: Blend of Arts and Government
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2When Livingston L. Biddle Jr. was nominated as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, the appointmentwhich has its criticshad an unusual symmetry: Mr. Biddle drafted the legislation that set up the endowment 12 years ago. The 59yearold Mr. Biddle was at that time a special assistant to Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, a college classmate who was called at today's confirmation hearings on the Biddle appointment, the father of the [arts] endowment.

title: I.M.F. Gold Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund sold 524,800 ounces of gold at an average price of $161.86 an ounce. The I.M.F. said successful bids at today's auction, which was held under the bid price method, ranged between $161.76 and $163.27 an ounce.

title: PROPOSAL TO NAME JUDGES IS OPPOSED
description: A proposed constitutional amendment providing for the gubernatorial appointment of judges to the New York State Court of Appeals was attacked yesterday as pernicious, elitist, mischievous and undemocratic by a group of sitting and retired state judges.

title: Black Judge Nominated for South
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)President Carter announced today that be was nominating Robert F. Collins to be a Federal district judge for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The White House said that Mr. Collins, a 46yearold native of New Orleans who has been a judge in the magistrate section of the Criminal District Court for Orleans Parish since 1972, would become the first black Federal judge in the Deep South since Reconstruction.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT BOSTON

title: CARTER MAKES PLEA TO JEWS ON MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  President Carter told a group of Jewish leaders tonight that intemperance or partisanship should not be allowed to thwart what he said might be the best opportunity for a permanent Middle East peace settlement in our lifetime.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN REJECTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2The Senate brushed off today, by a vote of 74 to 16, an attempt to use general revenue funds from the Treasury along lines proposed by President Carter to pay for part of the cost of Social Security benefits.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Piano: Poise, Precision And Polish
description: CAROL ROSENBERGER is clearly a pianist who likes to keep busy. When she comes to New York from California to give recital at Alice Tully Hallas she d on Tuesday nightshe is apt to bring works that demand the playing of thousands of notes in tricky combination

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP)Millions of Britons were without electricity for threehour periods today as power workers continued a work slowdown.

title: Rocket Damages Rhodesian Hotel
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 2 (UPI)A rocket fired from Zambia at a civilian plane caused a fire today at a luxury hotel in western Rhodesia. The attack coincided with the arrival in Rhodesia of Field Marshal Lord Carver of Britain for talks on ending the fiveyearold guerrilla war.

title: Concert: Music Project Tries Collage
description: THE MUSIC PROJECT is an ensemble of 11 young instrumentalists who formed their association last year for the best of chambermusic reasons: they are friends. The rapport required for the more intimate varieties of musicmaking can, when it is present and made evident to the listener, pump blood even into a performance that does not reach the highest levels of individual or group virtuosity.

title: Bizarre Case Needs a Push
description: Right from the start, investigators have called it an outlandish case, a web of alleged racetrack fraud so bizarre it boggles the mind. The story involves the wholesale switching of horses (fast horses substituted as ring

title: New York Dock Pay Accord Seen
description: The New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association were reported yesterday to have reached agreement on the guaranteed annual income issue for the port of New York.

title: Autos and Repair Insurance
description: THE MOTORIST we'll call Al Harvey was distressed. His automobile had lost a lot of pickup lately and John Shanahan who runs the Washington Garage in Bergenfield, N.J., had just come up with a very painful diagnosis. The vehicle needed a valve job. Estimated cost: $350.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Atlantic City Master Plan Urges Slum Razing and Closing Airport
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 2A Washington consulting firm, hired seven months ago by this resort community for $500,000 to study how the city might best accommodate gambling casinos, recommended tonight that an airport be moved and rundown residential neighborhoods be cleared.

title: Thinking Big: Oversized Accessories
description: PARDON MY SAYING SO, but I can see from your ashtrays you're not thinking big enough. Aocessorizing is the moment of truth In decorating, it separates the pros from the rest of us. Today even a novice can get the basics right using matching sofas and chairs or a 10section modular sofa on a striking rug in a bare white room.

title: In New York, Spring Fashions Are Light and Loose
description: THE MUSIC was rhythmic, but reasonably gentle as background music for fashion shows generally goes.The dresses were loose, sweet and gentle, too, and it was fascinating to mark the difference in style from the first show Clovis Ruffin presented exactly five years ago. Then, the clothes were based on Tshirts and fairly hugged the body. Now. they almost ignored it.

title: Jazz Gets Compensation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 (UPI)The New Orleans Jazz decided today to accept the Golden State Warriors No. 1 draft choice in 1978 and $75,000 as compensation for E. C. Coleman. The defensive specialist was signed by Golden State as a tree agent shortly before the start of the season.

title: U. N. COUNCIL AGREES ON ARMSBAN TERMS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2The 15 members of the Security Council agreed at a private meeting today on the terms of a revised proposal for a mandatory embargo on arms sales to South Africa to induce it to change its repressive racial practices.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FIELDS IN CLOVER Tonight at 10, Irving Fields is initiating a Thursday series of interviews with prominent popularmusic composers during the regular stint of the Fields trio in the mainfloor lounge of the Copacabana, 10 East 60th Street. Mr. Fields. a veteran pianistsinger on the local scene, and his two colleagues play for dancing and dining from Tuesday to Saturday, 9 P.M. to 2 A.M. There is a disco downstairs.

title: New York State Is Taking Over Municipal Credit Union in the City
description: The New York State Banking Department last night took over the Municipal Credit Union, saying loan delinquencies were threatening the interest of all 112,000 members, who are present or former New York City or state employees.

title: Substance Usually Made in Brain Grown in Bacteria
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Scientists in California have successfully grown in bacteria a substance that is nermally produced in animal and human brains and is believed to have important potential for treating diabetes and other serious disorders.

title: Dance: Beverly Brown Presents Her Own Distinctive Twist
description: THE moody, introspective quality of Beverly Brown's solos generally suggests silent struggle, even when she takes a nostalgic look backward. as in Glympses of When. In this and in other pieces, she drew on her special lyrical energy to successfully carry a program of such restricted emotional range that it might have caused lesser artist to founder. She presented five pieces at the Cubiculo Tuesday evening, including Whelk Woman, the debut piece of her choreographic

title: BONDS REFERENDUM IS UPHELD IN ALBANY
description: New York State's highest court, reversing two lowercourt decisions, ruled yesterday that it could not remove Governor Carey's proposed $750 million bond issue from next week's ballot.

title: ABC Admits Mistakes in Link to Boxing Tourney
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Officials of ABC Sports today admitted making mistakes in the planning of the United States Boxing Championships but defended the payment of $10,000 to an employee who had criticized the quality of the fighters in the tournament.

title: The Tremors in Campus Labs
description: The State University of New York at Albany admitted last week that some of its psychology teachers had conducted potentially dangerous experiments on students without informing them of the risks. In one experiment, women were given electric shocks by a machine that the State Health.Department considered unsafe. In another, a student was burned on the face by a malfunctioning lamp. None of the experiments caused serious injury. But the episode revealed a most casual attitude toward state and Federal regulations designed to protect human guinea pigs in scientific experiments.

title: 3 TERRORISTS HINTED AT SUICIDE, BONN SAYS
description: BONN, Nov. 2The West German Government disclosed in an official report today that the three terrorist leaders who were found dead in their prison cells last month had made veiled threats of suicide long before in interviews with federal officials.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: INCOMING ARRIVING TODAY, NOV. 3

title: Two U.S. Agencies Start Inquiry Into Dieters Deaths
description: Two Government agencies have started an investigation to determine whether a connection exists between the use of liquid protein for weight loss and the deaths of 12 people who had been on the popular diet. The deaths are said to have occurred this year.

title: ROGER POINCELET
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 (Reuters)Roger Poincelet, a former French jockey who turned to training in recent years, died in hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Youngstown Lessons
description: WASHINGTONThe spreading effects of intensified competition and global stagflation hit Youngstown, Ohio, last month with the announcement that 5,000 steelworkers were being laid off. A few weeks later the Zenith Corporation began to lay off 5,600 workers in places like Watsontown, Pa.; Springfield, Mo.; Sioux City, Iowa.

title: Dr. W. Alden Spencer, 46, Researcher Specializing in Neurological Field
description: Dr. W. Alden Spencer, professor of physiology and neurology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Tuesday at his home in Westport, Conn., atter a long illness. He was 46 years old.

title: An Illustrated Benefit for Books
description: CHARITABLE New Yorkers seem to be having quite a love affair with Paris lately. No sooner was the April in Paris ball over than the faithful turned up at the Wildenstein galleries to preview an exhibition called ParisNew York: A Continuing Romance.

title: OwensIllinois to Lift Glass Prices
description: OwensIllinois Inc. announced plans to increase the selling price of its glass containers by an average of about percent, effective Dec. 15. This is the fourth price increase in the last two years on glass containers by the cornpany, the most recent one an 8 percent average increase on April 1.

title: Stocks of Jeans and Other Imports Fading in Strike
description: One month into the longshoremen's strike that has shut down container shipping operations from Maine to Texas, consumers are finding shortages in such diverse imported commodities as furniture, cheese and specialty apparel.

title: Campaisen Funds Virtually Stop Flowing to 3 Mayoral Candidates
description: Campaign funds have virtually stopped flowing to three of the four major New York City mayoral candidates and the Democratic candidate, Representative Edward L Koch, is running a relatively lowbudget campaign that reflects the view that he is an almost certain winner of next Tuesday's election.

title: Concert: A Wernick Premiere
description: THE main item of interest at Elsa Charlston's recital Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was the premiere of Richard Wernick's Contemplations of the Tenth Muse (1976), a setting for soprano and piano of four short, simple verses by the 17thcentury American poe: Anne Bradstreet.

title: Prison Term for Threat to President
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 2 (AP)A Brunswick, Ga., man was sentenced to 30 months in Federal prison today for threatening the life of a President of the United States James Ferrell, 39 years old, pleaded guilty to the charge in July. He was accused of saving last January, I want to kill the President and unless I get some help I will have to. No specific President was named.

title: Art People
description: NOT A DISPUTE but awell, difference of opinion, has surfaced among some local ItalianAmericans over use of the old police headquarters on Centre Street, recently leased by the city for $1 a month to the Little Italy Restoration Association (LIRA). Should the splendidly ornate old : pile, stretching the length of a block and rising six stories, become an international cultural center for all ethnic groups in the area? Or should it assume the function of a national center for ItalianAmerican culture?

title: Seoul May Permit U.S. to Query Park At Embassy There
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Nov. 3The South Korean Government has agreed to let American officials question Tongsun Park in the United States Embassy here, according to sources close to negotiations between the two Governments over the Park case.

title: Auctions
description: NUDES MAY NOT be uncommon in art and photography, but the 13 studies of nude models photographed by Thomas Eakins that will be auctioned by Sotheby's next Thursday, are both rare and remarkable. For one thing, three are of nude females posed probably by the painter's students, in the early 1880's, and they are among the few such images to survive. Most such female nude studies by Eakins are believed to have been destroyed by family friend following Mrs. Eakins's death so as to prevent any possible damage to Eakins's reputation. Then too, three pictures of male nudes are related to Eakins's renowned painting The Swimming Hole.

title: An American Banker's Findings in Vietnam
description: HONG KONGFor an industrialistturnedbanker and the first American businessman to visit North Vietnam in more than tw.o decades, a visit to Hanoi and Haiphong could not help but create high expectations and the formulation of many, questions. about the past, the war and the future.

title: Letters
description: I read in the Sept. 25 New York Times that the U.S. Department of Transportation may overrule the city's Bureau of Radiation Control and allow transportation of radioactive waste materials through New York City.

title: GISCARD ENDORSES SELFDETERMINATION FOR FRENCH CANADA
description: PARIS, Nov. 3President Valry Giscard d'Estaing assured Quebec today of France's understanding, confidence and support for any political direction it chooses to take.

title: A Social Security Tax Rise Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  The Senate rejected today, 49 to 41, a Republican attempt to substitute an increase in Social Security payroll taxes for all workers in place of a Democratic proposal for a big increase in the taxes paid by employers.

title: HOUSE REJECTS PLAN ON MEDICAIUABORTION VOTED BY THE SENATE; DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS REBUFFED Backers of a More Restrictive Bil[ Win, 193.172H.E.W. and Labor Funds Continued for Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The House rejected today a proposed Senate compromise on guidelines for Medicaid abortions despite intervention by Democratic leaders seeking to break a fourmonth deadlock on the issue. The vote was 193 to 172.

title: Mrs. King Triumphs Over Miss Turnbull
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 3Billie Jean King defeated Wendy Turnbull, a finalist at Forest Hills, 63, 62, last night in the $250,000 Colgate Series tournament, an event that involves the eight top performers in women's tennis.

title: FED MOVES ON RATES NOW TIED TO FACTORS OF TECHNICAL NATURE
description: The turmoil in the securities markets earlier this week that resulted from the perception that the Federal Reserve might have tightened monetary policy another notch may have been for nought.

title: The Changing Knicks
description: For much of the last 10 seasons Walt Frazier, in his stylish, cool manner, dribbled the ball up court slowly, called out a set play and put the New York Knick offense in motion. But now, things have changed.

title: Kissinger Says Palestinian State Would Endanger Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Henry A. Kissinger told members of the World Jewish Congress today that a separate Palestinian state, even if it proclaimed good intentions toward Israel, would inevitably be dangerous for peace in the Middle East.

title: Dulcimer Concert in Ridgefield, Conn.
description: The dulcimer, an instrument native to the Appalachian mountains, will be featured in a concert sponsored by the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art tonight at 8.30 P.M. in the church hall of the Jesse Lee Memorial United Methodist Church, in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: AIDE SAYS WEST'S MEDICINE IS NOT AIDING WORLD POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (Reuters)Major investments In clinical facilities and medical training have done little to improve the health of the world's poorest people, according to a top United States foreign aid official.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH a reviewer's life is not always a delicious one, it has its rewarding moments, foremost among them being the exceptional pleasure of being able to sample in depth the cuisine at Lutce, surely one of the country's most delightful and excellent restaurants. If there is one outstanding surprise here, it is the total lack of pretension of the staff or the management, and there is as equally warm a welcome for unknowns as there is for the steadiest customer.

title: BYRNE, SHAPP SIGN MASSTRANSIT ACCORD Agreement Calls for Construction Bof Two Branches of HighSpeed Rail Line That Connects States
description: CAMDEN, Nov. 3Governor Byrne and Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania signed bilateral consent agreements today calling for the construction of two branches of the Port Authority Transit Company's highspeed rail line that connects Philadelphia and Lindenwold in Camden County.

title: U.S. to Return Hungary's Crown, Held Since End of World War II
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Carter Administration, in a significant move to improve relations with Hungary, has decided to return to Budapest the Crown of St. Stephen, the symbol of Hungarian nationhood that has been in American custody since the last days of World War II.

title: South African Gold Glitters, but Mines Are Dark, Satanic World
description: WELKOM, South AfricaSeveral times a week a Douglas DC4 lumbers down a runway outside this windswept mining town on the first leg of a journey that terminates, for the payload, in vaults as far afield as Jidda and Fort Knox.

title: Cut in Nassau County RealEstate Taxes Proposed by Caso in Budget Plan for 1978
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 3A $1.024 billion operating and capital spending budget for 1978 that would reduce the county tax rate for Nassau County residents was proposed today by the County Executive, Ralph G. Caso.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kissinger Says Palestinian State Would Endanger Mideast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Henry A. Kissinger told members of the World Jewish Congress today that a separate Palestinian state, even if it proclaimed good intentions toward Israel, would inevitably be dangerous for peace in the Middle East.

title: Poll Shows Hostility to Germans Is Declining in Five Countries
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 3 (Reuters)The image of the ugly German has improved following the Mogadishu hijacking episode, according to an opinion poll published here.

title: Toilet Training: Searching fora Correct Method
description: Toilettraining procedures in this country have gone from one method to another over the last century, each new method making the previous one look archaic. In the light of today's usually gentle procedures, the Lenox Hill advice makes one wonder how the maternity ward class of 38 could have made it from infancy into 1977 with sanity intact.

title: MALTESE SPEECH IN CHINA CAUSES SOVIET WALKOUT
description: PEKING, Nov. 3 (Agence FrancePresse) Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta today attacked the Soviet Union at a dinner, provoking a walkout by the Soviet ambassador and representatives of the Soviet bloc.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 2.7%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.7 billion tonmiles, up 2.7 percent from the yearearlier level.

title: RapeRobbery Suspect's Neighbors Stunned
description: BERNARDSVILLE, Nov. 3Stunned neighbors of Bruce A. Ader portrayed the robberrapist suspect today as a generous and helpful man who was always volunteering to help neighbors with their chores and willing to allow flocks of children to use his backyard swimming pool.

title: Union Carbide Expansion
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, through a multimilliondollar expansion of its filinpackaging division's plant in Centervilie, Iowa, will increase its capacity to produce Perflex 62, a shrinkable meat packaging material. The expansion is scheduled for completion in the first quarter of 1978.

title: Talks to Resume in Boeing Strike
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 3 (AP)Representatives of the Boeing Company and striking machinists will resume bargaining tomorrow as the work stoppage enters its second month. The two sides have not met facetoface since late last week. Pete Horn, a Federal mediator said he hoped the talks would lead to fullscale negotiations in the very near future. The strike by 24,000 members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers affects Boeing operations in the Puget Sound area, Portland, Ore., Wichita, Kan., Cape Canaveral, Fla., and several missile bases.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses the ironic prospect that, at a time when emphasis is on the need for tax cuts, the prospect is for increases in Federal taxes for individuals and corporations. Page D5.

title: Foundation Directors Sworn
description: Mayor Beanie swore in the board of directors of the newly created Patrolmen's Benevolent Association sports foundation, which is headed by Jerome Shier, executive vice president of Martin Paints.

title: 25 Die as Heavy Rains Flood Athens and Piraeus
description: ATHENS, Nov. 3 (AP)Torrential rains swept down hills and overflowed rivers There and in the adjacent port city of Piraeus today, leaving 25 dead and damage estimated at millions of dollars.

title: RingerCase Inquiry Faced by Roadblock
description: The possibility of foul play at the South American end of the CinzanoLebon ringer case surfaced last night with the disclosure that at least three of the four equine parents involved were dead.

title: For an Incremental Approach To the Problem of Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter unveiled his welfarereform plan Aug. 6, just two days short of eight years after the announcement of Richard M. Nixon's Family Assistance Plan. Yet the events and prograrimsdespite the eight years that separate thembear a striking similarity. Dar. Nixon sala that the plan would be a total reform the transformation of a system frozen in failure and frustration into system that would work and would encourage people to work.

title: GISCARD ENDORSES SELFDETERMINATION FOR FRENCH CANADA
description: PARIS, Nov. 3  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing assured Quebec today of France's understanding, confidence and support for any political direction it chooses to take.

title: Notes on People
description: Princess Anne of Britain has been given a scientific prediction of the sex of the child she expects in the middle of this month, but she's not sharing the information with the public. Sources close to the royal family said that the Princess had hid an amniocentesis test, in which fluid is drawn from the womb not only to get an indication of an unborn child's sex but also to determine if there are abnormalities. Plans are for the Princess to be in London for the birth, around Nov. 14, which would be an agreeable coincidence. That is not only the fourth wedding anniversary of the Princess and Capt. Mark Phillips, but also the birthday of Prince Charles, the Princess's brother.

title: C.P.A. Group Seek Changes in Loss Data
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants proposed yesterday that the section of the auditor's report on financial statements that calls attention to potential losses be replaced by more comprehensive system of disclosure.

title: Accord Gained in Pascack Hospital Strike
description: WESTWOOD, Nov. 3Pascack Valley Hospital and its 195 striking nurses reached tentative agreement late today on a new twoyear contract to end a 40day walkout.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A S500,000 medical center that was designed to serve the needs of the eld.riy at Crestwood Village, one of the largest retirement communities in the East, in Whiting, was dedicated yesterday. It will open Monday. Some 200 people attended the ceremony, including township officials and staff members of the new onestory, residentiallooking facility.

title: Mayoral Contest in Buffalo Turning Into a 3Way Race
description: BUFFALOIf the experts are rightand they were not the first time around Arthur O. Eve, the upset winner in the Democratic mayoral primary in September, is also the frontrunner in the general election.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Daily Averages for the weeks ended:

title: Claire Nichtern Is Married
description: Claire Nichtern, a Broadway producer, was married yesterday afternoon in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building to Herbert Kallem, the sculptor. The bride won a Tony Award for her production of Luv. Mr. Kallem's works are included in collections at the Newark, Chrysler and Whitney Museums and at New York and St. Lawrence Universities and the University of Florida. He is president of the Sculptures Guild. Both the bride and bridegroom were previously married and divorced.

title: Sheen Leaves the Hospital, His Spirits Unimpaired
description: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen walked out of Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday with an almostjaunty air.

title: Queen Opens Parliament in Ritual Overshadowed by Worker Unrest
description: LONDON, Nov. 3Queen Elizabeth II opened a new session of Parliament today in a blaze of ageold pageantry overshadowed by widespread industrial strife.

title: New Faces: A Guide to the Season's Young Talent
description: New York has always been the lodestone for the artistic youngster from anyplace else. In they come from out of town with visions of stardom dancing in their heads. Some make it as spear carriers. Others are selected in the city's constant cullings of talent and find themselves raised above the crowd, enjoying a gleam of the spotlight.

title: Business Plans to Hold Spending Rise to 3% in 1978
description: Businessmen plan to increase their spending for new plants and equipment by only 3 percent in real terms next year as they remain wary of Government actions, a survey disclosed yesterday.

title: Detroit Gets a Symphonic Lift As Dorati Takes Up the Baton
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3Scalping? a woman wondered as a neatly tailored man plaintively searched the crowd in front of Ford Auditorium for someone who would sell him a ticket, possibly at any price, to hear Beethoven. That's something you might see outside Cobo Arena, a few steps away along the riverfront, during basketball playoffs.

title: MichiganWoman Acquitted In ExHusband's Slaying
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 3 (AP)Francine Hughes, accused of firstdegree murder in the burning death of her exhusband. was acquitted tonight by reason of insanity.

title: Music: From Buffalo With Oboe and Buzzer
description: FOR SEVERAL seasons now the Carnegie Hall Corporation has been presenting in its Recital Hall a series of contemporarymusic concerts put on by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts of the State University of New York at Buffalo. This is carrying coals to Newcastle. It there is anything New York does not lack for musically it is locally produced concerts of modern music.

title: Both Parties Hope to Hold Ground In Connecticut Municipal Elections
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 1With muniicipal elections coming up Tuesday in 158 cities and towns, both major parties seem to feel reasonably sure of keeping control of the parts of Connecticut that are traditionally theirs. And both are working energetically to take territory from the other in a widened battleground.

title: Beame and Goldin Charge S.E.C. Distorted Evidence in Its Inquiry
description: Lawyers for Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission staff had misrepresented evidence and had omitted sworn, uncontested testimony that contradicted its conclusion last August that ciy officials had misled investors during the fiscal crisis in 197475.

title: Top Spanish Red, Moscow Guest,Is Refused Podium at Ceremony
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3The Soviet authorities refused today to let the outspoken Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, deliver a speech at Kremlin ceremonies marking the 60th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: People and Business
description: Hiroyuki Shigemasa has been named president of the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company. He succeeds Kanji Goto, whd has headed the New York bank since Oct. 28, 1974 and has been reassigned to the head office of the parent bank, the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. Mr. Shigemasa joined the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. as a trainee in 1952 after graduating from Tokyo University in 1952. His most recent assignment was general manager in charge of domestic securities and debentures for the parent bank.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HOUSE HONORS HUMPHREY: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who has been diagnosed as having inoperable cancer, addressing the House of Representatives yesterday as Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. fought back tears. We asked you here because we love you, commented Jim Wright, the majority leader. Never before in the 200year history of the House had it convened in special session to honor Senator.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ALTERS BLACK PASS SYSTEM
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 3The South African Government announced changes today in the procedures for blacks seeking to migrate to the white areas of the country without substantially easing the restrictive pass laws that are the most resented feature of the apartheid system.

title: ELLSBERG SAYS ARMY HEED ABOMB PO'ER
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said yesterday that Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson delegated to their top six or seven military commanders the authority, under specific contingencies, to use the United States nuclear arsenal.

title: U.S. to Return Hungary's Crown, Held Since End of World War II
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Carter Administration, in a significant move to improve relations with Hungary, has decided to return to Budapest the Crown of St. Stephen, the symbol of Hungarian nationhood that has been in American custody since the last days of World War II.

title: 2 Opposition Members in Canada Assert Their Offices Were Bugged
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 3. The leader of the opposition announced in the House of Commons today that an eavesdropping device had been found in his office in Parliament.

title: Northern Ireland Wooing Tourists Again as the Violence Wanes
description: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland Northern Ireland is trying to revive its tourist industry now that sectarian violence apparently is declining.

title: Open Interest
GOLD RISES BY $3.50 AN OUNCE IN LONDON Pound Is Off 3c Against the Dollar on Concern Over Labor Woes
description: LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP)The price of gold rose today in London by $3.50 an ounce to $164.75, its highest level since August 1975.

title: New Berkowitz Judge Rules Out Making Disclosures About Case
description: A justice of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, reacting to criticism of his predecessor for talking too much about the Son of Sam case, yesterday slammed the door shut on interviews or the disclosure of documents involving the coming trial of the murder suspect, 24yearold David R. Berkowitz.

title: What Will Ali the Matchmaker Do?
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 3  Throughout his boxing career, Muhammad All has been part pugilist, part poet, part promoter, part publicist and part preacher. Now he's part matchmaker. Ali made this fight, Ken Norton says of his 15round heavyweight bout with Jimmy Young at Caesars Palace on Saturday night. He told everybody he was too old to fight both of us but that he would fight the winner. So here we are. But both Ken Norton and Jimmy Young are wondering when Muhammad Ali will there. By order of the World Boxing Council

title: TV Fare: Giants Game, Then SteelersBroncos
description: Channel 2, New York's CBS station, had a choice for Sunday and chose to televise the Giants home game with undefeated Dallas, which the Cowboys might decide quite early. The other game was St Louis at Minnesota, a About Pro Football matchup or expected of fensive fireworks to be televised nationally in late afternoon but not here. Because the Giants are playing at home, Channel 2 may not televise two games on the same afternoon, in keeping with the National Football League's antioverexposure policy. Channel 4 will televise a late game, Pittsburgh at Denver, starting at 4 P.M. The Jets play at home against Miami and, like the Giants, are decided underdogs. The Monday night game is Washington at Baltimore, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Previews of all games follow, with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: An Old Hand On Trumpet Gets to Lead Own Band
description: In the course of his 72 years, Doc Cheatham has played drums, soprano and Cmelody saxophone, cornet and trumpet. He has been in bands led by Cab Calloway, Benny Goodman, Jelly Roll Morton, Eddie Heywood, Machito,

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Up 1.2 To 203.1 From 201.9 a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 203.1 in the latest week from 201.9 last week.

title: BEAMS CHARGES S.E.C. DISTORTED EVIDENCE
description: Lawyers for the Beame administration charged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission staff had misrepresented evidence and had omitted sworn, uncontested testimony that contradicted its conclusion last August that city officials had misled investors during the fiscal crisis in 197475.

title: BIG RETAIL CHAINS MADE STRONG GAINS IN OCTOBER SALES
description: Registering one of the strongest displays of consumer buying of 1977, sales of 16 of the nation's largest retail chains surged in October, with 14 reporting doubledigit gains over 1976.

title: 2,500 Gather to Honor Carter as 1977 Winner Of Family of Man Award
description: In what officials of the Family of Man Award described as the largest turnout for the presentation dinner, since 1963, when President John F. Kennedy came to New York to receive the first such award, an estimated 2,500 religious, civic and business leaders gathered at the New York Hilton Hotel last night to pay tribute to the absentee 1977 winnerPresident Carter.

title: New York's Most Glamorous, Clamorous Walks
description: There are walks that make you happy, and there are walks that make you smile. There are walks that are snappy, and there are walks that take awhile. New York is a pedestrian city with something or someone always afoot. There are walking tours over all sorts of terrain and through all sorts of environments. These are walks, not to, but through places. Getting there is all the fun.

title: Film: 'Dragon' at Music Hall:Sweet, Green Fire
description: DID YOU EVER see an elephant fly? You did? Well, then, how about a chubby green dragon who trots across live-action landscapes with animated aplomb, and who can casually turn himself into a cloud of blue vapor? "Pete's Dragon," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, is the most energetic and enjoyable Disney movie in a long while.Pete is a rather strenuously cute little boy played by Sean Marshall, and Elliott is his fire-breathing, often invisible friend. Together, they run away from the filthy, snaggle-toothed Gogans (Mama Gogan is Shelley Winters), who have bought Pete from an orphanage for $50 and change and mean to keep him. Pete and Elliott wind up in Passamaquoddy, a Maine town that looks remarkably like a California movie set, with a populace that includes Jim Backus as the bumbling mayor, Mickey Rooney as the tippling lighthouse-keeper, Helen Reddy as the lighthouse-keeper's wonderful daughter, and Jim Dale and Red Buttons as a pair of half-funny, half-dastardly medicine salesmen. Lots of things happen to Pete and Elliott there, and every time anything happens, someone is sure to sing about it.Directed by Disney veteran Don Chaffey, "Pete's Dragon" is full of performers who nicely detract attention from one another's weaknesses. Sean Marshall doesn't sing well, but Helen Reddy does, so she often accompanies his vocals. Miss Reddy is serviceable but undistinguished as an actressshe has a tendency to behave as if she were a very bright light bulb in a very small lampbut she so often finds herself in the company of Messrs. Rooney, Dale or Buttons that her scenes work well.Onna White's choreography is charmingly ragtag, especially when it comes to the Gogans, and the score by Al Kasha and Joel Hirschhorn (whose lesser credits include "The Towering Inferno" and "The Poseidon Adventure") has some sunny moments. At two hours and 14 minutes, the movie is a lot longer than it needs to be. On the other hand, Elliott (whose beeps and bomps and chomping sounds are supplied by Charlie Callas) is very sweet and emotive, and you don't often see children's musicals as ambitious as this one any more.Kids may love it, but adults will find themselves wondering about a thing or two. Granted, a movie starring a green dragon invites a few jokes about characters' seeing things that aren't there; even so, there is an awful lot of drinking in the script, and the film treats alcohol carelessly enough to give one pause. Also, there is something disconcerting about the musical number in which Miss Reddy and a chorus of children proclaim that "There's room for everyone in this world." Passamaquoddy counts a handful of blacks among its population, but the children in that scene appear to be exclusively white.

title: Progress on Truce For Rhodesia Seen By British Official
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 3 (Reuters) Britain's designated representative in Rhodesia, Field Marshal Lord Carver, said today that he was making progress in talks with officials here on arranging a ceasefire in the guerrilla war between Rhodesians and black liberation movements.

title: A Social Security Fix but Not a Solution
description: When older Americans sneeze, Congress runs a fever. That's the most reasonable explanation for the mess both houses of Congress are making of Social Security reform,

title: Carter's Wife Visits Mexico, Attends Ballet
description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 3Rosalynn Carter came to this Mexican border town today for an afternoon of goodneighborliness and culture with Carmen Romano de Lopez Portillo, the wife of Mexico's President.

title: 4 Killed in Motel Blaze; 20 Guests Leap to Safety
description: NEW CASTLE, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP)About 20 motel guests smashed windows and leaped to safety early today as fire raged through a twostory Holiday Inn in this western Pennsylvania community. Four persons were killed.

title: Broadway
description: COLD STORAGE, the play by Ronald Ribman that got such fine reviews when it was done at the AmericanPlace Theater last season, will come to Broadway in December. Mr. Ribman has revised the play somewhat, and it will have a new director in Frank Corsaro, but it will still have half its original cast in Martin Balsam. Mr. Balsam will be Joined by Len Cariou, who won Tony nominations for his appearances in Applause and A Little Night Music. The play will go into rehearsal on Nov. 28, start previews on Dec. 22, and then open at the Lyceum Theater sometime during the next week. The producers are Claire Nichtern and Ashton Springer.

title: U.N. Assembly Calls Upon Governments To Prosecute or Extradite All Hijackers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3The General Assembly condemned air piracy today and called on all governments to take steps to prevent it by tightening airline and airport security and agreeing to prosecute or extradite hijackers.

title: PROVENZANO TRIAL DELAYED BY LETTER
description: An unusual letter from a key witness to a Federal prosecutor delayed the scheduled opening yesterday of the trial of Anthony Provenzano. a New Jersey official of the Teamsters Union, who was charged with a kickback conspiracy involving a pensionfund loan.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Marilyn French's Painful Trip To Liberation, Literary Success
description: I wanted to tell the story of what it is like to be a woman in our country in the middle of the 20th century, Marilyn French said, deep into a 90minute interview.

title: U.S. Companies Avoid Insuring Horses Imported From South America
description: A horse doesn't speak, a specialist in animal insurance said yesterday. A horse will never tell what happened to him. And he's an easy animal to dispose of. So if you overinsure horse, you're putting a temptation there.

title: Exchange Plans Halt In Sugar Quotations
description: The Board of Managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange has voted to suspend publication of spot quotations for sugar because of uncertainties created by a lawsuit filet against the exchange by the Justice Department.

title: Top Mayoral Candidates Queried In Talks Before Catholic Priests
description: The sharpest questions were directed at Edward I. Koch as, one by one, the four major New York City mayoral candidates spoke yesterday to a roomful of Roman Catholic priests.

title: Detroit Gets a Symphonic Lift As Dorati Takes Up the Baton
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3Scalping? a woman wondered as a neatly tailored man plaintively searched the crowd in front of Ford Auditorium for someone who would sell him a ticket, possibly at any price, to hear Beethoven. That's something you might see outside Cobo Arena, a few steps away along the riverfront, during basketball playoffs.

title: Famed Seal Gets to Winter Home
description: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)Andre, the celebrated harbor seal, got a star's welcome yesterday as he arrived at his winter home here. An estimated 200 youngsters and adults greeted him at the New rang land Aquarium, where Andre was placed in 4 pool with other seals and is to perform three times a day. The seal was flown from his summer ome in Rockport, on the Maine coast, and was accompanied by his trainer, Harry A. Goodridge. Each spring, Andre swims the 160 miles from Massachusetts to Rockport where he holds the title of honorary harbormaster.

title: RESIDENTS CRITICIZE ZONING FOR CASiNOS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 3Members of minority groups reacted angrily today to this resort's proposed new master plan, contending that it met the needs of developers of gamblingcasino hotels but left lowincome residents in danger of eviction from their homes with no relocation housing in the city.

title: Which Rule of Law?
description: No one who has known Richard Helms over the years would wish for him to have suffered more severely in the plea bargain he recently struck with the Department of Justice. And perhaps all the justifications for that bargain are valid. Still, to borrow a phrase from Attorney General Griffin Bell, this agreement doesn't set well.

title: Books: Seven Pillars of Fiction?
description: THE LEGEND that is Lawrence of Arabia receives a severe battering in this new life by Desmond Stewart. And it is not because Mr. Stewart is out to denigrate the man or to diminish the hero. Thereis no malice in the book. On the contrary. Even when he is most subtle in laying bare the exaggerations and the romancings in Lawrence's claims or in the claims made by others in his behalf, Mr. Stewart keeps before the reader the complex person and the tortured personality behind the fictions. The effect is devastating nonetheless.

title: Dance: Kei Takers Human Tableaux
description: WHAT IS ONE TO DO with a young artist who remains always interesting but who never reaches the depth for which she seems to be striving?

title: Judith Raskin to Sing in Hicksville Program
description: Judith Raskin, soprano with the Metropolitan Opera Company, to make her second appearance with the Sea CHU Chamher Players tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Hicksville (L.I.) Junior High School on Jerusalem Avenue. Miss Raskin will sing Ezra Laderman's From the Psalms and Schumann's Frauenliebe und Leben.

title: Glories of Armenia doing on Display
description: An exhibition of the cultural heritage of the Armenian people, who were strategically but often tragicallyplaced on a crossroads between the ancient Eastern and Western worlds, will go on view Sunday at Columbia University's Low Memorial Library.

title: Management
description: Do it NOW, Alan Lakein urges. Time is money. Work smarter, not harder. There's always enough time for the important things.

title: State Is Auditing City Banks As They Expand in Bahamas
description: NASSAU, the BahamasAs a fullscale audit effort by New York State tax authorities gets under way, several of the largest New York banks have taken steps to enlarge their offices in this island tax haven.

title: Commodity Futures Lose Ground
description: Commodity futures prices declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade following weeks of rising prices attributable to rumors of a poor Soviet grain crop.

title: Notes on People
description: Princess Anne of Britain has been given a scientific prediction of the sex of the child she expects in the middle of this month, but she's not sharing the information with the public. Sources close to the royal family said

title: Jackson, to Speed Energy Bill, Bids Carter Delay Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)House and Senate leaders sought ways today to speed up work on energy legislation compromise. Senator Henry M. Jackson said President Carter might not get the legislation until just before Christmas and suggested the President cancel his plans for an overseas trip later this month.

title: Vermonter Dies at 109
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 3 (AP)William Aikey, thought to be Vermonts oldest resident, has died at the age of 109. Mr. Aikey, who was born here in 1868, attributed his longevity to good, clean living and keeping away from liquor. He walked long distances and never smoked cigarettes, although he was fond of a pipe. Mr. Aikel began working in textile mills when he was 10 and retired at the age of 79.

title: Unkempt November
description: Autumn rain and autumn wind have brought down the color from the treetops, and now the countryside begins to have the ragged, unkempt look of November, as though things had been neglected. Nature isn't very neat in these matters.

title: CUTS IN RAIL SERVICE AVERTED FOR JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 3Amtrak dropped its plan today for substantial reductions in service in New Jersey this Sunday after being assured of an extra $8 million in operating funds from Congress.

title: Oakland, Calif., Teachers Strike
description: OAKLAND. Calif., Nov. 3 (AP)The first teachers strike in Oakland history began today with picket lines up outside nearly every school in the 50,000pupil district. Members of the Oakland Education Association voted 1,160 to 780 last night to walk out after contract negotiations with the Oakland Unified School District broke off. Schools remained open, with classes taught by substitute teachers. Teachers have asked for a 15 percent salary increase, among other provisions.

title: Portrait of a Busy Composer
description: Today will be a busy day for Jacob Druckman. The 49yearold Pulitzer Prizewinning composer will attend this afternoon's concert in Avery Fisher Hall by the New York Philharmonic, because it is playing one of his works. He will then dash about to rehearsals of two other works to be performed tonight. one in a program at Carnegie Recital Hall, the other in a Buffalo Creative Associates program at the New School.

title: New York City's First Known Case Of Legionnaires Disease Reported
description: The first confirmed case of legionnaires disease in New York Citythat of a 68yerarold woman who was stricken seven weeks ago and has since fully recovered was reported yesterday by the city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Pascal J. Imperato.

title: Jones Boy Captures Puissance
description: A green horse that didn't know how to quit and a woman rider competing in the event for only the third time in her career combined last night to win the $2,000 Puissance Stake high jump as the National Horse Show completed its third day at Madison Square Garden.

title: Deaths
description: AGGERRose on November 2nd. Wife of the late Oliver P. Beloved mother of Donald and Robert and Simone. Dear grandmother of David, Benlamin, Samuel, Ellen, Mark and April. Service today Friday 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at Bist Street. Interment private.

title: At the Movie
description: "MY MOVIE MADE $1.50 on opening day in a theater outside of Denver. It was one child's admission. I believe that's a record. By the end of the week, the box office skyrocketed to $86, and then the movie was yanked.

title: Two Teams Share Lead By Stroke in Disney Golf
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 3 (UPI)Chi Chi Rodriguez and Victor Regalado combined on a 10underpar 62 today and shared the firstround lead with Gibby Gilbert and Grier Jones in the $200,000 Walt Disney World national team golf tournament.
