title: Metropolitan Museum Historic Area Is Approved
description: A new Metropolitan Museum historic district in which 120 buildings have been designated as landmarks was unanimously approved yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.,

title: California Court Rejects Request By Black Panther Chief for Files
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (AP)The California Supreme Court turned down today the request of Huey Newton, the Black Panther leader, to gain access to documents and records of five Federal agencies.

title: Levitt Audit Finds 5th of Students In SEEK Program Are Ineligible
description: New York State yesterday released an audit of the controversial SEEK program that it said showed one out of five students ineligible and a $2.4 million overpayment by the state in one recent year.

title: Deaths
description: DIBLASIJudge Rudolph F. We mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, devoted friend, and decent human being whose life was devoted to giving of himself to those who needed him.

title: Halston Downtown Has Its Own Elan
description: Everyone knows there are two Halstons. One is known as Ralston Uptown. He holds forth at his boutique and salon at Madison Avenue and 68th Street. That's where the rich and powerful and prestigious go to shop and, perhaps, get the maestro's personal attention.

title: Advertising
description: An unscheduled clash between the past and current heads of a major research firm on the validity of magazine audience research highlighted the eighth annual TrendSpotting Seminar of Media Decisions magazine yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
Bostock Is Leading Light in FreeAgent Pool Today
description: Lyman Bostock, a thirdyear major leaguer who posted the majors third highest batting average this year while earning only $1,000 above the mintmum salary, will he the first free agent selected today in baseball's negotiation rights draft at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Art: The Fun Of David Hockney
description: FEW CONTEMPORARY PAINTING exhibitions are more entertaining than David Hockney's. What fun they are to see! They give us as world that can be instantly aonrehended and enjoyed. The figures in them are obviously drawn from firsthand experience. The objects too  a vase of red tulips, say, or a patterned bedspread or a modern folding chair  have a vivid uptodate feeling. Even the light in them has the kind of turnedup synthetic clarity we recognize as the light of our time and no othera light compounded, in about equal parts, of psychological candor and improved technology. And the painting itself is immensely clever and accomplished, glossy in fact, and its high technical finish carries an amusing undercurrent of comedy and wit.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Justice Tyler Guilty On Perjury Charge; Faces Up to 7 Years
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan last night found Justice Andrew R. Tyler guilty of firstdegree perjury arising from his testimony before a grand jury about his relationship with a racketeer. The crime is a felony punishable by up to seven years in prison.

title: Koch and Goodman Speak Out for Court Amendments
description: Representative Edward T. Koch, the Democratic mayoral candidate, was at news conference yesterday to speak out in favor of three proposed court amendments.

title: World News Briefs Carter Allows P.O.W.'s To Tell More to Enemy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)President Carter opened the way today for future Americans taken prisoner by an enemy to give their captors more than name, rank, service number and birth date if they are tortured.

title: Wagner Accuses Stein of Violating Election Laws, and Draws Denials
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., the RepublicanLiberal candidate for Manhattan Borough president, yesterday accused his Democratic opponent, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, of three electionlaw violations, including a charge that Mr. Stein's father, Jerry Finkelstein, had contributed more to his son's campaign than is permitted by law.

title: Screen: 1900, Bertolucci's Marxist Saga
description: Bernardo Bertolucci's 1900 is a fourhour, fiveminute (plus intermission) movie that covers approximately 70 years of Italian social and political history, from 1901, the year Verdi died and peasants were still in bondage to the landowners, to the 1970's, when a capitalist movie producer would put up millions of dollars to make a film such as 1900, which is essentially a Marxist romance. This is progress of a very particular sort.

title: For Children
description: The End of the World

title: News Summary
description: The Crown of St. Stephen and other crown jewels will be returned to Hungary by the United States, which has held them in custody since the end of World War II. They were turned over to American military officials by their Hungarian guards to keep them out of Soviet. hands. The crown, dating to the year 1000 is a symbol of Hungarian nationhood. Its return by this country is regarded as a major diplomatic move towards normalizing relations with Budapest, especially in the area of trade. [Page A1, Columns 45.]

title: Miss Hearst Criticizes Appellate Court Decision
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 3 (UPI)Patricia Hearst said today that she was not getting fair treatment from the judicial system, and one of her attorneys warned that she would be in danger if she was returned to prison.

title: Simple Funeral Marks End of Detroit Crime Boss
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3The thick perfume of roses hung heavy in the air behind the drawn curtains in the Bagnasco Funeral Home as people speaking in muted voices made their way across the thick gold carpet to pay their final respects to Joseph Zerilli, the Mafia boss of Detroit, who died Sunday at the age of 79.

title: Mount Etna Spews Lava
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 3 (AP)Mount Etna erupted today and sent a stream of lava nearly a mile down the north side toward the city of Randazzo, 2 miles away. Experts said the volcano, which erupted several times last summer, was not threatening any populated or cultivated areas.

title: Thousands StrikeIn Israel to ProtestEconomic Changes
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 3 (UPI)Thousands of Israeli workers went on strike and conducted protest marches today against the Government's new economic policies that reduce socialism and emphasize free epierprise.

title: Gold Fever Once More on the Rise
description: Gold is backagain.

title: Books of The Times
description: PRETEND THAT last Month's budget left you with a surplus for a change. Say $31.27. You don't owe anyone, not even a department store or a guy you lost a bet with. Pretend you can't think what to dc with all this money. One recom

title: Easta and West Meet in Jazz at the Beacon
description: Western jazz, rock and classical musicians and composers began turning to the East for both musical inspiration and spiritual sustenance during the 1960's. John McLaughlin and Alice Coltrane, who are performing at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, tomorrow night at 8, with their respective groups, were part of that trend.

title: HARRY N. KUESEL
description: Harry N. Kuesel, who retired in 1957 as manager of the New York City uptown branch of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I., after month's illness, He was 85 years old and lived at 10 Ridge Drive, Port Washington, L.I.

title: A Choreographer Of Time and Space
description: Anyone who saw Robert Wilson's avantgarde opera Einstein on the Beach a year ago at the Metropolitan Opera House will never forget its extraordinary openingLucinda Childs performing a walking solo on a diagonal. As one of the leads in this production, Miss Childs won an Oble award and gained her widest audience as an actress. The offers of roles in films and theater quickly rolled in.

title: Dissident L. I. Catholic GroUp Wins Suit Over Attendance at Service
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday overturned a State Supreme Court ruling in Nassau County that no more than 25 persons could attend a dedication mass at the new national headquarters for a group of dissident Catholics in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., on Sunday.

title: Gold Fever  Once More on the Rise
description: Gold is backagain.

title: Police Studying Arrest of Sturgis, Who Denies Threatening Accuser
description: A Police Department investigation was ordered yesterday into the arrest of Frank A. Sturgis, convicted Watergate burglar and former Central Intelligence Agency spy in Cuba, for alleged telephone threats to hone Marita Lorenz, whom Mr. Sturgis says he once recruited to kill Fidel Castro.

title: Two Elephants in U.S. To Calve Next Year
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP) Old Diamond, the largest bull elephant in captivity, has mated with two females and each should bear offspring next year, zoo officials say.

title: Intrigue by Tito's Wife Is Reportedly Investigated
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3Senior Yugoslav Defense Ministry officials are said to be investigating reports of politics; intrigue involving a number of military officers and the wife of President Tito.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: E.E.C. AIDE TO OFFER PLAN FOR REFORMING WORLD STEEL OUTPUT
description: BRUSSELS, Nov 3A plan for reforming and strengthening the world's troubled steel industry will be proposed to the Carter Administration next week by Europe's senior steel official.

title: 3 Indicted in Poverty Fraud
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 3 (UPI)Three members of the Puerto Rican Association for Community Organization, an antipoverty agency here, have been indicted on charges of bilking the state of nearly $150,000. The defendants are Perfecto Oyola, director of the juvenile program, Marta Santiago, a social worker, and Blanca Cabreta, a counselor.

title: Consumers Contend Warranty Law Fails To Aid Car Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Federal warranty law has failed to make it easier for buyers to get satisfaction on defective new automobiles, leaders of consumers groups said today at a conference called to assess the effect of the law, which is nearing its third anniversary.

title: Wagner Accuses Stein of Violating Election Laws, and Draws Denials
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Republican. Liberal candidate for Manhattan Borough President, yesterday accused his Democratic opponent, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, of three electionlaw violations, including a charge that Mr. Stein's father, Jerry Finkelstein, had contributed more to his son's campaign than is permitted by law.

title: Carter's TV Nominee Is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  President Carter's nomination of a former White Citizens Council member from Mississippi to the board of a major public broadcasting agency, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, has led publicinterest and civilrights groups here to try to block his confirmation.

title: Music: Robert Shaw Leads Bach Aria Group at Tully Hall
description: TWENTY YEARS AGO or more, Robert Shaw was among the leading proponents of the chambermusic style of Bach performance. His barnstorming tours around the country did a great deal to persuade the public that Bach's music sounded best when performed with the modest choral and instrumental forces that the composer had at his command.

title: Capt. Rupert M. Weeks of Pan Am; Served as Check Pilot for Airline
description: Flight Capt. Rupert M. Weeks of Pan American World Airways, its chief pilot at the New York base from 1956 through 1973, died of a heart attack Sunday in his home, 18 Ivy Lane, Setauket, L.I. He was 56 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
JUDGE RUDOLPH DIBLASI OF THE FAMILY COURT, 58
description: Judge Rudolph F. DiBlasi of Family Court, who had served as a City Councilman and State Assemblyman from Brooklyn's Bushwick section, died Wednesday at MemorialSloan Kettering Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
SECURITY COUNCIL AGREES ON TEXT FOR ARMS EMBARGO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 3The 15 members of the Security Council agreed tonight on the final wording of a resolution imposing a mandatory embargo on the sale of arms to South Africa and decided to approve it tomorrow.

title: Marshal Amazasp K. Babadzhanyan; Commanded Soviet Armored Forces
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (UPI)  The commander of the Soviet Army's armored forces, Chief Marshal Amazasp K. Babadzhanyan, died yesterday at the age of 71, the Tass press agency announced today.

title: Carter's Wife Visits Mexico, Attends Ballet

title: Ironic Prospect: Tax Rise When the Need Is Big Cuts

title: Screen: Voyage Into Oblivion:Failed Aspirations
description: "VOYAGE TO GRAND Tartarie" is brought to us by Jean-Charles Tacchella, the director who hadn't yet brought to us "Cousin, Cousine" when he made "Grand Tartarie," his first feature, a comedy of such consistent mirthlessness and accidental cruelty you might believe them to be his method.Although I'm an admirer of "Cousin, Cousine," which became one of the most successful foreign-language movies we've had in years, I can see some associations between its rather casual treatment of other people's feelings and the total self-absorption that Mr. Tacchella displays in "Voyage to Grand Tartarie," which opened yesterday at the D. W. Griffith and Quad Cinemas, a social satire made with a heavy hand and small mind.Only someone dangerously sure of his own talents would think he could makeas Mr. Tacchella has described "Grand Tartarie"a film that is a "farcical trip through our society" as well a "satire of films which make fun of contemporary society." If Mr. Tacchella were a shipbuilder, you might expect him to put sails on a submarine."Voyage to Grand Tartarie," a title that is supposed to suggest a trip through hell, is set in a landscape that is meant to be a surreal projection of a France in the grip of social and political revolution, environmental pollution and emotional alienation.The journey is undertaken by Alexis (Jean-Luc Bideau) after his pretty young wife is arbitrarily shot down by a maniac in a cowboy suit as she comes out of a supermarket. Alexis, one is asked to believe, feels so much grief he expresses none at all. He withdraws his money from the bank, packs one shirt in a suitcase, and climbs in to his car with the intention of committing suicide when his money runs out.Unfortunately he has too many whimsical adventures ever to carry out his plan. With a completely deadpan expression, Alexis alternately observes the idiocies around him and participates in them. It's a lunatic world, Mr. Tacchella tells us over and over again, a mysterious place where a businessman works so hard he has to take sleep cures twice a year, where people carry guns to and from work, where everyone's on strike, where water is about to be rationed and where nothing is so awful at home but that news of a war in Kenya doesn't make things seem better.Alexis's life becomes a kind of elongated movie serial, a point that is emphasized by his reading "Fantomas" adventures in moments of repose. He has a couple of desultory affairs along the way, including one with a young woman played by Micheline Lanctot, who has a very pretty face but is otherwise so husky-voiced and androgynous I began to wonder if she could possibly be a boy. This suspicion was further increased by Mr. Tacchella's decisionwhich I ultimately took to be just another failed joketo shoot several scenes featuring Mr. Bideau in the nude while the actresses remain prudishly clothed from the neck down.Mr. Tacchella has no knack whatsoever for the cinema of the absurd. Images that are intended to strike us as revealing and ridiculous simply look like mistakes, things that should have been left on the cutting-room floor but weren'ta little girl cheerfully burying a cat alive, or a woman shining the shoes of her husband while he hangs by his neck from a tree. Only Luis Buuel has the tact and the wit to deal successfully in such expressions of rage.The movie is such a mess it even fractures the talents of Mr. Bideau, the Swiss actor who has proven himself in such films as "La Salamandre," "The Invitation" and "Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000." In this film, he behaves like a zombie."Grand Tartarie" is not completely incapable of creating some sense of wonder, if only the wonder that the man who made his debut with a movie of so many failed aspirations could have gone on to make "Cousin, Cousine," a small, beautifully acted love story, simultaneously tough and lyric, which never overreaches itself in the juvenile ways of his first endeavor.

title: Theater: Six Women Who Defied Society
description: IN OUT of Our Father's House, Richmond Crinkley's Academy production at Theater of the Riverside Church, six 19thcentury American women become representative pioneers. In astronomy labor, suffrage and other worlds they find liberation from roles to which societyand specifically their fathers assign them, A woman, they are told, is an inferior order of being. The necessary response is to defy authority wherever they find it.

title: Firestone Official Pleads Not Guilty
description: Robert P. Beasley, former vice chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, pleaded not guilty in New York Southern District Federal Court yesterday to a 40count indictment charging him with diverting more than $1 million intended for illegal political contributions to his own benefit.

title: Bateman's Campaign Is Grounded By Poor Weather and Poor Health
description: LAKEWOOD, Nov. 3A combination of poor flying weather and a fever grounded the campaign of State Senator Raymond H. Bateman today.

title: SCOPPETTA NAMES PANEL TO STUDY PAROLE SYSTEM
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, announced yesterday that a 10member advisory panel would examine New York State's sentencing and parole structure.

title: Seoul May Permit U.S. to Query Park At Embassy There
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 3The South Korean Government has agreed to let American officials question Tongsun Park in the United States Embassy here, according to sources close to negotiations between the two Governments over the Park case.

title: 12 TRUCKERS ACCUSED IN DOABLE PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)The Interstate Commerce Commission charged in a Federal suit today that 12 large Middle Western trucking companies illegally retained $2.3 million in inadvertent double payments from shippers.

title: U.S. and Congo Resume Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  The United States has reopened its embassy in the Congo after a 12year break in diplomatic relations, the State Department announced today. Representatives of the two Governments met in West Germany in June and agreed to resume the ties.

title: Top Spanish Red, Moscow Guest, Is Refused Podium at Ceremony
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3The Soviet authorities refused today to let the outspoken Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, deliver a speech at Kremlin ceremonies marking the 60th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Justice Department disclosed yesterday that it was conferring with the Federal Trade Commission to decide which agency would take on an antitrust investigation of the $400 million takeover bid by the Eaton Corporation for the Carborundum Company. A spokesman for the Justice Department said that his agency had asked for the job.

title: Belgium Seeks 88 Olympics
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 3 (UPI)Belgium will bid for the 1988 Summer Olympics, Raoul Mollet, the president of the Belgium Olympic Committee, said today. He said Belgium would apply to have the Cames spread around the country rather than in one city.

title: Stocks, Although Faced by Threat Of Rise in Inflation, Close Mixed
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday although the specter of growing inflation loomed over Wall Street: the Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, finished ahead 1.82 points at 802.67. However, declines on the New York Stock Exchange slightly outnumbered advances.

title: October Wholesale Prices Up 0.8% For Biggest Increase in Six Months
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  Wholesale prices, which generally point to the levels consumers pay later, rose eighttenths of 1 percent last month, the largest gain in half a year, mainly reflecting sharply higher prices for farm products and processed foods, the Labor Department reported today.

Vance and Zbigniew Brzezinski, his national security adviser.

description: CLEARLY, it is no easy matter to be the showcase for American modernism. The Whitney Museum of American Art has, for much of its 47year career, been chided for not giving a balanced view of the native product. But it may well be that such a view is not possible. In any case, the ups and downs of Whitney policy, which have ranged from the comatose to the far out, have reflectedif sometimes by defaultthe struggles afflicting the art of which it is custodian.

Boorstin, the Librarian of Congress, is a highly respected historian, who has also written books for the current marketplace, such as The Americans.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: THE WORLD UPSETS Wallace Shawn. When his first play, Our Late Night, was running at the Public Theater in 1975, he continued to support himself by working as a shipping clerk in the garment district. One day, rolling a dress rack along the street, he acciaentairy ran down one of the actors from his cast. Within months after the play won an Obie award for distinguished playwriting, Mr. Shawn found himself gainfully, but regretfully, employed in another in his series of odd jobsas a $3anhour Xerox machine operatorwithout even the privilege of Xeroxing his own scripts.

title: Theater: TeethStudy of Class Guilt
description: ONE of the less agreeable byproducts of the British class system is class guilt. At its ripest, it can make class arrogance look almost good.

Fraser, chairman of a House subcommittee engaged in the investigation of alleged Korean influence buying, tried today to remove suspicion that Representative Edward J. Derwinski, the senior Republican on the subcommittee, had disclosed information endangering South Korean intelligence officer who was defecting to the United States.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 President Carter asked the heads of Government departments and agencies today to report by early next month what steps they were taking to deal with the problems and complaints of Congressmen's constituents in coping with the Federal bureaucracy.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The House rejected today a proposed Senate compromise on guidelines for Medicaid abortions despite intervention by Democratic leaders seeking to break a fourmonth deadlock on the issue. The vote was 193 to 172.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: EVERAL weeks ago, a CBS executive criticized ABC for descending to the level of dramatized cartoons and comic strips in its orimetime schedule. The executive evidently forgot that his own network had recently acquired Wonder Woman, an ABC reject. Tonight at 8, for embarrassing good measure, CBS is offering a twohour production called The Incredible Hulk. based on a character born in 1962 in the pages of Marvel comic books.

title: Louis Reported Stable After Heart Surgery
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)Joe Louis, the former heavyweight boxing champion, was reported in stable condition today after undergoing surgery at Methodist Hospital.

title: Bridge:
description: For a variety of reasons, the standard of play in a pair contest deteriorates markedly in the final round. Some players are showing signs of fatigue; some have lost interest because their results have been poor and they have no hope of a high rank. Others are beginning to think about the ride home. And still others feel that the time has come for some desperate effort to end with a good score.

title: Lakeland Voters Reject an Arbitration Proposal on Teachers Strike
description: MOHEGAN LANE, N.Y.Voters in the Lakeland Sthool District tonight overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to submit a bitter. 39day teachers strike to binding arbitration.

description: TRENTON,Nov. 4Governor Byrne has apparently overtaken Senator Raymond H. Bateman in their race for Governor, according to a poll released today by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: G.O.P. Hails Row B, Downplays the Party
description: The Manhattan Republican Party hired a big red doubledecker bus yesterday, festooned it with signs boosting the party's candidates, loaded the candidates on and took a sixhour streetcorner tour, hailing everything about their candidates but their Republican Party label.

title: Penn State and Pitt Face Bowl Roadblocks Today
description: North Carolina State and West Virginia have struggled through some successful seasons in recent years but have never reached major bowl status. While the Wolfpack is haying a fair season this fall, the Mountaineers have slipped so badly from their early season hopes that they could have a losMg year.

title: China's Leaders View Last 10 Years as Lost
description: PEK1NGTen lost years! This is the phrase echoed by Chinese political, industrial and educational leaders as they estimate the magnitude of the tasks faced by China's new leadership after the political turmoil of the last decade.

title: Inspiration Copper Omits Quarterly Dividend
description: Directors of the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company voted to omit a dividend payment to stockholders in the fourth quarter. The board's decision was based on a loss of $6.2 million incurred in the third quarter, continuing low demand for domestically produced copper and the restriction on dividends imposed by the loan agreement relating to the company's pollutioncontrol financing.

title: Rhodesian Leader Denies Reports of Gains in Talks With Briton and U.N. Aide
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 4 (Reuters) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that no progress had been made in talks between British representatives and Rhodesian military officials on achieving a ceasefire in Rhodesia's guerrilla war.

title: Seton Hall Beats Upsala, 1911; Vikings First Loss
description: SOUTH ORANGE. N. J., Nov. 4Seton Hall University defeated Upsala College, 1911, tonight in a college football game. Upsala had won its first seven games this season.

title: Dollar Moves Up After Hectic Week; Gold Gains Again
description: The dollar gained ground yesterday in foreign exchange trading against Europe's major currencies and the yen, ending a hectic week in which it fell to record lows against the yen, Swiss franc and West German mark, The Associated Press reported.

title: Humphrey Not for Stein
description: Andrew J. Stein, the Democratic candidate for Manhattan Borough President, proudly announced an endorsement yesterday from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. only to be chagrined later in the day to discover that Mr. Humphrey had not intended to endorse him.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: South African Minister Asserts Arms Ban May Incite Violence
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 4 (AP)Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today the United Nationsdecreed arms embargo against South Africa was an incitement to violence and would stiffen the resolve of South Africans to defend their country. He denounced Western nations that joined in approving the measure today.

title: ?ard of Thanks
description: MARLOWEGeorge J. The family of George J. Marlowe sincerely thank their friends and relatives for their kind expression of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: Security Council Cited Threats to Peace
description: The United Nations Security Council, in voting a mandatory embargo on arms sales to South Africa, said yesterday that it was acting under Chapter VII of the world organization's Charter, but it did not specify which of the Chapter's 13 articles it was invoking.

description: KARAK, PakistanLuke Fournier, a genial geologist from Sanford, Me., moved excitedly from one side of the little airplane to the other, pointing down at the brown trackless wilderness a thousand feet below.

title: Around the Nation
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 4 (AP)The. Maryland Court of Appeals today directed Marvin Mandel, the suspended Governor, to show by Nov. 25 why he should not be suspended from law practice.

title: OTTAWA EXPRESSES ANNOYANCE AT PARIS
description: OTTAWA,Nov. 4The Canadian Government expressed irritation today over the French award of the Legion of Honor yesterday to Rene Levesque, the separatist Premier of Quebec, by reminding France that Canadians were not allowed to receive foreign decorations without Ottawa's approval.

title: Casino Planner Would Shift Airport
description: ATLANTIC CITY,Nov. 4 Angelos C. Demetriou, 'his resort's master planner for casino gambling, managed to satisfy both sides this week in a controversy over whether to save or close the city's intown airport, but the proposed solution moving the airport a mile west to Great. Islandmay bump into state and Federal regulations protecting wetlands from construction.

title: Prime Rate for Bank of America Is Increased to 7 % from 7 %
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 (AP)The Bank of America raised its prime lending rate to 7  percent from 7  percent today, the last major bank to do so.

title: People and Business
description: Federal rules on disclosing information about municipal bond offerings are virtually inevitable, according to John Evans, a Securities and Exchange commissioner. Public demand for Washington surveillance of such bonds, he said, is coming in the wake of the New York City credit crisis and because of disenchantment with bondrating agencies, concern by municipal workers about pensions and the growing number of individuals investing in municipal bonds.

title: Unemployment Inches Up to 7%, Disappointment to White House
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 4Unemployment across the nation rose, by a tenth of a percentage point to 7 percent of the work force in October keeping the jobless rate essentially the same for six months.

title: Senate, in Payroll Plight, Continues Abortion Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Fearful of being blamed for payless paydays for more than 200,000 employees of two Federal agencies, the Senate grudgingly agreed today to a House proposal that conditioned continued funds for the agencies through Nov 30 upon continuation of a strict curb on the use of Medicaid funds to DRY for abortions.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Finally, the Only True Explanation for Everything
description: The Quiet Folk are a gentle and peace able tribe if left undisturbed. Because they have lived for so many thousands of years in the depths of the earth, they know the hiding places of all ores and precious stones, and are extremely wealthy. Any human foolish enough to attempt to cheat them of their gold will only succeed in angering them. upon hearing the sounds of church bells, drums or farm machinery, and become violent if the Church is even mentioned.

title: Grumman's Earnings Decline 5% In First Drop for a Quarter in 77

The Bethpage, L.I., company said the figures reflected the impact of fewer scheduled deliveries of Navy aircraft.

title: Notes on People
description: Mississippi's two United States Senators, James O. Eastland and John C. Stennis, will have served together in Congress for 30 years and a day as of tomorrow. They will thus have served longer than any pair of senators from one state in history, eclipsing the old longevity record of Senators John D. McClellan and J. W. Fulbright of Arkansas. The two Mississippi Senators were honored yesterday on the floor when the majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, read a letter from President Carter wishing them many more years of dedicated service to their state, their country and the United States Senate. Mr. Byrd congratulated his colleagues on reaching this memorable point in their outstanding careers.

title: Cannon Fodder in the Stands
description: The Army football team scored 48 points last Saturday, and each touchdown was saluted by the roar of a cannon in the end zone in Michie Stadium. This is standard operating procedure at West Point involving little or no risk, for if the personnel at the Military Academy can't handle firearms competently, this country will be in trouble when those little green men from Mars move in. It is something else entirely when untrained undergraduates at the University of Arizona or Missouri play with artilleryas Rob Hart can testify and Randy Crustals can't. One year and three cranial operations after an overloaded cannon blew a hole in his head at of the ArizonaWyoming game, Rob Hart of Bedford, N.Y., is making a recovery. Six weeks ago another overloaded field piece exploded at the University of Missouri at Rolla. Randal L Ctustals, 21, was killed and six other students were injured.

The quake was centered 100 miles southeast of Adak in the Aleutian chain.

title: 'Heroes,' Excruciatingly Obvious Film
description: "Heroes," co-starring Henry (The Fonz) Winkler and Sally (The Flying Nun) Field, brings to the motion-picture theater all of the magic of commercial television except canned laughter. Well, no truly rotten movie is perfect."Heroes" is about Jack Dunne (Mr. Winkler), a demented Vietnam veteran of repulsive winsomeness, a fellow who attempts to demonstrate the proposition that certified nuts have an exclusive franchise on truth and beauty. When we first meet Jack, skylarking around Times Square, he tries to interrupt a recruiting officer who's about to sign up six enlistees. However, Jack simply winds up back at the veterans' hospital, where he's been an off-and-on patient for five years."Heroes" is the story of Jack's flight from the hospital and his cross-country bus trip toward California, where he plans to start a worm farm. Jack is meant to be a lovable eccentric or, as one of the other characters says of him, a person who's "got rainbow, honey." It's the latter quality that apparently appeals to Carol (Miss Field), another lovable eccentric, a young woman who is taking a bus trip to Kansas City, Mo., so she can have time "to think." Instead, she falls in love with Jack."Heroes," which was written by James Carabatsos and directed by Jeremy Paul Kagan, who directed Mr. Winkler in the television film "Katherine," is something more than just a bad film. It's a frighteningly bad film because it could well be the definitive theatrical motion picture of the future.Like the medium that spawned the talents who made it, "Heroes" deals in concepts made so simple that their meanings would be obvious to the dimmest minds. Gestures and emotions are fore-shortened, truncated. Watching Mr. Winkler and Miss Fields "act" is suddenly to understand what television may eventually do to movies. Actors in television series and often in television movies simply don't have time to develop or discover characters. They must be entirely visible from the first minute they're on.One result is the sort of performance that Mr. Winkler gives in this film. It's one that seems to be aggressively cute not because he's appealing, but because the will to please is so naked and the mannerisms are so unconnected to life. Television is creating a school of acting made up entirely of signals that evoke emotions less often than they label them.I can imagine some not-too-distant time when we'll all sit around our home screens watchingand becoming emotionally involved withcomedies and dramas that show not people, but transistorized robots of the sort the Disney people have developed. They'd simplify casting, eliminate the union problem and would offer numerous merchandising possibilities.Merchandising is something else that "Heroes" deals in. By blaming Jack Dunne's emotional problems on his traumatic Vietnam experience, the movie somehow denies the true horrors of that war while purveying bitterness for easy, supposedly painless entertainment.Harrison Ford, who may be one of the most-seen movie actors of the day because of his role in "Star Wars," is effective in a supporting role too small to make the picture worth seeing."Heroes," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance suggested", contains some mildly vulgar language, but is otherwise almost prudish enough to be shown on television on Saturday morning.

The audience greeted him with cheers when he came on, and listened reverentlySir Georg's New York audiences go to his concerts as if in churchto his performances of Michael Tippett's Symphony No. 4 and the Bruckner Seventh.

title: WILLIAM KURELEK
description: TORONTO. Nov. 4 (AP)William Kurelek, an artist who depicted prairies and other Canadian scenes, died yesterday. He was 50 years old. His death was attributed to cancer. Queen Elizabeth II of Britain and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City own some of his paintings. He leaves a wife and four children.

title: READER'S DIGEST PAYS 1.5 MILLION TO WOMEN
description: In one of the biggest settlements of a sex discrimination lawsuit, The Reader's Digest agreed yesterday to pay more than $1.5 million to 2,600 women currently and formerly employed by the magazine.

title: LEGAL EXPERTS SPLIT ON EQUAL RIGHTS PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Two constitutional scholars disagreed sharply today over the procedure that Congress would have to use in extending the period in which states can ratify the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: Brooklyn Couple Invent Automatic Dog Washer
description: A Brooklyn couple has invented an automatic dog washer. Clem and Antoinette Blafford were granted Patent 4,056,078 this week. The design provides two enclosures separated by a gate. In the first enclosure, the dog can stand under sprays discharging soapy and clean water. Its head is outside, so it gets nothing in its eyes, nose or mouth. When the dog goes into the second enclosure, a blower automatically sends a stream of heated air all around the animal.

title: The Endowment of Livingston Biddle

Arts and Humanities. Mr. Riddle is nut without credentials fur the job; he helped to write the legislation creating the Endowment in 1965, served for a time as deputy chairman under Roger Stevens and later did Congressional liaison for Nancy Hanks, who headed the Endowment for eight fruitful years. The nomination is also a tribute to the influence of Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the subcommittee that employs Mr. Biddle and monitors the work and budget of the Endowment.

title: 'First Love,' Film of the 70's, Misogynistic on Ugly Affair
description: "I think it's loathsome that we sleep together. I feel like a you-khow-what," says a character named Caroline to her college sweetheart, Elgin, in "Sentimental Education," the 1950's short story by Harold Brodkey on which "First Love" is very loosely based. The film, written by Jane Stanton Hitchcock and directed by Joan Darling, is a 70's update with a vengeance.We seem hardly to have met the two young lovers when Elgin begins asking Caroline about her orgasms, and Caroline chides him, not at all pleasantly, about those postcoital moments when "you're no good to me anymore." If "First Love" is to be believedand there's no good reason why it should bethen these days romance is a much uglier and hard-boiled business than it ever used to be.The title promises warmth and a tentative, trembling sense of discovery, but this simply isn't that kind of movie. Elgin (William Katt) a handsome and reserved college student who is looking for the real thing, becomes smitten with Caroline (Susan Dey), a fellow student who appears to have been through the real thing more times than she can count. Caroline is involved with an older, married man when Elgin falls for her, and this apparently has something to do with Caroline's father, who committed suicide in her dollhouse (it was a roomy dollhouse) when she was small. This, and a would-be contemporary air of sexual overkill, is perhaps supposed to explain why Caroline is a heartless and abrasive tease who resorts to wisecracks at even the most intimate moments. It doesn't.Miss Darling (who directed the first episodes of "Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman"), by not bothering to cast much light on Caroline's nasty nature, shows herself to be as peculiarly misogynistic as such other women directors as Elaine May (in "The Heartbreak Kid") and Lina Wertmuller (especially in "Swept Away"). The two main female characters in "First Love" are Caroline and the predatory, rather pathetic Shalley (Beverly D'Angelo), and they both pounce avariciously upon Mr. Katt, who seems passive and rather saintly under pressure. ("You can't handle a real womanyou want us all to be shy violets" shrieks Shelley, after Elgin rejects her grabby advances.) Both Miss Hitchcock's script and Miss Darling's directing suggest that he is far too good for either lover.Though Miss Darling brings not the slightest whit of tenderness or understanding to the love scenes, the movie is not without its gentle touches. It opens with slow-motion, idyllic-looking footage of Mr. Katt playing soccer alone, and it includes a lush, very prominent score. In fact, when Mr. Katt and Miss Dey have their first sexual encounter, they are accompanied by a Paul Williams ballad.However, the music is so over-bearing that it says nothing about intimacy, but a lot about Miss Darling's fear of being alone with her characters, or of leaving anything at all to the audience's imagination. As a director, she seems comfortable only with smart remarks or with scenes that hammer home every last nuance. "When you know this room, you'll know me," says Miss Dey, leading Mr. Katt through her childhood bedroom. The pictures on the wall might as well have dialogue balloons.Miss Dey's Caroline is flippant and unconvincing. But the good news is that Mr. Katt's perforance far transcends the chilliness of its surroundings. His Elgin is bursting with hope and urgency even when Miss Dey does nothing to warrant his enthusiasm, and in his rosy optimism there are hints of what might, in more sympathetic hands have been. Even so, Mr. Katt's work is passionate and resourceful, and it deserves to be seen.

title: SHORTAGE OF JUDGES CRITICIZED IN REPORT
description: TRENTON,Nov. 4A shortage of judges and a backlog of 167,000 cases have bogged down the New Jersey judicial system, its administrator, Judge Arthur J. Simpson, said in an annual report today. He said there were 32 vacancies among 306 authorized judgeships.

title: THIS IS THE END OF THE GAME;
description: For some time, conservationists have warned that wildlife is disappearing from the green hills and valleys of Africa. Despite a recent ban on sports hunting in Kenya, the great herds of elephant, zebra, wildebeest, giraffe, gazelle, lion and cheetah continue to decline, and many people believe that we have, finally, reached the end of the game  the carefree romp in the wildlife paradise by white settlers, biggame hunters and profiteering Africans. The end of that game poses an urgent question: can the animals that remain coexist with Africa's expanding human population? On this and the following pages, photographer Peter Beard chronicles the tragic disappearance of the glory that was once Africa. Beard's pictures, from his forthcoming Doubleday Dolphin book. The End of the Game, will be exhibited at the International Center of Photography, starting next Sunday. On page 43, New York Times science writer Boyce Rensberger reports on the vanishing herds.

She succeeds Mary Brooks. Mrs. Hackel, from Rutland, was the Democrats unsuccessful canklidate for governor in Vermont last year.

title: Election Day and the Right Decision
description: IT'S THAT time of year again and, frankly, I'm scared. It isn't the lengthening night that frightens me or the death of summer. It's Election Day.

title: Susan T. Denenholz Engaged to Bruce Rivkin
description: Mrs. Victor Denenholz of Manhasset, L. T., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Joyce Denenholz, to Bruce Charles Rivkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Rivkin of Cliffside Park, N. J. A wedding in the spring is planned.

title: Avocational Ensemble Excells
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. HAVING enjoyed the opening program by the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester (about which I wrote in last week's column), I was especially eager to hear the county's other major avocational ensemble, the Westchester Symphony Orchestra. This mission was most agreeably accomplished on Oct. 29, when the W.S.O. opened its 53d season at the White Plains High School.

title: Are the Indicators All That Useless?
description: It was the kind of event that gives statistics a bad name.

title: Births
description: Bergin

title: GRETA KELLER DIES; SINGER AND ACTRESS
description: Greta Keller, the cabaret singer and actress, died of cancer on Friday at her home in Vienna. Miss Keller, whose career spanned more than half a century, was in her mid70's.

title: Charles Dorrance, 94, Head Of West Virginia Coal & Coke
description: Charles Dorrance, president of the West Virginia Coal and Coke Corporation from 1937 until his retirement in 1951, died Friday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 94 years old.

title: Bean Soup
description: Here is the recipe for the famous Senate Restaurant Bean Soup: Take two pounds of small Michigan Navy beans, wash and run through hot water until beans are white again. Put on the fire with four quarts of hot water. Then take one and onehalf pounds of smoked ham hocks, boil slowly (approximately three hours) in covered pot. Braise one chopped onion in a little butter and, when light brown, put into bean soup. Season with salt and pepper, then serve. (Do not add salt until ready to serve). Eight portions.

title: He Plans a Grand Political Alliance of FrenchSpeaking Countries
description: OTTAWAFor two centuries FrenchCanadians largely existed in a circumscribed and introspective world, culturally and politically isolated from the other peoples who shared their language. The 1967 visit of President Charles de Gaulle to Montreal and his electrifying endorsement of a free Quebec changed that. Now those Quebeckers who want to separate their predominantly Frenchspeaking province from the rest of Canada look frequently to aid and comfort from the mother country. But to offset that, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, himself a FrenchCanadian but one who wants to preserve the Canadian federation, has a Francophone scheme of his own, even grander than the de Gaulle vision.

title: A Blessing for New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN GOOD Chinese restaurants are hard to come by in Connecticut, but New Haven is blessed with Blessings, a 20yearold establishment that has become an in place, attracting Chinese food buffs from all over the state. We've been there twice in recent weeks and look forward to returning.

title: ROUTINE PROMOTIONS FOR PUPILS ON WANE
description: CHICAGOIt is 10:30 at the Walter L. Newberry School, a twostory redbrick building near the Old Town section, and the 9 to 11yearolds in Jean Schmidt's class are working on a series of 72 reading objectives.

title: More Women Sought for Military
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)If the Pentagon has its way, women will constitute onetenth of the armed services enlisted personnel by 1983

title: Underwater Safari in Florida In Pursuit of the Spiny Lobster
description: Theres really nothing to snorkeling. You just lie flat on your face, float and breathe through your mouth. That is, until a wave or passing swimmer splashes water into your snorkel, at which point, you strangleunless you learn to blow the water back out. This, especially in salt water, is much to be preferred to swallowing the stuff.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WESTWOOD

title: Corrections
description: It was incorrectly reported in last week's edition of the Long Island Weekly that Greta Walker's husband divorced her and left her with a son to support. She initiated the divorce proceedings against her husband, who is paying alimony and child support.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Ask any bowling instructor what bothers novice bowlers the most and he probably will point to hand position.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Art and the Guggenheim Foundation for fostering great photography, but thank Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, too.

title: Byrne and Bateman Campaign Hard In Race for Jersey's Governorship;
description: TRENTON, Nov. 5As the campaign for Governor of New Jersey drew to a close on a dismal weekend, both candidates followed hectic schedules today that included Governor Byrne addressing rallies in Paramus and North Bergen and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman on a walking tour of Union.

title: ExC.I.A. Employees Pay Fine for Helms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence who was fined $2,000 yesterday for failure to testify fully and accurately to a Senate committee, will he able to pay the debt with money collected at a meeting of retired employees of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayNational, Madison Square Garden, international and open jumpers, fine harness horses, threegaited, fivegaited equitation, 6 A.M. 2 P.M., 7:30 P.M.

title: The Classic Conflict
description: If I were to contest these charges, I believe that grave and perhaps irreparable damage to the United States would result. So Richard Helms said in explaining his ???????? last week to plead nocontest to a misdemeanor. The plea bargain avoidd a charge that Mr. Helms had committed perjury, a felony, when he swore to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the C.I.A. under his directorship had not aided the opponents of Chile's Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens. The Justice Department, too in explaining its reasons for making the bargain, emphasized the possible risk to national security.

title: ,Siege Ends, 4 Children Safe
description: ST JOHNSBURY, Vt., Nov. 5 (UPI)Steven Bowen, 33 years old, was arrested early today after a siege in which he is charged with holding four children as hostages all night. The children were found unharmed and Mr. Bowen was taken to the St. Johnsbury Regional Correctional Center and was held in $25,000 bail.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: JERZY KOSINSKI calls George Levanter, the hero of his novel Blind Date, a small investor. But to me he is more like a claims adjuster in the ainbiguous morality of the modern world. Among other things, Levanter is a skier and, as the West declines, he finds sport on its slope. When, on page nine, we learn that the teenaged Levanter slept with his beautiful mother, we are being put on notice that he is no ordinary man.

title: Oklahoma Routs Oklahoma State, 6128
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 5 (AP)Oklahoma's quarterback, Thomas Lott, engineered a 6128 rout of Oklahoma State today that kept the Sooners in the Big Eight Conference lead. ine sooners now nave a ou comer ence wonlost record, leading Nebraska (41), which defeated Missouri today. Iowa State (32) lost to Colorado, 127, and dropped out of a tie for second place. Oklahoma State is 23.

title: LOCKHEED WILL REENTER MACHINISTS STRIKE TALKS
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (AP)Under prodding from a Federal mediator, the Lockheed Company has agreed to resume negotiations next Thursday on key issues in a 4 week strike that has slowed production of the giant aerospace concern in five states.

title: Dormant West Eighties Touched by Wave of Chic
description: For more than a year, Shirley Copperman, her brother Ira and her friend Steen Sigmund had been trying to open restaurant on Columbus Avenue in the seventies. Each time they thought they had a spot, it seemed another restaurant would pull in ahead.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: THIS election year has been a good one for New Jersey cities. In addition to doing some special favors for Jersey City, where the local administration made clear what it was demanding in return for political support, the State Legislature agreed, for the first time, to make in lieu payments to cities.

title: I Wish I Had More Eyes
description: WHO in the art world has not seen them at some time or other, those three uncannily alike, small figures of the Soyer brothers, gravely browsing together among pictures on exhibit, so absorbed in their looking that each might well have voiced Raphael's plaint in this book: I wished I had more eyes, in the back and in the sides of my head? This gentle, ruminative book, then, like any good Russian tale, tells the story of an obsession. The obsession, however, is not quite the simple one we might expect of a purportedly straightforward realist painter. And in fact, the writing Soyer, who makes a number of rueful asides about his alienation from the weird ephemeral art movements of the mainstream of his time, turns out to be not so outside the Zeitgeist as he thinks.

title: Talking and Testing
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have been talking for 20 years about a ban on nuclear testingand testing as they talked. Last week, the Soviet Union took the talk significantly further. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said Moscow would be willing to suspend nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes as well as undereround weapons tests. All other atomic testingon the grouna, above the ground and under wateris prohibited by a 1963 treaty.

title: Music and Mobiles When Calder and Satie Joined Forces
description: Two famously unconventional artists from two rarely connected arts will be celebrated this week in a restaging of a symphonic drama in which the actors on stage are three massive mobiles. The occasion will be two performances, Thursday and Friday, at the Beacon Theater, of Erik Satie's Socrate. The Gertrude SteinVirgil Thomson opera, Four Saints in Three Acts, will be on the same program and may get more attention, but Socrate is certainly the more curious part of the program. For is not only a musical event but sculptural one; occupying the stage will be reconstructed sets, not seen since 1936, that were designed for Socrate by Alexander Calder. How do the eccentric musician and the pioneering sculptor happen to be found together? On this uncommon confluence of talents hangs a tale that should not go untold.

title: Crimson Air Game Routs Penn, 3415
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5Unpredictable Harvard, which had lost three games in Harvard Stadium this season and six over the last two years, scored four touchdowns in the second period and went on to defeat Pennsylvani?? 3415, this gray afternoon.

title: Hotline Help for Battered Women
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: School Strike Vote Frustrating to Many In Lakeland Dispute
description: MOHEGAN LAKE, N. Y., Nov, 5Parents, school board members, teachers and mediators in northern Westchester County's Lakeland School District expressed frustration and even desperation today as they sought a way to settle a 39day teachers strike in the district.

title: Vendors in India Say Pushcarts Provide Freedom if Not Riches
description: UDAIPUR, IndiaThe life of Panna Lal Gupta, a 58yearold vendor in this princely city of Rajasthan, revolves around a pushcart. From 9 in the morning until after midnight he pushes his fourwheeled cart, selling an assortment of edibles.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON

title: Transit Agency Aide Plunges to His Death
description: Jacques Nevard, the chief spokesman and director of public affairs for New York City's Transit Authority, leaped to his death yesterday, leaving a note that said he could not bear having his career tarnished by the current furor over transit officials expense accounts.

title: SPIRITISM IN HARLEM: ADJUNCT TO RELIGION
description: There are herbs for aches and pains, oils and incense for perfuming the air and candles, crucifixes and religious statuary for the home. But Otto Chicas,'s large botanica in Spanish Harlem also sells statues of African gods, Buddhas and cigarstore Indians.

title: Amy Gold Betrothed To Warren S. Elkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Gold of Kings Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynn Gold, to Warren S. Elkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Elkin of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Monument to a Dead Self
description: ANNE SEXTON was one of the most important American poets of her generation. She was both praised and condemned by critics for the intense confessional quality of her poetry. At first, it would have been easy to dismiss heras the 1950's often dismissed budding young female writersas just another stircrazy neurotic housewife who wanted to write. But it was not easy to do so for long. She was a housewife and she was also neuroticshe is emphatic, in her letters, about bothbut she had energy, talent and ambition. Although she did not start to write seriously until she was 29, by the end of her 18year poetic career she had published nine books and had whatever wordly success poetry can bestow. She had won a Pulitzer Prize, had appeared at international poetry festivals, had held down a university teaching position although she had never gone to a university, and had attracted a wide readership. In 1974, for no immediate reason, she killed herself at her home in Weston, Mass.

title: The World's Cleanest Pigpen
Article 1  No Title
Arkansas High Court Gets Black
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 5 (AP) George Howard Jr. will be appointed to the Arkansas Supreme Court, apparently the first black ever on the state's highest tribunal, Gov. David Pryor said yesterday.

title: The Bill Collector Rang Twice
description: Twelve Midwest trucking companies were charged last week with illegally keeping $2.3 million instead of refunding it to shippers that had accidentally paid their transportation bills twice.

title: A WellDone Whodunit
description: STAMFORD

title: Events Today
description: Police Show Crime Exposition: crime prevention displays and demonstrations; noon to 4 P.M.; Wasner College, Grymes Hill,S.I

title: Article 6  No Title
FourAlarm Fire Causes Damage To Several Wall Street Buildings
description: Firemen battled a stubborn, fouralarm fire for more than four hours last night that caused heavy damage to several fivestory commercial buildings in the Wall Street area.

title: Beauty
description: Horror stories about the way women are treated in beauty salons are rife. And, it seems, getting rifer. Tales of an hour's wait for a $40 haircut are commonplace. And once a woman is finally ensconced in the chair she may find her hair being yanked, pulled, prodded and heatironed while the rest of her is subjected to loud music and kinky photographs on the walls. Invariably, she has the feeling of being excluded from a salon in group made up of the hairdressers and chic, beautiful clients. Some hairdressers won't even do what the client asks for: If she wants her hair rollerset, or even blowndry, it's possible she may be referred to a salon down the street.

title: Realty News
description: Whitney Communications Inc., which publishes such magazines as Interior Design, Art in America and Oil Daily and which has an interest in the International Herald Tribune, is consolidating and expanding its offices in midtown.

title: When Rights and Law Conflict
description: THE RELEASE and publication of a Connecticut State Police report that concluded that Peter A. Reilly had murdered his mother raises a disturbing conflict between the Freedom of Information laws and the rights of the individual.

title: Inner Circle Of Infighters Around Carey
description: When you walk on that second floor, you expect Lucretia Borgia to pop out from behind a pillar. That was one Democrat's colorful description of the figurative elbowing, bodychecking and hairpulling within Governor Carey's inner circle New York that operates out of the second floor of the State Political Capitol.

title: Stein Questions Wagner's Links and He Is Rebutted
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr., his opponent in the race for Manhattan Borough President, had received support from immoral and unconscionable adulthome operators.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: OVER the years, during rambles about the Island, I have never failed to be startled by encounters with apparitions stepping out of bushes, trudging through the sands, peering down from heights. At first glance, they appear to be mounds of cameras, tripods and innumerable leather cases. At second glance. a person, usually a man of any age, is discernible beneath the panoply of equipment. This is your photographer, one of the Island's most sturdy breed of hobbyists.

title: $100 Billion in Leases
description: In 1963 Pan American World Airways, like much of the smart money, began playing the newest game in high finance. Rather than buying three 707's, at $6.64 million per plane, the airline signed a 13year lease with the embryonic Sally Leasing Company of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Bildungsroman Irishstyle
description: ALMOST 20 years ago, before Ken Kesey's McMurphy, before Joseph Heller's Yossarian, Dangerfield Lives was on blackboards and toilet walls. Sebastian Dangerfield had scurried out of The Ginger Man, J. P. Donleavy's first novel, into existence as the patron cad of the collegiate underground. His latest hero, Reginald Darcy Thormond Dancer Kildare, will never make the graffiti. The Donleavy hero hasn't grown up, just become more respectable, the gentleman Dangerfield pretended to be in his homemade Trinity Collge rowing blues. Darcy Dancer lives, all right, but he is contained in this novel, where he won't be inspiring belief and attracting followers.

title: Nassau Puts a Tax On Tilts and Replays
description: YOU can drop a coin into an electronic amusement device in the Family Fun Center in the North Shore community of Bayville and wrestle with a mechanical arm. Win or lose, it costs you 25 cents.

title: FILM VIEW
description: VINCENT CANBY

title: If Only East Could Go West When It's Fall
description: IT'S autumn again, I think. I live in California and it's hard to tell. I'm from New York and I'm homesick. I feel a little awkward being homesick, because I've been a native Californian for almost three years.

title: Woman's Place: Home to an Idea
description: DARIEN I WAS convinced that this was a particularly exciting time in history to be a woman, but until I talked seriously to Ida, I wasn't sure what to do about it, said Ruth Lyon, a former actress and mother of five who went back to college six years ago at the suggestion of her husband. She attended Sarah Lawrence's Center for Continuing Education and received an M.A. in women's studies last June.

title: The Faces Are Familiar in Minneapolis Mayoral Race
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5Mayor Charles Stenvig and former Mayor Albert Hofstede are running against each other for the third time, each having won once, and Minneapolis voters are less than excited about the contest.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: High tea. If you're an American in London and Barbara Cartland invites you to tea, you're due for a very royal, very English reception. The Great Lady of Romantic Fiction will send her white RollsRoyce around to your Mayfair hotel to drive you the 20 miles out to Hertsfordshire, where she'll be waiting to welcome you to Camfield Place, the stately country mansion where she's been livingand workingfor the past 25 years.

title: Donna H. Kantor Is Fiancee Of Stephen Edward Krasner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kantor of Teaneck, N. J., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Helaine Kantor, to Stephen Edward Krasner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Krasner of Cliffside Park, N. J.

title: King Scores 36 but Nets Lose to Cavaliers, 10593
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 5 (AP)Bingo Smith poured in 30 points to offset a 36point effort by Bernard King tonight and help the Cavaliers to a 10593 National Basketball Association victory over the New Jersey Nets, Cleveland's fifth straight triumph.

title: INTERVIEW
description: CHAPPAQUA

title: Miss Nagelsen Upse?
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 (UPI)Sixteenyearold Ivana Madruga, Argentina's newest prospect, upset Betsy Nagelsen of the United States, 63, 63, today in the semifinals of the River Plate women's tennis tournament. Miss Madruga, who had to qualify to get into the tournament, showed poise and an assortment of shots.

title: No Title  Article
description: Letters should be addressed to: Editor, Westchester Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. The writer's address and telephone number should be included for verification. The Times reserves the right to condense and edit letters.

title: Adventure Stories
description: The construction of a straightforward adventure story would seem to be the easiest possible task to set before a novelist. Great powers of observation or analysis are rarely required. Come up with a strong narrative idea and a few interesting characters situated in an exotic locale, let the reader get a sense of danger, lace the whole thing with a goodly doliop of sex and you have the makings of a popular success.

title: STAMPS
description: For its final issue of the year, the United Nations is again devoting philatelic emphasis to atomic energy. The subject has become a matter of increasing controversy in a world that is not sure how safe atomic energy is in its peaceful uses and how unthinkable in time of war.

title: CAMERA
description: Antique cameras have a fascination that goes beyond the boundary of age alone. They possess a high level of craftsmanship, beautifully fashioned fine wood, (mahogany, cherry, walnut, oak) and are painstakingly put together. The fittings are highly polished brass, with beautifully mounted lenses. Later models were fitted with magnificent leather bellows in gleaming black or flaming red colors.

title: Stakhanov, a Soviet Miner, Is Dead; Name Was Byword for Hard Work
description: Aleksei G. Stakhanov, the Soviet coal miner of the 1930's whose name became a byword for speedup work both in the Soviet Union and abroad, died yesterday lin Moscow. He was 71 years old.

title: Cornell Defeats Columbia In Ivy Cellar Battle, 207
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 5  While scramble for a piece of the. Ivy League football title was taking place elsewhere, Cornell and Columbia fought to escape the league cellar today. The Big Red managed to pull the Lions down to their level by scoring a 207 victory.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: When Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall, was campaigning against an unknown insurgent Democratic candidate for the Greenwich Village district leadership, he charged that his opponent had neither the experience nor the ability to get things done for his constituents.

title: Test of CB Users Aid to Police a Success
description: ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP)A 12week test of cooperation between citizens band radio users and state troopers produced positive results and just began to tap the vast communications potential of CB's, the Superintendent of the State Police, William Connelie, reports.

title: Rail Commuters Demand FirstAid Plan
description: WHEN the 5:39 P.M. train of the Long Island Rail Road pulled out of Pennsylvania Station for Merrick, Bellmore and Wantagh a few weeks ago, it appeared headed on a routine trip, with the evening card games continuing from where they had left off in the morning and other passengers reading their newspapers.

title: Charles Barquist to Wed Janis Levart Next April
description: Janis Levart, who expects to graduate in June from the Northeastern University Law School, plans to be married in April to Charles Barquist, who is in his final year at the Harvard Law School.

title: The Copper Industry in the Doldrums
description: The nation's second largest copper producer, the Phelps Dodge Corporation, last week reported a loss of $21.9 million for the third quarter, and slashed the dividend from 55 cents a share to 15 cents.

title: DELAY IN CARTER TRIP GETS VARIED REGRETS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5Postponement of President Carter's 25,000mile trip to four continents provoked disappointment, resentment, understanding or official indifference in the countries he had intended to visit.

title: Baseball's Big Spenders Vs. the Great Pretenders
description: Elliott Maddox, a former Yankee who was banished to Baltimore, was speculating after Friday's freeagent draft and the prospect of the Mets signing and reuniting him and Ron Blomberg.

title: The Newest Advances in Sound Systems
description: Innovation has been the propellant of the audio movement since its beginnings. In fact, the audio industry might be described partly as a business producing consumer goods, partly as the ongoing pursuit of an esthetic ideal. The long way from Edison's tin horn to the touted virtues of modern stereo has been traveled, for the most part, in small steps. There were, of course, those rare imaginative leaps to carry the technology forward; but mainly it was the cumulative effect of gradual improvement that, over the years, led the electronic conveyances of music to their present levels of performance.

title: ACQUAINTANCES TELL OF MEDICSALESMAN
description: Business acquaintances of the medicalsupplies salesman who reportedly took part in an operation at a Long Island hospital in an incident that led to indictments last Wednesday have described the salesman as a con man, liar and braggart.

title: Alabama Wins, Clinches S.E.C. Title, Bowl Berth
description: BATON ROUGE, Nov. 5 (AP)Tony Nathan scored two touchdowns on 1yard plunges and threw a 20yard touchdown pass as secondranked Alabama overcame a rash of fumbles to down Louisiana State, 243, today and capture its sixth Southeastern Conference championship in seven years.AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 5 (AP)Bruce Threadgill threw two touchdown passes and a defensive back, Kenny Johnson, set up two more scores with pass inter

title: Article 18  No Title
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS

title: Turmoil in the Currency Markets
description: LONDONThe Bank of England will bring out a new onepound note next year. It will be considerably smaller than the current versionreflecting, some suggest, Britain's shrunken place in world financeand it carries a picture of Isaac Newton, father of things that fall. The pound isn't always falling, of course, nor are British workers always on strike or in the midst of a slowdown. It just seems that way.

title: Late Brown Kick Tops Green,1310
description: HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 5Make no mistake, in the battle between two of the Ivy League's powers today, Brown appeared to be a better football team than Dartmouth. But make no mistake was what Brown couldn't do, and it took the Bruins until the final six seconds to prove they were the better team.

title: Potato Crop on L.I. Is Down 16%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Taking the Penn for a Ride
description: THE developments of recent years may make it hard to believe, but in fact railroading was our number one industry not so long ago and the Pennsylvania Railroad was the bestmanaged major enterprise in the land. It was put together by Philadelphia aristocrats who believed in hiring the best railroad executives to be found and turning them loose with only these instructions: give top service and never, never do anything to besmirch the reputation of the Main Line gentry who clip the coupons. For most of its life, the Pennsylvania tried to operate by that code.

title: A LETTER TO BREZHNEV
description: Dear Leonid Ilyich:

title: HOWARD SKOGLUND
description: SUN CITY, Ariz., Nov. 5 (AP)Howard Skoglund, a partowner of the Minnesota Vikings football team, died at his home here today. He was 74 years old.

title: Barbara A. Sheehan And Julian Simmons To Marry March 18
description: Barbara Ann Sheehan, a financial consultant with Marsh & McLennan,a New York insurance company, plans to be married March 18 in Boston to Julian Thayer Simmons, who is in his second year at the University of Cincinnati Medical School.

title: Potato Farmers Keep Eye on Price
description: ALBANY

title: BONN REPORTED WEIGHING TANK DEAL WITH SAUDIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 5West Germany is reported in the process of entering the Middle East armaments market in a tank deal with Saudi Arabia.

title: There's Nothing I Like About It But It May Be a Classic
description: It seems fitting that Leonard Cohen, who has written so eloquently and so often about the imprisoning powers of love, should live on a tiny street bounded by larger boulevards named Rachel and Marianne In a plain, peaceful,workingclass neighborhood in the heart of the city, the songwriter and author keeps a smallish flat, furnished minimally and very clean, with floors that don't lie quite straight and long lace curtains that blow in the breeze.

title: TV VIEW
description: The clever diversionary skills that the commercial networks employ to promote their own protectionist ends can once again be fully appreciated in a recent Congressional Report called Violence on Television. The study was inspired by the fact that a portrayal of violence on television and its possible effects on society have been of increasing concern to the Congress and to the American people. Four days of hearings were heldthree in the summer of 1976 and the final one last March at which testamony was heard in Denver, Los Angeles and Washington from a total of 81 persons. The public forum was arranged by the House Subcommittee on Communications, which is chaired by Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, a California Democrat whose supposedly tough posture on the broadcasting industry was signaled last year with a declared plan to rewrite the Communications Act of 1934. In a matter of months, however, that project was scaled down to a review of the act. With this new violence report, Mr. Van Deerlin's toughness is beginning to assume the consistency of a runny custard pie.

title: Cities Needs May Torpedo Carter's Budget Plans
description: DETROITOf this city's 5,700 police officers. 1,120 are being paid with Federal money intended to stimulate the econo my. So are 350 of Detroit's 8OO garbage collectors and 160 of 1,470 firefighters.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF;
description: Jerome Klinkowitz is America's critical apostle of what he calls a new literature. A John the Baptist crying in the postmodern wilderness, he hails writers beyond Pynchon, Barth and Hawkes, writers whom he sees as peculiarly American, who inventively confront the outside world and invite the reader to participate imaginatively in the action of their novels. To his new collective of writers he assigns the name Superfictionists. The group includes Ronald Sukenick, Gilbert Sorrentino, Clarence Major, Steve Katz, Walter Abish, Russell Banks, Michael Stephens, Donald Barthelme, Jonathan Baumbach, Hunter S. Thompson, Ishmael Reed and Kurt Vonnegut Jr.

title: Chaminade Wins Title Behind Rogan, 180
description: HICKSVILLE, Li., Nov. 5Jim Rogan, a 6foot2inch senior quarterback, judiciously mixed his running and passing game today and directed Chaminade to an 18.0 victory over Holy Trinity, for the Nassau Catholic High School Football League title.

title: SADAT TIES PRESTIGE TO A GENEVA PARLEY
description: CAIRO, Nov. 5Some signs of emerging caution in Egypt's role as the prime Arab mover toward a new Middle East peace conference suggest that Cairo is considering more than its selfimage as a political and cultural leader in the region. More subtle domestic considerations also seem to be involved, including President Anwar elSadat's very political survival.

title: Purdue 22, Wisconsin 0
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 5 (UPI)Mark Herrmann, Purdue's freshman quarterback, completed 11of20 passes for 174 yards today to become the Big Ten's second alltime singleseason passer in guiding the Boilermakers to 22.0 victory over Wisconsin.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: O TIS G. PIKE, who calls himself a moderate Democrat and who has a way of knocking off Republican opponents for the seat he has held in the House of Representatives since 1961, has a prediction for the next Congressional elections:

title: Preservationists Win Delay in Strip Mining
description: LOUISA, Va., Nov. 5Preservationists struggling to bar the strip mining of the mineral vermiculite in the historic Green Springs area of centuriesold farms and country houses near here have won a delay of a year or more in proposals to excavate hundreds of acres of rolling pasture land. The delay could lead to a prohibition of the mining.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks have home games at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday against the San Antonio Spurs and 8 P.M. Saturday against the Nets, both Madison Square Garden. The Nets only home game at the Rutgers gymnasium in Piscataway, N.J., is at 8:05 P.M. Friday against the Chicago Bulls.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE saga of the Sullivan, Jack and Lenny, is well known to anyone who wasted any of his or her formative years along New Jersey's Irish Gold Coast (from Avon to Sea Girt). Jersey City boys, the Sullivans went to the shore and made their fortunes in the restaurant business at a variety of spots, Jack at a place in Spring Lake that bore his name for many years.

description: CCONCEPCION, Chile, Nov. 5 (AP) Growing numbers of businesses in the forested areas of southern Chile have abandoned oil and are using sawdust to heat their buildings.

title: The Region
description: New Jersey's Governor Brendan Byrne, far behind his Republican challenger, State Senator Raymond H. Batmen, when he started his race, is finishing it in much better shape. The latest polls, in fact, show he is now ahead. Mr. Byrne apparently managed this comeback by convincing people that the dreaded state income tax he championed is not so bad after all.

title: ART VIEW
description: The new Larry Rivers exhibition at the Robert Miller Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street (through Nov. 12), is in many respects a characteristic survey of both the problems and the pleasures this artist customarily offers us. The problems are mostly in the realm of tastea perennial issue in Mr. Rivers's art that shows no sign of abatement in the new workand the pleasures are mostly in the drawing. Fortunately, there is enough of the latter in his new exhibition to sustain us through the trials of the formerthat mixture of earnestness, ambition, parody and outright vulgarity on which so much of his art has foundered in the past.

title: Springfield: The Talk Is All of Revitalization

But along Main Street downtown, most of the other buildings are vacant above the first floor. In one block, three of 13 storefronts are empty. And like many other buildings here, the one that used to house the city's second largest department store wears a For Sale sign.
