title: Never in The Running
description: THERE was a time, almost inexplicable now but lasting nearly a generation, when Leon Trotsky was a cult figure among American Jewish intellectuals, and taken with earnestness by a broader group of nonJewish literary modernists seeking identification with the puzzling forces of the age. The harshness of the Great Depression and World War I, the Promethean circumstances of Trotsky's exile and murder, the general ignorance of things Russian, and the psychic tensions of immigrant acculturation all played a role in the myth of Trotsky as lone eagle and prophet with universal relevance, a myth difficult to dispel until supplanted in the next generation by the cults of Mao Tsetung, Ho Chi Minh, Che Guerara, Fidel Castro and other even more exotic (and successful) revolutionaries.

title: What's Doing in NICARAGUA
description: TWOOCEAN PLAYGROUNDVacationers can take their choice of two oceans in Nicaragua. The largest of Central America's. republics, with an area of 50,000 square miles (about the size of Illinois), Nicaragua lies between the Caribbean and the Pacific and has 200 miles of coastline on each side. In between, there are huge lakes, winding tropical rivers, junglecovered mountains, ancient Spanish cities and more than a score of volcanoes. Discovered in 1502 by Christopher Columbus on his fourth and final voyage to the New World, Nicaragua remained a Spanish colony until achieving its independence in 1821. With 2.3 million people, Nicaragua is a poor country and through the centuries it has been plagued by earthquakes, droughts and volcanic eruptions. The country's history has been equally tumultuous, with earthshakers such as Sir Francis Drake, John Hawkins and Lord Nelson among those who made brief appearances on the scene. Even today there are sporadic outbursts of violence stemming from clashes between Government forces and guerrillas seeking to undermine the regime of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle. Because of soaring world prices for agricultural products, Nicaragua has enjoyed two consecutive years of relative prosperity, and today officials are turning their attention to the development of tourist facilities to tide the country over the lean years.

title: LETTERS
description: I enjoyed Tony Kornheiser's article on Willis Reed (The Gospel According to Willis, Oct. 16), but I was bothered by his reference to the Protestant Ethic. Mr. Kornheiser implies that a man's salvation comes from hard work. I will not debate the merits of this, but it is not a statement of the Protestant Ethic, often mislabeled the Protestant Work Ethic. The Protestant Ethic, as any businessschool graduate who has read Max Weber's The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism and R. H. Tawney's Religion and the Rise of Capitalism knows, is a belief that man's position in the hereafter is evidenced by his success in lifei.e., a man who has made his fortune will undoubtedly go to heaven. His success need not come from hard work.

Now the film will be given a regular commercial run, starting Friday at Columbia I. Concerned with a charming, literate and wealthy French businessman (Fernando Rey), unruffled until he encounters an enigmatic young Conchita, the film, according to Mr. Canby, combines the effervescence and gaity of The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie with the dark wit of Tristana, and though it continues to explore themes we recognize from these and other Bunuel films, it is something quite other. description: When Bill Robinson was younger, he would swing anxiously at almost anything the pitcher threw. But last season, as a controlled 34yearold, he enjoyed his best year for the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: A Women's Vote Fails to Materialize
description: TRENTON 0N THE eve of the gubernatorial election, the women's vote appears to be divided along traditional party lines. The hope that New Jersey women's groups of varying shades of opinion could combine forces, establish a bloc vote and thus hopefully express a clear voice in state government affairs was dissipated last month, when a statewide coalition of such organizations fell to fighting among themselves following separate interviews with each of the prinicpal candidates for Governor.

title: That Baby  In the Car   Is in Danger
description: The proponents of automobile safety carriers for children have often expressed frustration at their inability to get many parents to use them. A recently published study provides still further reason for discouragement.

title: Cowboys Martin Is Likely to Put Heat on the Giants
description: The bedroom wall in Harvey Martin's bachelor apartment in Dallas featured Gordon Gravelle of the Giants last week.

title: DeGruchi Helps Plainedge Snare Victory and Top Spot
description: Plainedge permitted an opponent to score against its defense for the first time this season, but rallied in the second half and defeated Sewanhaka, 2215, yesterday to move into sole possession of first place in Nassau Conference 11.

title: Valdes Defeats Briscoe For Middleweight Title
description: CAMPIONE D'ITALIA, Italy, Nov. 5Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia won the vacant world middleweight boxing title tonight with a unanimous decision over Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia in 15 rounds.

description: Bloomfield, which was held to a tie in the first half, broke loose for four touchdowns in the final two periods and scored a 4214 decision over Irvington.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 5 (UPI)  Manuel Orantes of Spain scored an easy 61, 60 victory over Harold Solomon of the United States in the semifinals of the $100,000 Fred Perry open tennis tournament today.

title: RHODESIA AGREEMENT STILL SEEMS ELUSIVE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 5It has been 14 months since Prime Minister Ian D. Smith publicly agreed to the principle of majority rule for Rhodesia, but to judge from the current talks here a settlement is as elusive as ever.

title: Poet's Corner in Middletown
description: MIDDLETOWN WHAT name comes up when poets talk about the publication of poetry? The Wesleyan University Press. And when you say Wesleyan to knowledgeable bookseller, what is his mitomatic response? Ah, yes, poetry.

description: ROSLYN

title: The L.I.R.R.'s Punch Line
description: IN ONE month, a Long Island Rail Road commuter got a few that looked like Tshirts. He also got some that looked like boat propellers, turtles, spaceships, galoshes, boomerangs and messes on the floor.

title: Dole Asks Senate Inquiry On Grain Harvest Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, called today for a Senate investigation of reports that the Agriculture Department and the Central Intelligence Agency overestimated the size of this year's Soviet grain harvest.

title: Today'sProgram
description: MORNING EVENTS

title: GARDENING
description: CHORES for New Jersey gardeners will continue throughout November. For example, Mayblooming tulips should be planted some time before Thanksgiving.

title: POLITICS
description: EARLY this year, when publicopinion polls showed Governor Byrne receiving low marks from the citizenry, a Democratic strategist was asked whether he thought Mr. Byrne would seek a second term.

title: St. John Vianney Takes Clash of Unbeatens, 2112
description: Scott Fitzgerald ran for one touchdown and 100 yards in 14 carries as St. John Vianney overcame Point Pleasant Borough, 2112, in a battle of two teams that had won their first six games.

title: Lombardo, 75 , Dies Ina Texas Hospital
description: Guy Lombardo, the band leader known for a half century of New Year's Eve celebrations with 'the sweetest music this side of heaven, died last night at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 75 years old.

title: Excessive Budgets Seen in Greenburgh
description: In his article, Is SchoolTax Voting Obsolete? [Sept. 25] Bernd Brecher, president of the school board of Greenburgh District 7, continues the cry of his predecessors, that it is community frustration that makes the voters save a nickel on taxes by voting down the school budget. What a distortion of fact. There is no desire of the citizenry of District 7 to deprive their children of the transportation and athletic programs that are so important.

title: Livingston (70) A 3212 Winner
description: Dave McLaughlin and John Farese rushed for two touchdowns apiece as undefeated Livingston cruised to its seventh victory, 3212, over Morris Knolls yesterday at Rockaway. McLaughlin, who also passed for a 2point conversion, tallied on runs of and 55 yards. Farese scored from9 and 6 yards out. John Lucas also had a hand in Livingston's attack, rushing for 136 yards in 17 curies.

title: Jury Clears Nursing Home Aide
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (UPI)Denise Watson has been acquitted of murder and arson in the deaths of 23 patients last year at the Wincrest Nursing Home, where she was a housekeeper. Miss Watson collapsed in her attorney's arms when a jury's verdict was read in court yesterday.

title: A Chicken In Every Yard
description: IT IS conceivable that unknowing souls may inquire why having a small flock of chickens is at least twice as desirable as, say, having your own inground swimming pool. Let us answer their question by first defining what kind of chickens we are talking about.

title: Panel Urges Probation for Shepard
description: A hearing panel of the State Education Department has recommended that Dr.Martin Shepard of East Hampton, L. I., be placed on five years probation for unprofessional conduct involving alleged sexual intercourse with patients in his former Practice as a psychiatrist.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT CAN be assumed, I expect, that most of us think that the days of campus protests are over, that placidity and panty raids are once again what college is all about after the antiwar turbulence of the 1960's. Some of us like the quiet, some of us bemoan it as an indicator of the lack of student commitment to a cause, any cause.

title: Dance: Castro's Isadora Tribute
description: There is no more exciting name in dance history than Isadore Duncan, who even today continues to stir up controversy over so simple a thing as the exact date of her birth. The schclars disagree but by popular consensus the centenary is being celebrated this year by a variety of observances, including a program dedicated to her by Alonso Castro and presented Friday evening at the Theater of St. Clement's Church.

title: Haven of Common Sense
description: WASHINGTONSecretary of State Cyrus Vance, who runs one of the tidiest and hardestworking shops in this somewhat disorganized city, is at present engaged in two projects of what might be called rectification of the practice or methodology of United States policy, not its change in terms of national aims or aspirations.

title: Star Ball Coast Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 5 (UPI)Star Ball, a 5yearold mare from Argentina, ran powerfully in the stretch today and captured the inaugural $100,000 Yellow Ribbon Stakes for fillies and mares over the turf course at. Santa Anita.

title: Stratford Looks Beyond the Bard
description: STRATFORD WITH the American Shakespeare Theater faltering as a tourist attraction after two decades of success here, municipal and civic leaders have begun a drive to attract more visitors the year round.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEY'S top welfare offficials are not sure yet what prescription spells relief for them in coping with the heavy financial burden of a halfmillion or more cases.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, Franklin and Fremont Streets, BloomfieldA Streetcar Named Desire. Thursday through Saturday,8:30 P.M. (through Nov. 26). $2.90$4.90; students and the elderly, $1.90$3.90; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater, Bloomfield College.

title: DINING OUT
description: LA CISTERNA means the well. This pleasant Mineola dining spot was named after La Cisterna in Rome, a restaurant in the nowfashionable Trastevere section owned by the famed Ansaldi family. In addition to keeping the name, the local place is decorated with similar large wall paintings, depicting the comings and goings of some rather romanticized peasants at harvest time. Someone our party remarked that all the women in the paintings bore a facial resemblance to Liza Minnelli.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Medical authorities say it is neither unusual nor improper for salesmen of medical devices to be present during surgery so they can advise doctors on the use of their products. Participation in surgery is another matter. Last week, in a case that the Suffolk County, LI., District Attorney called the most scandalous he had ever prosecuted, a salesman was said to have performed crucial parts of an operation to implant an artificial hip.

title: Bayside, Clinton, Tech, South Shore Advance
description: Last season's finalists, Bayside and Clinton, and two Brooklyn powerhouses, South Shore and Brooklyn Tech, advanced to the semifinals of the public schools football playoffs yesterday.

title: Cleaning Up Fall's Souvenirs
description: LEAVES are on just about everyone's minds now. They cover the ground, cling to the trees, blow across the neighbor's lawn to yours and make a nuisance of themselves. A good wind storm will often make things progress rapidlyusually just after the lawns have had a good clean sweep.

title: Destructive Search of L.I. Home Fails to Answer. Trunk Mystery
description: H. Richard Uviller, a professor of criminal law at Columbia University, was telling his class the other day about the penetrative power of search warrants when he flashed before the students a newspaper article of last Oct. 10.

title: Early Kline Work Signals His Future
description: PURCHASE

title: New York State Agrees to Allow Added Hookups to Natural Gas
description: ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP)The state government, which last winter had to deal with a natural gas shortage of crisis proportions, agreed last Tuesday to let thousands of new customers hook up to gas lines for heating and other purposes.

title: Gerald S. Armstrong And Kristina Becker Will Wed on Dec. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. George John Becker of Ridgewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristina Becker, to Gerald Stuart Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Armstrong Jr. of Armonk, N. Y.

title: Dr. G. A. Alexander To Wed Miss Chase
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leroy B. Chase of Dennisport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sebell Elizabeth Chase, to Dr. George Atkins Alexander, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leslie L. Alexander of Brooklyn, and Oak Bluffs, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 10.

title: Growing Up Unread
description: IN Growing Up Absurd', Paul Goodman has some trenchant comments on what society does to its indubitably great and serviceable men, its Gandhis, Schweitzers, Einsteins, Picassos and Bubers. They are transformed into striking images and personalities, set up on a pedestal to be respectfully honored and ignored. We make no practical use or them, he says, for we actually find their careers troubling and disruptive and their personalities too odd to be exemplary. Instead we immunize people against their virus by creating glamorous images with empty roles.

title: CARTER SAYS SEOUL IMPEDES U.S. JUSTICE OVER TONGSUN PARK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 President Carter accused South Korea of impeding justice in the United States today by not persuading Tongsun Park to testify in an investigation of alleged Korean attempts to influence members of Congress improperly.

title: Search on for Clues to Ringers Roots
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 5.In the ivycovered clubhouse of the Jockey Club of Uruguay at Maronas Race Track this afternoon, the members sipped drinks in the salons or strolled the broad balconies, watching the finishes of the races below. Down the track, separated by high iron fences from the club, the Montevideo horseplayers sat in the rough concrete stands set aside for the public, raising ragged cries at the progress of the sevenhorse cards. A spring breeze rustled the new leaves of the locust trees outside, and there were birds squawking everywhere.

title: Future Events
description: Nov. 9Everybody joining Jacqueline Onassis and Walter Cronkite at the dinner for the International Center of Photography will get an autographed copy of Peter Beard's new book, The End of the Game. Diners on the center's second floor will be surrounded by the African animals Mr. Beard photographed to get spears raised against careless hunting. An auction of five of the photographs will follow the dinner, the proceeds of which will be used as matching funds for a challenge grant requested from the National Endowment for the Arts. Then guests go down to dance in the groundfloor gallery of the center's mansion at 1130 Fifth Avenue. Olatunji, an African tribal priest who has drummed his way into the music world, will set the beat for cocktails that start the party for the center's third birthday. Olatunji and his band also will drum for dancing. Dance if you dare. Tickets: $150 from Judy at 8601763.

title: Scientists Study Suburban Smog
description: YONKERS

title: Girls at Brooklyn Tech Corner Track Market
description: What do Secretariat, Seattle. Slew and Brooklyn Tech have in common? The triple crown, of course.

title: Buried Treasures in the R&H Archives
description: The Library and Museum of the Performing Arts may not be the most striking building in Lincoln Center, and doubtless millions of people have walked past it without the slightest curiosity on their way to concerts, operas, ballets and theatrical events. Yet, the Library houses the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound, and is one of the five largest and most complete institutional sound archives in the country. Of course, many people who don't use the facilitywhich is open only to scholars, students and other serious researchers'attach too much significance to the name, and think of the Archives as a repository for show tunes.

title: Adair Crew Will Need Week to Cap Well Fire
description: CHATOM, Ala., Nov. 5 (AP)It will be at least a week before Red Adair's crew of oilfield troubleshooters can cap, a poisonous gas well that has been spewing flames more than 100 feet into the air over southwest Alabama for days, a. Phillips Petroleum Company spokesman said today.

title: Home Style
description: Every apartment hunter can decipher that classified space saver. But other terms are not so easily understandable. For reasons of economy, classified advertisements cram as much information as possible in as little space as possible. Frequently, clarity falls by the wayside.

title: A Humbug Exalted
description: OUR century is rich in charlatans, frauds, fantasts. One of the least attractive of them, to me, is T. E. Lawrence, widely known (thanks to his persistent but discreet campaign of selfadvertisement) as Lawrence of Arabia. This startling new biography of Lawrence by an English novelist and authority on the Middle East comes festooned with praise by John Fowles and Paul Fussell. Like its subject, it invites serious attention.

title: President Uses First Veto to Bar Nuclear Reactor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 President Carter, using the first veto of his Administration, today rejected a bill that would have authorized $80 million for a controversial nuclear reactor on the Clinch River in Tennessee.

title: NEW ACTIVIST COURSE TAKEN BY CATHOLICS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 2Sister Margaret Cafferty scanned her audience of 500 Roman Catholic social activists here at the University of Notre Dame this week and recalled a moment of shared exuberance.

title: Massachusetts Lags In Cranberry Growing
description: BOSTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)The region that originated America's Thanksgiving holiday no longer is the nation's top producer of cranberries.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: Letters should be addressed to Editor, New Jersey Weekly, News Department, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters must include the writer's address and telephone number for verification. The Times reserves the right to edit and condense all letters.

title: No Traveling At the Moment
description: President Carter and his aides will keep their suitcases in the attic for a while. After balancing the potential domestic losses against possible foreignpolicy gains, Mr. Carter decided last week to look homeward and postpone his second trip abroad this year, which has been scheduled for later this month. me decision perhaps was routed more in significant symbolism than in real substance. How would it look if the President were not in the country while a House and Senate conference committee struggled over the most important sections of energy legislation that he has made the cornerstone of his Administration? (A chart on the status of the energy pro gram, Page 2). Inevitably, the postponement also raised questions about how highly the White House regarded the trip to begin with.

title: Indiana 24, Iowa 21
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 5 (AP)David Freud, kicked a 23yard field goal with 16 seconds left in the game today to lead Indiana to a 2421 victory over Iowa in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: First of 2 Trials Is Opening Over Estate Left by Hughes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5Nineteen months after the death of Howard R. Hughes, the struggle over his estate, one of the largest ever amassed by an American, will go to trial before a jury in Las Vegas Monday, with a second, competing trial to open a week later in Houston.

title: The Graying of AmericaTime for Thought
description: LIKE the abused child who cringes at the hand reaching out to stroke, fearing that it will strike, older people sometimes distrust financial benefits represented to them as advantages.

title: Tortola: Opportunities To Do Nothing, With Style
description: On the plane bound for the Caribbean, our neighbors were a New York couple dressed in matching hisandhers resort wear. We asked them what they intended to do on their vacation. The husband closed his monogrammed briefcase, tipped his martini and took a long puff on his cigar. Nothing, he said.

title: Topics
description: Brooklyn culture did not die when the Dodgers departed; there is much more to that borough than Bums and brownstones. Brooklynites are justifiably sensitive to the world's limited knowledge of its attractions and to the notorious reluctance of other New Yorkers, particularly Manhattanites, to cross the brooklyn Bridgenot the least of the borough's landmarks. Olmsted's Prospect Park, as any Brooklynite knows, is bigger and better than Central Park; the 19th century survives on its streets and boulevards in row houses and treeshaded homes.

title: Jean Moore Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Moore of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jean Ann Moore, to Robert John Edwards, on of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Edwards of La Jolla, Calif. A wedding in March is planned.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1977

title: Forever Casting a Neck Victor in Jersey
description: LAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 5???????? Casting, a colt who has been quietly building his reputation in the Midwest, made an impression on East??? viewers tonight with a neck victory in the $144,50C Young America Stakes (Or 2yearolds at the Meadowlands. With 26,278 looking on, the son of KaskaskiaEver Amber, by Ambiorix, earned $93,925 for his owners, William Farish 3d and Wyatts Humphrey. Neither owner saw the colt's victory over Believe It, however. They were on a hunting trip and didn't learn the result until 30 minutes after Forever Casting had posted his seventh success in 15 races and increased his earnings to $ 231.395.

title: Briton Works for Beavers Return
description: LONDON, Nov. 5(Reuters)A naturalist has begun a campaign to return to Britain the beaver, an animal that has not been seen here for 600 years.

title: Muhammad Ali Meets Ernest Hemingway
description: IN the opening line of Shadow Box, George Plimpton gambles. I never understood boxing. he writes, thus attempting to set up the reader for a sucker punch. The gambit is audacious, since boxing is the one sport that can bring out the prophet in a Quaker. Call it a literary righthand lead. But then, as one gets deeper into the book, he realizes he has read very little about the actual mano a mano. What has been offered are some Plimpton misadventures, personality portraits observed first hand and culled from history, a smorgasbord characters: boxers, writers, hangerson and peripheral zanies. So the opening gambit becomes a query: Does he really understand boxing? The question as gauche as speculating whether A.J. Liebling will ever finish his meal in The Sweet Science. By this time, the reader is so charmed and beguiled that he frankly doesn't give a damn.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IT WAS a neatly landscaped estate in New Canaan, Conn., but it took on the look of a country hoedown one evening in late summer. Round tables, set around the pool, were dressed in patchwork prints over floorlength, bluechecked gingham cloths. There were redand bluedotted Swiss napkins, and fresh vegetables and marigolds spilled out of old crocks and kettles. Huge white paper lanterns, with candles inside, swung from the trees. Bales of hay and authentic hayricks were part of the landscape.

title: Topalian Among 3 Backs With 4Touchdown Efforts
description: A trio of talented running backs each scored a quartet of touchdowns to Make the play away from some of the gonferences races in Nassau County yesterday.

title: Eleanor Andrews Is Married
description: The Bedford (N. Y.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Eleanor Sherrell Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilton W. Andrews of Houston, to Robert Gerdes Kuhbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Gerdes Kuhbach of Chatham, N. J.

title: Oregon Continues Abortion Aid
description: SALEM, Ore., Nov. 5 (AP)State ti. nancing of abortions in Oregon for women on welfare will continue through January as the result of an 8.7 vote by the Legislative Emergency Board. After ejecting six motions on the issue, the board voted yesterday to provide $40,000 in state funds until the hoard meets the last week In January. Gov. Bob Straub had asked for $1.8 million to pay. for an estimated 5,000 abortions through June 49, 1979.

title: GIORGIO LA PIRA OF ITALY, A WORLD PEACE CRUSADER
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Nov, 4 (AP)Giorgio La Pira, former mayor of Florence whose peace crusades in the Soviet Union, the Middle East and Indochina gained worldwide attention, died today of a brain hemorrhage. He was 75 years old.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Gibraltar has issued its first 10pound bank note. The nation has 10shilling, onepound and fivepound notes but this new tenner with the picture of Queen Elizabeth II is the highest recent denomination in paper money. Two 50pound issues were embossed witn the stamp of the AngloEgyptian Bank Ltd., Gibraltar in 1914, but these are now rare.

title: A Lifetime Of Popularity
description: Guy Lombardo's longtime image as Mr. New Year's Eve and the fact that his successful career as a band leader continued for more than 40 years after he had ceased to be an innovative tastemaker in popular music have obscured the fact that he brought as fresh and distinctive an approach to popular dance) Appreciationmusic in the late 20's as Benny Goodman did in the mid30's.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: YOU saw, last week on page one, that another book has arrived to explain everything. Bold books like Cannibals and Kings are a reviewer's dream, particularly if the reviewer is unencumbered by a special knowledge or anything remotely resembling the technical competence necessary to decide whether what the author says is true. We are then unleashed into rhapsodies of speculation. Anthropologyor economics, or psychodemonism, or the heavy breathing of the zodiacbecomes imaginative literature. What if? Why not? This, after all, is the real stuff, not merely metaphor.

title: Music: 3 Premieres With Tapes
description: The concert presented by the International Society for Contemporary Music on Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was a pretty bleak affair on the whole. The sympathies of the I.S.C.M. have traditionally centered on music growing out of the Second Viennese School of Schoenberg, Bergen and Webern, who were instrumental in forming the society during the 1920's, and most of the works on Friday's program hued closely to the party line.

title: Encounter in the Classroom
description: IT was ParentsMeettheTeachers Night in Westchester, the newest method of making a parent feel inadequate. One or another of my three children has always forced me to attend these showyourinterestinyourchild displays, and so I was in attendance.

title: Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport Gains a Helicopter Landing Pad Near Emergency Room
description: The doctors and nurses at Eastern Long Wand Hospital in Greenport made a mad dash from the building to their cars in the parking Jot. They were followed by laboratory technicians, volunteer workers and visitors. All ran to the parking lot and jumped into their cars to move then, out as fast as possible so that a helicoptez hovering overhead could land.

title: ANTIQUES
description: That 17block stretch of Manhattan's Madison Avenue, north of 66th Street, is aglow these days with the decorative arts styles that span five decadesfrom the Gay 90's to World War IL Since 1970, 11 such galleries have been added to that promenade of prestigious shops, long tenanted by the merchants of high fashion and art.

title: 7 Tourists Killed in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Nov, 5 (AP)Seven Dutch tourists were killed tod aywhen the bus in which they were riding collided with another bus on the winding road to Elath in southern Israel, the police reported. They said eight passengers on the other but had been injured. A police spokesman declined to identify the dead until positive identification had been made.

title: ByrneThere is no question that the tax system in effect in New Jersey today is fairer
description: TWO qualities above all have been the hallmarks of my administration: integrity and devotion to the public interest.

title: Mayor's Noncampaign Campaign
description: UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 5 (AP)A new carillon has been installed outside City Hall that sometimes plays Somewhere Over the Rainbow.

title: Prizes and Surprises at The Fair
description: FOOD was the common element that threaded its way through the crowd of thousands at last month's Riverhead Country Fair, most of whom arrived in time for lunch. In between slices of pizza or bites of sticky honey apples, visitors enjoyed the boat rides, parades, a ferris wheel and crafts exhibits.

title: Karen L. Gustafson Engaged To Robert H. Royer, Engineer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Gustafson of Severna Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Laurel Gustafson, to Robert Herman Royer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Royer of Brooklyn. A February wedding is planned.

title: Laws Regarding Search Warrants Given Wide Interpretation
description: The laws governing search warrants are in some ways quite explicit. For example, a warrant must set out the area to be searched and the search itself must be reasonably calculated to find the object.

title: Princeton Magazine Focuses on Business
description: PRINCETON

title: Beverly Bartel Married
description: The marriage of Beverly Amthor Bartel of Westport, Conn., widow of William Philip Bartel 2d, to N. Dale Sayre, a New York lawyer, took place yesterday In Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, The Rev. Dana Forest Kennedy performed the ceremony. Mr. Sayre, whose previous marriage ended In divorce, is a partner in the law firm of McLean, Boustead & Sayre.

title: Marc Gaelen, Student, To Wed Nina Fondiller
description: The engagement of Nina Fondiller to Marc Gaelen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Gaelen of Short Hills, N. J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Fondiller of South Orange, N. J. The wedding is planned for next August.

title: An Afternoon at a College Football Game
description: We arrive early, stuffing the thermos and binoculars under our seats and complaining about the snapback catches on our Sit Eezies. We can't remember if it's the eighth or ninth season we've done this in seats 14 and 15, row D, aisle E.

title: The Cost of Stagnation
description: Unemployment rose again last month, from 6.9 to 7 percent. But back in 1956, with the Eisenhower Administration in office and about to be reelected, unemployment in America averaged only 4.1 percent. Had that rate been maintained during the last two decades:

title: SELECTION
description: THE following etymologies have been taken from Morris Dictionary of Word and Phrase Origins, by William and Mary Morris, published by Harper & Row at $15. Mr. Morris is editor in chief of The American Heritage Dictionary, Mrs. Morris is coauthor of Harper Dictionary Contemporary Usage. Copyright  1977 by William Morris and Mary Morris.

title: KOCH, THE FAVORITE, MATCHES LATE DRIVE OF 3 MAYORAL RIVALS
description: Backed by television commercials and a blizzard of campaign literature, the four major mayoral candidates campaigned yesterday as if Representative Edward 1. Koch was not the heavy favorite to be elected on Tuesday as New York City's 105th Mayor.

title: Jenny Angel Gerard Is Bride
description: Jenny Angel Gerard, daughter of Sumner Gerard and Mrs. Grosvenor Gerard, both of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Barry Leslie Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Brown also of New York.

title: KOCH OUT IN STREETS FOR FINAL STRETCH
description: Cheered at a Puerto Rican market, booed at a street corner in an Italian neighborhood, embraced by the Democratic Establishment at a party lunch in the Bronx, Representative Edward I. Koch toured New York City yesterday and was greeted almost everywhere as the next Mayor.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I do sympathize with the problems working mothers face in finding day care for their children [The Working Mother: Frustrations and Solutions, Opinion Page, Oct. 16]. But I wonder what Barbara Masry implies in her plea for day care for those women who wish and need to join the mainstream of society. Is it possible that parents who have given up a career outside the home to care for their own young children are actually floundering in the backwaters of society?

title: BRIDGE
description: A recent proposal by the American Contract Bridge League to institute a retirement home for bridge players has generated some comment, most of it favorable. An imaginative extension of the plan has now been put forward by David Hutchinson in the excellent bulletin that he edits for Pennsylvania players. He writes as follows:

title: A New Form Of Life?
description: What if biologists were to announce that all along there had been three sexes, not two? Or that some of man's favorite cousins were perfect strangers? A group of scientists at the University of Illinois has reported an analogous discovery, reclassifying some familiar onecelled organisms as a previously unrecognized form of life.

title: It Epitomizes Recreational Land Development Difficulties Everywhere
description: LOS ANGELES'Surely the fairest picture the whole earth affords, wrote Mark Twain after first viewing Lake Tahoe. A century later, Lake Tahoeone of the deepest and clearest lakes in the worldand its surrounding forested basin still are, with some unfortunate qualifications, places of such surpassing beauty as to be widely considered a national, rather than parochial, asset.

title: Debbie Lebowitz Fiancee of Barry Pinkus, Lawyer
description: The engagement of Debbie Sue Lebowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Lebowitz of New Rochelle, N. Y., to Barry Charles Pinkus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pinkus of New Haven, has been announced by the future bride's parents. The wedding is planned for next summer.

title: Halpern a Fast Skipper With Slow Boat
description: Joel Halpern has beet saddled with the reputation of having a  slow boat. But that doesn't bother him: He knows speed is not the only thing; it's the ride that counts, as evidenced by his defense of the North American Offshore Power Boat  title. And when the top boats from five continerits battle on the turbulent waters off Key West, Fla., Saturday for the world championship,

title: Bateman The reality is that the tax will selfdestruct under the law next June 30
description: THIRTY years ago, New Jersey boomed. New houses went up by the thousands, factories were built, roads were constructed and new people moved in. But 30 years later, New Jersey is a different scene.

title: INTERVIEW
description: BOOK reviewers don't always get her name right. They call her Wilma Wurlitzer or Hilma Holitzer or Hilda Wolitzer. But one thing they do agree on about the tall, slim, blueeyed woman who has made her home in Syosset for the last 18 years: She is an extraordinary novelist.

title: Article 14  No Title

title: Willem MengelbergThe Case For Interpretive License
description: Philips Records's release of an eightdisk set containing the nine Beethoven symphonies plus the Fidelio Overture conducted by Willem Mengelberg is of interest both in itself and for the occasion it provides for a consideration of Mengelberg's posthumous reputation. The consideration suggests that he may not have been quite so perverse as his detractors assert, and that our notions of musical rectitude may be more affected by fashion than some of us would like to admit.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE home is often referred to as a sanctuary of peace and quiet, but all too often there is not as much quiet as one would really like on the inside. Rooms are smaller and frequently open intv each other without doors to close off adjoining areas, and houses are built with thinner walls that do very little to prevent transmission of noise from one room to another or from one apartment to another.

title: U.S. Documents Support Belief Israel Got Missing Uranium for Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5Two classified documents written in 1976 and made public today show that the nation's intelligence agencies suspected that Israel might have obtained up to 200 pounds of uranium missing from a Pennsylvania factory in the mid1960's and used it to produce nuclear weapons.

title: The Nation
description: The action had been threatened for two years, but when the United States officially withdrew last week from the International Labor Organization the shock was still considerable. And shock was just what the Carter Administration intended.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Stuffed Owl Proves a Point
description: NOTTINGHAM, England (Reuters)A stuffed owl has disappeared from an exhibition here devoted to Britain's vanishing wildlife.

title: The Total of Foreign Investment Is Probably Around $20 Billion
description: JOHANNESBURGWhat Joel Makwele read last week did not please him. At the United Nations, an arms embargo against South Africa was approved, but not the credit and investment sanctions that might force Pretoria to rethink its apartheid policies. Mr. Makwele, a helper to a white mechanic at a United Statesowned company in Johannesburg, might lose his job if the full range of sanctions was approved. But he still wanted an economic boycott that would force whites to choose between racial privilege and prosperity.

title: Inquiry Building a Case Against Gandhi Government
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 5In what used to be the ballroom of a maharajah's palace here, a special court of inquiry is building a strong, detailed case against the Government that was headed by Indira Gandhi.

title: Sanders (14: 50.8) Leads Long Island Charge
description: Odis Sanders of Freeport coasted to 40yard victory and William Floyd High School won the team title as Long Island runners dominated the featured race today in the state intersectional crosscountry championship yesterday at Malone, N.Y.

title: AWALK ON SAN FRANCISCO'S GAY SIDE
description: With one out of three voters estimated to be homosexual, Bay City politics and life style have changed sharply.

title: Miners Seek More Money To Bail Out Union Funds
description: BELLAIRE, Ohio, Nov. 5 (UPI)The president of District 6 of the United Mine Workers said today that coal companies would be asked to help bail out the union's health and retirement funds when contract negotiations resume Tuesday.

description: Jean Fink is judicial director of the League of Women Voters of Westchester and a board member of the Westchester Committee for Modern Courts.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Botwin of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Sue Botwin, to Peter Elliot Elman, son of Frank B. Elman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Hilda Kahn Elman.

description: THE home is often referred to as a sanctuary of peace and quiet, but all too often there is not as much quiet as one would really like on the inside. Rooms are smaller and frequently open into each other without doors to close off adjoining areas, and houses are built with thinner walls that do very little to prevent transmission of noise from one room to another or from one apartment to another.

description: An unlikely assortment of rock stars, scholars, blues musicians, librarians, concert promoters and record company executives gathered at the Lincoln Center

title: The Region/continued
description: Hours after election day in New York City this week, the first rumblings of the avalanche will begin. Few mayors, in fact, will have been clobbered by the city's problems so swiftly, with so little time for planning and so little opportunity for study and reflection, than the man who is elected Tuesday. The commonly accepted wisdom holds, moreover, that the next mayor will be all the more hampered by a bewildering array of constraints, built up over two years of fiscal emergencyoutside state and Federal auditors, an Emergency Financial Control Board and the Municipal Assistance Corporationall of them nibbling away at his prerogatives and powers.

title: Arround THE Garden
description: Gardeners were spared the inundation of slugs this year in many regions. They just weren't quite the nuisance they had been in previous years, particularly last summer.

title: FISHING
description: IT MAY BE an ill wind that blows no good, but last week's easterly wasn't all bad. Yes, all but the hardiest skippers remained at the dock. And the waters were muddied by 10foot swells that churned up bottom silt. But apparently the winds also pushed migrating bluefish, striped bass and weakfish westward from Montauk along the Island's South Shore.

title: South's Black Voters Have Yet to Demonstrate Their Strength
description: ATLANTAA dozen years have passed since the Voting Rights Act opened the way for full black participation in Southern politics. But the full potential of black political power in Dixie remains unrealized.

title: The Jews and Jimmy Carter
description: As Norman Mailer says, only the unsayable is really worth saying. And one of the unsayable things in our political life these days is that most leaders of the American Jewish community are acting as if President Carter is risking Israel's survival for an illusory Middle East settlement. Meanwhile Administration officials and other influential citizens are increasingly annoyed by the formidable resistance the President's diplomacy is getting from the American Jewish community. It is a quarrel of genera! concern. All Americans nave a staxe in the wisdom and success of Mr. Carter's effort to move toward an enduring Middle East peace. And his relations with the influential Jewish community bear on that success.

title: Johnny D., With Cauthen, Posts International Upset
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 5The highly regarded Exceller of France and Majestic Light of the United States, the top contenders for the 1977 turfhorseoftheyear award, were beaten today, much to the surprise of a crowd of 25,315.

title: Checks on Government Influence Sought at Conference on the Arts
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y.It's great that Uncle Sam has joined the arts act, but how do we keep down his voice? a theater man asked here Friday. Though he spoke in jest, his remark seemed to sum up a concern with the everincreasing role of government in the arts felt by most of his colleagues involved in the nonprofit performing artsadministrators, truseees, performers, students and government officials participating in a conference held by Columbia University's American Assembly on The Future of the Performing Arts.

title: Case Is the Talk of Aqueduct, Too
description: The old man walked with a cane, but his blue eyes were bright with the hope that comes from more the half a century of playing horses.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Brace Competition Necessitates Travel
description: A. breeder may have two dogs that look enough alike in type, style and color to form a brace and further realize that the pair needs more intricate training aad practice to move in unison. But there is a third consideration when contemplating participation in brace cornpetion. The exhibitor has to be prepared to make long triys and put a lot of mileage on a car because today there are few brace classes offered at allbreed shows. Just ask Barbara Wood of Manhattan. Ch. Ambara's AtiraKaDabra and Ch. Ambara's Ruffian'have just been retired after winning six of eight bestinshow brace competitions and are believed to have set a record for the year.

title: Sen. Weicker, Camille Butler Are Married
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, married Camille DiLorenzo Butler, his former appointments secretary, yesterday in New York. The 4:30 P.M. ceremony, in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, was performed by the rector, the Rev John G. B. Andrew the presence of the couple's families, friends, and a sprinkling of Washington dignitaries, including Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, and Mrs. Ribicoff, and Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Mrs. Powell.

title: INVESTING,
description: A new investment phenomenon called Babcock fever has broken out in Wall Street, infecting growing numbers of frustrated small investors hoping to reap the same big returns as market professionals. But the gamearbitrageis fraught with risks, and profits may be more elusive than the average investor realizes.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: HAVING previously occupied venues as exotic as the old Customs House and the basement of Lincoln Center, the New York Book Fair.an annual exhibit of small presses and little magazines  found a home this year under a yellowandwhite tent in Bryant Park. It immediately assumed the guise of a cultural county fair. There was even a distinct aroma of green growing things in the air, albeit a hangover from the tent's previous tenants, the New York flower show, which had vacated the premises only an hour before the book fair was scheduled to open.

title: Nun Designs Church Windows
description: CALDWELL. IT'S ODD. Sister Gerardine sais with a note of wonder, how something you never thought of doing can become the big thing of your life.

title: Mich. State 29, Minnesota 10
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5 (AP)  Ed Smith threw touchdown passes of 51 and 85 yards to a flanker, Kirk Gibson, and Chris Nielsen kicked three field goals today as Michigan State overwhelmed Minnesota, 2910, to tighter its hold on third place in the Big Ten.

title: CRIME
description: James K. MacDougall's WEASEL HUNT (BobbsMerrill, $8.95) and James Magnuson's THE RUNDOWN (Dial, $7.95) are completely different in locale and subject matter. But they share one important thing in commonan approach to the privateeye story stemming from the tradition of Hammett and Macdonald, in which the protagonist is a man of feeling, in which the prose is sensitive and rather subdued, in which relationships are as important as the plotting.

title: Illegal Football Betting Grows in County High Schools

They often travel in the company of a fourth housesnooper, Elric Esbersby, who is also known as the director of the Princeton History Project.

title: U.S, PREDICTS THREAT TO ITS MISSILE FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5The Defense Department says that the landbased Minuteman missile force of the United States is likely to be vulnerable to attack in the mid1980's and that a new treaty limiting Soviet and American strategic weapons will not help reduce the threat much.

title: Houston Oil: A Skyrocketing Wildcatter Comes of Age
description: HOUSTONBack before the turn of the decade, when he was a maverick geologist with a bunch of junk oil leases and a cubbyhole company called Houston Oil and Minerals, a lot of people kept their distance from Joe Walter, especially when he was prowling for cash to sink into one of those holdyourbreath wildcat wells on property that sensible oil companies had worked Over and abandoned decades before.

title: Murderer Gets 200300 Years
description: WOODSTOCK, Ill.,Nov. 4 (UPI)A convicted rapist, Richard Macek, pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of Nancy Lossman and was immediately sentenced to 200 to 300 years in prison. Mrs. Lossman and her 3yearold daughter were found slain in their Crystal Lake home in September 1974, Mr. Macek is serving a prison term in Wisconsin for rape and the authorities say he has been implicated in nine layings.

title: Charles du Pont Plans to Marry Leslie Swanson
description: Leslie Keating Swanson and Charles Francis du Pont plan to be married in February in Wilmington, Del., where Mr. and Mrs. Jarl Raymond Swanson, parents of the bridetobe, have announced the engagement.

description: IN our craving for nostalgia, we revive old movies and records, scour attics for old pictures and furnishingsparalleling progress with remembrances of things Past.

title: Hicksville Coach Confident As Roslyn Rematch Nears
description: Brad Baworski, Hicksville's coach, was unconcerned last Friday night about the semifinal game on Tuesday against Roslyn, the team that eliminated Hicksville from the soccer playoffs last year.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill to provide tax incentives for the production and conservation of energy, passed, 52 to 35, Oct. 31.

title: Rosalynn Carter: Balancing Roles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5It was standard scene: A buntingdraped platform, a row of local dignitaries seated in folding chairs and a gently smiling Rosalynn Carter, sitting upright, ankles crossed, hands disposed neatly, listening to a eulogy of herself as a representative of the American dream.

title: Two Legion Disease Cases Are Reported in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5 (AP)The State Health Department says two apparent cases of legionnaires disease, one of them fatal, have been reported in Virginia.

title: Levesque Survives French Rituals
description: PARIS, Nov. 5Premier Rene Lvesque, Quebec's No. 1 salesman for independence from Canada, has just completed a trying experience. For three days he had to undergo the formality and ceremony of an official visit to Paris, qualities that are foreign to the easygoing and blunt nature of a man who seems to find it hard to act in the traditional ways of a head of government

title: REFUGEE SQUATTERS A PROBLEN IN LISBON
description: LISBONRefugees from Mozambique cluster in the international airport's arrival hall here and speak of the racism, arrests, shortages and other hardships that led to their flight. The women wear light cotton skirts and blouses and plastic sandals, and shiver in the November chill of Europe.

title: PERFORMERS IN JAPAN LINKED TO DRUG ABUSE
description: TOKYO, Nov. 5The entertainment world has been shaken in recent days by the interrogation, arrest or conviction of a dozen prominent Japanese on charges of having violated strict laws against narcotics and marijuana.

title: GARDENING
description: ATTRACTIVE foliage plants that do well indoors are rather plentiful. Add the requirement that the plants have attractive flowers, and the list narrows considerably. Of those remaining, the gesneriads, the plant family of the gloxinia and the African violet, are best adapted for indoor growing.

title: Ohio State Wins, 350, From Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 5 (AP) Ohio State, held to one touchdown in the first half, erupted for three in the third quarter, including two within 13 seconds, and rolled to a 35.0 victory over Illinois today, remaining undefeated in the Big Ten conference.

Bliss 3d, son of Elizabeth McKee Bliss of Beaver Falls. Pa., and Mr. Bliss Jr. of Pasadena, Calif. The wedding is planned for December.

description: WITH the ultimate disposal of dozens of socalled excess public schools in the state wavering in the balance, concern is being expressed now that many may have been shut down too hastily. Such concern is mounting in the wake of an onrush of closings earlier this year.

description: LEAVES are on just about everyone's minds now. They cover the ground, cling to the trees, blow across the neighbor's lawn to yours and make a nuisance of themselves. A good wind storm will often make things progress rapidlyusually just after the lawns have had a good clean sweep.

The small university was known, then as now, more for its intellectual than for its athletic prowess. It was unbeaten in bowl

title: MARKETS

description: I envy Tod Hunt's experience with a hand lawn mower (Oct. 9). My own was quite different. Fed up with noise, fumes, empty gasoline cans and the balky starts of my power motor, I bought the kind of grass cutter that had served my family so well when I was a child.

title: Headliners
description: At first the disappearance was treated as another episode in West Germany's running struggle with the Red Army Faction terrorist group which previously has spilled over into the Netherlands. But when Maurits Caransa, a Dutch millionaire, turned up on an Amsterdam street last week, four days after being kidnapped outside a bridge club, he had another story to tell. His abductors were not political, Mr. Caransa said: As they said themselves, they were only out for money. And they got plenty of that. Although he managed to bargain them down from their nriginal demand for 40 million guilders ($16.4 million) and his associates finally did pay 10 million guilders ($4.6 million) in ransom. Police have found a car used in the kidnapping but otherwise no trace of the criminals.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI)  The General Electric Company has asked the Government to approve its proposed sale to the Soviet Union of the most powerful jet engine in the United States, it was disclosed today.

description: After all those dazzling seasons, O. J. Simpson's body has begun to betray him. He's now 30 years old, he has discovered his first gray hair, he had blurred vision for several weeks and he is about to undergo knee surgery, the occupational hazard of all running backs. His injury has been diagnosed as cartilage damage. which

description: A church in Memphis, Tenn., has become a restaurantdiscotheque. Where the pulpit used to be, a rock band plays. Where worshippers prayed, college students drink liquor and munch hamburgers.

title: Meryl Eve Leffe Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay Leffe of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Meryl Eve Leffe, to Michael Toback, son of Mrs. Gus Zahn of Passaic, N.J., and the late George Toback. Miss Leffe, an interior designer, is a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology. Her father is a senior vice president with the stock brokerage firm of Gruntal & Company. Mr. Toback is a student at Brooklyn Community College.

title: Book Review
description: BOOKS about Idi Amin fall into two categories those that expose him and those that exploit him. Lately, there has been an outpouring of both genres, an avalanche of Amin literature that threatens to push the dimestore paperbacks about Nazi storm troopers off the shelf. Unfortunately, the exploitative books outnumber the serious ones and, to a degree, they work to undermine them, by sensationalizing the grisly or comic myths that have long obscured a regime whose evil is very real, very banal and in no need of exaggeration. Two serious books, however, are worth comment.

title: Marianne Reed Married to Robert Ulmer
description: Marianne Louise Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clark Reed of Tinton Falls, N. J.. was married yesterday to Robert Charles Ulmer. son of Mrs. Robert William Ulmer of Tinton Falls and the late Mr. Ulmer.

title: Sara Seymour Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Seymour of Easton. Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Correll Seymour, to Macauley Whiting Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whiting of Midland, Mich. The couple are seniors at Princeton University, where they are majoring in chemical engineering. Mr. Whiting graduated from the Hotchkiss School.

title: Fashion
description: Surely some natural law precludes the possibility that women's clothes can be photographed in an infinite number of ways, but looking at almost a century's worth of fashion pictures, assembled by Nancy HallDuncan of Rochester's International Museum of Photography at Eastman House, you would never believe it. Since early in this century, in pursuit of sheer artifice, beautiful women have posed halfnaked, overdressed, underwater, on desert wastes, jumping, crying, embattled and beatified for an assortment of geniuses and journeymen. Some 250 of their pictures are included in this major historical survey of an influential aspect of the photographic medium, which comes to the

title: What a Populist Was, and Why Carter Isn't One
description: DURHAM, N. C.Beginning in the spring of 1976, when Jimmy Carter's nomination first became a distinct possibility, and extending through the ensuing campaign, a fairly uncommon ideological question intruded into mainstream American politics: Is he a populist?

title: VIOLENCE INCREASES IN ETHIOPIAN CAPITAL
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 5While the Ethiopian Government has been fighting wars with separatist movements in Eritrea and Ogaden, chaotic violence and assassinations have increased in Addis Ababa, where two Government officials and a policeman were shot to death in broad davlieht on Wednesday.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Liza, Liza, skies are gray. I don't mind so much that the various people, some careless, some nightclub knowledgeable, who've put together The Act, newly arrived the Majestic, have been opportunistic enough keep Liza Minnelli on stage, singing and singing and dancing and dancing, throwing back her head and crooking her knee in that chanticleer stance we all know so well, the whole night long. If she must perform so uninterruptedly that she basin time for a sip of water, a nibble on a sanciwich, an unflustered costume change (some are made on stage by ripping her apart or basting her together in more or less full view), she can still get something out of that.

title: He Wants No Part Of Your Raccoons
description: To the man in Larchmont who advises residents there to trap raccoons and take them to the northern areas of the county, let me say thanks. But, no thanks!

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WHENEVER I was asked what I would do with a hypothetical million dollars, never had to think very long. I always wanted to own a pipe organ. It had me spellbound, this incredible musical instrument, as I listened to recordings and live performances in concert halls, churches and museums.

title: The World/Continued
description: MOSCOWIt has now been 60 years since the cruiser Aurora opened fire with her cannonade of blanks in Petrograd and the Bolsheviks burst into the Winter Palace. The tenuous grasp of the revolutionaries has become the pervaSive power of the state. The visionary fervor has died away, the lust for sweeping change is spent. In its place stands an iron dedication to stability and control.

title: Article 4  No Title
CHESS
description: Of the many good reasons for meeting an opponent's mating attack against a castled king by a counterattack in the center, the strongest by far is the op portunity to penetrate on an open file, creating backrank mating threats.

title: All Into Plaintext
description: AT first sight, this book does not appear particularly prepossessing. The jacket copy invites one to compare it with A Man Called Intrepid, in its suspense and its revelations of hithe??? classified information about World War II intelligence operations. Such a statement raises prejudice immediately because Intrepid was not very suspenseful; it contained few, if any, real revelations, and, while its publishing record was excellent, it was worthless for history. The jacket copy increases this prejudice when it refers to the pathological secrecy and the ethical ambiguity of the American intelligence system, a statement that is unfair, untrue and reflects the sort of opinions propagated by minor dons who derive their opinions about secret intelligence from Daniel Schorr.

title: Woolfolk Sparks Westfield Romp
description: The irresistible force had little trouble against the immovable object yesterday as Westfield's team, rated No. 1 in New Jersey, rolled over Montclair, 350, at Woodman Field in Montclair before a standingroom crowd of 9,350. Westfield is unbeaten in 20 games, including one tie, and is averaging almost 38 points a game this season.

title: BRITISH CATHOLICS REVISE RULES ON MIXED MARRIAGES
description: LONDON, Nov. 5The Roman Catholic Church in England and Wales has decided that children of interfaith marriages no longer must be raised as Catholics.

title: A Castle Where the Comic Will Be King
description: MORT WALKER, reputed to be the most widely distributed cartoonist in the history of comic art, is the father of seven children and four simultaneouslyrunning comic strips distributed in 2,300 newspapers around the world, the bestknown of which is Beetle Bailey. A compact, friendly man, he remarked, I do everything big.

The crowd laughed and then cheered as the three women drivers covered the halfmile grassy field on the Ramapo College campus.

title: AllStar Cast
description: Anne Morrow Lindbergh wrote in her diaries of the awfulness of fame. Seldom has that been more apparent than with five showbusiness biographies that appear at this time. In addition to the usual slings and arrows all of us are subject to, the famous have the burden of being public figureswhich means anybodry, can write about them.

title: Removal of Fish and Wildlife Unit From Environment Agency Urged
description: ALBANY, Nov. 4The State Conservation Council has proposed to split up the State Department of Environmental Conservation by taking away one of its most important arms, the Fish and Wildlife Division, and setting it up as an independent agency.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR

While Continental Group may appear to have the upper hand in its efforts to settle in Norwalk's Sixth Taxing District, at least from the standpoint of the Norwalk Planning and Zoning Commission and the city administration, the issue is hardly settled.
