description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Among the persons whose careers are controlled to some extent by the Department of Justice are 8,400 special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, 9,000 employees of the Bureau of Prisons, 3,500 staff lawyers in the department itselfand four topless dancers in a local bar.

title: SmallBusiness Agency Will Issue Plan for Loans to Buy TV Stations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The Small Business Administration plans to publish a proposal tomorrow to give loans for the first time for the purchase and construction of radio and television stations as well as cable facilities.

title: Music: Philharmonia Hungarica
description: THE Philharmonia Hungarica under the direction of Reinhard Peters gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall. This is the group of Hungarian musicians who fled their country during the 1956 uprising and formed an orchestra. Some of them are still active in it, but now there also are some players who were children 20 years ago.

title: Graffiti, 141 Giant Eyes Along River Bank, Hint at Changing Japan
description: KYOTO, Japan  Katsuo Nakagawa was strolling along the famous wooded banks of the Kiyotaki River here one day admiring the bright autumn colors when, suddenly, he could not believe what he saw. There, staring back at him from the river were 141 giant eyes pink ones, white ones and black ones painted on rocks.

title: Amtrak Commissary, Unsanitary, Is Closed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)  Amtrak closed a commissary that supplies food to longhaul passenger trains after Federal inspectors found unsanitary conditions, a spokesman for the national rail passenger corporation said today.

title: Sound
description: THEORETICALLY, my records are in ruins by now, totally unlistenable and fit only for use as emergency Frisbees. Why? Because I listen to them, most often, on an automatic, multipleplay turntable  a changer. tend everybody knows that record changers chew up records. Audiophiles have been known to recoil in horror when they heard the telltale plop of one naked record falling down upon another in my system.

title: Bertrand Keeps Sailing Lead
description: CABO FRIO, Brazil, Nov. 9 (AP)John Bertrand of the United States maintained the top position today in the general standing of the Laser Class sailing championship after five races. in the sevenrace competition. Bertrand, the defending champion, finished second in today's race behind Cam Lewis of the United States. Lewis was 12th in the overall standing.

title: BUFFALO IS SURPRISED BY GRIFFIN'S MARGIN
description: State Senator James D. Griffin, the Mayor  elect of Buffalo, confounded everyone in that city by the margin of his victory over Arthur O. Eve, the Assemblyman who had hoped to become the first black Mayor of a major city in New York State.

title: Accused Policeman Pleads Insanity
description: The lawyer for Robert H. Torsney, a police officer accused of killing Randolph Evans, a 15yearold youth, on Thanksgiving night last year, told a jury yesterday that his client had, in fact, committed the murder,but that he had no control over what he was doing and no idea that what he was doing was wrong.

title: F.D,A, WARNS DIETERS ABOUT LIQUID PROTEIN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 9The Food and Drug Administration warned dieters today that the use of liquid protein food supplements could he extremely dangerous it cited the deaths of 16 women in recent months who had been taking the compounds to lose weight.

title: Canada Says the Mounted Police Opened and Copied Mail Illegally
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 9The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have opened and copied personal mail illegally since 1954, the Government said today.

title: In the Censor's Grip
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9In seventeenthcentury England no one could publish a book or paper unless he had submitted it to the royal authorities and been given a license. That was the classic form of prior censorship condemned by John Milton. The framers of the American Constitution had it in mind when they wrote the First Amendment to protect freedom of speech and press.

title: Big Step for Little Terrier
description: Earlier this year Ch. Badgewood The Huntress became the first dropeared Norwich Terrier bitch to win the national specialty in a terrier group. Earlier this week the little campaigner captured a second group at the Union County Show in Elizabeth, N. J. This was my swansong for the year. says Mrs. Philip S.P. Fell of Oyster Bay, L. I. the breeder, owner and handler of The Huntress. Today Mrs. Fell leaves New York to spend the winter in Florida.

title: School Custodians in Providence Are Ordered to Return to Work
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 9 (AP)A Superior Court judge ordered 281 striking school custodians back to school today, but classes remained closed after teachers refused to cross picket lines, cancelling classes for 20,000 students.

title: Why the Giants Don't Pass
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 9It is third down and 20. Bob Gibson, up in the press box, sends down a halfback draw. The play gains 5 yards, the Giants have to punt again and their fans boo.

title: Costikyan to Make It to City Hall as a Deputy
description: So eager was Edward M. Costikyan to find a mayoral candidate this year who could carry out his views, he ended up runhing for the job himself when no one seemed likely to do the Job as he saw fit.

title: Cellar in Albany Yields a Vintage Treasure
description: A collection of 19thcentury French wines, described as one of the most valuable ever discovered in the United States, has been found in the wine cellar of a famous old Dutch colonial mansion in Albany. The cellar had been sealed off for more than threequarters of a century.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHAPIRO CHARGED WITH CONSPIRACY
description: Morris A. Schapiro, the nation's largest dealer in bank securities, and his firm, M.A. Schapiro & Company, have been charged with being the hub of a secret and conspiratorial plan to accumulate and warehouse a controlling block of LITCO stock for sale to three Venezuelan buyers at a premium price of $30 a share.

title: U.S. Jury Convicts Mobsters Lawyer Of Evading Taxes
description: A Brooklyn lawyer who has defended many organizedcrime figures was convicted by a Federal court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of three counts of incometax evasion.

title: RISE REPORTED IN WEEK FOR HEATING OIL STOCKS
description: Inventories of distillate oil, used mainly for home heating purposes, rose 7.2 million barrels in the week ended Nov.4 to 255 million barrels, according to the latest supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute. Distillate stocks are running 22 million barrels ahead of the yearago period.

title: As Philippine Truce Fails, End of Moslem Revolt Appeais Far Off
description: ZAMBOANGA, PhilippinesAn upsurge In fighting between Moslem insurgents and Government troops in Mindanao has shattered an 11monthold ceasefire and created concern that the war is no closer to a solution than it was when it began five years ago.

title: Rains Continue to Disrupt Residents in New York; Carey Asks U.S. Aid for Those in Flooded Sections
description: Heavy rains continued to dampen and disrupt life throughout the New York metropolitan area yesterday. In northern New Jersey, state and local officials said they would seek Federal assistance for damages from Monday's and Tuesday's storm, already estimated at well over $75 million.

title: People and Business
description: White, Weld & Company, the investment banking and brokerage firm, announced yesterday that Frederick S. Wonham, its president and chief operating officer, had resigned. No reason was given.

title: Big Cross County Center In Westceheter Is Sold After a Long Litigation
description: YONKERS, N.Y.,Nov. 10 (UPI)The Cross County Shopping Centerthe owners of which assert it is one of the first, largest and most successful in the countryhas been sold to Leonard Marx, the developer, it was learned today.

title: Flying Nun Triumphs At Show in Toronto
description: TORONTO,Nov. 10  Madeline Mearns's Flying Nun defeated a strong field to capture the open jumper class today at the opening session of the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 11%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Department of Commerce reported today that total weekly retail store sales in the latest week was an estimated $13.95 billion, up 11 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.52 billion. Department store sales were about $1.52 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $1.37 billion.

title: U.N. Panel Urges Sports Boycott
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10A committee of the General Assembly adopted a report today that called on member countries of the United Nations to discontinue sports relations with those countries that practice apartheid.

title: As the World Turns
description: Looking ahead, even scientists fall into the cosmic trap of believing that virtually everything worth knowing is already knownthat only some details remain to be discovered. Looking back, we know this to be the ultimate human folly. Still, can we really accept the fact that we know as little as we do? The year 1977 should be memorably instructive on this point.

title: Money
description: Thursday, November 10, 1977

title: Sunbeam
description: Earnings of the Sunbeam Corporation in the quarter and six months ended Sept. 30 showed a sharp upturn, reflecting the excellent results of the domestic consumer products group, continued growth of the industrial and commercial groups and improvement in the international group.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For Opriods ended Sept. 30 unless, otherwiss, indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (0) overthecounter.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS Nov. 10 (AP)A legal effort to declare Ernest N. Morial ineligible for the city's mayoral runoff was rebuffed today.

title: Leningrad, Revolution's Cradle, Now Seems Rigid in Spirit
description: LENINGRADSixty years ago Nov. 7,the capital that Peter the Great built on the Baltic was alive with revolutionary ferment that swept in the age of Soviet power. Today the city named for Lenin is a Communist bastion of conservatismin architecture, in politics, in atmosphere.

title: ARTHUR LEVITT JR. NAMED AMEX CHIEF TO SUCCEED KOLTON
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., president of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., was elected yesterday by the board of governors of the American Stock Exchange as its fulltime chairman and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. PUBLISHERS SEND PLEA TO INDONESIAN ON WRITER
description: President Suharto of Indonesia has been urged by members of the Freedom to Publish Committee, of the Association of American Publishers, to investigate! the circumstances of the imprisonment of Pramoedya Atlanta Toer, a writer in penal exile on the small island of Buru.

title: Bridge:
description: MANILA, Nov. 10When the Far East Championships ended here today, the major titles had been won by India and Australia.

title: Ballet: An Illuminating Night With Agnes de Mille and Joffrey
description: THE STEALTHY rustle of history whispered unobtrusively through the City Center 55th Street Theater on Wednesday night. where the audience was nominally watching Agnes de Mille in something called Conversations About the Dance with the Joffrey Ballet. In fact that audience was privileged to be witness to the Goddess Terpsichore communing with one of her favorite prophets.

title: 3 Wounded in Gunfight Through Crowded IRT Train
description: Three persons, including a woman bystander, were shot and injured last night on a crowded Seventh Avenue IRT subway train as it roared south to Times Square from 72d Street.

title: Opera: Niobe Tears and All
description: FOUR YEARS AGO, the Clarion Music Society presented an opera by Agostino Steffani called Tassilone. The work was well received, and Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, Newell Jenkins and his group presented another Steffani opera, called Niobe, Regina di Tebe (1688), in its first American performance.

title: Vietnam Veterans and Elders Split by Difference in Values
description: When Tom Ambrose of Venice, Calif., came home from Vietnam, he joined the American Legion, following a path paved by millions of veterans since World War I. But after a year, he quit.

title: Music: Thomson, Satie And Calder at Beacon
description: IT WAS A journey into America's artistic past, though not so distant that some of the artists themselves could not be in attendance. Virgil Thomspon, preeminently, was there last night at the Beacon Theater to witness a concert performance of his Four Saints in Three Acts and a minimalist staging of Satie's Socrate that employed Mr. Thomson's English translation.

title: Pope Drops Penalty for a Remarriage After Divorce
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Pope Paul VI has agreed to lift the penalty of excommunication for American Roman Catholics who remarry after divorce, the United States National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced today.

title: Wild Elephants Didn't KeepThem Out
description: While African drums beat wildly in the background, Peter Beard, the Beautiful People's favorite photographeradventurer, greeted guests at bash in his honor Wednesday night and said he knew why so many of them had turned out.

title: Irwin Steig, at 76, Wrote Books On the Playing of Gin and Poker
description: Irwin Steig, author, artist and retired advertising and public relations director for the C. B. Dolge Company, Westport, Conn., died Tuesday in Point Pleasant Hospital, Point Pleasant Beach, N. J., after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 65 Glenn Avenue, Lakewood, N. J.

title: Cellar in Albany Yields a Vintage Treasure
description: A collection of 19thcentury French wines, described as one of the most valuable ever discovered in the United States, has been found in the wine cellar of a famous old Dutch colonial mansion in Albany. The cellar had been sealed off for more than threequarters of a century.

title: Michaels Angered by Todd and Jet Doctor
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 10An angered Coach Walt Michaels berated his quarterback, Richard Todd, in front of the Jets today, and also said he would fine the team physician for having admitted Todd to the hospital without first notifying the club.

title: Screen: Power and Nukes
description: THERE is a lot to be learned from the Film Forum's double bill on atomic power, and not all of it is about the subject at hand. The fortuitous pairing of The Last Resort, Dan Keller's documentary about the contested plan to build an atomic power plant in Seabrook, N.H., and More Nuclear Power Stations, a Danish film that examines the inner workings of an atomic plant outside Hamburg, teaches an interesting lesson about how to win an argument and how to lose one.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Rose To 204.1 From 203.1 a Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 204.1 from 203.1 last week.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
Andrew Mellon's Drawing Room Is the First Target as the Renovation of Capital Mansion Begins
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Donning a red hardhat and swinging a sledgehammer, James Biddle knocked down a flimsy partition today in what was once Andrew Mellon's elegant 40foot drawing room.

title: Slumping Celtics Send Havlicek, 37, to Bench
description: John Havlicek, 13 points short of passing Jerry West as the thirdleading scorer in National Basketball Association history, will not be in the starting lineup tonight when the Boston Celtics are hosts to the Buffalo Braves. In an

title: A Stolen 14thCentury Altarpiece Is Recovered and Suspect Is Held
description: A 14th  century Spanish altarpiece stolen in 1972 from a parish church in the Spanish province of Lerida was on temporary exhibition yesterdayin a conference room at the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Manhattan.

title: Provocation and Reprisal in Lebanon
description: President Carter could scarcely do otherwise, at his news conference yesterday, than urge the Arabs and Israelis not to allow a new cycle of provocation and reprisal across the Lebanese border to block the way a Geneva peace conference. Obstructing Geneva was undoubtedly the motive for the rocket attacks by Palestinian guerrillas, which killed three Israeli residents of Nahariya early this week.

title: World News Briefs
description: PANAMA, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Gen. Omar Torrijos, the Panamanian leader, invited seven United States senators to a fiesta today at his summer home in Los Santos to try to convince them to vote for the Panama Canal treaty.

title: Business Records
description: SOU1HERN DISTRICT Thursday, Nov. 10, 1977 Petition Filed By:

title: Patriarch David of Soviet Georgia; Head of Orthodox Church Was 74
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11The CatholicosPatriarch of the Georgian Orthodox Church, David V, has died at the age of 74, the press agency Tass reported today. It did not give the cause of death or say when it occurred. The funeral will be held next Tuesday.

title: Nervous Exhaustion Hospitalizes Indicted Pennsylvania Senator
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (UPI)State Senator Henry Cianfrani, who is under indictment on Federal charges, was admitted at Saint Luke's Hospital today suffering from nervous exhaustion.

title: Texas Gets Doc Medich
description: Dr. George Medich, taking time out from his duties at Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh, sold his pitching talents to the Texas Rangers yesterday for four years and slightly more than $1 million.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1977

title: Cornell's Ninth President Is Inaugurated
description: ITHACA, N.Y. Nov. 10A British educator with a reputation for keeping cool got the title here today that goes with the job he has been doing since August. The educator, Frank H. T. Rhodes, was sworn in as Cornell University's ninth president during ceremonies attended by 8.000 guests, including 27 other college presidents.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Remember the big apple, the cakewalk and the Susie Q? The choreographer Pepsi Bethel does, step by step. He has incorporated these and other popular dances of a bygone era into the repertory of his Authentic Jazz Theater Company, which goes on stage tonight at 7 at Rutgers University in Newark. Mr. Bethel's young troupe, a couple of generations removed from the big apple, is the vehicle for his driving ambition: to preserve authentic jazz dance, And effective these nine dancers are, according to Clive Barnes, New York Times dance critic, who has called their enthusiasm infectious and pronounced them worth seeing. The performance, sponsored by the Universal Jazz Coalition, will be in the Robeson Campus Center, 350 High Street. Admission is $2 (halfprice for students). From New York, take the No. 118 bus from the Port Authority Terminal to Pennsylvania Station in Newark: its a short taxi ride fromthere. Information: 924 5026.

title: Jewish Unit's Award Goes to Michael Burke
description: Michael Burke, president of Madison Square Garden, received the 1977 Human Relations Award of the American Jewish Committee at a testimonial dinner last night at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Steven Sheresky Marries Marcia Coker in New York
description: Marcia Coker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic T. Coker Jr. of Hemmingway and Myrtle Beach, S.C., was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Sheresky, son of Lyn Revson and Kenneth Sheresky, both of New York.

title: What's New in the Discotheques
description: THE NEWS from the discotheques is that touch dancing has gone the way of all flesh, and with it has gone selfcontrol. Idiosyncratic gyration is back, and to show it off like it's never been shown before, flamboyant decor, lighting, and special effects, are being offered by some of the newest, nattiest discos to ever flash laser lights or drop glitter on their clientele.

title: Brooklyn Tech Wanderers Ready For Its Semifinal Against Bayside
description: If I played football, I woudn't want to play for Brooklyn Tech. That's Joe Cuzzocrea talking and he doesn't play for anybody, he coaches Brooklyn Tech. Tomorrow, his Engineers meet Bayside in a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal game at Canarsie field at noon. Why Canarsie? That's what Cuzzocrea was talking about. Tech has no home field, it barely has a practice area. When the Engineers won a coin toss for the site selection, they picked Canarsie.

title: Insurance for HighRisk Early Days Of the Newborn Baby's Fragile Life
description: They're expecting a baby, so they're deeply engrossed in decorating a nursery, buying a layette, choosing a crib, a carriage, a changing table. They may he doing prepared childbirth exercises and perhaps even taking a course in parenting.

title: Violinist, 74, Still Going Strong
description: I used to stand In awe of people who played the violin late into life, says Joseph Fuchs, I do not any more.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: LOW MOODY'S RATING, COMPELS NEVI YORK TO CANCEL NOTE SALE
description: In a major blow to New York City's attempt at fiscal recovery, the city's underwriters abruptly canceled its longawaited sale of shortterm notes yesterday after Moody's Investor Service gave the offering its lowest possible investmentgrade credit rating.

title: MCA Plans to Add New Times to List
description: MCA Inc., which is already into such leisure time areas as TV, movies, records and books is about to acquire George A. Hirsch's fouryearold New Times, as the nucleus of a new magazine division.

title: N.Y. R. A. Seeking Return to Sunday Racing
description: The return to Sunday racing, after a year's hiatus, will he requested for 1978 by the New York Racing Association from the state's Racing and Wagering Board. The N.Y.R.A.'s board of directors, meeting yesterday, reported they were asking for Sunday programs to start on Jan. 22 and to last through July 23with two exceptions.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order cif DISi positions. Copyright 1377 by Daily Rating Forms. Ine.

title: The BurnsCarter Policy Rift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter's answers to economic questions at today's news conference suggested that some of the criticism of his policies by businessmen and their powerful friend in Washington, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, has registered.

title: The Hollow Promise of HumphreyHawkins
description: The socalled HumphreyHawkins Full Employment bill, which is about to be embraced by the White House, the Congressional Black Caucus and the nation's leading liberal politicians, is not the grand achievement of modern economic policy that its proponents proclaim. It is a gesture from a Government overly enchanted with symbols, a promise from a Government that should mind its promises, a flag for politicians to wave when next they need to demonstrate concern for the unemployed. It will not, however, solve the nation's unemployment problem.

title: Holland Tunnel, on Eve of 50th Birthday, Is Still Packing Them In
description: Fifty years ago this Saturday at 4:55 P.M. Calvin Coolidge pressed a golden telegraph key aboard his yacht Mayflower in the Potomac River. It was the same key that President Woodrow Wilson had used earlier to set off the final blast that opened the Panama Canal.

title: SUSPECT, 19, SEIZED IN SUBWAY SLAYING
description: A muscular Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday in the murder of a subwaystation porter, less than 36 hours after the slaying.

title: Aleksei I. Lukovets, Soviet Editor; Led the Daily Sovetskaya Rossiya
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10(Reuters)Aleksei I. Lukovets, chief editor of the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya, has died at 56, Pravda reported today.

title: Vatican Denounces Bombing
description: ROME, Nov. 10The Vatican newspaper published an editorial today condemning the Israeli bombing of southern Lebanon as amounting to outright slaughter.

title: Events and Openings
description: THAT OBSCURE OBJECT OF DESIRE, a F??? starring Fernando Rey, as the colombia i th???

title: Deaths
description: BERARDPhilippe, In Paris, France on November 2, 1977; beloved husband of Frederica Stevens of New York; stepfather of Mrs. Robert W. Barney, Mrs. Nicholas LeRoy King, Mme. JeanPaul Angles, and Mr. Philip Hone Auerbach. Funeral held November 7, Eglise Reformee, rue Cortambert, Paris.

title: Pentagon Chief Tentatively Backs Budget Rise to $130 Billion in 79
description: WASHINGTON,Nov, 10 Defense Secretary Harold Brown has tentatively approved a defense budget of at least $130 billion for the next fiscal year. The figure is several billion dollars more than Congress and defense analysts had expected.

title: Credit Suisse Levy Set at $28 Million
description: GENEVA, Nov. 10The Swiss National Bank today ordered Credit Suisse to pay the Government $28 million in negative interest on funds that its scandalridden branch at Chiasso is said to have failed to collect from foreign depositors.

title: Trainmen Threaten a Strike on L.I.R.R. on Monday
description: Long Island Rail Road conductors and trainmen said several hours after contract talks broke off yesterday that they would strike at one minute past midnight on Monday morning.

title: BERME WILL ACCEPT CARTER'S JOB OFFER
description: Mayor Beame has decided to accept President Carter's offer of the chairmanship of the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations and is scheduled to meet with Mr. Carter today in Washington to accept formally the parttime, unsalaried post

title: President Says He's Not a Critic Of Burns Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter said today that he had never had any disagreements on economic policy with Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and that he was not inclined to criticize Dr. Burns's recent actions, which have induced in creases in interest rates.

title: Issue and Debate
description: My expectation is that we will have a successful conclusion of the negotiations on a compromise with the Congressional sponsore of the HumphreyHawkins full employment bill, President Carter said yesterday, adding: And then the bill will be presented to the Congress with my endorsement.

title: Carter Finding Power Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 10It is not only Congress but also the White House mice that have been teaching Jimmy Carter the limits of Presidential power.

title: U.S. to Enforce Irrigated Land Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Interior Sec. retary Cecil D Andrus said today that he would not enforce Hie 160acreperperson limitation on federally irrigated lands before next March.

title: The 4:40 Ferry To S.I. Becomes Poetry Passage
description: It was an unlikely time and place for a poetry readingthe 4:40 P.M. ferryboat to Staten Island, crowded with commuters, many of them tired and soggy after a rainy day's work in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Bowl Prospect Stirs Hopes of 90 Colgate
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 10Mayor Robert Palmiter lives in Andy Kerr's house just two doors east of the Colgate Inn. The mayor knows what everyone else in this village knowsno matter how long Palmiter serves as mayor of Hamilton he will be living in Andy Kerr's house and not in the mayor's house.

title: Market Place
description: In February 1976, the Williams Inference Service informed its clients that a major zinc producer had reduced prices at a time when demand was picking up. This move. smacked of corporate pricecutting as a means of increasing market share and raised the prospect that other basic industrial companies soon might follow suit.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The board of directors of the Eastman Kodak Company voted yesterday to pay a special dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to the regular quar?erly dividend of 40 cents a share.

title: Clash at SouthWest Africa
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 10 (AP)South African soldiers killed 10 black guerrillas in what was called retaliation for a rocket and machinegun attack yesterday on SouthWest Africa's border with Angola, the military command announced today. It said there were no South African losses.

title: Music to Meet Someone Nice To
description: 1 don't go bananas over chamber music, but this is something different from the usualdances at a temple, or resorts, a middleaged woman in the audience remarked.

title: MONEY SUPPLY FALLS $34 BILLION IN WEEK, SPURRING BOND SURGE
description: Slower Rate of Monetary Growth Approaches Fed's 6.5% Goal Interest Levels Decline

title: At the Movies
description: SO many couples are separating, said Genevieve Buiold, briefly but genuinely distressed. I find this terribly disturbing. What I'd like to do is give a push for people staying together, for not disrupting the harmony of the family. These days, I'm more and more profamily.

title: POLICE INCREASE EFFORTS TO CATCH BROOKLYN RAPIST
description: The police have intensified their efforts to capture a young rapist who is believed to have assaulted a score of women in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn in the last 15 months.

title: Lebanese Deny Their Village Was Military Site
description: AZZIYE, Lebanon, Nov. 10Dozens of survivors of the Israeli air raid yesterday on this village denied today that there had been any military targets here, asserting that Azziye was nothing more than a modest farm center.

title: Golden Years at Central Plaza
description: The Central Plaza. the venerable fivestory building at Second Avenue and Seventh Street, which has, at various times, been a center for kosher catering, jazz and television, will celebrate its 50th anniversary Sunday by taking an affectionate look at its past while it makes a proud display of its present use as New York University's School of the Arts.

title: Many Homes Lacked Insurance, Easy to Obtain, in Recent Floods
description: TRENTON, Nov. 10  Hundreds of homes damaged by floods in New Jersey in the last two days were not covered by flood insurance, although it is available in almost every town in the state and at a relatively low cost.

title: CARTER DENIES HELMS WON BADGE OF HONOR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter bluntly took issue today with a statement by Richard Helms that it was no disgrace for him to have been convicted of telling less than the truth to a Senate committee.

title: The Creativity of Burrows, the Drama of de la Renta
description: Add another name to the success stories of the spring fashion season. Stephen Burrows scored with his collection for Pat Tennant shown at Henri Bendel's yesterday. The high spot was a group of dresses in floating chiffon, an idiom that can easily become banal.

title: Record Set in Shooting
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)Loner Wigger of Carter, Mont., established a world record today in the PanAmerican shooting championships with 1,159 points in free rifle at 300 meters. Officials said Wigger surpassed the record of 1,157 points set in 1968 by Gary Anderson of Washington.

title: Connecticut Seeks Tune to Strike The Right Chord as the State Song
description: HARTFORD,Nov. 10Before a small but critical audience of halfadozen Connecticut legislators, 20 proposed state anthems were played in the Capitol todayrobust and stirring marches, solemn hymns, ballads, even a number that had the unmistakable stamp of an old madrigal.

title: CHURCH GROUP ACTS OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: The National Council of Churches called upon its 30 constituent denominations yesterday to undertake to withdraw all their funds from financial institutions that deal with the Government of South Africa or businesses there.

title: Nancy Hanks Honored for Arts Role
description: That segment of the world of arts and culture that is centered in New York gathered last night at the Essex House to bless Nancy Hanks, a sort of return blessing for those that flowed from Washington during her eightyear term as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: 2 SIDES IN DOCK STRIKE MAY NEGOTIATE TODAY
description: The bargaining committees of striking longshoremen and their employers are expected to meet in Manhattan today for their first top level negotiating session in nearly three weeks.

title: The NewTime Religion
description: The recent suspension of two Long Island parishes from the American Lutheran Church for allegedly subordinating the Christian gospel to Jewish religious and social customs underscores a significant aspect of the present religious climate. That is the prevalence of hypenated forms of faith whereby adherents of one tradition take on additional spiritual identities.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Nov. 12

title: BYRNE IS COMMUTING TEACHER SENTENCES
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10Governor Byrne announced tonight to the New Jersey Education Association that he was commuting the sentences of 107 Matawan teachers and school secretaries who had been scheduled to start serving sevenday jail terms Wednesday for ignoring a court order to end their strike last month and return to work.

title: PRICES MOVE AHEAD IN WHEAT FUTURES
description: Wheat futures advanced, while corn and soybeans prices finished mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited the latest Government crop report released ater the close of trading.

title: Broadway
description: ALFRED DELIAGRE JR. is going to produce again, which is a very nice thing because Central Casting could not come up with any one who looks mcne the way a producer should look than does Mr. de Liagre: fastidious and elegant, with even the Legion of Honor in his lapel. Mr. de Liagre has produced, directed or coproduced 33 shows, and now, along with Roger Stevens, who is no sprite, either, he will produce Deathtrap, a murder mystery by Ira Levin. It will be directed by Robert Moore, who directed, among other things, The Boys in the Band, Promises, Promises and My Fat Friend, but who lately has been doing movies, and it will go into rehearsal at the end of the year. Then it opens at the Wilbur Theater in Boston on Jan. 23, and comes here in the middle of February.

title: Roosa Differs With Brimmer On Fed's Effort
description: WASHINGTON (AP)Two former Government officials, both mentioned as possible new heads of the Federal Reserve Board, gave Congress opposing views today of the monetary agency's performance.

title: The U.N. Today
Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: WEEK'S CAR PRODUCTION IS EXPECTED TO DECLINE
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP)Fewer cars will roll off the assembly lines this week because of temporary shutdowns of four auto assembly plants.

title: Now In New York
description: I was never really aware of the Elvis Presley mystique and the tremendous impact Elvis had on so many people till last weekend when I popped into the Riverboat to catch the Boat's salute to Elvis. Young Gregg Peters does a most accurate job of recreating the Elvis legend, right down to the glittering costuming. During the performance Gregg throws hundreds of scarves to the adoring audience Such hysteria  the gals were looking to yank him down from the stage  Gregg's manager had hire two bodyguards to protect the kid. To see the clamor for Elvis, you'd hardly know that Riverboat is also presenting a salute to the Jazz great, Louis Satchmo Armstrong, too. These twin salutes have been extended till November 19th. It's a helluva deal  No increase in Riverboat's. night club package of Steak, Unlimited Booze, Dancing, and the aforementioned Elvis Mania and Satchmo Salute. The whole deal (all inclusive) just costs you $11.95 per person plus the mini music charge Riverboat is located in the base of the Empire State Building and is New York's largest cabaretnightclub.

title: Art: The New Museum Where Small Is Beautiful
description: MANY a great museum has begun small. Visitors to Oxford, England, can still see the stately little town house in which the Ashmolean Museum was founded more than 300 years ago. Many an invaluable museum has stayed small, moreover. The Frick in New York, the Phillips Gallery in Washington, the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Bostonwho would wish them larger? Small is beautiful, in their case, and even if it were possible for them to grow bigger we should dread the result.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT PHILADELPHIA

title: CARTER URGES ARABS TO JOIN WITH EGYPT AND GO TO GENEVA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter, citing an everpresent danger of renewed war in the Middle East, urged today that the Arab countries follow Egypt's example and agree to an immediate convening of a Geneva peace conference with Israel, without quibbling anymore over procedural questions.

title: U.S. Ski Team Feted Twice
description: Members of the United States Alpine and Nordic ski teams were honored at a luncheon held by Ski Industries America yesterday at the Copacahana and at the annual fundraising dinner at the Hotel Pierre last night. The dinner produces about $100,000 each year for the ski team fund, which supports the squad's international activities as well as racing clinics and training camps in the United States.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Light Cavalry Overture, Suppe; Evening in the Country, Bartok; Concerto for 2 Violins, Vivaldi; La Puerta del Vino, Debussy; Crown Diamonds Overture, Auber; Motet, Quand je parti de mamie, Anon.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: REARRANGED chronologically, the family of Don Corleone returns to NBC tomorrow at 9 P.M. in the form of Mario Puzo's The Godfather: The Complete Novel for Television. Francis Ford Coppola's two films, The Godfather and The Godfather, Part II, have been reedited by Barry Malkin for marathon television presentation of two hours on Saturday, Sunday and Monday, with a final blast of three hours on Tuesday.

title: LOW MOODY'S RATING COMPELS NEW YORK TO CANCEL NOTE SALE
description: In a major blow to New York City's attempt at fiscal recovery, the city's underwriters abruptly canceled its longawaited sale of shortterm notes yesterday after Moody's Investor Service gave the offering its lowest possible investmentgrade credit rating.

title: Protest for Inquiry In Teamster Death Disrupts San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 10Thousands of union members staged a march that paralyzed the public bus system and virtually all truck traffic here today.

title: Indiana Commuters, Train Buffs and DayTrippers Think They Can Save Little Engine That Couldn't
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Nov. 10A dirtywindowed, shabby, antiquated commuter train may be an odd place to throw parties, but clowns, a juggler, and wine have become a regular part of the weekend scene on the South Shore Railroad line between Chicago and South Bend, Ind.

title: Opportune Foes for Giants and Jets
description: The Giants and the Jets take on last year's floundering expansion teams, Tampa Bay and Seattle on Sunday and the timing is right because the Giants have lost their offense and the Jets their quarterback, Richard Todd. Both local teams are favored. The GiantsBuccaneers game from Tampa will be televised by Channel 2 starting at 1 P.M., and Channel 4 will telecast Cincinnati at Minnesota, starting at 4 P.M., while the Monday night game will be St. Louis at Dallas, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Previews of all games follow with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: Cornell Dean Informs Rhodes He'll Resign
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10In a letter that Frank H. T. Rhodes, newly sworn president of Cornell will receive tomorrow morning, Harry Levin, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, has indicated that he will resign, it was learned late today.

title: Art: Asger Jorn, Prisoner of Time
description: THE Danish painter Asger Jorn (191473) was one of the more robustious figures to emerge on the European art scene in the years following World War II. First, in the period 194851 as a founding member of the Cobra group (an alliance of Danish, Belgian and Dutch painters), and then as one of those artists whose work regularly turned up at the big International exibitions, which in the 1950's and 60's still had the power to make an artist's reputation, Jorn acquired the uneasy celebrity of a rebel more and more adored by the establishment. Although never so wellknown in this country as in EuropeAmerican critics have paid him little attention he nonetheless came to be accepted as one of the fixtures of postwar art in Europe.

title: Advertising
description: For a person in the print media,it was the kind of a morning that could permanently fog your rosecolored glasses,

title: Diplomats in Cairo Report U.S. Shift on Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, Nov. 10The Carter Adminis tration has suggested some subtle but potentially significant modifications in its tentative formula for convening a new Middle East peace conference at Geneva, according to diplomatic sources here who have followed the negotiations.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: I.C.C. Grants Railroads a 5% Rise In Freight Rates, 11th Since 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Intertate Commerce Commission granted a reight rate increase to the nation's railoads today that the agency said could amount to a yearly revenue increase of nearly $1 billion.

title: Rains Continue to Disrupt State; Damages Estimated at $75 Million
description: Heavy rains continued to dampen and disrupt life throughout the New York metropolitan area yesterday. In northern New Jersey, state and local officials said they would seek Federal assistance for damages from Monday's and Tuesday's storm, already estimated at well over $75 million.

title: Cynthia Gregory to Leave Ballet Theater After Being Back a Year
description: Cynthia Gregory, the American Ballet Theater star who returned to the company a year ago, after a year's absence, said yesterday that she was resigning again from the company.

title: Yale's Last Hurdle to Ivy Title (Harvard) Bigger Than Statistics Show
description: Yale leads the Ivy League in total offense, total defense and scoring and Harvard ranks seventh in total defense, but observers of the Ancient Eight are wont to disregard statistics when The Game commences, Tomorrow in the Yale Bowl, before a crowd of 60,000 or more, Yale will try to win the league championship outright while Harvard, Brown and Dartmouth attempt to gain a onefourth share of the title.

title: 2 Reconvicted in Seabrook. N.H., Nuclear Protest
description: EXETER, N.H., Nov. 10The first of the 1,414 demonstrators arrested last spring at the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant site began here this week to appeal their preliminary convictions in what promises to be a year or more of individual jury trials.

title: 2 Germanys Wage a TugofWar Over 8 Rare Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10As World War 11 drew to a close, Nazi officials who feared destruction of priceless art works and other treasures in Berlin ar ranged to hide some extremely rare stamps from the Imperial Postal Museum, along with other valuables, in the shaft of a salt mine in Saxony.

title: Pop: A King Recalled
description: JOHNNY HARTMAN, who is singing songs associated with Nat (King) Cole in a tribute to the late singer that will continue for the next three weeks at Michael's Pub. 211 East 55th Street,sums up the difficult situation in which he finds himself in his introduction to Mona Lisa.

title: Books of The Times
description: IF, says Jeff Greenfield, there is one consistently dishonest element in every situation comedy, no niatter how realistic, how bold, how relevant or controversial it may be, it is that no one in a situation comedy is isolated, alone, atomized. In a country where family bonds are dissolving, where broken marriages are increasing almost geometrically, and where the trend of living alone is becoming an important national fact of life, the world of the situation comedy depicts strong bonds between friends, coworkers and family. No one sits home at night watching television; the most pervasive habit in American life today usually goes unrecorded in even the most realistic comedies because it is not funny.

title: The New York Post Is Rejoining Publishers Association for City
description: The New York Post has rejoined the Publishers Association of New York City, which represents the management of the city's major daily newspapers.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Nov. 10, 1977

title: 24 Young Inmates At Rikers Capture Van in Escape Try
description: Twentyfour teenaged inmates of the Adolescent Reception and Detention Center on Rikers Island commandeered a prison van in an unsuccessful escape. attempt from the island last night. Several guards were injured, including the van's driver, who was taken to the hos, pital in serious condition.

title: Now, It Is The Cities Turn
description: In gaining its new Mayor, New York is losing one of its most effective Representatives in the Congress  a strategic loss that comes just at the moment when a new national approach to this and other American cities is crucial to their survival.

title: Robot Phone Stirs Jitters And Attempts to Corral It
description: It seemed like a normal human reaction. The robot telephone had to be stopped.

title: Paying a Debt to (Some) Veterans
description: New York and 46 other states observe Veterans Day today, a fit time to remember that the most recent veterans, of Vietnam, have encountered indifference and even hostility since their return. As one of their spokesmen puts it, When World War II was over, a veteran would walk into a bar and everybody would buy him a drink. When the Korean War ended, he had to buy his own drink. When the Vietnam War was over, he had to buy everybody else in the house a drink. And even the Government, which sent him to Vietnam and should presumably be grateful, has been surprisingly slow to help him readjust.

title: Pro Football Statistics
Another Election Drive Begins: The Race for Koch's House Seat
description: With one election campaign barely ended, another began yesterday as the first of a half dozen expected candidates started running for Mayorelect Edward I. Koch's seat in the House of Representatives nearly two months before he will vacate it.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
CORRECTION
description: The new annual rate on dividends of CBS Inc. was reported incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The new rate is $2.40.

title: Publishing: Boll and Grass
description: WEST BERLIN

title: Fort Hood Commander Named
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Lieut. Gen. Marvin D. Fuller, the Army's Inspector General, was named today to become commanding general of the III Corp and Fort Hood, Tex. He will replace Lieut. Gen. Robert Shoemaker, who will become deputy commander of the Forces Command at Fort McPherson, Atlanta. No date was given for the changeover.

title: Ban on Radioactive Waste Urged
description: Shipping radioactive wastes through New York City could result in 10,000 immediate deaths in case of accident and more than a million latent cancer fatalities, Dr. Leonard Solon, a city health department official, said at a Federal hearing yesterday on an effort to resume such shipments.

title: VETERANS DAY
description: Schools, banks and most city and state offices in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day, while post offices, the stock markets and most commodities exchanges will remain open. Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations in New York City will be suspended.

title: 626 BLACKS SEIZED IN SOUTH AFRICA RAID
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 10The police arrested 626 blacks, including 198 schoolchildren, in a housetohouse sweep through the AtteridgevilleFaulsville black township near Pretoria today.

title: IsraelLebanon Border Quiet Again
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10The IsraeliLebanese border was calm today following the bombing yesterday by Israeli jets of a coastal area in southern Lebanon.

title: Red Army Suspects Held
description: AMSTERDAM, Friday Nov. 11 (AP)The police seriously wounded and captured two suspected Red Army Faction terrorists in a gunbattle in suburban Amsterdam. authorities said today.

title: Music: Deft Piano Effort by Bennett Lerner
description: BENNETT LERNER is a young pianist who has performed with the Group for Contemporary Music and studied with Claudio Arrau, which should indicate the breadth of his musical concerns. Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, he played a typical Arrau program, in fact, dealing only with three 19thcentury Romantics and culminating in Schumann's Davidsbiindlertanze, a specialty of the Chilean artist.

title: CARTER URGES ARABS TO JOIN WITH EGYPT AND GO TO GENEVA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter, citing an everpresent danger of renewed war in the ?Middle East, urged today that the Arab countries follow Egypt's example and agree to an immediate convening of a Geneva peace conference with Israel, without quibbling anymore over procedural questions.

title: Austrian Businessman Kidnapped
description: VIENNA, Nov. 10A wealthy 74yearold businessman was kidnapped near his suburban home late last night, and a note found in his car demanded a ransom of $3.1 million. The note said no political motives were involved.

title: Canada Confirms Widespread BreakIns by Mounties
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 10The Government said today that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police had been conducting raids on private premises at least since the middle of 1950.

title: JOB RECLASSIFYING SET IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Thirty thousand New York City clerical workers were given new job classifications yesterday as part of the city's efforts to have more flexibility in moving its employees around for greater efficiency.

title: Redgrave Defends P.L.O. Film
description: Vanessa Redgrave yesterday denounced opponents of the antiIsraeli documentary film she made in support of the Palestine Liberation Organization, maintaining that it was important that the Arab view he heard.

title: Opera: Met Offers Solid Traviata
description: THE METROPOLITAN Opera's first performance this season of Verdi's La Traviata was an example of smooth professionalism that was wholly admirable and not to be dismissed lightly. Everything was done very well; the composer was decently served. What was missing was the spark of personality anywhere, on stage or in the pit, but then that is a commodity that is hard to come by at any time.

title: 626 BLACKS SEIZED IN SOUTH AFRICA RAID
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 10The police arrested 626 blacks, including 198 schoolchildren, in a housetohouse sweep through the AtteridgevilleFaulsville black township near Pretoria today.

title: The Pop Life
description: ONE HEARS A LOT about hype in the world of rockandroll, but ultimately every act has to submit its wares to the public and be judged accordingly. This is a twostage process, involving both records and live performances. With the release on Warner Brothers of the Sex Pistol's first album, Never Mind the Bollocks. Here's the Sex Pistols, the most writtenabout but unknown band in the world can be easily heard at last.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets for Joseph Fuchs's Carnegie Hall recital at 8 P.M. Sunday are available at $10. $7.50, $6, $5, and $4. They may be purchased at the Carnegie Hall box office, or by telephone through Chargit, 2397177.

title: SENATE INQUIRY ENDS ON GENETIC RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Environmentalists testifying before a Senate subcommittee today called for strict regulation and control of research on recombinant DNA, or genesplicing, and preservation of state and local freedom to draft even stricter rules.

title: Koch to Seek End of Water Board
description: Mayorelect Edward I. Koch said yesterday he would ask the State Legislature to abolish the New York City Board of Water Supply, whose three Commissioners are among the city's best paid parttime employees.

title: Management
description: The nation's 600 largest companies transferred almost 100,000 employees last year, about 10 percent more than in 1975, thanks to an improving economy.

title: FORD SETS CHANGES AT NORTHERN DIVISION
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10The Ford Motor Company announced today a major reorganization of its North American Automotive division and the appointment of three new vice presidents, raising the number of company officials at that level to 44.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses the growing interest of Americans in owning goldalmost three years after it became legal. Although activity in the gold markets here is still not large in comparison with that for other avenues of investment, it is a significant segment that is growing steadily. Page D5.

title: About Real Estate
description: HARRISON, N.Y.The Prudential Insurance Company has begun to shatter pieces of the Westchester rock in site clearance for its first officeconstruction Droiect in the county.

title: Yonkers Teacher Pact Tilts Budget
description: YONKERS, Nov. 10The Emergency Financial Control Board warned city officials today that their current budget could not accommodate the labor settlement that ended a bitter threeandahalfweek teachers strike early last month

title: Mosso and Morgan Are Named To Accounting Standards Board
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the privatesector body that sets the accounting rules for corporate financial reports, announced yesterday, after a sixmonth search, that it had filled two of the three $125,000ayear vacancies coming up on its sevenperson board.

title: Merrill Fined $1.6 Million by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured and levied a $1.6 million fine against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the world's largest stock brokerage house.

title: VETERANS DAY
description: Schools, banks and most city and state offices in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day, while post offices, the stock markets and most commodities exchanges will remain open Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations in New York City will be suspended.

title: Pentagon Chief Tentatively Backs Higher Budget of $130.5 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Defense Secretary Harold Brown has tentatively approved a defense budget of at least $130 billion for the next fiscal year. The figure is several billion dollars more than Congress and defense analysts had expected.

title: Koch's Narrowed Win
description: The real story of the mayoral election is not so much that Edward I. Koch won but that his margin of victory was so small. Mr. Koch, who began the generalelection campaign with a 30 percent lead in the polls, sank to as low as 4 percent last weekend and managed to win by only relatively narrow 50 percent to 42 percent margin over Mario Cuomo.

title: EXPOLICE OFFICIAL GUILTY OF PERJURY
description: Adam Butcher, a retired deputy police inspector, was convicted yesterday of lying to a grand jury when he denied sharing in bribes regularly collected from gamblers in Harlem or knowing that some fellow officers had been corrupt.

title: Soviet Foreign Trade Chief Meets With Carter on Economic Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)President Carter today met with the Soviet Foreign Trade Minister. Nilcolai S. Patolichev, to discuss ways of strengthening economic ties between the two countries.

title: Women's Foot Race Set For Central Park
description: A fourmile run for women through Central Park, from West 72d Street to East 103d Street, will take place tomorrow, rain or shine, at noon. Hundreds of women are expected to take part in the race sponsored by the Perrier Mineral Water Company, the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union (A.A.U.) Women's Long Distance Runing Association and the Road Runners Club of New York. The runners will start near the Daniel Webster statue at West Drive and 72d Street, cross the park to the East Drive and continue up the East Drive to 103d Street, then turn and cross the park to the West Drive and return on the West Drive back to the starting point.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state grand jury yesterday indicted five men on stolenproperty charges in the first case stemming from project Alpha, a joint investigation of the North Jersey underworld by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the state police.

title: Books: Watching Our Words
description: THEODORE M. BERNSTEIN'S new hook, culled from his syndicated newspaper columns, is part manual of correct usage aim part excursion into word origins and language changes. It is all designed to help the reader reach the right word. The matter is serious, but the tone is lighthearted. Small jokes, murderous puns and witty turns of phrase make the hook a pleasure to browse in. (It's all right to end a sentence with a preposition.)

title: Health Insurance For Children
description: The authorities stressed the following suggestions on health insurance for children:

title: U.S. Raises Corn Crop Estimate 1%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that the nation's corn harvest, based on surveys Nov. 1, was expected to be 1 percent more than the 6.3 billion bushels forecast a month ago.

title: Who will remember, passing through this gate, The unheroic dead who fed the guns? Who shall absolve the foulness of their fateThose doomed, conscripted, unvictorious ones?
description: PRINCETON, N.J.We Americans are an optithistic lot, fond of facing a cheery future. Except fo'r a Bicentennial now and then, we don't care much far retrospection, especially where it is likely to shake us up. Not for us such grim exercises as the candlelight pilgrimage to the bonehouse at Verdun or watching the Queen all in black placing her wreath at the Cenotaph.

title: Stage: Darrow vs. Bryan Again
description: SEVERAL YEARS AGO the Joseph Jefferson Theater Company surveyed its audience to find out what plays it most wanted to see. According to Cathy Roskam, the company's artistic director, Inherit the Wind was at the top of the list. Responsive to its audience, this small, ambitious, neighborhood theater has opened the season with Inherit the Wind.

title: Soviet Sentences 2 Hijackers
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (AP)Two men who hijacked a Soviet airliner to Finland in July but fell asleep during negotiations on their demands have been sentenced to prison terms of 15 and 8 years by a Leningrad court, the official Soviet press agency announced today.

title: Restaurants
description: DURING the last 22 years, the Italian Pavilion on 55th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas has remained one of the city's more consistently dependable restaurants, offering stylish North Italian cooking with a few southern classics for good measure. Although recent visits indicate that the bloom is slightly off the rose, the Italian Pavilion for the most part still does a very good job on its most popular dishes, especially in the categories of pasta, meat and fish.

title: Steve Cady
description: If we'd got word on it, says the $2 horseplayer in the Aqueduct grandstand, we'd have sent the money in. Right, Charlie? His older companion nods his head as the speaker continues. They kept it to themselves. Right Charlie? Charlie nods his head again, and says Right. They kept it in the family. Who d'ya like in the next race? So much for the impact that New York racing's CinzanoLebon ringer scandal may have had on the average horseplayer. if

title: Islanders Scoring
description: First period1, Monreal, Lambert 2 (Mondo?), 6.33. 2. ? Montrea?, ? ? 8 (????? Lemaire), 6 37, Penalities Gainey, (? ?) Nystrom (4:11). D.Potvin. (8 17); Chartaw, (13:43); Lewis, (13 43).

title: Mime: Houle and Wibaux
description: BERT HOULE, an American and Sophie Wibaux, a French woman studied mime together with Etienne Decroux in Paris. Now based in St. Louis, they have come to New York for an engagement through Sunday afternoon at the Roundabout Theater, 333 West 23d Street.

title: Democrat Loses in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 10Ruth L. Sims, a Democrat who had apparently been elected First Selectman here Tuesday, lost by one vote in an official recount today. The winner in the recount was Rupert Vernon, the incumbent Republican. Today's tally was 8,830 to 8,829 in favor of Mr. Vernon, compared with the earlier fourvote margin for Mrs. Sims.

title: The BurnsCarter Policy Rift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter's answers to economic questions at today's news conference suggested that some of the criticism of his policies by businessmen and their powerful friend in Washington, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Arthur F. Burns, has registered.

title: BOLIVIANS ADVANCE DATE OF ELECTIONS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 10President Hugo Banzer Surez announced last night that the armed forces would restore constitutional government next year.

title: AN INTERIM CONSTITUTION ANNOUNCED IN THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 (Reuters) Thailand's military rulers announced today steps toward elections next year and said that until then the country would be run by a Government backed by the armed forces.

title: CORRECTION
description: The new annual rate on dividends of CBS Inc. was reported incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The new rate is $2.40.

title: Lodi Wading Out of Worst Flood in Years
description: LODI, N.J., Nov. 10For someone who was down to his last pair of shoes the rubber boots he had pulled on before wading away f ormhls Chestnut Street home Tuesday nightEd Jacobs was remarkably philosophical tonight as he surveyed the damage caused by the rampaging waters of the Saddle River in what Lodi officials called the worst flood ever to strike this Bergen County community.

title: Art: The Plight Of the Portrait
description: To figurative painters laboring in the shadow cast by abstraction, getting a likeness is incidental to the making of a work of art. More than any other genre, portraiture has become a ritual battle between artist and patron, which, in the name of a higher esthetic. the artist must win. As a result of this, together with other, more complex social causeportraiture has been in a decline for the better part of the century. The majority of the artists specializing in it at best mediocre craftsmen.

title: Marjorie Lynch Dies; ExU.S. Aide
description: TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 10 (AP)Marjorie Lynch, former Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is dead at the age of 57.

title: 3 Youths Wound Italian Executive; Leftist Group Takes Responsibility
description: TURIN, Italy, Nov. 10 (AP)Three youths shot a Fiat executive, Piero Osella, in the legs today.

title: Scaling the Heights of Wall St.
description: Some five weeks ago, Arthur Levitt Jr. was alone in the wilds of Cataract Canyon in Idaho, practicing survival among the mountain lions and rattlesnakes. Yesterday, back in a business suit. Mr. Levitt was in his more familiar Wall Street haunts where he has not only been surviving but moving rapidly to the topas evidenced by his appointment to be chairman and chief executive officer of the American Stock Exchange.

title: Dollar Up in Europe, Down in New York; Gold Loses Ground
description: The dollar eased against maior currencies in New York foreign exchange trading yesterday after scoring sharp acrosstheboard gains the previous session; in trading centers abroad, results were mixed, The Associated Press reported.

title: Rockwell Net Up 15.6% for Quarter
description: The Rockwell International Corporation reported yesterday increases of 15.6 percent for fourthquarter net income and 17.9 percent for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

title: Television
173,714 Datsuns Are Recalled For Flaws In Emission System
description: CARSON, Calif., Nov. 10 (UPI)Nissan USA said today it was voluntarily recalling 173,714 of its 1977 Datsun models to correct two potential emission problems.

title: Harmony Goal After Election
description: TRENTON, Nov. 10When Governor Byrne arrived at the State House yester day for the first time after his impressive reelection victory, he was applauded by dozens of capitol employees in the parking lot.

title: A1 Capp, Harbinger of the Age of Irreverence, Gives Up Cartoons but Not Irascibility
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  He wasn't Shakespeare, he wasn't even Milton, but in the last 40 years Alfred Gerald Caplin made quite name for himself as Al Capp. Has he not been compared to Rabelais, to Swift, to Mark Twain? Did John Steinbeck not proclaim him the best satirist since Sterne, worthy of Nobel Prize?

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Thursday, November 10, 1977

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: It will soon be three years since the right to own and hold gold legally was restored to American citizens, but only recently has their interest begun to approach the proportions that proponents of the authorization had predicted early in this decade. That suggests that an increasing number of investors in this country think there is more economic trouble ahead. And it has stirred concern among Government and private monetary officials over the possible implications for inflation and the international status of the dollar.

title: Lodi, N.J., Residents Wade Out Of Worst Flood It Had in Years
description: LODI, N.J.. Nov. 10For someone who was down to his last pair of shoes the rubber boots he had pulled on before wading away from his Chestnut Street home Tuesday nightEd Jacobs was remarkably philosophical tonight as he surveyed the damage caused by the rampaging waters of the Saddle River in what Loth officials called the worst flood ever to strike this Bergen County community.

title: Rescuers Look for Victims
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10 (AP)Lebanese and Palestinian searchers dug deeper today into the rubble left by raiding Israeli planes and the Lebanese Government said that death toll from the raid had risen above 100.

title: Coffee Groups Quietly Influence U.S. Price Pacts, House Unit Told
description: For more than 15 years, the American coffee industry has maintained an influential and largely unpublicized position close to the United States Government officials who negotiate international coffee agreements, according to documents obtained by a House subcommittee.

title: Koch Asks Scoppetta for Inquiry Into Smear Attempt
description: Mayorelect Edward I. Koch yesterday called on the city's Commissioner of Investigation, Nicholas Scoppetta, to inquire into allegations that the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said he had information damaging to Mr. Koch.

title: Al Capp, Harbinger of the Age of Irreverence, Gives Up Cartoons but Not Irascibility
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  He wasn't Shakespeare, he wasn't even Milton, but in the last 40 years Alfred Gerald Caplin made quite a name for himself as Al Capp. Has he not been compared to Rabelais, to Swift, to Mark Twain? Did John Steinbeck not proclaim him the best satirist since Sterne, worthy of a Nobel Prize?

title: Spain's Airports Face Strike
description: MADRID, Nov. 10 (UPI)Representatives of the nation's 13,000 airport workers called a threeday strike today that was expected to paralyze Spanish airports when it begins tomorrow. Labor representatives said the Government had not granted promised pay increases and fringe benefits.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J. Nov. 10King Ranch's Pressing Date, the 21 favorite, scored an impressive victory in the $54,150 Hydrangea Handicap tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: DR. HAROLD R. CONNELLY SR.
description: Dr. Harold R. Connelly Sr., a dentist and chief oral surgeon at St. Vincent's Hospital, in Bridgeport, Conn., for 30 years, died Nov. 1 of natural causes on a hunting trip in Ellsworth. Me. He was 72 years old and lived at 310 Park Boulevard, Lordship, Stratford, Conn.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Moody's Is Only Key For City NoteBuyers
description: Moody's Investors Service is one of two major rating companies that, for a fee, provide investors with judgments about the soundness or riskiness of securities. Standard & Poor's Corporation is the other.

title: Islanders Bow To Aroused Canadiens, 51
description: UNIONDALE,L.I., Nov.10The forecaster warned there was a cold front moving in tonight from Canada. He didn't say it would be the Montreal Canadiens, however. Under heavy attack from their fans for their slump, the defending National Hockey League champions proceeded to frost the Islanders, 51, in their first meeting of the season at Nassau Coliseum.

title: VILLAGE VOICE EMPLOYEES VOTE TO ACCEPT CONTRACT
description: Employees of The Village Voice late yesterday to accept the first labor contract between employees and management inthe weekly nwspaper's history, thus averting a strike, a spokesman said.

title: Plane Crashes on Top of Car
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 10 (UPI)A small private plane crashed on top of a car driving down a busy expressway during the morning rush hour today, but the police reported no injuries.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1977

title: William R. MacDonald, 52; Aided In U.S. Mapping of the Antarctic
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10William R. MacDonald, who was instrumental in the mapping of the Antarctic, died yesterday in Annapolis, Md. He was 52 years old.

title: More Nuclear Debate: II
description: When President Carter supposedly vetoed the Clinch River breeder reactor the other day, what he actually vetoed was an authorization bill for the Energy Research and Development Authority. But an $80 million appropriation for the breeder project is tucked away in a separate bill that requires it to be spent despite Mr. Carter's veto.

title: Canada Expels Iraqi Diplomat
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (Reuters)Canada declared the secondranking diplomat in the Iraqi Embassy herr persona non grata in September (or unacceptable spying activities, External Affairs Minister Donald C. Jamieson said today. He was commenting on a report in today's Tormitn Sun that said that t,ie diplomat, Tank Abu al KhaT had been expelled for luring members of the Kurdish refugee Com rnmiity here hack to Iraq, where they faced imprisonment. The Kurds have hero fighting for independence from Iraq.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1?77

title: Dow Soars 14.12 to 832.55 In Best Rise in Over a Year
description: The stock market had its best session in more than a year yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average soared 14.12 points in heavy trading.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Thursday, Nov. 10, 1977

title: PatientDoctor Relationship Is Examined
description: The threat by Coach Walt Michaels. of the Jets to fine the team's physician, Dr. James A. Nicholaseven if it is only a token $25raises serious questions about the patient  doctor relationship in sports.

title: Art People
description: THINGS ARE looking up at the Museum of the American Indian in deep trouble several years ago when the state Attorney General's office charged its director and some board members with mismanagement and disposal of parts of the collection in a surreptitious and wasteful way.

title: Yale Calls Last BlueCollar Offer Final
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 10Yale University's director of operations, Alfred Dobie, said today that the university had made no significant changes in its best and final offer to 1,400 striking bluecollar union workers who rejected the offer almost six weeks ago.

title: SOVIET OFFERS URANIUM FOR JAPANESE IMPORTS
description: TOKYO, Nov. 10The Soviet Union informed Japan today that it was keenly interested in selling enriched uranium in exchange for imports of Japanese industrial plants.

title: President Says He's Not a Critic Of Burns Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  President Carter said today that he had never had any disagreements on economic policy with Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and that he was not inclined to criticize Dr. Burns's recent actions, which have induced increases in interest rates.

title: U.S. Captures Wightman Cup
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov 10The United States won the Wightman Cup for the 40th time tonight when Rosie Casals defeated Michelle Tyler of Britain, 62, 36, 64, and the doubles team of Billie Jean King and JoAnne Russell wiped out Sue Mappin and Lesley Charles, 60, 61. That gave The United States a 40 lead in the sevenmatch tennis competition.

title: Janos Starker Shifts at Carnegie From Classical Cello to Jazz
description: My friends are going to be amused to hear me playing calypso, jazz and all that bass stuff, said Janos Starker. The distinguished interpreter of the classical cello repertory was talking about a piece by David Baker, which he is going to introduce in his recital in Carnegie Hall tomorrow night.

title: Notes on People
description: Opera lovers got some exhilarating news yesterday from San Diego. It was announced that two of the world's operatic superstars  in alphabetical order: Beverly Sills and Joan Sutherland would star together in a new production of StraussDie Fledermaus in the fall of 1980. The production, conducted by Richard Bonynge, Miss Sutherland's husband, will have the two prima donnas alternating in the roles of Rosalinda and Adele, and will be the major work of the season for the San Diego Opera Company, The two stars, who have never appeared on a stage together, have similar repertoires. Their joint engagement was announced by Tito Capohianco, general director of the San Diego Opera.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: friday, Nov. 11, 1977

title: Boston Ballet Starts Year With the New and the Old
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11The Boston Ballet started its 14th season at the Music Hall last night with a promise hanging over its head, or at least floating rather pleasantly around its ears. During all the years E. Virginia. Williams has germinated, nurtured and cosseted her young New England company, it hits always been short of a proper performing home Now there is fresh chance, not of a brandnew hams but a bandnew remodeled one.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 11  David M. Roderick, president of the United States Steel Corporation, announced here today that suits will be filed Shortly against European steel manufacturers which, he charged, are dumping steel on American markets at below production costs. Another company official said the suits would be filed with the United States Treasury Department within two weeks.

title: U.S. ASKS FOR WARNINGS ON LIQUID PROTEIN DIETS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)The Federal Government today asked 29 manufacturers and distributors of liquid protein to put warning labels on the diet product immediately.

title: Personal Investing
description: The stock market investor win find no comfort in the newly published A Halt Century of Returns on Stocks and Bonds. One of the authors, Prof. Lawrence Fisher of the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, says there is a fairly strong chance that the investor won't got all his money back. Page 29.

title: Israeli Leader Says He Welcomes Offer By Sadat for Talks
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 11Prime Minister Menahem Begin asked the citizens of Egypt today to join Israelis in a silent oath of no more wars, no more bloodshed, and no more threats.

title: A Singer With Something to Say
description: Joan Armatrading, the singersongwriter from the Caribbean and Birmingham, England, played to an adoring audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday. Once a cult figure, Miss Armatrading has become a phenomenon. Her performing savvy has blossomed since she played at the Bottom Line last year, and she is a commanding singer with something to say. But her music still leaves something to be desired.

title: Motor Inn Play Falls by the Wayside
description: Longfellow's Wayside Inn has become a motel outside Boston in A. R Gurney Jr.'s new play. And the travelers gathered there are not telling tales but living them.

title: A Simple Garage in Jersey for Repairing NotSoSimple Cars
description: STOCKTON, N.J.Quiet rock music rolls out of a stereo that is the most complex instrument at a simple garage here to which car owners from Philadelphia, New York City and as far away as Massachusetts bring some of the world's most precisionbuilt automobiles.

title: Veterans Day: Pride and Protest
description: For the several hundred marchers and a scattering of spectators along a 15block route down Fifth Avenue, the annual Veterans Day parade yesterday fittingly commemorated the dead of two world wars and the Korean and Vietnam Wars.

title: A Blind Newsdealer Wards Off a Robber
description: A 70yearold Greenwich Village newsdealer who is legally blind foiled a robbery by a 16yearold youth yesterday morning, according to the police.

title: About New york
description: Sidney Horenstein was born 13 years B.P., before present, the paleontologists reference to 1950, the year that has been set as the base date of radiocarbon dating. Born here, his soul is as New York as the Manhattan schist, and as he strolls he spots fossils along our streets lying squiggled and fluted like paisley in commonplace frocks.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: CLEANWATER RULES EASED BY CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11A HouseSenate conference committee has agreed to give industry more time to install antipollution equipment and to relax Federal controls over the nation's environmentally delicate wetlands.

title: People and Business
description: The Arabian American Oil Company announced yesterday in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, that John J. Kelberer has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the company, effective Jan. 1.

title: H. R. Lamb, New York Law Firm Partner
description: ?orace ?. Lamo, a ???????? partner in the law firm. of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MaMacrae at 140 Broadway, died yesterday in a Fairfield, Conn., nursing home after a long illness; He was 85 years old and lived at 672 Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Laundering of Funds Alleged
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 11The civil suit against Mr. Mendelsohn, to be filed in Superior Court here on Monday, will accuse himof widespread violations of campaign disclosure laws, according to the California Fair Political Practices Commission.

title: KOCH LIKELY TO ASK BADILLO TO ASSUME HIGH POST IN CITY
description: Representative Herman Badillo, who after losing in September's Democratic mayoral primary became a key adviser to the ultimate winner, Representative Edward I, Koch, will be offered a high position, probably as a Deputy Mayor, in the Koch administration, according to sources close to the Mayorelect.

title: Who'll Manage While Mr. Koch Mayors?
description: While the Mayorelect reads his transition papers, pressures grow on every side. The Federal loan must be renewed, a task now complicated by the adverse rating of city notes by Moody's, the rating service. Urgent labor negotiations impend. A budget deficit of awesome dimensions looms.
