description: WOMEN TEACHERS seem to be winning by inches while losing by yardson all frontsin the struggle for sex equality in academe.

title: Meredith Miller, Student, Fiancee of Michael Long
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Miller of Stamford, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Ellen Miller, to Michael Peter Long, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Lung or narrow, zssex, thgiana. A wedding in the winter is planned.

title: Sharon Robinson, Cellist, Performs with Vitality
description: Sharon Robinson, a cellist who is well known in chambermusic circles in New York, made her New York recital debut at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Thursday night, assisted by Samuel Sanders, pianist. The event was presentea by Fro Musicis, an organization with the dual purpose of aiding young performers and providing musical programs in hospitals, prisons and other public institutions.

title: BACK AT THE LBJ RANCH DORIS KEARNS GOODWIN
description: By the time I joined the White House staff in the early spring, President Johnson was beginning to regain his spirits. The country had responded positively to his March 31 withdrawal from t he Democrat ic Presidential race. Ifis publicopinion polls had gone up, and for the first time in months, he was beginning to think that history might respond well to him He thought, for moment, that he could even bring about an end to the war in Vietnam.

title: In Defense of Mansfield Training School
description: THE FIRST American institution for the mentally retarded was established in 1848 by Samuel Gridley Howe at the Perkins Institute in Massachusetts. His school was modeled after institutions in Paris in which the remediation of brain dysfunction was attempted through an elaborate series of physicalsensory exercises.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Retriever
description: NORWICH, Vt.Sleep came quickly in my upstairs bedroom of the old Vermont farmhouse, and well it might have for the sweet smell of woodsmoke drifted up the stairs and I was snug under a quilt filled by the lady of the house with the down and feathers of dozens of woodcock shot by her husband, sons and friends.

title: Eddie and Hot Rods Offer Sharp Rock In American Debut
description: Eddie and the Hot Rodsfive young men from Britain none of them named Eddieare a rock band that has just been at Max's Kansas City. After a short Canadian tour, the group made its United States debut at Max's on Thursday.

title: Dr. Eugene Feenberg, 71, Was Professor of Physics At Washington University
description: Dr. Eugene Feenberg, professor emeritus of theoretical physics at Washington University in St. Louis and a physics professor at New York University from 1938 to 1943, dial Monday at Barnes Hospital, St. Louis, following a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: Dec. 6 Coal Strike Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)The chief industry negotiator in the coal labor talks says that it will he impossible to avert a nationwide strike Dec. 6 unless the United Mine Workers begins to negotiate realistically. Joseph P. Brennan, president of the Bituminous coal Operators Association, issued his statement ittter three consecutive days of negotia. lions with the union, He indicated that no progress had been made in trying to re solve the issue.

title: BAY STATE BACKS SHOPPING ON SUNDAY FOR CHRISTMAS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP)Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has signed into law a bill allowing retail stores to be open on Sundays between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: Woolfolk's Three Scores Spark Rout by Westfield
description: Hal (Butch) Woolfolk ran for three touchdowns, giving him 26 for the season, as undefeated Westfield posted its eighth victory, 420, at home over Linden. Frank Kelly added touchdowns on runs of 7 and 3 yards as Westfield extended its unbeaten streak to 21 and its victory streak to 18 by posting its sixth shutout.

title: Triumph Achieved By Point Pleasant
description: Russ Leming plunged 1 yard in the second period and Uri Smith scored from 2 7drds out in the third quarter to gile Point Pleitsunt Borough (71) a 148 victory over Asbury Park (62).

title: CHESS
description: Without taking time to recuperate, and without waiting to attend the final banquet and prizegiving ceremony at the United States Championship Tournament in Mentor, Ohio. Leonid Shamkovich, a former Russian grandmaster who emigrated to Israel and now lives in New York, rushed off to compete in the 211player Swiss system Hartford Open.

title: Turkey Farms: A Vanishing Breed
description: CALVERTON WILLIAM MILOSKI started turkey farming in the Riverhead area in 1937 and he's been at it ever since. Business is good, he said, although the cost of feed is high, gas and electricity are high, taxes are high and labor is high. I will continue as long as I can go. Bu' I don't know what's going to happen when 1 die.

title: Nickel Inventories Not Worth a Dime
description: The international nickel market, like the depressed copper market, is suffering its worst downturn in decades. Huge inventories, built up during the recession, have sent priceand the earnings of major producersto painfully low levels.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: A legacy of red ink, inherited from the Penn Central and five other bankrupt railroads, is still plaguing the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the private organization formed out of the six troubled carriers in 1976.

title: Russian Soprano Displays Charm
description: Evgenya Baum!, a Soviet soprano who has been living in the United States for the last two years, gave a debut recital In Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. She is a pretty young woman with poise and temperament, and she has a singer's basic qualification, a fine voice. It is bright, with an attractive beat that seems prevalent among Slavic singers, and, except when pushed, the tone gets purer and more lovely as the voice goes higher.

title: Flood Score Is Decisive For Kennedy
description: Coach Bob Spano's Kennedy of Somers team capitalized on two John Jay mistakes and dropped the Indians from the unbe;:ten ranks with a 147 victory yesterday. The victory gave Kennedy a share of the Conference B North Division title with John Jay, which has a 71 wonlost record, and all but eliminated Rcn Lyons's club from Section I borough play.

title: Pollution Bounties
description: Under a littleknown bounty clause in the Federal Rivers and Harbors Act of 1899. two Pennsylvania State University teachers gave the United States Attorney information that led to accusations against four Pittsburgh companies as river polluters.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: The appointment of new directors, Livingston Biddle Jr. at the National Endowment of the Arts and Joseph Duffy at the National Endowment of the Humanities, has unleashed the usual charges of politicking, and tributes to the virtues of the old order. Two pieces in the Sunday Times of Oct. 16, by Hilton Kramer and David Dempsey, upheld the ideals of quality in the arts and expressed the fear that standards would be dissolved in political considerations by the Carter Administration. Mr. Kramer argued that the new heads of the two endowments were undistinguished and were appointed for political reasons. Michael Straight, former deputy to Nancy Hanks at the N.E.A. and acting director until Mr. Biddle takes over, also was quoted as saying that the appointments heralded a policy of political interference in the arts by President Carter and his advisers.

title: A Letter From London
description: London is beautiful. Right now I find myself where I usually end up at least several times daily, in the park. Although traffic has an established stronghold, the trees reign supreme.

title: Alternative School Is Offered In a Harlem Community Center
description: Elevenyearold Larry Redick attends school in a Harlem community center wedged between a drugaddiction treatment center and a police station. He is one of 11 children whose parents have enrolled them in that educational program, some for the third year, rather than in the city school system.

title: President Lopez Portillo Has Recognized the Inescapable, That His Country Is Economically Dependent
description: MEXICO CITYDespite nationalist protests, Mexico's economic difficulties have apparently convinced President Jose Lopez Portillo that the country must come to terms with its dependence on the United States. So Mr. Lopez Portillo has patched up Mexico's relations with Washington which had deteriorated during the Government of former President Luis Eciteverria Alvarez. Last week, in a gesturethat pleased Washington, the new Administration announced that Mexico would not join the Organization of Petroleum 1.;xporting Countries even though its exports will exceed 1,1 million barrels per day by 1982. The yearold Mexican H gime has also ordered construction of a $ 1. 5 billion natural gay; pipeline to the Texas border and has sharply increased crude oil exports to the United States.

title: County Weighs 14 Waste Plans
description: SINCE County Executive Alfred B. DelBello earlier this year abandoned exclusive negotiations with Union Carbide to provide a county solidwaste disposal system at the Grasslands Reservation, no less than 19 different companies have submitted highly technical proposals on what to do with the county's garbage.

title: Love Story, Sea Story
description: ndisputably one of our most gifted and ambitious writers for children, Natalie Babbitt has taken an almost dangerously outmoded theme for her fifth and latest novel: the constancy of love. To today's young readers, as familiar with separation and divorce as they are with the institution of mar.

title: A Sculptor Looks at Life
description: PRINCETON IT WAS another of those interviews to be expected after more than half a century of successful sculpturingand for a moment Dorothea Greenbaum, a gracious, attractive artist of considerable charm, appeared perplexed.

title: Piggyback Heart Stops Beating
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov. 12 (AP)Dr. Christiaan Barnard said today that apiggyback heart that he grafted onto the heart of a young patient last August had stopped beating and would be removed.

title: Miss Goodstein, Lawyer, Is Betrothed to Dentist
description: Mr. and Mrs Julian Goodstein of Woodbridge, Conn.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara M. Goodstein, to Dr. Vincent E. Barbarisi, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Barbarisi of Scarsdale N.Y.

title: Arthur Fisher Fiance Of Elizabeth Percy
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Saxton Percy to Arthur Edward Fisher of Branford, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Joyce Saxton Percy of Woodbridge, Conn., and Stephen Percy or Stratrord, Conn. Mr. Fisher is a son of Mrs. Joseph C. Fisher of New Haven and the late Mr. Fisher. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Gadfly Finds Politics Addicting
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN Boine Johnson retired last March as Mayor of Scarsdale, the Town Board gave him a framed photograph of Paul Feiner, a resident who had been one of his consistent critics. Mr. Johnson, responding to the spirit of the occasion, asked Mr. Feiner, who hardly ever misses a meeting, to autograph it.

title: Coast Race Will Settle the Lesser Issues
description: Now that the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racings (NASCAR) has announced its longawaited rules changes, it remains only to run the final race of 1977 before all attention is turned to next season. The final 1977 race will be the Los Angeles Times 500 at Ontario Motor Speedway. The major issue of the Winston Cup Grand National driving championship already has been settled, with Cale Yarborough, however, is trying to add to his season moneywinning record. He has collected $388,691 in 29 races.

title: Erosion Is Still A Major Problem
description: NEW JERSEY'S plan to battle erosion from wind and water on building development sites is approaching its second birthday, and state officials supervising the control program are grumbling that it is understaffed and underfinanced.

title: Children's Books
description: Roundup is a word generally associated with criminals or cattle. In the spring and fall it happens to picture books. They are gathered into a small space to be branded, on some unspoken theory that because they have been created for short readers they are to be handed short shrift. Out of several hundred published this season, 16 have been carefully chosen to be dissected here on the head of a pin. Two deserve the whole space. Almost all of the rest are either good enough or flawed enough to be worthy of serious discussion because each is the result of serious thought, work and art. How come, if a picture is worth 10,001) words a picture book is lucky to get 50? No wonder reviewers give starsthey take less than words. A fresh round of stars for CLEVER BILL (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, ($5.95) by William Nicholson. First published in England in 1926, it teaches two arts: the pacing of a picture book and simplicity. The words and excellently drawn pictures take turns speaking for one another. The story is one strong uncomplicated line. Mary, invited to visit her aunt, packs her favorite things but forgets her toy soldier, Bill Davis. He runs after her down the stairs, along the road, over the pages that separate them so fast that he was just in time to meet her train at Dover. There he bows, and Mary, handing him a bouquet, proclaims, Clever Bill. We a're left breathless; this exemplary artist has not missed a beat.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS
description: Life as we know it today is rather different from life as we knew it as little as five or ten years ago. Recent discoveries, including two reported only in the last few weeks, have significantly changed our ideas about how and when life began on the primordial earth.

title: Children's Books
description: The titles on this list were selected by the children's editor. Quoted comments are from the Book Review.

title: Hughes Documents Disclose Big Losses in Last Decade
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12Although Howard R. Hughes died one of the nation's wealthiest individuals, documents that have become available because of litigation over his estate depict him as a poor businessman.

title: Funny Books
description: NITIIOLOGIST Charles Keller has put Together I really firstrate collection of American humor from colonial days up to the present. Although intended for children, the breadth of Its selections can more than hold its own against similar adult books. All of the masters of American humor, from

title: A Day on the Ground With Those Feeding Thousands in the Air
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines chefs are seasoning a rijsttafel, Scandinavian Airlines System chef's helpers are chopping veal for Norwegian meatballs and Olympic Airlines sauciers are lovingly assembling lobster thermidor in gleaming copper casseroles. The scene: the bustling kitchen of Marriott InFlite Services, which covers an acre at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

title: South Africa's Seat of Power
description: There Is only one thing the outside world wants. That is nothing more and nothing less than oneman, onevote in South Africa.

title: Texan Fights His Life Sentence For Nonviolent, $230 Offenses
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 12A Texas prisoner who has been convicted of three nonviolent crimes that netted him $230.11 fighting to have his life sentence overturned on the ground that it is cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Insights for Grand Jurors
description: VISITATIONS to correctional and related facilities are made by grand jurors to gain perspective. By becoming familiar with the justice system as a whole, they perceive the relative part they themselves play in it. Thus visits to the various courts and correctional institutions are an enducational process for grand jurors, resulting in their being better equipped for the performance of their sworn duty.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Farewell to a Daughter
description: William Allen White, who won renownand the Pulitzer Prizeas the forthright editor of The Emporia (Kansas) Gazette, wrote one of his most moving editorials on the death of his 16yearold daughter, Mary, in a riding accident in 1921. Friday evening at 9 on ABC, the story of their relationship will be told in Mary White, a twohour drama based on the late editor's writings. Ed Flanders, above, plays William Allen White and Kathleen Beller his daughter, of whom he wrote in final farewell, A rift in the clouds in a gray day threw a shaft of sunlight upon her coffin as her nervous, energetic little body sank to its last sleep. But the soul of her, the glowing, gorgeous, fervent soul of her, surely was flaming in eager joy upon some other dawn.

title: New Rochelle Art a Cut Above Norm
description: PARIS has the Mona Lisa, Rome has the Sistine Chapel, London has the Elgin marbles and New York has Picasso's Guernica. So what does New Rochelle have? The Landing of the Huguenots.

title: The Leonids An AllStar Show
description: GREAT interest was shown last August in the meteor showers of the Perseids. Amateur astronomers exchanged experiences of their viewing and even I braved the mosquitoes in my yard for a few nights, trying to catch a glimpse of these beautiful shooting stars and fireballswithout much success.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayFlyig Arrow, Calrfornia Road, Bronaville, N.Y. Novae, green local and children's working hunters; equitation. 8:30 A. M.

title: Government Moves Against Redlining
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board moved last week against redlining, the practice of denying mortgage loans in neighborhoods thought to be declining.

title: North Shore Clinches; New Hyde Park, Too
description: North Shore untracked itself in the second half and wore down a solid Elmont team, 280, yesterday to clinch the Nassau Conference V championship. Meanwhile New Hyde Park rolled over lastplace Great Neck South, 410, to capture the Conference 1V crown.

title: How Much Is an Athlete Worth? And Who Decides?
description: David B. Saxe wrote a recent article on this page ('Help for Sports Fans? They Need Plenty of It, Oct. 30), It consisted of a listing of intemperate, illinformed and undocumented charges concerning professional sports. Considering that the author is a public official (consumer advocate, director of law enforcement, New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs), his article was deplorable.

title: Engagements
description: AckermanKramer Dr. and Mrs. Calvin Kramer joyfully announce the engagement of their daughter, Leslie, to Mr. Karl Ackerman of Medford, Mass.

title: At 79, Suzuki Tempo Is Still Agitato
description: MATSUMOTO, JAPAN HE moves with more effort now and is a little hard of hearing in one ear. But the experi. enced hands and quick fingers still draw the same mellow sounds and energy from the violin, and his eyes still light up at the sight of a child.

title: Births
description: Zaks Dr. and Mrs, Arthur Zaks (nee Mary Leanore Rega) are happy to announce the birth of Laura Anna Zaks on Oct It 1977. The Proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Fred Zaks of Brooklyn. N.Y. and Colonal and Mrs. John A. Rega of Huntsvalle, A1.

title: Top Suffolk Aides Are Back in School
description: HAUPPAUGE ARTHUR BERGMANN, Suffolk County's Chief Deputy Executive, was up at 5:30 the other morning, and within the hour he was on the road, headed toward Suffolk's office complex here.

title: Deaths
description: SY RANArthur G. (Colonel US Army Ref) On Friday, August 26, 1977 in Portsmouth, VA Naval Hospital. Survived by his wife, Evangeline V. Syran, father of Dr. John A. Syran of Virginia Beach, Virginia and Mrs. Virginia Padgett of Marietta, GA. avid by five grandchildren. Was buried with full military honors in Arlington National Cemetery on August 29, 1977.

title: 5 Killed in CarVan Collision
description: BELLINGHAM, Mass., Nov. 12 (UPI)A van and a car collided headon last night, killing five persons and injuring two others, the police said. The dead were identified as Paul May, 17 years old; Paul Dalpe, 18; Hobert loyal,

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are hosed nen:milderprocessed sales figures from 1400 bookstores in every region in the United States.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations is recognizing distinguished women in the world. Last month Canadian educator Dr. Pauline Jewett, was awarded the FAO Ceres Medal named for the Roman goddess of agriculture or. Jewett was the first woman to be president of a major coeducational universitySimon Fraser, near Vancouver. She received her Ph.D. in government from Harvard and did her postdoctoral work at Oxford and London. A writer of articles on government and political problems, and formerly member of Parliament, Pauline Jewett was also a director of the Institution of Canadian Studies at Carleton University, Ottawa. She is a strong supporter of the FAO and the United Nations goals of freedom from hunger and want, and the advancement of women's rights.

title: FOOD
description: IF you insist on a freshkilled turkey to grace your Thanksgiving table this year, you will be joining what appears to be a trend. The Long Island turkey population may be dropping, but this has nothing to do with demand.

title: F. J. Close Jr. Fiance of Mary E. McDonough
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. McDonough 3d of Plainfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth McDonough, to Frederick Joseph Close Jr., son of Mrs. Close of Summit, N.J., and the late Mr. Close. The wedding will take place on Dec. 16.

title: GARDENING
description: THOUGH leaves have been on homeowners minds in recent weeks as they raked and raked to get out from under, the trees themselves are of some concern. This is evident particularly in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, where tree maladies has been taking their toll.

title: THE 60's COME TO A FULL BOIL 1968
description: The decade of the 1960's was an extended national trauma that left its mark on everyone who lived through it, and 1968 was its climax. Everyone knew where he stood: in defiance of the war, in support of the war; for black power; for student power, for the rights of the silent majority. Family dinners erupted into bitter debate, with generation pitted against generation.

title: A Jet History Lesson
description: If the New York Jets quarterback, Richard Todd, was not a star before, he is now. When he rejoined the Jets last Thursday after having spent three days at Lenox Hill Hospital for treatment of a damaged right knee, he found himself in the middle of a dispute between Coach Walt Michaels and Dr. James Nicholas, the club orthopedist. The coach was annoyed at not having been notified last Monday that his quarterback was being hospitalized. The coach even spoke facetiously of a $25 fine for one of the sport's most respected physicians. That mixup has been described by Jet officials as a communication gap. But the dispute had Michaels and some Jet players wondering if Richard Todd were receiving star treatment from the orthopedist, who is celebrated for having sewn together Joe Namath's knees.

title: Penn Holds On to Defeat Dartmouth, 73
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 2Pennsylvania's football team stopped Dartmouth on the 2yard line in the fourth quarter to preserve a 73 victory this cold, sunny afternoon.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERSON, Oscar Theodore, resident of Tucson for 8 years, formerly of New Jersey, passed away suddenly on October 30th. He is survived by his wife, Marione; one son, two daughters, one sister and and six grandchildren. Before his retirement In 1963, Mr. Alexanderson, was Corporate Comptroller of Bristol Meyers Company, in New York City, Funeral Services were held on Thursday, November 3. 1977, in Tucson. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mobile Meals of Tucson, Inc., 155 West Helen Street, Tucson, Arizona 85705.

title: 4thQuarter Spree Led by Williams
description: Willis Reed is usually quick to open the dressing room to the press after a Knicks game. It was different last night. The Knicks coach kept it closed for five minutes to give his team lashing for their play, which required a lastquarter surge to defeat the New Jersey Nets, 10190, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kissinger Caper
description: THE authors of In the National Interest, who accompanied me on many trips, display remarkable powers of imagination and inventiveness. This will come as no surprise to those multitudes who are already familiar with their reporting. Flair should never be disparaged, whether in journalism or in diplomacy.

title: Raleigh Mayoral Vote Caps Struggle Over Growth
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 12Rather than the simple, seniorcitizen Cinderella story of a 73yearold political novice who upset a vigorous, veteran incumbent, the victory of Isabella Cannon as Mayorelect is considered here as the latest skirmish in a continuing power struggle over the economic future of this capital city of 150,000.

title: Children's Books
description: Charles Dickens in arty childhood had nurse scared him stiff with stories ot ghosts and weird, ghaistt doings. He never forgot those prickly joys of terror; rte be came no mean hand himself in writing such tales and, as an editor of various publications, in exacting such tales from others.

title: New Cantata Singers And Players Appear
description: The New Cantata Singers and Players of Washington, a company of 8 singers and 12 instrumentalists modeled after the Bach Aria Group, made its New York debut Wednesday night at Town Hall. The program, of seemingly interminable length, included works by Vivaldi, Bach, Michael Haydn, Mozart, Schubert and Brahms. The performances, though often spirited, were mediocre at best.

title: The Saga of Norah Smaridge
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR I'M a rci du gr ieo ussaid i no nil N e rloirgahht British voice, a twinkle in her friendly eyes. I want to know what makes things tick and then write about them. Meanwhile, I'm broadening my own horizons. It's amazing how many fascinating and incredible people, things and processes there are in the world.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Feed trees Have professionals check weakened or dead tree limbs for pruning and cabling.Don't forget to plant bulbs; they are better in the ground at this late date, than le ft forgotten on the tool shed shelf.Last call to pot up hardy bulbs for forcing this winter indoors.

title: Photo Gallery's Lonely Days Are Over
description: NEW HAVEN RUNNING an art gallery is not one of the easiest of enterprises, as most people who have tried it will tell us. There are not only the predictable costs of putting the organization together and finding an appropriate building and display area; there are also the decisions of selecting artists for exhibition, dealing with the demands of the artists and finding a public that will eventually make its way to the gallery's doors.

title: CAMERA
description: Seldom does anyone react to new book on photography as enthusiastically as he does to a new camera. Yet, the photoinstruction book plays a vital role in understanding the medium. There are many photonarrative books so visually exciting that the reader gains the impression of being there with the photographer, sharing his reaction to the scene before the lens.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Since there are over 150 species of these elegant buttercups often called windflowers, cultural rules are set for particular species. One of the most popular for forcing in pots is the tuberousrooted Poppy or Caen anemone (Anemone coronaria). These velvetpetaled flowers have brilliant colors ranging from reds to blues and white. They require a sandy soil mixture which has some lime content. They have been grown outdoors in this area successfully in protected coldframes for early spring flowers. In the South, they can be planted outdoors. Or they can be forced to bloom in cool sunny greenhouses where temperatures are controlled. Forcing them in the environs of a house or apartment is difficult because of the low humidity and warm room temperatures.

title: Schools Get Tough On TV Addicts
description: TWO months ago, the Board of Education in Niagara Falls, N.Y., unanimously adopted a resolution urging parents and students to choose television programs more carefully and to limit the viewing so that pupils will make the best possible use of their time and talents.

title: An AdministrationWith Rural Roots Now Must Address the Cities
description: WASHINGTONThere may be no area of public policy with a wider gap between expectation and accomplishment than urban policy. Now, the Carter Administration, under heavy pressure from its black and urban constituency, ready to take its turn in the urban swamp, braving crosscurrents of political prerogative, bureaucratic territorial defense and hard economic realities.

title: The Question Is Now Serious: Is NATO Really Necessary?
description: WASHINGTONDoes NATO make sense? asked United States official the other morning. Is it anachronistic? Is it viable? We don't quite ask these questions because after all this time, it's the only thing we've got.

title: DETECTIVE BUREAU HURT BY ATTRITION
description: A New York City Police Department report has warned that the detective bureau is suffering a serious manpower drain because of a high rate of attrition.

title: Yaron Helmer Fiance Of Diana L. Shapiro
description: Diana Lynn Shapiro, a candidate for a master's degree in chemistry at the Stevens Institute of Technology, and Yaron Helmer, a senior at the Rutgers Law School, will be married in January.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Rabbi Bertram W. Korn, guest.

title: CALIFANO TO VISIT EUROPE FOR VIEWS ON HEALTH CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will visit Britain and West Germany next week to study universal health care systems in those nations.

title: Far Away Places
description: IN 1941, with the war raging in China, United States Marines commmandeered the fossil bones of a 500,000yearold human known as the Peking Man, with the idea of transporting them to the United States for safe keeping. Unfortunately, the Peking Man never got here lie mysteriously vanished and no one knows what happened to him.

title: Bayonne (80) Turns Back North Bergen
description: Bayonne turned back a 2point conversion attempt with two minutes remaining to edge North Bergen, 76. Bayonne (80) scored in the first period on a 23yard pass from Pat Gallagher to Dwayne Williams. Kevin Foye kicked the decisive extra point.

title: A Big BrotherBig Sister Project Helps 150 Nassau County Children
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I.When Howard Frank) of Bellmore decided to serve as a volunteer in the Big BrothersSisters', of Nassau County, his unwritten commitment was for one year. Now, a year and a half later, Mr. Frank) intends to stay a Big Brother as long as I'm alive and as long as some little brother needs me.

title: No One Knows What Makes a Good School
description: EXPERIENCED teachers may be either more or less successful than inexperienced teachers. Class size may have slight or virtually no impact on student achievement. The amount of money a district spends per pupil makes little or no difference.

title: ART

title: Jonathan Sulds to Wed Katharine Cooper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Cooper of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Diane Cooper, to Jonathan L. Sulds, son of Vivienne F. Sulds of White Plains and the late Irvin P. Sulds. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Robin A. Arbon Is Bride Of Dr. James Reardon 3d
description: Robin Alexes Arbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Arbon of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. James J. Reardon 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reardon of Elmont.

title: New Panel Will Study Admission Of Women Into the Rabbinate
description: Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, announced yesterday the appointment of a 13member commission to study the admitting of women into the rabbinate.

title: Three Early Scores Key Detroit Victory
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12As General Manager Ted Lindsay's Tshirts promised, Aggressive Hockey Is Back in Town here in the Motor City. Scoring three goals in the opening period while their visitors adjusted to their new style, the Red Wings forged a 31 victory over the New York Rangers, marking their first success against New York at the Olympia in the last five meetings here between the two teams.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS SUING OVER AIRLINE INSECTICIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Ncv. 12An organization of airline flight attendants has sued the Department of Agriculture in Federal District Court here to stop the practice of spraying airliners with insecticides such as DDT.

title: A Lab Follows Agriculture East
description: BAITING HOLLOW SUFFOLK COUNTY'S agricultural industry is all out here on the East End now, said Prof. Wilbur Selleck, director of Cornell University's

title: Tax Reform: Does It Balance Rich and Poor?
description: THREE weeks from now voters in Maine will go to the polls and decide whether to repeal a fouryearold law designed to bridge the spending gaps between rich and poor school districts. The vote will be watched closely across the country be cause it reflects open revolt against one of the most controversialand perhaps the most importanteducational developments of the 1970's schoolfinance reform.

title: Notes: A Spirited Young Foursome
description: Listening to Daniel Avshalomov and David Geber swap banter, one is tempted to say, Oh to be young and a member of a string quartet The two are violist and cellist, re soectivelv, of the American String Quartet, which has an average age of 25 and which, as a unit, is only four years old. They get more fun out of doing something they love than do people at circus.

title: Stamford Catholic Captures Division
description: Stamford Catholic secured a berth In the Fairfield County championship game as it defeated an intracity rival, Rippowam, 36.0, and won the West Division crown.

title: Backers of Shah And His Critics To Demonstrate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12A feud is Jeveloping between Iranian residents of the United States who plan to demonstrate in support of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi during his visit next week and those who Dian to nrotest.

title: Why Hollywood  Finds Profits out of This World
description: The millennium has arrived early. Science fiction is now big business in the entertainment industry. Long lines of ticketbuyers circle theaters all over the nation (and soon, all over the world) to see Star Wars. Dozens of sciencefiction shows are already on TV every week, or in production for the coming winter's second season.

title: Food
description: For nearly three weeks recently, we traveled about Italy, covering more than 2,000 kilometers and sampling the food in several provinces, principally those from the center of the country going north. Some of the food was the cause of absolute bliss; some of it the cause of considerable despair.

title: Dog Show Calendar

title: Undefeated Colgate Wins 10th, 4839, as White Stars
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 12 (UPI)Henry White raced 97 yards on a kickoff return for one touchdown and twisted his way 67 yards with a screen pass for another today as he led undefeated Colgate to a 4839 victory over Northeastern.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: TO mark the 30th anniversary of the founding of the Quarterly Review of Literaturea little magazine of remarkable quality and endurancethe editors, T. Weiss and Renee Weiss, have been issuing a series of retrospective collections drawn from the pages of their own journal. has proved to be an excellent idea. The readership of the Quarterly Review was always, perforce, small one. Though it regularly published such writers as Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams and e. e. commings at a time when the commercial magazines still considered these poets controversial and unintelligible, these were not names to. attract large numbers of readers. Nowadays, of course, Stevens is the hero of the academy, Williams the subject of a literary cult, and Cummings ()hen patronized as a sentimentalist, while a magazine like The New Yorker regularly publishes without apology poems and even short stories more hermetic than anything to be found in the little magazines 30 years ago. And since the writing of literary history is now a lost art, it is all the more important for us to be reminded of exactly what our serious literary culture consistedof as recently as the 40's and 50's, and exactly how it functioned at the higher altitudes of achievement.

title: 280 AMERICANS ELIGIBLE TO LEAVE MEXICAN JAILS
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12 The United Statees Embassy completed a list yesteri day of 280 Americans being held in Mexican jails who are eligible to complete their sentences in the United States under a prisonerexchange treaty.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The greatest honor Britain can bestow upon its citizens, the Order of Merit, an Order limited to 24 living Britain, has just been awarded for the first time to a choreographer. The recipient, of course, is Sir Frederick Ashton, C.H., C.B.E., who can now add an O.M. to the already formidable alpha bet of initials clinging grandly to his name. It is a wonderfully well deserved honor for Ashton, who nowadays, along with Henry Moore, is generally regarded as Britain's greatest living artist. It is alsoand its symbolism will not be lost on the British publica signal honor to the art of dance itself and the role it has played in British art during the 20th century. When Ashton had his first dancing class the idea of any dancer or choreographer receiving an O.M. would have been as unlikely as Britain (or for that matter the United States) having a national ballet.

title: Small Radio Station Could Bring Aid in a Disaster
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)A solution to the communications problems often experienced in disasters like the dara break at Toccoa, Ga., last Sunday hai been demonsetrated to Federal officials. title: The Global Scramble for Phone Billions

title: Aloft at Mach 2, a Critic Rides and Rates the Concorde

The answer, in short, is that I didn't think it so dastardly. Of course the people who live in the takeoff and landing paths of noisy airplanes have a right to complain, and one trusts that eventually such pressure will lead to the imposition of strict noise controlswhich a technology that can reach the moon can surely meet.

title: POINT OF VIEW

Currently more than 15 percent of the city's labor force is being paid with Federal monies. Indeed, bondrating expens suggest that it would take New York a decade before it could sell bonds on a continuing basis. The reason usually given for the city's inability to float new bonds or notes is that they will find no buyers.

More importantly, its menu, although limited and containing only a couple of surprises, very good indeed.

While we're at it, making book on those novices who may in time win the sweepstakes, we'd better take a careful look at the work of one Patrick Meyers, whose Feedlot is now entering its last scheduled week at the Circle Rep in Sheridan Square. Mr. Meyers's special knack is for hitting you right in the eye you're watching him with.

title: Jersey Police Chief Loses Appeal; Failed to Press an Arson Charge

The court said the Police Chief violated the law by failing to inform the Morris County Prosecutor and insurance companies that he had caught the man who set fire to a church and two homes.

description: In the article on A Woman's Place last week the name of Liz Hohl was incorrectly given, as was the telephone number of the organization, which is 6554302. Fees for the fiveor sixpart workshops are $35 to $70 for the complete series.

description: At Connectquot, swimming is a team sport. Not only do the girls swim as a team, but Martha Morrell and Ray D'Annolfo also coach as a team.

title: Leslie Carroll To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Sinclair Noyes of Watertown, Conn., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Noyes's daughter, Leslie Scott Carroll, to Geoffrey William Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ray Crawford of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Fashion
description: To the soaring soundtrack from Star Wars, worn by handsome, healthy models who strode down the runway like confident goddesses and gods, some of the best modern fashion clothes cut, draped and shaped for the 70's  was introduced last month in Milan, now a fashion capital rivalling Paris and New York. The weeklong Milano Alta Moda Pronta  a weeklong event presenting readytowear clothes for next spring and summer featured the collections of 48 Italian designers and manufacturers. It is of enough importance to attract 1,000 buyers  17 percent of them American  who spend around $2.3 billion a year, and have steadily increased their orders by 30 percent annually for the last five years. This season, partly thanks to the sales success of this fall's Italian fashions in American stores, and partly to the excellent designs shown, American store buyers increased their orders appreciably. In February, when the clothes arrive in local stores, Americans will find not only the familiar Italian labels such as Fendi, Missoni, Mila Schoen, Roberta de Camerino and Andre Laug, but a whole new group of other designer names; Giorgio Armani, Gianni Versace, Muriel Grateau, Basile, Walter Albini, Cesare Scuinnach, Guy Paulin and Laura Biagiotti. These new designers have such talent and sense of what clothes today should be that their impact on world fashion is assured. In a way, there is something about the spirit of the clothes they designthe vitality, the freshness, the lack of artifice, the simplicity of cut, the comfortable sij wearability even when the silhouette is some what extreme  that reminds one of what is done by American designers. It's fashion  but it's easily understandable.

title: Election Fallout: The Issues Ahead
description: NOT more than six of New Jersey's 11 Democratic members of Congress appeared to be on Brendan Byrne's side last spring, when he scored an uphill victory to win the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Closed Schools Split Catholics in Detfoit

title: The Battle of Candlewood Lake (Contd.)
description: NEW FAIRFIELD ANOTHER ideological clash over property rights and zoning may be the offing over Candlewood Lake, one of the great natural settings the state. Just a little over a year ago the state dropped what had become a political hot potato over a proposal to turn a 253acre site on the lake into a public park. Earlier plans for the property, which failed to win necessary zoning approval, included the building of 315 luxury homes on acre lots and, when that application was rejected, construction of multiunit housing for 8,000 persons.

Ten of the 16 finalists have been determined and at least two more nations will find out this week whether they will spend next June in Argentina or join the Americans in watching the tournament on television. The Americans. however, will have the distinction or having to pay to watch the tournament on closedcircuit television screens.

title: A Buyer's Guide To College Guides
description: IT takes nearly $30 and several trips to the bookstore, but it is surely the first and arguably the best investment a parent or prospective stpdent can make when the task of choosing a college looms. The money will get you a selection of guides to American colleges and universitiesaliout 10 pounds worth of information from the statistical and comparative to the atmospheric and even iconoclastic.

title: 12 Monks Ask Brezhnev For Permission to Reopen Historic Kiev Monastery
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP)A dozen Russian Orthodox monks have appealed to Leonid T. Brezhnev the Soviet leader, to allow them to resume religious duties at a historic Kiev monastery that was converted into a tourist attraction 16 years aeo.

title: Christian Lips, Louise P. Hook Set Paris Bridal
description: Louise Pabst Hook of Belmont, Mass.. and George Mathew Verity Hook of Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Elisabeth Hook. to Lieut. Christian Lips of the French Army. son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lips of Paris.

title: CBS All Stars Fail to Live Up To Their Celestial Appellation
description: Billy is sounding crisp tonight, musician remarked during intermission at the All Stars concert Friday in Carnegie Hall. Billy Cobham, the drummer, was sounding crisp. But that may be the best thing that can be said about the evening.

title: Hyman, Braff and Grosz Play Jazz
description: Jack Kleinsinger's concert series, Highlights in Jazz, which is usually focused on jam sessions, changed its format from Thursday evening at the Loeb Auditorium, La Guardia Place at Washington Square South, to offer series of solos and duets by Dick Hyman, playing piano and organ; Ruby Braff, on cornet, and Marty Grosz, singing and playing guitar.

title: Nancy Fuld, Law Student, Betrothed to Daniel A. Neff
description: Nancy Gerstley Fuld and Daniel A. Neff, magna cum laude graduates of Brown University and members of Phi Beta Kappa, plan to be married in June.

title: SPORTS
description: WESTWOOD THERE was a jogger from Woodcliff Lake with a painful Achilles tendon, a quarterback from West Essex High School with a tender knee and, of course, the women complaining about bad backhands and tennis elbows.

title: Italy's Outcast Population
description: ROMEWhen Italy's Communists formally agreed to cooperate with the country's Christian Democratic Government last July, they created a political no man's land to their left, The territory is inhabited by students and young workers, by many of Italy's two million unemployed peoPie and by the discontented of all kinds, who live on the fringe of society and feel rejected by it.

title: Specialists in India Are Creating Thriving Gains in Dry Wasteland.
description: JOBNER, IndiaTwenty years ago this village on the edge of the Rajasthan desert was desolate and virtually unapproachable. Today, it has a population of ]0,000 and a hardsurface road connecting it with Jaipur, the state capital, 40 miles to the northeast.

title: U.S. Presses Effort To Direct Business To Minority Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Despite legal challenges and other serious obstacles, the Government is pressing ahead with its most ambitious effort ever to promote business for companies owned by members of racial minority groups.

title: Want ads
description: work better for you in The New York Times Call (212) 3543900

title: Carter's Economic Act
description: WASHINGTONTreasury Secretary Michael Blumenthal has given another strong hint that the Carter Administration is tilting toward stimulative tax relief next year rather than the tax reform Jimmy Carter talked about all through his campaign and his first year in the White House.

title: Marie E. Dent Is Fiancee Of Stephen John Scofield
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Dent of Douglas Manor, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Elaine Dent, to Stephen John Scofield, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Scofield of Denville, N. J. me couple plan to be married next March.

title: Capital Drives Prosper
description: THE long recessioninduced drought in college fund drives is over. Colleges across the country are again in the midst of an ambitious round of campaigns to raise record amounts of money to replace deteriorating plant and to replenish endowments eaten away by inflation.

title: Madison Takes Suburban Title
description: Matt Slane ran back two Interceptions for touchdowns as Madison Borough remained unbeaten and untied by blanking New Providence, 330. Madison's eighth success clinched the Suburban Conference championship.

title: Fairies and Enchantments
description: Never has Mollie Hunter's prose seemed so exactly right, so perfectly cast as in these four stgries. If it were not apparent frpm the title page that they are new, one would assume that Hunter had chosen all four from the hundreds in Celtic folklore and was acting only as collector. But they are all new, and delightful: easy to read but rich in tone.

title: Anyone Here for Farming?
description: AFTER a walk around my backyard the other day, I went into the house and got right on the phone to my friend, Mimi the lawyer, to tell her that I was planning to be a farmer.

title: L.I. Police Arrest Drouin
description: HUNTINGTON, LI., Nov. 12Jude Drouin, the New York Islanders eventempered, playmaking center, was arrested early this morning after he allegedly sprayed Mace at a college student he thought was harassing him.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike Put Off
description: Long island Rail Road trainmen and conductors have postponed a threatened strike pending a court hearing scheduled for tomorrow. Page 40.

title: A Memorial to Mrs. Dodge
description: MADISON ST. FRANCIS OF ASSISI, cast in lifesize bronze, rises from massive rock. He is accompanied by his beloved shepherd dog and birds, and is profiled against vast stretches of rolling hills on the distant sunlit horizon.

title: The Reasons Behind Byrne's Victory
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE gambled his political career on his ability to convince New Jerseyans that the state income tax was equitable, and he won the gamble in the closing days of the campaign, like a riverboat hustler pulling an inside straight on the last deal of the cards.

title: A Russian Touch of Class at Marble Hall
description: RYE SONYA LUDWIG, social director at Marble Hall, does not merely enter a room. She makes an entrance with a style and pan ache that belie her 78 years. Then, her dark eyes flashing, she glances around for new faces, so that she can exercise her prerogative as the maven of mixandmingle at the women's spa. Hello, darlings, whoever you are, she purrs.

title: Trenton Prison: An Appeal To Close It
description: ON AUG. 19, Robert Mulcahy, the state's Commissioner of Corrections, unveiled plans for the $37 million, 800bed, twophase renovation of Trenton State Prison. At his side during the wellattended press conference were several state and local officials, giving the impression that this use of a $41.5 million bond issue had the broadest political support. Whether it should is another question.

title: Emigre Warns U.S. Against Underrating Soviet Science Work
description: Despite continued repression of dissent in the Soviet Union, Moscow has adopted a pragmatic attitude in getting as much science as possible out of even dissident and Jewish scientists, an migr Soviet physicist says.

title: Between Karl Barth and Captain Kangaroo
description: RAIN up a child in the way he should go, and when he is old he shall not depart from it, says the Book of Proverbs, and Whoever causes one of these little ones to sin, it would be better for him to have a great millstone fastened round his neck and to be drowned in the depth of the sea, Jesus warns his disciples for anyone who sets out to teach children religion or to write religious books for them, this is the problem in a nutshell. If you don't do it right the results may be disastrous.

title: Malaysia, South Korea Tie
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 12 (AP)Malaysia and South Korea played to a scoreless tie after a 30minute over time period in the final match of the King's Cup soccer tournament. The teams will share the Thai King's Gold Trophy.

title: Oil Executive Plunges to Death After Police Balk First Attempt
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 12 (AP)An oil company executive apparently leaped to his death from his ninthfloor office yesterday after the police who stopped him from jumping minutes earlier released him, the authorities said.

title: Two Boys Are Hurt In Explosion
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 11 Two 9yearold boys who were playing on an abandoned truck in an empty lot here were critically burned this afternoon when the truck's gasoline tank exploded. They were rusfhed by helicopter to the burn unit of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center in Manhattan, where they were both said to be in critical condition. The boys were identified as Eric Neher of 45 Beechwood Avenue and Peter Eggers of 30 Drake Avenue, both in New Rochelle.

title: Budget Aide Named in Albany
description: ALBANY (UPI)Joseph Gornes, branch manger for Sperry Univac Corporation in Washington, has been appointed to the $46,849 post of deputy state budget director, Budget Director Philip Toia said that Mr. Domes, who holds a bachelor's degree in business administration from the University of South Carolina, has extensive experience in data processing.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: OSAKA, JapanJapanese industrialists tend to have terse sayings that sum up their personal business philosophy. That of Toshihiko Yamashita dates from his days as an airconditioning executive: In times of prosperity, don't overheat; in times of adversity, remain coolheaded.

title: State Tackles The Energy Crisis
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS I THINK New Jersey is definitely a leader at this point, said Frederic W. Hammesfahr, chairman of the newly established New Jersey Energy Research Institute.

title: H.E.W. Tells Iowa Library It Accepts Lack of Ramps For Handicapped People
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12A spokesman said today that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is not opposed to the lack of facilities for people wheelchairs at the public library in Rudd, Iowa, a small farming community with a population of 429 persons, none of whom is confined to a wheelchair.

title: City U. Rising Again
description: CALLED by some th' world's largest jungle gym, the unfinished north academic complex at City College has stood for two years silhouetted against the New York skyline. A tangle of steel keams and concrete generally anchored in a sea of mud, it is a monument to New York's fiscal crisis.

title: They Confirmed the Notion at Last Week's Meeting That the Brain Can Only Be Understood Through Chemistry
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.Fifty years ago Sigmund Freud suggested that every mental event would some day be found to be basically chemical.

title: HOUSE VOTING ON A BILL ON OIL CARGO CORRECTED
description: On Oct. 23, 1977, The New York Times incorrectly reported votes by Congressmen from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a bill to guarantee United States flag ships a 9.5 percent share of the country's oil imports. The bill was defeated, 257 to 165, on Oct. 19.

title: Beautiful Begonias Can Be Selected for Those Smaller Places
description: The only thing that might limit an interest in begonias, is lack of imagination. Space is not a problem. There are many begonias just right for small places. A few can be suspended in hanging containers. A number of them can be planted in glass bubbles or terrariums. Others can be displayed as bonsai. And many can be grown in conventional pots.

title: Health Products Aid State's Economy
description: TRENTON WHILE much of New Jersey's industrial base has been stagnating, the 100 or so companies that manufacture pills, notions and other.health products have been booming.

title: Sugar Game: Consumer Loses
description: WASHINGTON  The curtain came down on a classic capital shadow play last week, a drama in three acts involving a standard cast of characters politicians, lobbyists, businessmen, farmers and the President. Also woven into the script: lahor policy and international trade.

title: Oceanside, Plainedge Earn Shutouts, Titles
description: Two teams carrying underdog images, Oceanside and Plainedgs, relinquished their alsoran roles yesterday and clinched Nassau Conference championships. Oceanside roared past Massapequa, 460, to take the Conference I crowd and Plainedge turned in its fifth shutout to defeat Uniondale, 60, for the Conference 11 title.

title: Oklahoma Clinches Tie In Big Eight Title Race
description: NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 12 (UPI)Billy Sims, a sophomore halfback, scored touchdowns on three of his six carries and Kenny King, a fullback, rushed for 121 yards today as Oklahoma routed Colorado, 5214. The victory assured the Sooners of at least a tie for the Big Eight Conference title.

title: ART
description: MORRISTOWN OSCAR WILDE once said that only a fool doesn't judge by appearances, and his observation has been certified countless times in fashion.

title: PEOPLE
description: A CRYSTAL BALL sat atop the royal scepter at two major retail chains last week as veteran planners took the helm at Sears, Roebuck & Company and the F. W. Woolworth Company.

title: Julian Bream Exciting on Lute And Guitar in Town Hall Show
description: Julian Bream, who in addition to being the world's foremost lutenist is an eminent guitarist, played his annual Town Hall recital Thursday night. As usual, he performed on both instruments and delighted a large, youthful audience.

title: Special Children Need Special Help
description: THE 1950's and 60's hold no nostalgia for parents of learningdisabled young adults. Those past decades heard strange new terms. Minimal brain damage and invisible handicap were, among the 40odd new terms that came into use. Confused, often desperate, parents seeking information and help for their children found that the professionals they sought out for consultation were usually no better informed.

title: James Allen Barnett to Wed Kathryn Ann Kilzen in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kilzen of FaIr Haven, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ann Kilzen, to James Allen Barnett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lester A. Barnett of West End, N. J.

title: DINING OUT
description: SIMPLY calling Koban, in Port Jefferson, Japanese restaurant leaves a great deal unsaid. Like most of the Japanese restaurants on the Island, it departs from Japanese traditions, but it does so with plenty of highly individual taste and style. If authenticity is not your primary interest, dining at Koban is a refreshingly delightful experience.

title: TV on the Eve of Drastic Change
description: Although ABCTV has climbed to the top of the primetime ratings moun tain, Leonard H. Goldenson, chairman of ABC Inc., has been delivering speeches, that could be accompanied by the caption,Why Is This Man Frowning? while business and profits have never been better, the industry is beginning to feel the heat of new technologies that will undoubtedly add up to radical changes in the distribution, content and consumption of that contemporary behemoth called communications.

title: Westchester/ThisWeek
description: BALDWIN PLACETobacco Road. Today. at 2 P.M. Man of La Mancha. Thursday to Saturday 8:30 P.M., next Sunday at 2 P.M. (through Dec. 11). $5.50, except Saturday $6.50. Special rates available for groups, students under 18 and the elderly on Wednesday, Thursday and Sundays. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6. 6281169.

title: Bette Ackerman Affianced to David Taylor, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Ackerman of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bette J. Ackerman, to David J. Taylor, a partner in the Washington law firm of Peabody, Rivlin, Lambert & Meyers.

title: Prosecution Nearing End of Case In the Drug Trial of Leroy Barnes
description: Undercover agents testified last week as Federal prosecutors neared the enc of their case against Leroy (Nicky) Barnet and 14 other defendants charged wits participation in a major narcotics opera. lion in Harlem.

title: Lufthansa Resumes Algiers Flights After Cancellation Oyer Security
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 12 (AP)Lufthansa Airlines, which canceled a flight to Algeria this week over a security dispute, announced that today's flight to Algiers flew on schedule.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market, buoyed by encouraging economic developments, posted its best weekly gain the year last week in accelerated trading.

title: Betsey Heath to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Heath of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Stanton Heath, to Robert Thomas Walsh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh of West Hartford.

title: The Tide Turns for the G.O.P.
description: LAST Tuesday's elections on the Island could mark the end of the devastating Watergate era for the Nassau and Suffolk Republican organizations.

title: President's Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Following is the text of President Carter's Thanksgiving Day proclamation, issued yesterday:

title: The New Question s4 to Ask About Schools
description: PEOPLE looking at houses all want to know it the school Is going to close, said a suburban New York realestate broker. Often I can't tell them. Families have considered schools one of the most important factors In making a decision about where to live. They have asked questions about reading scores and extracurricular activities. Because of recent events, there are now new questions to ask before buying or renting a home.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: A Receiver to Take Over Control Of Methodist Retirement Homes
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UPI)A receiver has been named to take over control of the United Methodist Church's Pacific Homes, a chain of 14 retirement homes in California, Arizona and Hawaii.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Vancouver's Penny Stocks: You Takes Your Chances
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaGlass and steel skyscrapers have replaced the saloons and dance halls spawned by mining booms of the 19th century, but this city remains a stronghold for the last of the Wild West stock exchanges, where penny stocks glitter brighter than Miss Kitty's rhinestones and flimflam artists have long found a home.

title: Flood Control: A Losing Battle
description: OAKLAND WHEN more than five inches of rain fell in New Jersey last Tuesday, a familiar scene recurred: Key highways were inundated, the basements of thousands homes were flooded and dozens of streams overflowed. It has happened before and it will happen again, not only along the Atlantic Coast, but in the hills of western Bergen County, the plains of Passaic County and the valleys of Union County. Hardly a community escaped the ravages of water making its own path.

title: ANTIQUES
description: New Yorkers in recent weeks have.been exposed to what amounts to a spectacular Oriental festival. And it's not over yet. The multifaceted celebration has been centered in many placesmuseums, art galleries and auction housesand offered a panoramic selection of 10 centuries of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Tibetan, Javanese and Nepalese artifacts, decorations, screens, paintings and sculptures.

title: Spielberg's Journey From Sharks to The Stars
description: Im beginning to understand how FarrahFawcettMajors must feel, joked director Steven Spielberg, whose new film Close Encounters of the Third Kind has made him a focus of attention for everyone from Wall Street financiers to UFO enthusiasts. Columbia Pictures, whose stock has fluctuated convulsively in response to early reviews of the movie, has high hopes and $25 million riding on the story of a power company lineman, played by Richard Dreyfuss, who sights a UFO and is thrilled and transformed by the experience. But for Mr. Spielberg, the stakes may be even higher.

title: TERRORISM TERMED A NEW TYPE OF WAR
description: Terrorism could develop into a form of surrogate war, recent studies have concluded, with governments employing terrorist groups or organizing their own to carry out a wide range of hostile acts az ainst other states.

title: CAREY ASKS CARTER FOR MAJOR FLOOD AID
description: Governor Carey, citing an estimate of $5 million in damages to 3,000 homes on Staten sland and 300 homes in Rockland County, formally appealed to President Carter yesterday to declare New York State a maior disaster area.

title: Ah, for the Days Of Not Frills But the Frays
description: I suspect that the oldtimer, while strongly denouncing the World Series smoke bomb and the civilian dashing from bleachers to home plate, is muttering that the punishment fits the crime and finds explanation, if not an excuse for such conduct.

title: LETTERS
description: Raoul lierger's article on judicial legislation ('The Court, Oct. 9) underscores a fundamental issue that surfaces daily in our city's newspapers. To wit, IS it the job of the judiciary to proscribe taxi cruising in Manhattan, or to eliminate curbside parking, or to impose tolls on formerly tollfree bridges, or to determine whether or not the SST should be allowed to land in Niw York?

title: Patronage? It's All in the Lenses Of the Beholder
description: Attention turned again last week, as it does from time to time, to Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedmannot because he is the only man in City Hall who has monogrammed lenses in his eveelasses but because he is scheduled to get the choicest patronage plum of all, appointHall ment to the Board of Water Supply. The board has few duties, but Mr. Friedman would be paid $20,000 a year for life as a commissioner and would get, an office, a car and driver with the position, which Mayorelect Edward I. Koch says should be abolished altogether, along with the rest of the boarda job that can be done only by the State Legislature. Mr. Friedman has been Mayor Beame's chief of patronage, so there is a certain poetic justice in his winding up with such an easy position.

title: Lillian Carter Feeling Better
description: DUBLIN. Nov. 12 (Reuters)President Carter's mother Lillian, who is 79 years ()id, was almost fit enough today to resome the itinerary of her trip to Ireland alter having neen ordered to nett yesterday with a cold, Mrs. Carter is in Ireland an exchange visit arranged by the rienciship Force.

title: Paris in the Winter: For Lovers and Others
description: I have heard about Paris in the springthe streaky pale glowing color of the city and the clouds called moutons hanging in the skybut that Paris is not the city I know. I've gone to Paris six times, and always in the winter: Things just work out that way.

title: Australia Advertises Openings for Spies
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (Reuters)  The Australian Government seems to be having trouble recruiting spies.

title: High Spirits Reign in Darien
description: FINDING wit and sophistication in a dinner theater production is akin to getting drunk at Schrafft's. Both can be done, but it isn't expected. But let me assure you that wit and sophistication are onstage at the new Darien Dinner Theater's opening production of High Spirits, the Hugh MartinTimothy Gray musical adaptation of Noel Coward's Blithe Spirit.

title: Slovenian Philharmonic Stresses Personality
description: The Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra, which appeared Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall as part of its first American tour, is not about to challenge the grand, rich and famous spillphonic ensembles of this world. It is not very large or very polished or very smooth or brilliant. Its oboe player, true to Central and Eastern European tradition, sounds like an expiring mallard.

title: Future Farmers Name President
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 12 (AP)The Future Farmers of America have elected a 19yearold Texas cattle rancher to be their president for the coming year. He is J. Ken Johnson, who started development of a herd of registered beef cattle while he was going to Nacogdoches Hign School, was president of its student body, received the American High School Award for Excellence and was a member of the National Honor Society.

title: Russell Baker Has a Flarium
description: USSELI. BAKER asks us to believe, in this his first junior book, that there was ??? a mad scientist named Dr. Frankenstein who lived in the far away kingdom of Delirium.

title: Urals
description: DUTCHRachel, beloved wife of Alex. Passed away suddenly. Relatives and friends are deeply saddened and extend heartfelt sm. pathy.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR A CHANGE, the bulls on the economy and the stock market had something to cheer about last week as some of the fog enveloping the business and political scenes began to lift. Most of the latest data showed that business activity ran fairly strong during October after the wellrecognized and worrisome lull that started in midsummer.

title: N. Rockland Gives Ramapo First Loss
description: A touchdown 25 seconds before the end of the first half and a field goal 19 seconds before the end of the game vaulted North Rockland into the Rockland County P.S.A.L, race yesterday with a 107 victory over previously undefeated Ramapo.

title: SOLAR TEST FACILITY IS NEAR COMPLETION
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.A facility with 5,500 mirrors focusing on a 200foot tower, part of the most ambitious effort so far to develop the technology needed for conversion of solar energy into largescale electric power, is nearing completion here.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: BUILTIN masonry fireplaces almost always have an ash pit and cleanout door below the hearth that is accessible either I rom outside (in back of the fireplace) or from inside (in the basement, just below the fireplace).

title: P.L.O. Ready to Quit Israel Border Area, But on Own Terms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 12The Palestine Liberation Organization is fully committed to an agreement for limited withdrawal of its guerrillas in southern Lebanon from the Israeli border, Palestinian officials said today. But they added that the guerrillas would not withdraw would not t urn over positions to Israeliunder the pressure of Israelei gunfire and backed Lebanese Christian militia forces.

title: Brown Turns Back Columbia, 2114
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Nov. 12Maybe Brown was paying too much attention to what was happening in New Haven and not enough attention to what was happening on its own football field. The Bruins defeated a tenacious Columbia team today, 2114, but doing so was a struggle, requiring a tiebreaking touchdown in the final quarter.

title: Carter Endorses Colleges Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)  President Carter today gave a rare endorsement to a campaign aimed at raising $50 million for 41 predominately black colleges sharing in the United Negro College Fund. Although the financial status of these colleges is quite weaktheir academic contributions and social contributions have been superb, the President said. He greeted leaders of the fund at the White House.

title: Orchid Lovers Grow in Bunches
description: AN orchid, said Rex Stout, is not a flower as a gladiola or a poppy is flower. It is a signal for seduction. Mr. Stout was referring to growing, not wearing, orchids. He knew that the orchid does to men what it does to insects. It traps them.

title: Black Superstar on the Frontier
description: When Reggie Jackson accepted the car given by Sport magazine to the outstanding player in the World Series he said unusual things.

title: DelBello Looks To 2dTerm Goals
description: WHITE PLAINS THE word fulfilling crops up frequently when Alfred B. Delbello discusses his plans for his second term as Westchester's County Executive. We spent the first four years trying to identify the county's major problems and developing responses to them, he said in an interview. I think the second term will be mainly occupied with fulfilling those program goals.

title: Psychic Energy: A Mind Trip
description: JERSEY CITY IN A dimly lit, shabbily furnished room that would seem to inspire lethargy, a group of people here are seeking to unlock the secrets of an elusive and perhaps profound energy. They are shooting for the stars, so to speak, trying to tap inner psychic energies that purportedly will permit them to bend spoons, send wordless messages and move objects with their minds.

title: Yes: They Teach SelfConfidence
description: IN the mid19th century, the pattern of public education was established on coeducational lines, not because American society was strongly convinced of feminist aspirations for equal rights for women but because educating women alongside men was seen to be expedient. Forces inside and outside the classroom effectively dictated that women's roles and intellectural aspirations would be different from, and complimentary to, those of men.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: National Easter Seal Child Named
description: ST. LOUIS. Nov. 12 (UPI) A 5yearold boy from Illinois has been named as the 1978 National Easter Seal Child, the symbol of the more than 350,000 disabled persons of all ages who are helped each year by tho Easter Seal services. The selection of Tony Zidek of Wonder Lake was announced Tuesday at the society's annual meeting. He is in the kindergarten at West School in Crystal Lake.

title: Woman Pressing Suit Over Infant's Identity
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12 (API)A woman who claims that hospital employees gave her the wrong haby after she gave birth to a son in 1969 says she is disappointed that a jury considering her $1

title: The Adventures of Gertrude
description: OU tell me a Trudy, says Martha to her mother, and the story begins like this: Once upon a time there was a girl whose name was Gertrude but they called her Trudy and she had a brother. His name was Jacob. Strange to tell, however, the characters in each story look just like Martha

title: Deths
description: LEWISRose. Beloved wife of Abraham. Loving mother of Anita Rhodes & Neville. Adored grandmother of Harold, Jennifer, Alan, Matthew, Andrew & Jonathan. Services Sunday tgam at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel Long Bch Rd at Greystone, Rockville Center LI.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: To appraise a building objectively requires detachment, and the two structures I am about to discuss are ones to which I am attached in a very special way; therefore this will be a subjective report. Both buildings  the Avery Architectural Library at Columbia University and the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University  were home to me for many years. In retrospect, those were wonderful years when the sheer, heady pursuit of knowledge and the luxury of total immersion in the arts was its own justification and end. How one to be objective about the privilege of associating with great minds and great books? How to cast a cool eye on places that were the source of revelation and discovery?

title: R. B. Machinist Fiance Of Caroline Hirschfeld
description: Mr. and Mrs. Georg Hirschfeld of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Castelleras, France, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Monika Hirschfeld, to Robert B. Machinist, on or Mr. and Mrs. Morris L. Levinson of New York and Townshend, Vt.

title: Stores in Bronx Remain Profitable Despite Troubles
description: It was the morning after last July's blackout. Sixtyoneyearold Joseph Weinberg stood in the back of his empty furniture store on East 138th Street in the heart of the South Bronx and vowed he would not return. His 3,300 squarefoot showroom was vacant except for four chandeliers, a bookcase and a couch. Except for the green carpeting on the floor could have been confused for an empty airplane hangar.

title: Isolation Scary at First To CityBred Suburbanites
description: Moving to the suburbs doesn't give city people a sense of security. It doesn't even give them a false sense of security. What they get is a false sense of danger, especially for the first few weeks.

title: Karen Buranskas Plays A SureHanded Cello
description: Karen Buranskas, who made her New York debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hal', is a young cellist who isnt bashful about showing off her technique. And no wonder.

title: Wine
description: It's fashionable these days to describe Band() as Italy's best wine. Certainly, there are sonic impressive examples around  big, hefty wines with lots of flavor. They ago well and they're riot too expensive. No doubt about it, llarulo is a formidable wine and, perhaps, it really is the finest product of the Italian vineyards.

title: 61 Measles Cases in Milwaukee
description: MILWAUREE, Nov. 12 (UPI)The University of Marquette said today that 61 diagnosed cases of rubclia (German measles) had been rcported at the school since Oct. 14. Bit. tho University of WisconsinMilwaukee reported onty one diagnosed case of the disease. About 1,000 students received vaccine under week's free immunization program.

title: Hastening To Death
description: DYLAN THOMAS owed me two pounds when he died. Ten thousand people could make such a claimand not a voice would be raised in doubtwho handed the money over, as I did, only pretending that it was a loan. And when Thomas asked for a loanknowing he would never repay it, knowing you knewhe delighted in the lie, delighting in the poet as con man, pirate or bad boy. Such playacting could seem an innocent pleasure, but in his character it connected with pain.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: CONVERSATIONS with a child. What a wonderful, tender thing, the adult bringing the wisdom of the ages to the youngster and receiving in turn the penetrating and pithy illumination that only a young and as yet uncorrupted mind can bring to bear with such striking simplicity. Hands across the generation gap and a feeling of such warmth as can result only from this rare interplay of maturity and youth.

title: Energy: Facing the Problems
description: It was a normal Presidential tactic for Jimmy Carter to plan a whizzbang trip abroad to focus the nation's mind on foreign policy right after the Bert Lance affair. John F. Kennedy acted similarly following the Bay of Pigs when he flew to Europe for a successful talk with de Gaulle in Paris and an unsuccessful talk with Khrushchev in Vienna.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: SPEAKING of children's books which we do this week, one 01 !he most honored authorillustrator; of hem is Leo Lanni. Mr. Lionni was here recently, having come from his home and studio in tile Chianti Hills near l'uscany, ???aly. to celebrate three ovents Mat pretty much box his pro. tessional compass. The first was a new children's hook the: 15th) for Pantheon, A FV. Story. The second was a showing of his drawings and sculptures at the Staempfli Gallery, representations of strange and beautiful imaginary plants never previously seen upon this earth except in Mr. Lionni's mind's eye. And the third was ihe publication by Knopf of his first adult hook, Parallel Botany, which is a fulldress, scientifically couched monograph on the origins, habitat, morphology, etc., of the plants in his imaginary garden.
