title: That Helms Badge Of Honor
description: WASHINGTONPresident Carter's affirmation that the former Director of Central Intelligence, Richard Helms, deserves no badge of honor for deceiving the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was well taken. What is remarkable is that, for all the public debate over the sentencing of Mr. Helms, there has been remarkably little challenge to Mr. Helms's basic contention that I found myself in a position of conflict. He had argued that his oath to the Central Intelligence Agency to protect secrets was fundamentally irreconcilable with his oath to tell the truth to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. I do not accept this.

description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 12 (AP)Mary Lou Crocker of Louisville, Ky., was the surprise leader after the second clay of the Colgate Far'East women'ss golf tournament today as she scored a 71 for 142 after 36 holes.

description: WHEN Cathleen Sheehan's friends ask her, How come you have a black brother? the 8yearold, blond, blueeyed Garden City child says, with just hint of exasperation, I tell them what adoption means.

As, probably, they have not. They are among the more than 2,000 children's txxiks published each year in America that for one very good reason or another have been rejected by children almost on sight.

title: The Vandenberg
description: THE truth journalists seek to report is often complex and piecemeal, so the temptation assume the novelist's omniscience must be strong. Now Marvin Kalb and Ted Koppel, diplomatic correspondents for CBS and ABC, respectively, have succumbed and given us In the National Interest, a diplomatic thriller set in the Middle East. Mr_ Kalb, with his brother Bernard, wrote a rather favorable biography of Henry Kissinger, while Mr. IN THE NATIONAL INTEREST By Marvin Kalb and Ted Koppel. 371 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.

title: Metropolitan Major Colleges: More Home Talent Staying Home
description: Wayne McKoy and Jeff Ruland stayed home. Two of the finest big men on the national schoolboy basketball scene last season are at St. John's and Iona, respectively, and that's enough to make the entire New York metropolitan area coaching profession happy.

title: THE ART OF BEING O'KEEFFE
description: She started out like any little girl in Sun Prairie, Wis., playing with her dolls, sewing clothes, listening to stories read by her mother. But by the time she was Georgia O'Keeffe already had crazy notions of being an artist, and when she was 18, she set out on her determined and often solitary course. Along the way, she met an art teacher with a simple but, to her, revolutionary approach. His idea was  to fill a space in a beautiful way. Ever since, in both her art and her life, O'Keeffe has been filling space in beautiful ways. On canvas, she has distilled her unique vision of nature: an expanding universe in the heart of a flower, the closeness of a lust horizon, the rhythms of life in a sundried bone. As woman, she has projected an image of courage and quiet passion, an image that spurred her husband, pioneer photographer Alfred Stieglitz, to make hundreds portraits of her (two are shown here). On Tuesday, Nov. 15, Georgia O'Keeffe, still keenly engaged in painting and developing new skills as a potter, will turn To celebrate her birthday, WNET will present that evening an hourlong program on O'Keeffe, the first film she has ever allowed to be made of her life and work.

title: 100 Animals Facing Death if Not Adopted
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12About 100 animals at the Elmsford Animal Shelter will have to be put to death by Monday unless they are adopted, the agency has warned.

title: Poetry Journal Yields Rich Harvest
description: ROMAINE MURPHY of Tarrytown went to the Hartsdale post office recently and asked for the mail in Box 76. She was not surprised that it filled her shopping bag. The single week's delivery contained 127 envelopes, each with a poem enclosed. One envelope, in fact, was crammed with 10. Mrs. Murphy, a poet herself, is one of five women who edit poetry magazine called Gravida, medical term that means a woman heavy with life, or pregnant.

title: Coming Attractions
description: HARTFORD THERE never was any doubt among Democrats that as soon as the curtain fell on last week's elections, they would begin rehearsing their lines for the next. When politicians point with pride to the voting results in one town, or view the results in another with alarm, chances are they are not thinking so much of the narrow scene in that town as they are of the iarger drama to come.

title: The Man of a Thousand Patents
description: When Thomas A. Edison died, President Hoover was urged to order all electricity throughou! the United States turned off for a minute on the day of the funeral. Cooler heads had the prescience to warn that a power outage in New York City or elsewhere was no way to memorialize genius. The country that celebrated Edison as the most famous American settled prudently for a reverential dimming of nonessential lights. As Ronald Clark, the most recent biographer of Edison, observes, the result was impressive.

title: ARABS MEET IN TUNIS; NEW RIFTS THREATEN GENEVA UNITY EFFORT
description: TUNIS, Nov. 12Foreign ministers of the Arab League countries opened a threeday meeting here today amid pleas for solidarity in the face of at least two potentially divisive issues.

title: There aren't any tools in this trade. Training is some knowledge, a lot of experience and a backyardful of intuition.
description: Farm was a large stone wall that Slew refused to approach. It took some rough handling, but in time Turner was able to ride Slew up to and along the wall. You pick out something they don't want to do, says Turner, and you just make them do it. When you finally get to the race track later on, you'll have much more control. You'd rather have them hate the farm or hate the barn  discipline them there  but love the racetrack. Racing or training, that's the one place you don't want problems. Handling classy young horses is, according to Turner, just like raising smart kids. Without discipline, they're not worth five dead flies. But it's got to be done right  channel their spirit but don't break itand it's got to be done early, or it's just too late. More than once, when he was too frisky for his own  or Turner'sgood, Slew felt the sting of a shank end across his nose. But by early spring he'd got the

Abrams. $45. with a mustache and Sonny Liston as a black Santa Clans), his famous logotypes (Zum Zum, National Airlines, Tonsil Records, Charley O's), his package design (the Brasserie takeout picnic carton), hisad campaigns (N.Y. Bets, Inver House, Braniff, Wolfschmidt, Olivetti) is at once a testament to his belief in his own genius and evidence that his belief is not misplaced.

title: Children's Books
description: Waiting at the schoolyard 0, pick up my 7yearold son, 1 listened to the children insulting each other with the same rhymes I learned in a different schoolyard, and i asked myself, why does nonsense survive? Why do even the most scurrilous specimens get passed on from child to child and traded, along with baseball cards and secrets? Is it because nonsense at its best gives them faith without commandments and wisdom without diplomas? But shouldn't the best poetry for children do as much?

Sometimes at night, when it is raining and worry that the roof is leaking or the basement is flooding, it all comes back to me in vivid detail. I have been transferred to New York from the Midwest and am faced with the task of finding new home.

title: A BLACK IS ELECTED NEW ORLEANS MAYOR
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12  Ernest N. Morial was elected Mayor of New Orleans today and will become the first black to servein that post.. When he takes office next year he will have the largest constituency in the South of any black official.

title: Comeback of a Victorian Village
description: SEA CLIFF EIGHT years ago when Lois Eklund, a retired department store executive, decided to open an antiques shop in this quaint Victorian village, part of the main business area was a grim, poorly lighted avenue. Six out of 10 shops were abandoned, and the likelihood that they would ever be revitalized appeared slim. Although Sea Cliff was once a major East Coast resort where New Yorkers gathered by the thousands to enjoy a summer by the sea, interest in the village had waned over the years.

title: Thief Repays City After 25 Years

Edward Finamcre, city park superintendent, said he had received a $10 bill with an anonymous note saying, Enclosed is $10 for two benches that were stolen from Lincoln Park over 25 years ago. I hope that this covers the cost of replacing them.

For the next few weeks or months or years, the character, looking forever spruce, changes clothes at will, coming up with variations of costume that would be beyond the capacity of a steamer trunk.

Members of his family have been harassed.

title: HOW LONG CAN AFRICA'S WHITES HOLD OUT?
description: The 2,000mile journey through White Africa, from the northern reaches of Rhodesia to Cape Town in South Africa, was ended. How brittle, how removed, to chatter at a New York cocktail party about the agony of apartheid, black revolutionaries, and the jealous blood love of the White Afrikaners for the land. Then, suddenly, the faces become painfully vivid again in a burst of headlines. South African police arrest scores of black leaders, ban their organizations and leading newspapers, and confine white supporters.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONSecretary of Labor Ray MarshallFreddie Ray before he dropped his first namelooks and sounds a lot like the kind of person President Carter had in mind when he said during his campaign that he would bring nonWashington types into his Administration. The economist from the University of Texan. with big glow drawl, even slower grin, gap between the two front teeth and a boyhood spent in a Baptist orphanage, is not the kind of figure Washington is accustomed to regarding as belonging to the establishment of either party.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: BRIDGEPORTPaintings and watercolors. by Milton Ossorio, extended through Nov. 23, Housatonic Community College, 516 Barnum Ave. 5796409.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TOMORROW South America, West Indies, Etc.

title: Peddlers Who Sank Roots
description: HELENE GERARD had just shown her visitor a page from a notebook she keeps of written reportsill fact freeassociation impressions. she saysof taperecorded interviews she is conducting in her search for traces of the late 19thcentury Jewish peddlers of eastern Long Island.

title: FISHING
description: FISHING around the Island has been about as unsettled as the waters. The three weeks of easterly winds have tended to hold summer fish inshore while smatterings of winter fish should begin to make their appearance known on the offshore wrecks.

title: She Led a Quiet Life of LuxuryNow Leads AntiApartheid Fight
description: JOHANNESBURGFor years, Bridget Oppenheimer, wife of the world's leading diamond and gold magnate, Harry F. Oppenheimer. stayed out of the public eye. Her most conspicuous enthusiasms were for racehorses and being hostess of Brenthurst, the family's San Simeoulike estate on a treecovered hillside in northern Johannesburg.

title: A Serbian Town Honors Thousands Massacred by Nazis
description: KRAGUJEVAC, YugoslaviaEach fall for 30 years, tens of thousands of Yugoslays have converged on this small central Serbian sown to honor ex, memory of 7,000 victims, including 300 schoolboys, of a reprisal massacre by German soldiers.

title: What Made Arnold Wesker Rewrite Shakespeare
description: WASHINGTON Mention Shylock to most people, and their eyes glaze over with dim memories of antiSemitic clichesthe rich, Jew, the usurer, the unrealistic bond of a pound of flesh.

title: GARDENING
description: THOUGH leaves have been on homeowners minds in recent weeks as they raked and raked to get out from under, the trees themselves are of some concern. This evident particularly in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, where tree maladies has been taking their toll.

title: GARDENING
description: THE plant industry is alarmed at recent articles appearing in variety of publications listing many commonly grown plants as being ppisonous to humans. There have also been indications that the Federal Trade Commission is preparing a list of such plants on which a warning label indicating their toxicity will be re(mired when they are sold.

title: JOHN M. OGDEN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP)Funeral services will be held Wednesday for John M. Ogden, a retired baseball exec, utive and Philadelphia Phillies scout who signed Dick Allen to the team in 1960. Mr. Ogden, who was 80 years old, died Wednesday in Lankenau Hospital.

title: Ethiopian Regime Is Planning To Issue Special Identity Papers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 13 (Reuters)The Ethiopian Government is introducing special papers to be issued to genuine revolutionary patriots as part of a program to end violent political opposition.

title: VIETNAM IS SEEKING FULL CIVIL CONTROL
description: HUE, VietnamA cyclist with a red armband followed me around Hue, occasionally calling in Vietnamese to people who smiled for my cameras. They quickly turned away.

title: FRENCH LEFTS FIGHT REACHES GRASS ROOTS
description: REIMS, France, Nov. 12Only weeks after the surprising breakdown of the CommunistSocialist alliance in France, discord between the parties is filtering down to the grassroots level and further undermining the chances of a leftist takeover of the national Government in the legislative elections next March.

title: The MayorElect
description: When Mayorelect Edward I. Koch goes to Harvard University this week for four days of seminars with other newly elected Mayors on how to run a city, one of his instructors will be Victor Gotbaum, the New York labor leader whom Mr. Koch will have to deal with soon after taking office.

title: Knicks Box Score
description: NETS (90)

title: Seahawks Top Jets For First Shutout
description: The Jets made history yesterday, Seattle history. They became the first team that failed to score a point when playing the Seahawks, the expansion outfit that had lost 14 of 18 games in its twoyear history. The 19th game was theirs, by 170 over the New York team, which hit its low point of the campaign.

title: Prosecutor Expects More Arrests In Bolles Killing Within 6 Months
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 13The prosecutor of the Bolles murder trial says he expects more arrests In the case within the next six months.

title: Sports Today
description: 69th annual IC4A championships, at Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, noon.

title: Scoring and Statistics in N.F.L. Yesterday
description: INDIVIDUAL LEADERS

title: G.A.O. SAYS ALIENS RECEIVE $72 MILLION WELFARE AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Federal welfare payments to aliens in five states alone cost taxpayers more than $72 million last year, according to a General Accounting Office report released today.

title: Arms Control and the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13As it presses toward completion of negotiations with the Soviet Union on a new armscontrol agreement, the Carter Administration has become caught up in an awkward rearguard battle with critics in the Senate who fear the United States has already traded away too News much. Analysis To a far greater degree than previously, foreignpolicy conservatives like Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, have capitalized on Admin.. istration briefings to try to influence the final stages of negotiations, implying that they will not support the'ultimate treaty unless their present misgivings about the basic outlines of the accord are relieved.

title: Game Day: Busy Time For Jet Medical Team
description: On the sidelines, heads suddenly turned yesterday when Carl Barzilauskas began to scream in agony. His right kneecap had popped out of place, and he kept falling to the Shea Stadium turf as he tried to get up.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Even before the details of a new SovietAmerican strategic arms accord are settled, a lively debate has broken out over whether the proposed agreement would put the United States at a military disadvantage.

title: An Old Sport, Abercrombie & Fitch Says It Must Close Historic Doors
description: Abercrombie & Fitch says it is going out of business.

title: 2 Killed in Fort Devens Crash
description: FORT DEVENS, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP)Two New Hampshire men were killed when their 1938 airplane, which they had just repaired, crashed on takeoff from Moore Army Airfield at Fort Devens. Maj. Conley Thompson, public affairs officer at the base in Ayer, identified the dead as Edward J. Fritz Jr., 51 years old, of North Hampton, N.H., and Arthur C. Moulton of Hampton, N.H.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES.

title: Perahia, Youth and a Rarity
description: The Mannes College of Music benefit concert in Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon was very much a family affair with an accent on youth. All the performers are in their 20's and each has close connections with the school the American String Quartet has been in residence since 1975 and the pianist Murray Perahia is one of Mannes's most distinguishe graduates.

title: TV: Uplifting Essay on Aging
description: Television's attitude toward the elderly has always been terrifyingly practical. Retired people on fixed incomes are not stuff of the average advertiser's dreams. Therefore, the elderly don't count for very much in a programing process usually geared to consumers between the ages of 18 and 49. The Lawrence Welk Show, for instance, may have been getting respectable national ratings, but its audience profile was heavily skewed to older people, and the program was unceremoniously yanked from network presentation several years ago.

title: ALABAMA TRIAL SET TODAY IN 1963 CHURCH BOMBING
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 13Robert Chambliss, a 73yearold retired mechanic, goes on trial here tomorrow on charge of firstdegree murder in the first prosecution arising from the reopening by the state of inquires into the 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church in which four black girls were killed.

title: Notre Dame Weighs Effort to Delay Bowl Decision
description: Notre Dame is probably the only university in football that could ask for a delay before accepting a bowl bid and still get the bowl of its choice when all the pieces finally fall into place. Executives at the nation's most prestigious football college may decide this week to ask for a postponement of their bowl decision when the Cotton and Sugar Bowls proffer bids Saturday afternoon in South Bend, Ind., home of the Fighting Irish.

title: Spanish Prime Minister Discloses Two Attacks On His Official Residence
description: MURCIA, Spain, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Peime Minister Adolfo Suirez said unidentified gunmen fired a machine gun on the Moncloa Palace, his official residence in Madrid, early today for the secold time in two days.

title: Williamsburg Officers Elected
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 13 (AP)Trustees of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation have elected Carlisle H. Humelsine as chairman of the board and Charles R. Longworth as president. Mr. Humelsine succeeds Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court as board chairman, and Mr. Longworth will succeed Mr. Humelsine as president. The elections were held yesterday.

title: Music: Y Debut
description: It is a rare pleasure to hear an orchestral program performed with such lavish attention to detail as at Saturday night's formal debut of the Y Chamber Symphony at the 92d St.Y.M. Y.W.H.A.

title: ARCHBISHOP IS ORDAINED HEAD OF CYPRIOT CHURCH
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Archbishop Chrysostomos was enthroned today as head of the independent Cyprus Orthodox Church, and immediately made it clear that he would play an important role in the Greek Cypriot community's political affairs.

title: Mayer Wins Tourney in Straight Sets
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Sandy Mayer of the United States won the singles title at the ninth Stockholm open tennis tournament today by routing Ray Moore of South Africa, 62, 64, in a match lasting only 55 minutes.

title: Mozambique IsViewed as Africa's Best Hope for the Flowering of Socialism's New Man
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique  The idealistic left, in Africa, Europe and America is now looking to this country as it once looked to Ghana. Algeria and more recently Tanzania as fertile ground for the nurturing of socialism's new man.

title: Chess:
description: The heart of the problem of defending the castled king position is preventing the attacker from gaining open lines in that sector.

title: European Soccer
description: By Reuters.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (Reuters)The American Medical Association and the American Bar Association called today for the elimination of criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: 3 Governors Ask U.S. to Extend Deadline on Nitrite Ban in Bacon
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 13 (AP)Governors of three states in the Middle West have asked Bob Bergland, the. Secretary of Agriculture, to reconsider a deadline set for next Jan. 16 for the removal of nitrites in bacon processing.

title: Exxon Hopes to Begin Drilling Off Atlantic Coast in Early 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)The Exxon Corporation said it hoped to start drilling exploratory wells off the middle Atlantic coast around the beginning of next year.

title: Second in Command In Ethiopia Regime Is Reported Purged
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov, 13 (AP)Lt. Col. Atnafu Abate, ranked second in Ethiopia's ruling military council, has been purged, the Ethiopian radio said today.

title: A Black Man of Many Firsts Ernest Nathan Morial
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13Being the first black man is nothing new to Ernest N. Morial, the first black to be elected Mayor in this Deep South city.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: with a time of 25 minutes 19.5 seconds. The race was held for the benefit of a 3yearold local girl, Megin Post, who has leukemia. Megin's father, Kurt, was the last entrant to cross the finish line. Bill Sieben of Rahway finished second and Tom Fleming of Bloomfield was third.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: On Oct. 19, the South African Minister of Justice announced that a number of organizations were declared to be unlawful and that certain publications were prohibited. The banning of certain individuals, including Percy Qoboza, editor of The World, was announced simultaneously.

title: Galaxy's Speed Through Universe Found to Exceed a Million M.P.H.
description: By measuring the movements of the earth against the glow left from the fireball in which the universe was born, scientists have found that the Milky Way galaxy, the home of this solar system, is hurtling through space at more than a million miles an hour, relative to the universe as a whole.

title: BAN ON GIRL'S POEM ROUSES CONTROVERSY
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13Hundreds of spectatorsincluding teenagers, educators, elected officials and the elderlyhave repeatedly crowded into a Federal courtroom here for a trial that will decide whether a 77word poem by a 15yearold girl should be banned from a suburban high school library.

title: Rebels Kill 25 in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 13 (AP) Communist insurgents attacked tribesmen guarding a road construction crew in northern Thailand and killed 25, the police reported today. They said the incident occurred in Phayao Province, 375 miles north of Bangkok.

title: Five Bombs Explode in Belfast On Eve of Walkout by Firemen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 13 (AP)Five firebombs exploded in Belfast tonight, setting off blazes that gutted several buildings on the eve of a planned strike by firemen here and in the rest of Britain. Four other bombs were defused by army experts the police said.

title: Horse Show Summaries
description: Local Working Hunter ChampionshipChampion, Ale to ??? Fairy Whisper 15 points; reserve, Kim Sutton's Banner, 8.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The stock market staged a big rally in the final two days of last week, with the sharpest increases and heaviest volume in over a year. There were certainly technical aspects to the rally; the Dow industrials had twice sprung back from the 800 level and many institutional investors thought the market was oversold, with dividend yields on stocks rising but yields on bonds declining.

title: Rock: Boylan
description: Terence Boylan, who opened for the Cate Brothers at the Other End Friday and Saturday, is connected to the world of Los Angeles rock, being the brother of a wellknown producer there and a former associate of Steely Dan, lie is from this area, too, and the Other End shows were filled with the expected cheering section of recordcompany personnel and invited hangerson plus the Boylan family and claque. By and large they all had something to cheer about.

title: Books of The Times
description: In her latest book, and her first major work of cultural criticism since Styles of Radical Will appeared in 1969, Susan Sontag has turned her cool contemplative eye to the subject of photography. When all is said and done, photography does end up the better for it. For On Photographycom prising six essays that first appeared in a slightly different form in The New York Review of Booksamounts to a stern indictment of the camera and all its issue. As Miss Sontag writes in a paragraph that is typical of her assault The limit of photographic knowledge of the world is that, while it can goad conscience, it can, finally, never be ethical or political knowledge. The knowledge gained through still photographs will always be some kind of sentimentalism, whether cynical or humanist. It will be a knowledge at bargain pricesa semblance of knowledge, a semblance of wisdom: as the act of taking pictures is a semblance of appropriation, a semblance of rape.

title: F.C.C. Report on Blackout Urges Steps to Protect News Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Federal Communications Commission, in a report released today, said that the nation's two primary national news agencies were disrupted by the New York power blackout in July but that most other communications links were maintained with emergency power sources.

title: Common Market Believed to Back De Larosiere as New I.M.F. Head
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Common Market is lining up behind a single candidate, Jacques de Larosire, director of the French Treasury and a close triend of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, as the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund, making his appointment almost certain, qualified sources reported today.

title: Foes of Shah and Neutron Bomb Demonstrate at Carter's Church
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)About two dozen protesters, some objecting to the visit of the Shah of Iran and some opposed to the neutron bomb, chanted before President Carter today as he left church services.

title: Carter Ancestral Site Reported Discovered
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 13 (UPI)Spokesmeo for a British genealogy concern say they have found President Carter's ancestral plantation in Tidewater, Virginia, it was reported today.

title: U.S. Actions and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  From sugar to shoes, from crude oil to payroll taxes, actions by the Government are pumping new inflationary pressures into the economy. Neither Congress nor the executive branch wants inflation.

title: Spaniards, a Little Late, Discover Picasso
description: MALAGA, Spain  The Spanish are discovering a great artist who was born in this southern coastal city on Oct. 25, 1881. His home town has even been having some lowkey, posthumous birthday celebrations. Some say he was the greatest painter of the 20th century. His name was Pablo Ruiz Picasso.

title: STUDY SAYS U.S. PROGRAMS FOSTER EXODUS FROM CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)  The Federal Government has encouraged migration from the nation's cities through interstate highways, home mortgage policies and other programs, a study released today concluded.

title: School Results
Radio
description: 78 A.M. WNCN. The Barber of Seville Overture, Rossini: Rondo in D (K. 184). Mozart; Danse Espangnole No. 2 for Harp, Granados; Concertino No. 2, Ric. cioti; Overture in C in the Italian Style, Schubert.

description: Giants 10, Tampa Bey 0. Seattle 17, Jets 0. Atlanta 17, Detroit 6. Baltimore 31, Bt.ttalo 13. Chicago 28, Kansas City 27. Denver 17, San Diego 14. Los Angeles 24, Green Bay 6. Miami 17, New England 5. Minnesota 42, Cincinnati 10. Oakland 34, Houston 29. Pittsburgh 35, Cleveland 31. San Francisco 10, New Orleans 7 (overtime). Washington 17, Philadelphia 14.

title: SOMALIA EXPELLING ALL SOVIET ADVISERS, HALTS USE OF BASES
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 13Somalia today ordered all Soviet advisers to leave the country within seven days, ended Soviet use of strategic naval facilities on the Indian Ocean and broke diplomatic relations with Cuba.

title: SOMALIA EXPELLING ALL SOVIET ADVISERS, HALTS USE OF BASES
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 13Somalia today ordered all Soviet advisers to leave the country within seven days, ended Soviet use of strategic naval facilities on the Indian Ocean and broke diplomatic relations with Cuba.

title: ISRAELI LEADERS SAY COMMENTS BY SADAT ARE A POSITIVE STEP
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13  President Anwar elSadat's offer to come to Jerusalem to appear before the Israeli Parliament as part of the Middle East peace effort was described today by Israeli leaders as a positive development, but not as a substitute for a Geneva peace conference.

title: Credit Markets Seeking to Extend Recent Gains Through This Week
description: The credit markets, revived last week by encouraging words from the White House and by the biggest decline in the money supply in at least two years, scored their biggest weekly advance since April, when President Carter abandoned his plan for a tax rebate.

title: OnceOpposed Housing for Aged Is Now Flourishing in Brooklyn
description: As William J. Graves watched the dedication yesterday of the Shore Hill elderly citizens' housing development in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, he recalled an incident on a cold day in 1973 when there was growing opposition too construction of the project.

title: P.S.A.L. Football Final Set for Memorial Field
description: Bayside and South Shore will play for the Public Schools Athletic League football championship Saturday at 1 P.M. at Memorial Field in Flushing, Queens. Bayside, the defending champion, gained the final by scoring 21 points in the fourth period last Saturday for a 2912 victory over Brooklyn Tech. South Shore defeated Olinton, 146. on a passlateral play that went for 76 yards.

title: Wall Street Betting on a Reprieve From OffFloor Trading Deadline
description: Wall Street is betting that it will receive a reprieve from a Jan. 1 deadline for the removal of the last barriers to trading New York Stock Exchange securities away from the floor of the exchange.

title: Harry Combes, Basketball Coach 20 Years at University of Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 13 (AP)Harry Combes, who coached the University of Illinois basketball team to four Big Ten Conference titles and three National Collegiate tournament appearances, died today after an illness of several months. He was 62 years old.

title: Music: Strings
description: Winding up a threeweek American tour, the Tel Aviv University Strings arrived in New York for a concert at the Central Synagogue on East 55th St. Saturday night. The 19 musicians are all students at the university's Samuel A. Rubin Academy, and under the baton of Shalom RonlyRiklis they proved to he a most proficient group.

title: LAWRENCE E. DEUTSCH
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (UPI)  Lawrence E. Deutsch, president of the Los Angeles Music Center Opera Association died yesterday of cancer. He was 57 years old.

title: Young and Old Agree and Differ
description: TEANECK, Nov. 13In an unusual lesson the other day in Sherri Borrin's sociology class at Teaneck High School, teenagers and senior citizens agreed that while similarities existed in restrictions and dependency on others for housing and transportation, differences also existed in values and opportunities.

title: Tornado Death Toll Down 60%
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 13 (AP)The 1977 tornado season is about over, the National Severe Storms Forecast Center says. And, although the number of tornadoes this year has increased 20 percent, deaths are down 60 percent. The center said yesterday that there were slightly, more than 800 tornadoes this year, about 125 more than the annual average in the last 20 years. There have been 42 deaths, well below the average of 110.

title: AllBlack World War I Regiment Honored
description: Survivors of the 369th Regiment, the allblack volunteer unit that was awarded 171 French Croix de Guerres and a dozen other citations for bravery, were honored last night at a dinner reception at the 369th Armory in Harlem.

title: ISRAELI LEADERS SAY COMMENTS BY SADAT ARE A POSITIVE STEP
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13  President Anwar elSadat's offer to come to Jerusalem to appear before the Israeli Parliament as part of the Middle East peace effort was described today by Israeli leaders as a positive development, but not as a substitute for a Geneva peace conference.

title: City U. Presidents Attack Charge of Extravagance
description: The presidents of some of the City University's 18 colleges accused in an audit by New York City's Comptroller's office of following a pattern of extravagance said yesterday that the report reflected a misconception of the duties of college presidents.

title: U.S. Actions and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13From sugar to shoes, from crude oil to payroll taxes, actions by the Government are pumping new inflationary pressures into the economy. Neither Congress nor the executive branch wants inflation.

title: News Summary
description: Somalia, angered by Soviet support for Ethiopia in the war over the disputed Ogaden region, took dramatic steps against the power that has been its prime ally for eight years. All Soviet advisers were ordered to leave within seven days, and Soviet use of strategic naval facilities on the Indian Ocean was ended. In addition, Somalia broke dip. lomatic relations with Cuba and formally renounced the 1974 treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union. [Page 1,Column 1.] Somalia's break with the Soviet Union and Cuba was the culmination of shifting alliances that has left Moscow with a precarious foothold in the Horn of Africa, a key area of the third world Moscow had apparently hoped to weather the warfare between Somalia and Ethiopia, both beneficiaries of Soviet military aid, and had made frequent pleas for a halt in the fighting. The supply of Russian weapons to Somalia was reportedly cut back in a vain effort to force the Government to abandon its drive into the Ogaden region, which it claims despite a century of Ethiopian occupation. [1:2.]

title: Police Milan Use Tear Gas To Quell New Protests by Leftists
description: MILAN, Italy, Nov. 13 (UPI)The police used tear gas to disperse a demonstration by the leftist Youth Circle group today in the second day of violent protests against the closing by the government of three leftist party offices.

title: Late Goals Help Flames Top Rangers
description: The Atlanta Flames won their first game in seven road contests this season, and the big loser was the club the Flames need to beat the most, the New York Raneers.

title: Bradshaw Throws 3 Scoring Passes as Steelers Beat Browns, 35 to
description: As in several other games this season Terry Bradshaw was not available for most of the finalquarter action against the Cleveland Browns at Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh yesterday. But the often injured Steelers' quarterback, before suffering another injury to his left shoulder, had already thrown three touchdown psses that helped the embattled Steelers to beat the Browns, 3531, and go into a tie for first plce in the Central Division of the National Football League's American Conference.

title: DOCKWORKERS REACH 3YEAR SETTLEMENT TO END 44DAY STRIKE
description: North Atlantic shipping employers and striking longshoremen reached agreement yesterday on a new threeyear contract that was expected to bring an end by next weekend to the strike that has tied up container shipping on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts for 44 days.

title: U.S. WEIGHS MEETING ON GENEVA OBSTACLES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Carter Administration is considering asking Israeli and Arab foreign ministers to meet with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance in Europe early next month in an effort to overcome whatever obstacles may remain for convening a Middle East peace conference in Geneva.

title: Jersey Seeks a Cut In lmports of Textiles.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  A dozen members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation have joined in urging the Special United States Ambassador for trade negotiations to seek a rollback in the massive volume of textile imports from Taiwan to protect New Jersey's hardhit textile industry.

title: Bronx Police Precincts Being Revised In Move Requiring Shifting of Officers
description: The New York City Police Department Is drawing up plans for a largescale revision of all precinct boundaries in the Bronx on Jan. 3 in a move requiring shifts of officers and equipment and calling for many of the borough's 11 existing station houses to develop new community ties.

title: GERALD C. LUKEMAN
description: Gerald C. Lukeman, former president of the Institute for Business Planning, a subsidiary of the publishing company of PrenticeHall Inc., died Saturday at the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after brain surgery. He was 71 years old and lived at Hampton Mews, Easthampton. L.I.

title: Hartwick and Clemson Triumph In N.C.A.A. Soccer Tournament
description: Hartwick and Clemson posted openinground victories yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: Bossy Gets 2 In Islander 60 Victory
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 13What did Chico Resch and the Islanders do tonight that no goalie or National Hockey League club had been able to do this season against the Washington Capitals?

title: Growing Role in Anticrime Work Is Beim Won by Private Groups
description: During the month of August and up through the first week in September, hardly a day went by when Representative Edward I. Koch did not remind people on his campaign stops that he favored the death penalty. After squabbling about it with Secretary of State MaUrban Affairs rio M. Cuomo during the Urban runoff campaign, Mr. Koch Affairs dropped the issue. Before he did, he was sharply criticized by opponents, who said the Mayor had nothing to do with the death penalty and who also argued that capital punishment had little to do with the crime rate.

title: Lack of Witness Protection Poses Problems for Criminal Prosecution
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13You can't depend on the cops to protect you and you can't protect yourself, the young woman said, so you have to be nuts to testify or even give your name.

title: Events Today
description: GOLDA by William Gibson; directed by Arthur P?nn? starring Anne Bancroft; presented by the Theater Guild, Philip Langer, Armina Marshall and Mariyn Langer at the Morosco Theater, 217 West 45th Street, 6:45.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (AP)American technicians have removed an antenna from the roof of the United States Embassy, 17 months after discovering that it was sending highfrequency radio signals into a telephone on the American ambassador's desk.

title: Joffrey Dances Ashton Like a Dream
description: The Joffrey Ballet's fall season at the City Center 55th Street Theater will definitely be remembered as the one in which Sir Frederick Ashton came to the Joffrey in a big way. No fewer than five of his ballets were in repertory, and at the season's final matinee yesterday the company gave another of its allAshton programs The Dream, Monotones and Facade.

title: VORSTER DOUBTS BLACKS WILL START RACIAL WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (Reuters)South Africa will continue to have sporadic troubles and uprisings but not a racial war, Prime Minister John Vorster says.

title: TWO ARABS ARE KILLED IN EXPLOSIONS IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 13Two Arabs were killed this morning in separate explosions in Jerusalem.

title: JetsSeahawks Scoring
JEFFERSON PATTERSON, 86; SERVED AS AN AMBASSADOR
description: Jefferson Patterson, a career diplomat who came out of retirement to serve as Ambassador to Uruguay from 1956 to 1958, died Saturday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 186 years old and lived in Washington.

title: CAREY, KOCH AGREE ON WESTWAY STUDY
description: Governor Carey and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch said yesterday they would name a committee to study the effects on jobs and local economic development of trading Federal funds earmarked for the Westway project for money to upgrade the city's subways.

title: Market Place
description: The robust stock market rally last Thursday and Friday surprised professional investors and small investors alike. In two memorable sessions, the Dow Jones industrial average boomed 27 points, finishing the week at 845.89. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange alone amounted to a thumping 67 million shares.

title: PLO, HINTS AT TERMS FOR GOING TO GENEVA
description: TUNIS, Nov. 13A ranking political official of the Palestine Liberation Organization indicated today that the P.L.O. was willing to cooperate with a new Middle East peace conference at Geneva it it were extended an invitation by the United States and the Soviet Union through United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: Kidnappers Free Vienna Millionaire After Cash Is Paid
description: VIENNA. Nov. 13 (AP)A Vienna milKonaire was freed today by kidnappers who had demanded $3.1 million for his return. He arrived home in a taxi with a son who had made the ransom drop, a family spokesman said.

title: U.N. Agency a FundRaising Star
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 Through what diplomats say has been aggressive lobbying for funds, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities has become one of the fastestgrowing agencies here at a time when many of its sister organizations are strapped for money.

title: Spaniards, a Little Late, Discover Picasso
description: MALAGA, Spain  The Spanish are discovering a great artist who was born in this southern coastal city on Oct. 25, 1881. His home town has even been having some lowkey, posthumous birthday celebrations. Some say he was the greatest painter of the 20th century. His name was Pablo Ruiz Picasso.

Carey, Koch Agree On Westway Study
description: Governor Carey and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch said yesterday they would name a committee to study the effects on jobs and local economic development of trading Federal funds earmarked for the Westway project for money to upgrade the city's subways.

title: Gas Regulation Body Petitioned on Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A consumeroriented coalition plans to petition the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission formally tomorrow to take action aimed at increasing availability of natural gas and lowering the price.

title: Fred the Newsboy
description: Readers of Horatio Alger know that a newspaper route was once the surest road to success for an enterprising lad who didn't mind hard work in all weather. But Fred Blanford, who came from Nicaragua to attend high school in Hamburg, Iowa, has been put on notice by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service that If he doesn't quit the morning paper route that brings him $9 a week he may be deported.

title: The SALT Sellers
description: WASHINGTON  Customer comes into a grocery store, sees the shelves loaded with huge bags cf salt, barrels of Salt blocking the aisles. Says to the grocer: You !mist sell a lot of salt. Groper replies: I hardly sell any salt, but the salesman from the salt companycan he sell salt!

title: Search for Fisherman Ends
description: SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me., Nov. 13 (UPI)Coast Guard officials have called off the search for the last of five crewmen whose fishing boat ran into rough seas south of Mount Desert island and sank. One fisherman was presumed dead, the body of another was found and three others survived the incident Friday, when the 83foot dragger Seabreeze radioed the Coast Guard about 6:25 P.M. that she was in trouble and taking in water.

title: WALTER B. ROWLAND
description: Walter B. Rowland, an electrical engineer and a managerial executive with the Union Carbide Corporation from 1920 until his retirement in 1961, died Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after a lone illness.

title: NEW ORLEANS VICTOR CREDITS WHITE VOTES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13This city's black Mayorelect, Ernest N. Morial, acknowledged today the white support that gave him his victory margin in a tight election yesterday, and said that it was an indication of the type of city New Orleans is, a city where leadership and ability counts for more than race.

title: Jan Van Dyke Choreographs Delicate Solo
description: Choreographers react to music in a variety of interesting ways, and one of the more unusual ones is that employed by Jan Van Dyke. She snuggles into the heart of the score, allowing the sound to surround her as she moves comfortably along. Perhaps the most successful of the solos she created for herself in this way is Waltz, which was given with four other solos Saturday evening at the Cubiculo.

title: Beethoven by New World Group
description: Normally the Symphony of the New World presents varied programs centered on a work by a black composer and offering a soloist, besides. This allows one to concentrate on the novelty and the soloist, and the orchestra's sometimes worthy but rarely distinctive performances needn't be dwelled noon.

title: SENATOR CRITICIZES WEST'S TROOP PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today that a new Western proposal to reduce NATO and Soviet bloc forces in Central Europe was meaningless and irrelevant without cuts by the Soviet Union in its forwarddeployed combat units. He added that it would he more difficult to break the deadlock with the Soviet Union over negotiations on mutual reductions of forces in Central Europe than to reach agreement on limiting strategic arms.

title: Streak for Roebuck
description: From 1960 to 1962 Ed Roebuck of the 1Los Angeles Dodgers did not lose a game in 80 mound appearances. He won 12 in that time.

title: Tamar Helena Gronner Bride of Wayne Kallman
description: The marriage of Tamar Helena Gronner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Gronner of Bergenfield, N.J., to Wayne Jay Kallman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kaman of Peabody, Mass., took place yesterday in Temple BethEl in Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi Samuel Mendelowitz nerformed the ceremony. The bride, a special education teacher with the Krebs School Foundation in Lexington, Mass., is an alumna of Northeastern University, Her father is founder and secretarytreasurer of the Speedycut Company in Fairfield, N.J., machine tool importers.

title: Party Time for Willoughby Walk
description: it has been eight years since the tenants of Willoughby Walk began to meet to discuss ways of saving their homes. Yesterday they met againthis time for a victory celebration led by Senator Jacob K. Javits. Families in the racially integrated, middle  income Brooklyn complex have won the right to convert it into cooperative apartments.

title: Crab Norfolk: The Making of an Uncomplicated Dish
description: In a recent column that dealt with harvesting of crabs in the waters around Baltimore, mention was made of a dish called crab Norfolk. It was subsequently pointed out that it was not a dish commonly found in research through many standard works that boast of being definitive on American regional cookery.

description: Supermarket News (next week) and Advertising Age (the week after that) will be carrying rather unusual centsoff coupons from Reader's Digest.

title: Loser Agrees to Pay Cost of New Election
description: MILL CREEK, W.Va., Nov. 13 (UPI) A Randolph County Circuit Court judge has ordered a new mayoral election at the request of a candidate who lost the original election in Mill Creek 10 days ago and has agreed to pay $150 in administrative costs for a second one.

title: Events/Sports

title: Search for Missing Plane Is Hampered by Blizzard
description: JAY, Vt., Nov. 13 AP A blizzard in the mountains today prevented a state police search party from reaching the wreckage of an aircraft near Jay Peak that could be that of a plane reported missing for a week.

title: Foides Plays AllBeethoven
description: Though he once played frequently here. Andorldes's all Beethoven recital Sunday afternoon at Hunter College was his first New York concert since 1974.

title: Inquest in Pretoria Ready for Testimony on How Black Leader Died
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 13A converted synagogue in this capital city will be the scene, starting tomorrow, of an inquest into the death of Stephen Biko, whose death in police custody two months ago shook South Africa as much as any event in years.

title: Commodities
description: In July 1975, a frost devastated the coffee crop of Brazil, the country that traditionally supplies onethird of the world's coffee. In the ensuing months, prices skyrocketed, as the result, it was widely believed of the frost.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 13  New Jersey's two million homeowners are paying more than they should for electricity and natural gas, and it is partly the fault of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, according to the State Public Advocate, Stanley C. Van Ness, who has told the board that its restrictions on utilities have been more cosmetic than real.

title: News Summary
description: Somalia, angered by Soviet support for Ethiopia in the war over the disputed Ogaden region, took dramatic steps against the power that has been it prime ally for eight years. All Soviet advisers were ordered to leave within seven days and Soviet use of strategic naval facilities on the Indian Ocean was ended. In addition, Somalia broke diplomatic relations with Cuba and formally renounced the 1974 treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet. Union. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: WASHINGTON STUDIES STEEL PRICE FLOOR UNDER ALL IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.13Foreign steel mills would be permitted to sell without penalties in the American market at 5% percent below a reference price based on production costs of Japanese steel companies, under a plan being worked out by President Carter's interagency task force on steel.

title: Carnegie Hall to End Its LiveIn Studios for Artists
description: Carnegie Hall has decided to end the right of creative and perfuming artists to live in the studios beside and above the concert hall, a tradition of Bohemian life that dates to the turn of the century.

title: Prince Plans Book on Aga Khan After Leaving U.N. Refugee Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13After 17 years of looking after the world's millions of homeless refugees, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan is giving up his influential and prestigious position as High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Soviet Parliament Sets Session
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (Reuters)The Supreme Soviet, the Soviet parliament, will meet Dec. 14 to approve the economic plan and budget for 1978. An announcement here did not say how long the session would last, but the sessions rarely have lasted more than three days.

title: Music: Eroica
description: Figuring a full house and an average audiencemember age of 50 to 60, there were 150.000 to 175,000 accumulated years of human life on hand Saturday afternoon for the first of Charlotte Bergen's free symphony concerts at Carnegie Hall. All those years and ears didn't really hear a great concert. But it was more than worth the price, and there is something swept and wonderful about the very notion of these afrairs, ana about the venerable Miss Bergen's presence on the podium in the first place.

title: Halt in F.B.I. Computer Plan Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A California Congressman has asked Attorney General Griffin B. Bell and Dr. Frank Press, President Carter's science adviser, to halt the planning of a controversial computer service that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has long sought to provide for state and local law enforcement agencies.

title: L.I. Youth Fleeing Dog Impales Head On Automobile's Radio Antenna
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 13 (UPI)A Long Island teenager fleeing from a snarling Doberman pinscher suffered critical head injuries yesterday when he scrambled onto the roof of a car and fell onto the radio antenna, the police reported.

title: Rosalie Greenfield Bride of William Grossman
description: Rosalle Carole Greenfield and William Billett Grossman were married yesterday in Hampshire House by Rabbi Judah Cahn. The bride, who will retain her maiden name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Benjamin Greenfield of Palm Beach, Fla,, and Swan Lake, N.Y. Mr. Grossman's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Grossman of Roslyn Estates. L.I.

title: Industry Setbacks Put Gloom in Steel City's Executive Clubrooms
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9The smoky steel mill silhouettes that made Pittsburgh infamous are still visible here, framed on impressionist canvases hanging in the polished, ornate rooms of the Duquesne Club, where the city's moneymaking elite has lunched for generations.

title: 2 Dance Concerts With Common View
description: It was John Martin who defined modern dance not as a system but as a point of view. Two dance concerts on Saturday suggested that this still holds true. One program was a matinee by Dorothy Vislocky's company at the Hunter College Playhouse. The second was the concert presented Saturday night. at the American Theater Laboratory by the Marcus Schulkind Dance Company.

title: Bridge:
description: A player who passes and then comes to life with a double when his righthand opponent bids a suit has a highly specialized hand. He must be short in the opponent's suit and have a hand slightly short of an opening bid.

title: Consumer Aides Find U.S. Jobs Are Frustrating
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13'When we were on the outside, we could sue the Government and at least stop it from doing something bad or force the bureaucracy into doing something good, said Carol Tucker Foreman, once director of the Consumer Federation of America and now Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Consumer and Nutrition Services.

title: Women in Agriculture Fight for Their Families and Their Farms
description: GREEN BAY, Wisc., Nov. 12  Joan Adams, slender and blond, tends cattle in Oklahoma.

title: Westway, Still the Best Way
description: Now that we can talk about Westway again without election posturing, it is time to face real facts and figures. Mayorelect Koch has pronounced the mammoth replacement for the derelict West Side Highway a disaster that will never be builtexcept if he's wrong or fails to persuade Governor Carey, in which case it might be built. He had best begin with some very precise calculations.

title: Starker Introduces a Work by David Baker
description: The newsworthy item about Janos Starker's cello recital Saturday night at Carnegie Hall was the first performance of David Baker's Singers of Songs, Weavers of Dreams (Homage to My Friends) for cello an dpercussion. But what gave the evening its artistic satisfaction was the simple (or notsosimple) excellence of Mr. Starker's playing throughout the program.

title: South Africa and the Double Standard
description: In our letters columns today. Johan Adler, the Deputy Consul General of South Atrica, asserts that his troubled country is a microcosm of the world, and that its efforts to cope with complex racial, rational and cultural problems deserve understanding rather than condemnation. The world, and this newspaper, he complains, apply a double standard by condemning in South Africa what they overlook elsewhere.

title: 95,000 in New York City to Lose FoodStamp Eligibility
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  The New Food Stamp Reform Act, recently signed by President Carter, means that 95,000 of the 1.1 million recipients of stamps in New York City will no longer be eligible. In addition, 675,000 will, have their benefits reduced from as little as $3 a month to very substantial amounts. But 260,000 of the very poor will be added to the program or receive benefits. These figures have been compiled by Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, who has had a major role in steering foodstamp reform legislation through Congress this year.

title: 14 L.I.R.R. Unions Agree on Pact as Strike by Conductors Still Looms
description: A coalition of 14 unions reached agreement on a new contract with the Long Island Rail Road last night, according to Harold L. Fisher, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, who said he still remained hopeful that a threatened strike tomorrow by the union representing conductors and brakemenwhich is not in the coalitioncould be averted.

title: Indians Tribal Credentials Are Contested in Court
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13  In attempting to prove that they are legally a tribe, the Wampanoag Indians have shown, in the first four weeks of the trial of their land claims suit here, that they have Indian ancestors, internal politics, a medicine man and a chief.

title: 170 Passenger Cars From Railroads Golden Age Face New Uses as Diners, Gift Shops, Classrooms
description: BEACH GROVE, Ind., Nov. 11Outside a huge old brick building with 1907 emblazoned on its facade, where the spectacular steam locomotives of a vanished era used to go for repair, the stinging wind of the season's first cold snap tore at the dying, scrubby weeds of the rail yard, showing no mercy on the memories remaining there.

title: ROBERT F. McALEVY
description: Robert F. McAlevy, a judge in New Jersey Superior Court from 1964 until retirement in 1975 and a commissioner of the Port of New York and New Jersey from 1958 to 1964. died Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in Hoboken, N. J., after a long illness. He was 71 years old and a lifelong resident of Hoboken.

title: Information Kiosks Help Bus Riders Solve Puzzle
description: Some of New York City's most intractable mysteriesthe routes and time schedules of Transit Authority busesare being revealed to passengers on test routes in Manhattan and Queens, and if the experiment works the secrets may soon he shared with everyone.

title: Canada, in Jumpoff, Takes Nations Cup
description: TORONTO, Nov. 13The Canadian Equestrian Team won the Nations Cup the most coveted international class in equestrian competitionafter jumpoff with the United States Equestrian Team today at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

title: ORTHODOX JEWS SEEK NEIGHBORHOOD HELP
description: Orthodox Jews have started an interethnic program to preserve the Borough Park section in southwest Brooklyn from deteriorationthe first of such neighborhood selfhelp efforts they hope to sponsor across the nation.

title: Setback for Moscow Is Worst Since 1972 In Such a Key Area
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 13  Somalia's decision to expel Soviet advisers and break relations with Cuba is the culmination of a shifting pattern of alliances that has left Moscow with a precarious foothold in the strategic Horn of Africa. Not since Egypt's expulsion of Soviet advisers in 1972 has the Soviet position in a key area of the third world suffered such a dramatic setback.

title: New Cattle Disease in Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 13 (Rettters)  A new strain of bluetongue disease, which causes deformity and death in sheep and cattle, has been identified in Australia's Northern Territory. Primary Industry Minister Inn Sinclair said the origin of the new virus, which had been found in insects, was unknown, Urgent control action was being taken and foreign nations were being notified, he added.

title: Panel Recommends 1% Increase In Interest Rate on Student Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)Banks should earn at least 8 percent interest on federally guaranteed loans made to students, an advisory panel has recommended to Corigress. The current minimum interest rate is 7 percent.

title: Advertising
description: As promised, RichardsonMerrell has announced the new agencies for its multimilliondollar Oil of Olay account (it's Young & Rubicam) and for its Lavoris mouthwash (it's Della Femina, Travisano & Partners).

title: 240 Yearlings Are Sold For Record $1.7 Million
description: YONKERS. Nov. 13 (AP)The Ord Glory yearling sale at Yonkers Raceway ??? today with record attendances and figures for the two day auction.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOON IN HIGH Workers in the West 34th Street area and shoppers at Gimbel's will find a colorful hourlong splash of song and dance today through Friday in the store's eighthfloor housewares department. The overall label for the free diversions is New Yorka Holiday in Any Language, with a special setup of international foods and delicacies.

title: Ruth Weinstein, Lawyer, Is Wed to Stephan Rosen
description: Ruth Ann Weinstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benedict X. Weinstein of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Stephan C. Rosen. son of Mr. and Mrs, Harry A. Rosen of Westbury, LI. The ceremony was performed in Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I., by Rabbi Joshua Hertzberg.

title: South Africa Group Names Black
description: MASERU, Lesotho Nov, 13 (Reuters)Desmond Twit is resigning as the Angligan Bishop of Lesotho to become the firs black secretary general of the South Alican Council of Churches, according to an announcement made in the Anglican cathedral here today.

title: TOUGH SENATE STUDY ON AUDITING PRACTICE ENDS ON SOFTER NOTE
description: A lengthy and, at the outset, sharply critical Senate inquiry into the public accounting profession is concluding on a much milder note. In a unanimous report to be released today, a Senate subcommittee is recommending that the accounting profession be relied on largely to police itself, subject to closer Federal oversight and the possibility of stricter legislation later.

title: Permissiveness, and Growing State Control
description: AVON, N. Y.In a permissive society, all forms of authority become suspect. The pronouncements of statesmen, judges, teachers and parents invite skepticism or open disbelief. People doubt the disinterestedness of such pronouncements and look for the hidden motive behind them.

title: Seewagen Net Victor
description: WEST SETAULET, L.I., Ncv. 13 ??? Seewagen, the East's No. I tennis player, won the $500 Trail of Tournaments singles final today with a 62, 5.7, 63 victory over Dave Oberstein at the Brookhaven Racquet Club.

title: Volume of Commodity Futures Traded in October Jumped 14%
description: The volume of commodity futures trading jumped 14 percent last month frcm the 1976 level, after being virtually unchanged in September, according to figures released by the Futures Industry Association over the weekend.
