title: STATE POLICE HEAD OPPOSES FILES CURB
description: The Superintendent of the New York state police urged a legislative task force yesterday to abandon efforts to enact a law that would sharply limit the right of the police to keep dossiers on political dissidents.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The New York Times/Jack MannIns
Editor Quits Washington Star Amid Reports of Planned Cuts in Staff
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 15James G. Bellows, the editor who was regarded here Es inztrumental in bringing to the financially precarious Washington Star at miciyur its first profitable quarter since 1970, resigned today. His action came amid reperts that the capital's only after?? newspaper planned new payroll cuts that could reduce the staff by 10 percent.

title: A Chewing Gum Sweetener Linked to Cancer in Rats
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Nov. 15Federal and state health officials said today that a sweetener used in nationally advertised chewing gum, Orbit, had been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals fed massive doses of the substance in a British laboratory.

title: SWAMI PRABHUPADA, 'HARE KRISHNA
description: A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, a onetime Calcutta chemist and Sanskirt scholar who brought the Hare Krishna movement to the United States, died Monday at his temple in Vridaban, India.

title: U.S. Skiers at Camp
description: KILLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 15 (UPI)Thirtytwo members of the United States Alpine ski team arrived at Killington ski resort today for final training before leaving for the European World Cup tournaments, which begin later this month in Llvigno, Italy. The team will practice slalom and giant slalom racing on the I1/2mile long Cascade trail.

title: Letters
description: Who's to Blame?

title: Yields on New, HigherGrade Bonds Drop Moderately
description: Yields on new issues of highergrade corporate and taxexempt bonds declined moderately yesterday, partly as the result of the rally in the bond market late last week and partly because relatively few such securities are scheduled for sale for the rest of the year.

title: Antique Clothes in Boutiques and Barns
description: In boutiques all over the city they are called antique clothes. In upstate New York they are just old nightgowns and petticoats, but they are being auctioned off like the finest 18thcentury Boulle commode. The capes and camisoles hippies paid dimes and quarters for at Salvation Army sales back in the 60's are now getting gold bullion prices at the best little shops in town.

title: West German Wins Jumping at Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 15The West German Equesirian Team scored its first victory of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight when Willihert Mehlkopf rode Cyrano to victory in the Hit and Hurry Stakes.

title: Knicks Triumph Over Jazz
description: The real Jim Cleamons finally joined the Knicks last night.

title: Speak for Yourself, John
description: I have been intrigued from boyhood, which was spent entirely in Massachusets, with the feast of Thanksgiving, for reasons that were more historical than gastronomical. We followed a New England tradition at our house not only to spread a feast but also to set out on the table two small ceramic figures: the statues of John Alden and Priscilla Mullins.

title: Schlesinger Attacks Oil Executives For Paranoia
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 15  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger ventured into the nation's energy capital today and told nearly 3,000 antagonistic oil executives that their attitude toward the President's energy plan is laden with myths and paranoia.

description: Restaurants can buy instant nostalgia at auction.

title: TV: Last Hurrah and Drunk's Nightmare
description: TWO RELATIVELY ambitious dramatic productions are on television this evening. One, The Last Hurrah on NBC at 8, is smoothly crafted, professionally produced and almost excruciatingly dull. The other, The Arcata Promise, a British import on Channel 13 at 9, is uneven, often extremely irritating, brilliantly acted and as memorable as some horrible nightmare.

description: VENICE

title: Beame to Name 2 to Water Board
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he planned to make two appointments to the controversial New York City Board of Water Supply, which the State Legislature may try to abolish at the request of Mayorelect Edward I. Koch.

title: White House Turkey Accepted by Mon dale
ALLEN LOCKERMAN
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 15 (AP)Allen Lockerman, an Atlanta lawyer and one of the agenes of the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion involved in the capture of John Dillinger, the bank robber and gang leader who was slain at the Biograph Theater in Chicago in 1934, died yesterday at Piedmont Hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: Marinaro, ExJet Back, Is Signed by Seahawks
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 15 (AP)A freeagent running back, Ed Marinaro, has signed with the Seattle Seahawks, the team's general manager, John Thompson, said tonight.

title: U.S. Brief Supports Affirmative Action In the Bakke Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Department of Justice told the Supreme Court today that Federal laws barring racial discrimination in higher education do not prohibit a graduate school admissions program designed to overcome the effects of past discrimination.

title: Godfather
description: IN A SEASON full of disappointments for CBS and NBC, the serialized version of Francis Ford Coppola's two Godfather motion pictures could become the most expensive disappointment of all. The national audiencepopularity ratings for the first two nights of the fournight NBC presentation fell far short of industry expectations.

title: I.B.M to Leave India and Avoid  Loss of Control
description: Disputes With Other Nations Brewing

title: Canada Cost of Living Up 1%
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 15 (AP)Large increases in food and home ownership charges pushed th ecost of living up by 1 percent in October, Statistics Canada reported today. The increase was the highest for any month since March and resulted in a 12month inflation rate of 8.8 percent as measured by the Federal agency's consumer price index.

description: Frank J. Prial

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15The Casino Control Commission, which will license and oversee gambling parlors in Atlantic City was threatened today with court action by the American Civil Liberties Union for restrictions that the A.C.L.U. said might be unconstitu. tional.

description: Developer Indicted On Bribe Charge

description: Say cottage cheese and people think of diets and conjure up visions of President Nixon in the White House, eating his with ketchup.

title: Best Buys
description: THIS isn't a horoscope column. But there is probably a turkey in your future. What matters is not the sign you were born under, but the one the turkey is reclining underthe one with the price on it.

title: Black Women M.D.'s: Spirit and Endurance
description: WHEN DR. LENA F. EDWARDS leaves home each morning, she takes a pair of pajamas, a comb and a brush because, she said, I never know what's going to happen.

title: 10Day Sales of U.S. Cars Up 14.4%
description: DETROIT, Nov. 15A 14.4 percent increase in unit sales of Americanmade cars during the first 10 days of this month compared with the similar period a year ago was reported here today by the nation's major automobile producers.

title: News Summary
description: Israel sent a formal invitation to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to visit Terusalem and to address Israel's Parliament. Prime Minister Menahem Begin's invitation, approVed overwhelmingly by the Parliament, was given to the American Ambassador in Israel for relay by the American Ambassador in Egypt, to Mr. Sadat. It was in response to the Egyptian leader's remarks that he was willing to visit Israel in his quest for Middle East peace. [ Page A1, Columns 56.]

title: Second Suspect Is Seized In Slaying of Executive In East Side Apartment
description: A second young man was booked yesterday as a suspect in the murder of a retired 68yearold garment executive last Saturday in his rooms at the luxury Sovereign Apartments at 425 East 58th Street.

title: Beame Signs Laws to Curb Arson
description: Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday two bills sponsored in the City Council at his request aimed at reducing arson by helping take the fun and profit out of it.

title: St. Louis Fans Suddenly Adore Their Cardinals
description: When the Cardinal football team arrived back in St. Louis from Dallas yesterday at 2:30 A.M., the airport at Lambert Field was far from empty. There were 2,000 fans, mostly young ones, on hand to greet the players following their sterling victory over the Cowboys, which had been achieved three hours before.

title: VISITING SPANISH RED IRKS YALE STRIKERS
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15Santiago Carrillo, the Spanish Communist Party leader, began a speaking tour of the United States here today by crossing a picket line at Yale University and criticizing American labor.

description: A lost gold cufflink led yesterday to a golden windfall for the New York Public Library and the start of a new fund drive to help it overcome its deficit.

title: Two U.S. Officials Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)The Senate confirmed today the nominations of Cerald D. Fines as United States Attorney for the Southern District of Illinois and Audiey A. Kaslow of California for a sixyear term as a member of the United States Parole Commission.

title: Princess Anne Gives Birth to Boy, Fifth in Line to the British Throne
description: LONDON, Nov. 15Princess Anne gave birth to a 7pound, 9ounce boy this morning. He is Queen Elizabeth's first grandchild.

title: The New York Times/Jack Mannino
A Spokesman For Catholics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Moments after finishing his first news conference today as the newly elected president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, Archbishop John Raphael Quinn was urgently taken aside by a priest. We need you for a moment, the priest said. The priest went on to explain that a storm was brewing on a delicate theological mater that was soon to come to the floor of the bishops meeting.

title: Louisville Festival Offers 6 New Plays
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

title: FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Amid record grain crops and falling market prices, American farmers are expected to net $20 billion in 1977, about the same as in 1976, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
Cello: Moye in Dream Debut
description: IT ISN'T OFTEN that a musician plays a concerto with the New York Philharmonic before making his official recital debut but Eugene Moye is an uncommon young artist. Mr. Moye's Philharmonic debut came last Septeinh, r w nen he appeared as soloist in David Baker's Cello Concerto, but by that time he was already fairly well known he reabouts as principal cellist of the New World Symphony. His recita debut on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall was, therefore anything but premature.

title: At the Met, Utensils Are !Food For Art
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has just seasoned its collections with a dash of culinary history. About three dozen 16thcentury cooking utensilssonic obscure to contemporary chefs, but many instantly recognizableare concocted in Il Genio della Cucina ('The Genius of the Kitchen'), a 1569 etching recently bought by the museum.

title: Brookhaven Laboratory to Get Super Light Bulb
description: A new research technology, using extremely highenergy light to probe solids, gases and various biological materials, is coming into its own and is expected to make possible a wide range of fundamental discoveries.

title: Yen Advances to a Postwar High Amid News of Big Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, Nov. I5The yen, which climbed briefly to a new postwar hie of 245 to the dollar under heavy trading at the opening of the Tokyo foreignexchange market today, closed the day at 245.50 as a result of intervention by the Bank of Japan.

title: Clashes and Tear Gas Mar Shah's Welcome in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  President Carter welcomed the Shah of Iran to the White House today in ceremonies disturbed by drifts of tear gas as supporters and opponents of the Shah clashed outside the White House in a battle of fists, stones and nailstudded boards that left 92 demonstrators and 27 policemen injured.

title: Pennsylvania Students Protest Lag in Aid for Colleges
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., Nnv. 15Several thousand students chanted and hooted derisr..ely on the step: of thr Stain Capitol today to protest the Leg stature's decision to defer approval of $300 million in funds scheduled to go to educational nstittitions, Minding Pennsylvania State. Temple and Pittshurgh Universities.

title: Rock: A Study In Contrasting Country Styles
description: JOHN STEWART and Sierra, who are at the Other End this week, present an interesting contrast within the genre that is unsatisfactorily labeled country rock. Mr. Stewart, who was an original member of the Kingston Trio, has come a long way since the era of buttondown folk music, and although the members of Sierra are younger, they have been around, too.

title: Clashes and Tear Gas Mar Shah's Welcome in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  President Carter welcomed the Shah of Iran to the White House today in ceremonies disturbed by drifts of tear gas as supporters and opponents of the Shah clashed outside the White House in a battle of fists, stones and nailstudded boards that left 92 demonstrators and 27 policemen injured.

title: Notes on People
description: IN Moscow,Andrei Sakharov, the dissident leader and Nobel Prize laureate, told Western newsmen yesterday that the K.G.B. (intrnal security agency) had prevented him from submitting a question at a recent meeting of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. He said the question involved alleged political prisoners and he tried to present it under normal rules of the academy, of which he has been a member for 24 years. I was surrounded by K..GB. men who stood in a wall around me and would not let me leave my seat until everyone had left. Mr. Sakharov said. He added that the incident took place at a session marking the 60th anniversary of the Russian Revolution and that it was witnessed by foreign scientists and many of the 2,000 members of the academy.

title: About Real Estate
description: NEWARKThe Ballantine brewery fi the Ironbound section of Newark hasn't been Ballantine's brewery since 1969. The Investors Funding Corporation, a holding company with interests in real estate and financial services, acquired the property when it bought P. Ballantine & Sons. Since 1972 the breWery hasn't even produced beer. The Falstaff Brewing Corporation bought the Ballantine label and other assets that year and started making Ballantine beer in Falstaff facilities.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

description: Exchange to Join Others Planning New System for Trading

title: Renovation Has Put New Face on Savannah
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 15Lady Astor once dubbed Savannah the pretty lady with a dirty face, a reference to the dilapidated condition of the city's hundreds of 18thand early 19thcentury town houses and stores.

title: NINE ARE CHARGED IN A NARCOTICS CASE
description: Six men and three women were charged yesterday with participation in an extensive narcotics conspiracy that allegedly resulted in the sale of wholesale quantities of Mexican heroin and Colombian cocaine in New York City.

title: DelBello Urges Rise To 8% in Sales Tax For All Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15  County Executive Alfred B. DelBello called today for a uniform 8 percent sales tax throughout Westchester to help pay for a 1978 county budget of $410 million. The alternative, he said, would be an 8.8percent rise in property taxes.

title: U.S. Endorses Trip, But Still Puts Stress On Talks in Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The United States officially welcomed today the projected visit of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to Israel and stressed that it hoped the unprecedented event would improve the chances for a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East and not serve as a substitute for it.

title: U.S. NARROWS FIELD TO 3 IN RAILROAD TIE BIDDING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Department of Transportation said today that competition for a $30 million contract to make concrete railroad ties in the Northeast Corridor had been narrowed to three bidders, including an American syndicate that is allied with a South African company.

title: Advertising
description: A Blue Ribbon for Young & Rubicam

title: Eoccer League Adds Team, Transfers Two Franchises
description: Philadelphia became the 22d member of the North American Soccer League yesterday. The league also approved the transfer of two other franchises.

title: LITARY DISCHARGING 40% OF ITS RECRUITS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Defense Department said today that more than 40 percent of recruits in the volunteer armed force; were discharged before completing their first term. The rate twice as high as it was in the days of the draft, which ended in 1973.

title: Museum Expedition Will Assess Damage to Tombs of Pharaohs
description: Egypt's Valley of the Kings, in whose rock walls the tombs of 25 pharaohs restled securely for more than 3.000 years. is cracking and crumbling so severely that many tombs are believed to be near collapse.

title: Village Nursing Home Asks Lease on Life
description: Genevieve Camlian says it is quite simple why she has lived to be 93 years old: Every afternoon right after lunch, she travels one block from the Village Nursing Home to her other home, the NoName Bar, where she enjoys her daily ration of Guinness Stout.

title: DR. LEVIN L. WATERS, 67, AT YALE SCHOOL SINCE 38
description: Dr. Levin L. Waters, a pathologist noted for research in cardiovascular disease, died of a heart attack Monday in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Guilford. Conn.

title: Ann CarterCox Delights in Song
description: LIKE some popular and folk performers. Ann CarterCox is an artist for whom singing is a naiural expression. Unlike them, she can apply herself to art songs with complete success, for she has not only technical ease, but also a stylistic range. Particularly in her ability to enunciate English clearly but without affection did she seem far superior to the average voeal recitalist in the classic field.

title: U.S. Industries Raise Output 0.3%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.15(AP)The nation's industries Increased their output by three tenths of one percent in October as demand increased for automobiles and parts, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: China Is Interested In Grumman Fanjet
description: China has expressed interest in acquiring executive jet transports made by the Grumman American Aviation Corporation, a subsidiary of t he Grumman Corporation, Bethpage, L.I., spokesman for the parent company said yesterday.

description: BURBANK, CALIF.

title: Felder Installed as 6th President of Upsala College
description: EAST ORANGE, Nov. 15Dr. Rodney Otto Felder was installed today as the sixth president of Upsala College and cautioned students and leaders of the academic community against placing a higher value on personal or professional goals than on the challenge of moral responsibility.

title: Radio Dramas Return Friday
description: Earplay, the National Public Radio network's drama series, begins its 197778 season on Friday with the first of 26 hourlong radio plays, Wings, by Arthur Kopit, author of Oh, Dad, Poor Dad. In New York, the program will be presented on WNYCFM at 10 P.M. with Mildred Dunnock, Cara DuffMacCormick and Richard Ramos in leading roles under the direction of John Madden. The subsequent dramas will be heard Fridays at 10 P.M. for the next 25 weeks.

title: Sister of Officer in Killing Case Says He Was Thrashed as Child
description: The sister of Robert Torsney, the police officer accused of seconddegree murder in the killing of Randolph Evans, 15 years uld, last Thanksgiving night, testified yesterday in Brooklyn State Supreme Court that the defendant had suffered severe beatings as a child at the hands of his a busive father,

title: F.T.C. Will Pursue Oil Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Federal Trade Commission expressed fresh determination today to press its sprawling antitrust case against eight big oil companies even though the case has been bogged down for four years.

title: Cancer Warning Labels Ordered By F.D.A. on Saccharin Products
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 15 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration today told ?? soft drink bottlers and other users of saccharin to begin placing cancer warning labels on products as soon as possible.

title: Greek Politician, Trying for Comeback in Election, Baptizes Babies
description: SITIA, Crete, Nov. 13Greek politicians do not just kiss babies, they baptize them. Constantine Mitsotakis, a 59yearold politician who has formed his own party for the election next Sunday, has baptized more than a thousand in his native Crete.

title: Interior Parts Of Met Museum Now Landmark
description: Parts of the interior of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were designated a New York City landmark yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: ELMER TAYLOR
description: COTTONWOOD, Idaho, Nov. 15 (AP)Elmer Taylor, a greatgrandson of former President Zachary Taylor, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. Accuses Soviet on Invitations
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15An American union leader charged today at the European security conference here that the Soviet Union had withheld delivery of invitations to Andrei D. Sakharov and five other Soviet human rights activists to address the annual convention of the A.F.L.C.I.O. in Los Angeles next month.

title: Discrepancies Appear in Police Testimony at Biko Inquest
description: PRETORIA, Nov. 15A series of discrepancies in police testimony emerged today as a lawyer for the family of Stephen Biko tried to show that his captors were mounting a courtroom coverup in an attempt to save themselves from prosecution for the death of the young black leader.

title: Aeroflot Seeks Canada Refueling
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 15 (UPI)The Soviet Union's state airline, Aeroflot, has asked: the Federal Transport Department for permission to use Gander Airport in Newfoundland as a regular refueling stop. A Transport Department official said that the request had been approved in grin ciple as a means of helping the local economy, but negotiations on specT7 terms are still going on.

title: School Menus: Parents In Action
description: A year ago Cynthia Stein, a New Yorker end mother of two, decided to do something about the poor quality of the foods served to her children at school. She assembled concerned parents at the Dalton School, and after months of meeting and lots of grumbling they succeeded in getting Hawaiian Punch and hot dogs off the school menu.

title: 2 Professors Deny They Received Offers to Represent Palestinians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15Two American professors of Palestinian origin who are being mentioned as possible representatives of Palestinians in any resumed Middle East peace conference in Geneva expressed annoyance today over such speculation and said that they had not been invited by anyone to play such a role.

title: New York Tax. Exemptions Granted to 8 Businesses In JobFostering Project
description: Eight commercial development projects, which will cost private investors a total of $4.2 million, were awarded tax exemptions yesterday by NewYork City's Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board. When completed, the eight projects are expected to create about 230 new permanent jobs.

title: Events Today
Something a Nickel Can Still Buy
description: What will 5 cents buy today? Two pieces of penny candy. A few books of matches. Or, if you know where to go, a loosey'a cigarette so named because it is drawn loose from an open package of cigarettes at the time of purchase, and then sold separately.

title: NEW YORK TOP COURT VOIDS 2 KEY PORTIONS IN THE DEATH PENALTY
description: Key portions of New York's threeyearold death penalty statute were declared unconstitutional yesterday by the State Court of Appeals.

title: Requiem for the Hunger Committee
description: It has had hairbreadth rescues before, but this time, barring some parliamentary miracle, a young institution of uncommon compassion and extraordinary impact seems certain to die. The least that can be done now to mourn it well.

title: CONSOLIDATION URGED FOR MUNICIPALITIES

Shapiro, head of special prosecutions, who, together with John 3. Berry, appeals case chief, will also leave to join the law firm of Hefting, Lindeman, Goldstein & Siegal. Robert Del Tufo, now head of criminal justice the State Attorney General's office, will succeed Mr. Goldstein.

title: Australian Harness Track Is Stage for Dramatic Accident
description: Malcolm Shaw is run over by a sulky after falling from his rig during a race at Melbourne's Kilmore track. At right, a wheel rolls over his head. Shaw was lucky, escaping with only minor abrasions.

description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 15 (Reuters)Cubans living in Somalia left the country today, less than 48 hours after the Government had broken diplomatic relations with Havana.

title: CARTER LAUDS SHAH ON HIS LEADERSHIP

title: Godfather
description: Fortyfive inmates of the Queens Itouse of Dentention found watching the first installment of the television serial The Godfather so fascinating that they refused to return to their cells on schedule, a spokesman for the city's Correction Department reported last night.

title: Miss Austin, Going on 15, Will Play in L.I. Tourney
description: Tracy Austin is coming East again. The little Californian, who will be 15 years old next month, will play in the Rolex international tournament beginning Dec. 26 at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. The best youngsters from 50 countries are being invited to compete.

title: Japan Wins Volleyball Title
description: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 15 (AP)Japan won the second women's World Cup volleyball championship today by beating South Korea and finishing the fournation championship round undefeated. The 1976 Montreal Olympic gold medalists beat the Koreans, 156, 1511, 915, 1510, losing only two sets in the championship round. Cuba finished sceond with a 56 record. South Korea third with 46 and China last with 48.

title: J. HARLEY MURRAY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI).J. Harley Murray, editor of the WhaleyEaton news letters and a former reporter for the International News Service, died of cancer today at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 67 years old.

title: 2 Mares at Keeneland Bring $650,000 Total
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 15 (AP)Costly Dream, a mare, brought $350,000 today at the November breeding stock sale at Keeneland, and a second mare, Swinging Doll, brought $300,000.

title: Some Firemen Leave Picket Lines to Fight Worst London Fires
description: LONDON, Nov. 15British firemen remained on strike today, but several groups left their picket lines to respond to emergencies. Their action eased fears that the walkout could result in a catastrophe, with hundreds cf people killed.

title: A School Backs Down On Its Spanking Rule
description: JONES, Okla., Nov. 15 (AP)Rhonda Davis, a 16yearold high school student who was late to school five times. has gone to court over a rule that had been forcing her to stay home unless she let her principal spank her.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Lawrence Van Gelder

title: Momentum in the Middle East
description: Egypt's President Anwar elSadat has once again chosen the grand initiative to unblock the logjam of Middle East diplomacy. He first did so in July 1972, when he threw out his Russian advisers, closed off his access to Soviet arms, and turned to the United States for help. He did so again in October 1973, when he launched a war he knew Egypt could not win. And now he has done with his dramatic request to visit Jerusalem to tell Israel's parliament, the Knesset, of his desire for a permanent peace.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Contact in the Past Was Done Indirectly
description: The planned visit to Israel hv President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, if it occurs, would he a dramatic departure from past contacts between Israel and the Arab world.

title: Draths
description: HANDLER  BERNARD (Boruch) Suddenly & tragically deceased on November 15, 1977. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Shani, Malke, & Miriam. FatherInLaw of Heshy. Son of loving mother Sarah, beloved brother of Solomon, Muriel, Abe, Helen & Moshe. Loving SonInLaw of the Stubenhauses. A young tree cut off in the prime of his lite. The Grieving Handler & Stubenhaus Family.

title: Museum Provides a New Look for Lizards and Snakes
description: Reptiles and amphibians, creatures that many think of as slimy, cold and repulsive if not inherently evil, have a new home at the American Museum of Natural History that might succeed in giving them a better image.

title: CHINA, FRENCH BANK REPORTED NEAR DEAL
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 15A French bank is reportedly close to signing an agreement with China to provide an estimated $250 million for Peking to purchase French oildrilling technology and equipment, knowledgeable business sources here say.

title: About Education
description: A plan proposed by the New York Board of Regents to mandate periodic refresher courses four professional fields got a warm reception yesterday at the annual Conference on the Professions.

title: Amnesty Group Sets Sunday Stage Event
description: Amnesty International, the organization working for the abolition of torture and for the release of prisoners of conscience, is sponsoring a theatrical event, The Night of the Empty Chairs, Sunday evening in which a number of figures prominent in American cultural life will act out, read or sing from the work of those who have been imprisoned for their views, Conceived by Art Buchwald and directed by Arthur Penn, the event will he presented at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, at 8 o'clock.

title: Defense Questions Photo Identification in Bomb Trial
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 15A state witness is expected tomorrow to identify Robert E. Chambliss as having been in a group of white men she saw outside Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church the night before a bomb exploded, killing four black children.

title: Draths
description: BANKSAmalie Baruch.On November 13, 1977. Devoted mother of Perry Belmonl.Frank. Memorial service St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Sth Ave at 53 St.11AM Wednesday, November 30.

title: Hawks Earn A 11 Deadlock With Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 15Carbon copies in almost all respects, the New York Islanders and Chicago Black Hawks, naturally, played in a 1.1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Lance Lawyers Deny Overdrafts By Others Were for His Benefit
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 15Attorneys for Bert Lance, the former Budget Director, said today that except for the overdrafts in his own accounts and those of his wife, they knew of no instance in which any of the hundreds of thousands of dollars in overdrafts at the Calhoun (Ga.) First National Bank had been intended to benefit Mr. Lance financially.

title: Good Work, Good Works
description: EVANSTON, Ill.Americans like to think of themselves as the people whose hard work makes the world work. We are Cael Sandburg's people making steel, stacking wheat and butchering hogs. Our image is not the reality.

title: Sadat, Again The Master of the Decision
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.President Anwar elSadat's offer to go to Jerusalem in search of peace has burst upon the world with the same suddenness as his launching of the Yom Kippur war in 1973. If the visit should take place now that Prime Minister Menahem Begin has extended an invitation to Mr. Sadat, it would be one of the most dramatic events in the theater of Middle East politics since 1948.

title: Radio
Africa in Perspective
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.There is little probability, no matter what else happens, of any outbreak of largescale fighting Involving the Republic of South Africa for at least another decade, according to Ambassador Andrew Young, chief of the United States Mission to the United Nations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Six Lakeland school district teachers jailed for defying a hacktowork court order during their 10week strike won a reduction in their original 30day sentence. It was reduced to time served.

title: Stuffing the Bird: The Inside Story Of Thanksgiving
description: IT IS one tnan's considered opinion that there are two things better than the Thanksgiving turkey. The first is a wellmade stuffing; the other is the turkey, second time around, turned into a cold sandwich with freshly made mayonnaise. In that the United States is a polyglot nation, it is small wonder that the character of turkey stuffing in this country (and in the homes of Americans abroad) frequently takes on fascinating foreign flavors.

title: Astronautical Meeting Oct.
description: BELGRADE, Nov. 15 (AgenceFrance Press) The 29th congress of the International Astronautical Federation will be held at Dubrovnik from Oct. 1 to 8, according to press reports. United States and Soviet Astronauts will be among the 1,200 experts present, representing 48 countries.

title: 41 UPSTATE JUDGES FIGHT TICKETS CASE
description: Fortyone upstate town and village justices, in a court petition seeking to block further state investigation into alleged fixing of traffic tickets, have asserted that they have been notified of planned charges against them by the New York 1State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: REPUBLICANS ATTACK CARTER ENERGY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Republican spokesmen tonight attacked President Carter's energy program as too weak to meet his own goals and a surrender to the threat of an energy shortage through ignoring the possibility of increased domestic production

title: Arbitration Bills On
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15Pressure mounted today on the lameduck New Jersey Legislature to act Monday on bills that would allow public employees to strike and that would require binding arbitration in salary disputes involving teachers.

title: Conference to Explore History of Entertainment
description: A scholarly fourday conference to study the History of American Popular Entertainment will convene at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center today through Sunday. The event is sponsored by the American society for Theatcr Research and the Theater Library Association. Among those expected to appear arc Ann Corio, Joey and Judie Faye. Chuck Green, Max TAebman, Max Morath, Morton Minsky and Joe Smith.

title: Minoru Kuroda, Hirohito's Liaison With MacArthur During Occupation
description: TOKYO, Nov. 15 (AP)Minoru Kuroda, who was official interpreter for Emperor Hirohito and his chief liaison with Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters during the postwar Allied occupation, died today of cirrhosis of the liver, the Imperial Household Agency said. He was 78 years old.

title: Recital: SingleMinded Duo
description: The Duo RitterAllen has been together since Melvin Ritter, a violinist, married Jane Allen, a pianist, in 1958. they are based in the St. Louis area, where trey man teach: Monday's appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall was their eighth New York recital.

Muriel Margolis and Dr.William D. and the late Felicia Solins.Dear sister of Samuel Bisgyer and Rose Solomon. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Services Wednesday 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels Queens Blvd. 8 76 Road, Forest Hills.

description: Dred Scott, Marbury v. Madison, Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, and quite possibly Bakke v. University of Californiawould public understanding of the great issues involved in those landmark United States Supreme Court decisions, and of the Court itself, have been greater if all Americans had been able to hear and watch the arguments before the Court in those cases?

title: AMALIE BARUCH BANKS
description: Amalie Baruch Banks died Sunday at her home in the Ritz Tower Hotel in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: Dow Up 4.42 as Strong Recovery Overcomes Early Stock Weakness
description: The stock market overcame early weakness yesterday to stage a strong recovery led by glamour issues. An increase in trading volume lent authority to the upswing.

description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1977

title: Solomon Hit With $1,350 Tennis Fine
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 15 (AP)Harold Solomon, tossing his racquet and swearing at the umpire, was fined $1,350 today after a surprising loss to Ove Bengtson of Sweden in the first round of a $135,000 international tennis tournament at the Wembley Empire Pool.

title: Excess Surgeons, Excess Surgery
description: That any sane nation, having observed that you could provide for the supply of bread by giving bakers a pecuniary interest in baking for you, should go on to give a surgeon a pecuniary interest in cutting off your leg, is enough to make one despair of political humanity. So wrote George Bernard Shaw in tun in a prerace to The Doctor's Dilemma which illuminates a contemporary patient's dilemma: When a surgeon says cut, who can dispute the advice? Ask another surgeon, says the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in a belated recognition of the problem.

title: Q&A
description: n Someone recently gave me some Q. very fresh squid, which I have in my freezer. Do you have a recipe for squid in your files?

title: GRAINS
Hughes Aides Seek To Halt Subpoenas In Inquiry on Drugs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15Two aides to the late Howard R. Hughes will urge a Federal judge in Reno tomorrow to quash subpoenas recwiring them to appear before a grand jury in Las Vegas on Thursday.

title: For Boston, Mustard From the King's Men
description: NORWICH, ENGLAND IF BEN COOK FAILS at his new job in the United States, someone sure to say he couldn't cut the mustard, because Ben Cook's new job is mustard. Mr. Cook, a jolly Englishman with the physique of a fireplug and the relentless enthusiasm of a trayeling salesman, is going to Boston to manage a shop for Colman's, the General Motors of the mustard trade, which will open next month in 216yearold Faneuil Hall.

title: Milwaukee Pollution Order Signed
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 15United States District Judge John F. Grady signed a judgment order today that requires the City of Milwaukee to clean up its sewage pollution in Lake Michigan. The order formalized an agreement between Milwaukee and the State of Illinois. Illinois had sued Milwaukee, charging that the city was harming Lake Michigan with its sewage. The agreement requires Milwaukee to install advanced sewage treatment facilitis and to abide by pollution standards in the lake that are stricter than those required by the Federal Government.

title: TIGHT CURB ON COSTS AID RETAILER PROFITS
description: K Mart, Penney and Carter Hawley Show Gains From 76 Periods

title: Labor Department Finds Abuses In New York City Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Evidence of irregularities, mismanagement and a wide range of abuses in the administration of the 1977 Summer Youth Employment Program in New York City has been found by the Departmernt of Labor.

title: GLEASON IN NEW ORLEANS FOR PORT CONTRACT TALKS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (UPI)Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremens Association attended contract talks here today and said he would insist that Gulf Coast shipowners agree to the same terms accepted by those in the Northeast.

title: Germans Tighten Flight Security In Face of Threats to Lufthansa
description: BONN, Nov. 15New flight patterns md unusually tight security precautions went into effect today at West German airports because of terrorist threats that three Lufthansa airliners would be blown up in flight.

title: Wood, Field G., Stream: Gentler City Sounds
description: Lying awake and sweating in a Manhattan bedroom recently, I was the recipient of a brilliant thought that, carried to fruition, could make metropolitan life more pleasant.

description: The price of gold dropped sharply in Europe while the dollar held fairly steady against most major currencies in foreignexchange trading yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

description: Marilynn Carew seldom sees her husband, Rod, become emotional, but she knew he was excited about being named the American League's most valuable player.

description: ROME, Nov. 16 (AP)Banco di Roma's management committee said today the bank was completely detached from an investigation into possible foreign ex1 change fraud involving Michele Sindona,1 fueitive financier.

description: ENTRIES

title: SOUTH IS STILL FOCUS OF MOST RIGHTS SUITS
description: In Louisiana, a black baby died at birth and a white funeral home refused to accept the body for burial. In Jacksonville, Fla., a black entered a barber shop and was told he could not net a haircut.

title: Stage: Merchant Intelligent but Weak
description: THERE IS NOT MUCH USE seeking comparisons between Arnold Wesker's new play, The Merchant, and Shakespear's Merchant of Venice. Mr. Wesker has used the same rough elements of plot and the same principal charactersall of them with a widely different human weight and meaningfor a totally original play. otrisarchant, which opened yesterday at tiluiRbrinouth Theater, is a play of ideas. It Is provocative, generally intelligent and sometimes strained or confused. Its writing has moments of ferocious brilliance and wit; on the other hand, its dramatic structure is weak and its dramatic impact fitful and uncertain.

title: West 23d Street
description: SQUATshort for squattersis an exiled Hungarian experimental theater company that began working as a group in Budapest in 1969. For the last year and a half it has been nomadic, performing throughout Western Lurope and making its American debut last June at the New Theater Festival in Baltimore.

title: $2 Million in Bogus Bills Seized 4 Linked to Colombo Gang Held
description: More than $2 million in counterfeit $50 bills were seized yesterday just a few hours after four men allegedly linked to the Colombo organized crime family were arrested in Brooklyn. The seizure and arrests followed a sixweek investigation by the United States Secret Service and members of the Brooklyn Organized Crime Strike Force.

title: Miss World Entries Quit Over South Africa Issue
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 (Reuters)Three contestants withdrew today from the Miss World contest, two of them over the participation of South Africa. The third withdrawal, by Miss Philippines, was also an apparent protest against South Africa's racial policies.

title: SHAH, SHIFTING STAND, PLEDGES TO OPPOSE INCREASE IN OIL PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Shah said today that, as a result of two days of talks with President Carter, Iran would actively work against an increase in oil prices next year.

title: Browns Passer May Drill Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16The Giants have a Sunday appointment with a dentist. He is Dr. David Mays, who also operates the Cleveland Browns offense now that Brian Sipe, the regular quarterback, is out for the season with a broken collarbone.

title: BOMBING AND DEATH TOLL DOWN SHARPLY FOR YEAR
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 16 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today a sharp decline in the number of bombings and their toll im deaths, injury and property damage in the United States and Puerto Rico in the first nine months of this year.

title: Some Enlightenment on Harnessing the Sun
description: THERE IS something inexplicably appealing about solar energy. Like the sun itself, it draws worshipers. Never mind that it may still cost more than oil or even  electricity, solar energy strikes a lot of its supporters as the real way to bring power to the people. Exxon doesn't own it. Con Ed doesn't install it. The Department of Energy can't regulate it.

title: 175 Snail Darters Moved To Stbawninz Grounds
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 16 (AP)Leaving their dip nets behind, biologists have transplanted 175 snail darters from below Tellico Dam to their spawning grounds in the Little Tennessee River.

title: Motorists to Be Allowed to Park At Most of 14,000 Broken Meters
description: Nearly onefourth of New York City': 64,6S9 parking meters are not workinl because they have been vandalized or broke through normal use, city traffic of ficials said yesterday. The smashed, head less or missing meters have cost the city million in lost revenue during the first 10 months of 1977, they said, and have drawn scores of complaints from motorists and businessmen.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: TESTS HAVE shown that windows in an average house account for a high percentage of the heat lost during cold weather if the windows have only a single pane of glass and no storm windows. Adding storm sash will cut this heat loss by anywhere from 30 to 60 percent, depending on how cold it is outside and how much window area is involved.

title: COngress Unit Tells New York To Tighten Budget Accounting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16New York City is meeting a statelegislated mandate in gradually eliminating municipal operating expenses from its capital budget, but it should nevertheless apply stricter budgetary standards, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Luckinbill Returns To Shadow Box
description: Laurence Luckinbill, who won Tony nomination for his performance in The Shadow Box last season, has returned to the cast of the Michael Cristofer play after several months away to fulfill other commitments. He will again portray Brian in the production, which is now at the LuntFontanne Theater.

title: GERARD G. HAYNES
description: Gerard G. Haynes, for 10 years a staff photographer in Brooklyn for The New York Daily News, died yesterday morning in Methodist Hospital. Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 37 years old and lived at 1563 81st Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Haynes, an awardwinner member of the New York Press Photographers Association, is survived by his mother, Mary Haynes of the Brook address, and three brothers, Thomas, William and Brian.

title: David Goldberg Was First Rabbi To Serve Navy
description: Rabbi David Goldberg, the first Jewish chaplain in the Navy, died Tuesday at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 91 years old and lived at 2166 33d Road, Long Island City, Queens.

title: Conferees Near Accord on Rates For Electricity
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16House and Senate energy conferees moved close to an agreement today on setting Federal standards for retail electricity ratemaking aimed at encouraging the use of electricity at offpeak hours.

title: The New York Times
description: Yesterday. U.S. District Court Chief Judge Lawrence A. Whipple presided at the largest naturalization hearing in the history of the State.

title: Providing for Pets in Wills
description: Across the nation every day any number of dogs, frightened and defenseless are suddenly abandoned and thrust into overpopulated towns. But these dogs are not strays. They are victims of a mounting problema devoted

title: Witness in ChurchBombing Trial Links Dynamite to the Defendant
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 16The state rested its case in the Birmingham churchbombing trial today after presenting witness who said that she saw packages of what appeared to be dynamite at the home of Robert E. Chambliss two weeks before the explosion in September 1963 that took the lives of four black children.

title: Helen Forrest Brilliant as Ever
description: WHEN HELEN FORREST was the queen of the Swing Era band singersshe sang with the three major swing bands of the day. Benny Goodman's, Artie Shaw's and Harry James's, record equaled by no one elsethe key to her success was her ability to sing with color, shading and expression within the extreme limitations imposed on a band singer. These limitations i. eluded being held to a single chorus of a song and to tempos that were chosen for their dancing appeal and/or the instrumental aspects of the performance. But never, not ever, with the needs of the singer in mind.

title: Belgrade Exhibit Is a Barometer of. Decade's Art in East and West
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 16An unusual exhibit of painting and sculpture of the 1970's from the East and West is providing a surprisingly accurate barometer of this decade's cultural climate in the Communist and nonCommunist world.

title: Academy Won't Readmit Cadet Who Supports Child
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 16 (AP)There is a catch in the new, Air Force Academy policy that permits a cadet who becomes pregnant to return after giving birth: She cannot come back if she has a denendent child.

title: MAJOR RAIL PROJECTS SCHEDULED IN STATE
description: NEWARK, Nov. 16Executives of Amtrak and Conrail outlined here today plans for major improvements in both longhaul and commuter train service in New Jersey.

title: HONOLULU MAYOR REFUSES TO WAIVE NOSMOKING RULE
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 16 (UPI)If the Democrats are going to'smoke, they are not going to hold their 1978 midterm convention in Honolulu, Mayor Frank Fasi says.

title: Palestinian Executed For Killing Arab Aide
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Nov. 16 (Reuters)A I9yearold Palestinian was executed by firing squad today for having killed the deputy foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates an airport shooting last month, officials here said.

title: Jersey Fares on Interstate Buses And Trains Going Up 10 Percent
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15Fares on interstate commuter buses and on all rail passenger trains in New Jersey will be increased an average of 10 percent July I because of higher operating costs, state officials said today.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IIOHN BARRYMORE made such an open book of his own life not only in the selfparody of his final years, but also in the early, readily acknowledged contempt he felt for the craft he practiced and the scavenger he called himself that there's scarcely need to dip into another. Yet I learned at least one thing I hadn't known from John Kobler's Damned in Paradise. John Barrvmore climbed Mont Blanc.

title: ENTRIES
6 Whitehouse Units Closed by Genesco
description: Genesco Inc. yesterday closed six of its 12 Whitehouse & Hardy stores in the metropolitan area as the latest step in its program to operate only profitable companies.

title: Tighter Security Asked at Training School
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16Rehabilitation programs at an upstate training school for boys at which a 13yearold inmate was murdered last June should be sacrificed !temporarily for more security, State Senator Ralph J. Marino said today.

title: SUPPLY OF DISTILLATE OIL AND CRUDE ROSE IN WEEK
description: Supplies of distillate oil were at record high of 260.5 million barrels for the week ended last Friday, according to the latest weekly supply figures released bYthe American Petroleum Institute. This compares with 255 million barrels the week before.

title: Derailed Tank Cars Uprighted
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 16 (UPI)Four derailed Southern Railway tank cars, three of them loaded with poisonous hydrocyanic acid, were uprighted west of the downtown area without incident early today, allowing some 2,500 evacuated residents of aninesquare block area to return to their homes.

title: Third Man Held in East Side Slaying
description: A third suspect was arrested yesterday in the burglar murder last Saturday of 68yearold Harry Kassoff in his bedroom at the luxury Sovereign Apartments at 425 58th Street in Manhattan.

title: ..Lee Sellars, at 68, an Executive In Public Relations and a Lawyer
description: Lee Sellars, a lawyer and public relaions executive, died Monday at Lawrence Hospital. Bronxville, N.Y. He was GS yej FS old and lived at SO1 Granmatan Auoruo, Mount Vernon, N.V.

title: Disks: Jazz Classics
description: Jazz has long been caught between the worlds of popular and classical music. What this has meant for jazz as a music is that it has survived on the periphery, drawing some strength from the popularmusic business and some from our cultural institutions without ever really being accepted by either. What it has meant for jazz musicians is something else again.

title: Dispute Over a Talmud
description: The state has entered the case of Burlington Township woman who spent 138 days in jail in a dispute over ownership of a Talmud said to be valued at $500,000.

title: U.S. Gymnasts Post Victory
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 16 (UPI)The United States junior girls gymnastics team defeated the Czechoslovak team, IS4.75181.95, last night, avenging an earlier unofficial loss in Albuquerque, N.M. The best United States performances come from Kelly McCoy of Kettering, Ohio, 9.55 in vaulting; Marilyn C Jpman of Diablo, Calif., 9.45 on the uneven bars: Chapman and Linda Kardos of East Vandergrift, Pa., both with 9.35 on the balance beam, and Kardos and McCoy, both with 9.40 in the floor exercise.

title: Five Pioneers In Medicine Get Lasker Awards
description: Two pioneers in the development of an important diagnostic technique and three world leaders in the study of the vital body substances called prostaglandins were named yesterday as winners of the Albert Lasker Awards in medicine.

title: Thomas J. Deegan Jr., Organizer Of 6465 World's Fair, Dies at 67
description: Thomas J. Deegan Jr., who helped orramze the New York World's Fair of 196465 and was chairman of its executive committee, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence at the Hyde Park Hotel, 25 East 77th Street. He was 67 years old.

title: Boxing Champions
description: 1. Carlos Palomino, W.B.C. welterweight

title: City Hall to Get Young People (at Least 3)
description: The wide red bow pulling back her brownish hair, the collegegirl sweater and skirt, the everdwindling sixpack of Tab on her cluttered desk do not enchance Maureen Roseanna Connelly's image as a major municipal powertobe.

title: Stockton Upsets Connors In Tennis at Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 16 (UPI)Dick Stockton, capitalizing on a powerful serve, won two straight 12point tiebreakers to upset Jimmy Connors tonight, 6.5, 65, in the 532.000 World Champtionship Tennis Challenge Cup.

title: BELL CHIDES PRESS ON UNVERIFIED DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell told a group of newspaper publishers today that newspapers had an unhealthy habit of picking up and reprinting information that had been published by others without first attempting to verify it on their own.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: READING, Pa. (UPI)More homeowners are turning to electricity for heating, according to a survey of 60,000 householders in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The number of those surveyed using natural gas and oil to heat their homes declined, while the number using electricity increased 2 percent over a oneyear period.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday. Nov. 16 1977

title: Boston Entertains Blacks Who Were Attacked There
description: BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP)A group of black students who were attacked Monday by a group of whites while visiting Boston, dined at City Hall and then went out on the town, with the city picking up the tab.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran said today that he had rejected higher insurance rates for small cars that had been sought because of their damageability and the greater severity of injuries in smallcar accidents.

title: Letters
description: For a Safer City

title: Continued Urban Job Aid Vowed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 16Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that the Federal Government would finance jobs in many of the nation's cities for the foreseeable future.

title: Cello: Recital of Mixed Blessings

title: Tears and Sympathy for the Shah
description: The tear gas that drifted across the White House lawn Tuesday as the Shah of Iran was being greeted by President Carter signaled the somewhat awkward nature the occasion. A President committed to advancing the cause of human rights worldwide was offering a fullhrmors welcome to a ruler as close to an absolute monarch as exists these days.

title: Meyers Excels as Bucks Inflict 116406 Loss on Nets
description: PISCATAWAY. N.J., (AP)  Dave Meyers collected 29 points and grabbed 12 rebounds, sparking the injuryplagued Milwaukee Bucks to a 116106 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Tennis
Buffalo Accepts $1.8 Million In Payment From Penn Central
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 17 (AP)Following Ilie acceptance of a $1.B million settlement! offer, the bankrupt Penn Central ceased In be the largest delinquent taxpayer in Buffalo.

title: Walter Watts, 75; Helped to Develop Color TV for RCA
description: W. Walter Watts, a retired senior officer and director of the RCA Corporation and a developer of color television, died Tuesday in the Community Hospital of the Palm Beaches, in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was i5 years old.

title: U.S. Sees Cuba's African Buildup Blocking Efforts to Improve Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Carter White House is seriously disturbed by the steadily expanding Cuban military presence in Angola, Ethiopia and other African countries and sees no possibility of reestablishing full diplomatic relations with Havana under these circumstances, highranking Administration officials said today.

title: The Man Who Speaks for Bikc
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 16To judge from the murmurs of approval that roll across the crowded courtroom benches, Sydney Woolf Kentridge, chief lawyer for the family at the inquest into the death of Stephen Biko, is earn ing an admiration among Man South Africas blacks this in the week that is rare for white men in this rigidly segregated society.

title: Psychologist at Trial of Torsney Calls Him Subject to Violent Outbursts
description: Robert Torsney, the policeman accused of seconddegree murder in the shooting of a Brooklyn youth last Thanksgiving night, was described by a psychologist at his trial yesterday as an overcontrolled man afraid of his feelings and liable to explosive outbursts.

title: Gold Bullion Futures Prices Off; Contracts Set a Record at 13,712,
description: A record 13,712 gold bullion futures contracts changed hands yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange. Eath contract covers 100 troy ounces of the metal.

title: Home Rule for Scotland and Wales Passes a Key Hurdle in Commons
description: LONDON, Nov. 16The British Government won a pivotal victory tonight in its historic effort to grant partial selfgovernment to Scotland and Wales.

title: 5.6% Home Building Rise In October Best in 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)Construction of new houses jumped 5.6 percent in October as the housing industry enjoyed its best month in four years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: U.S. Says Castro Has Transferred 60's Policy of Intervention to Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Carter White House is seriously disturbed by the steadily expanding Cuban military presence in Angola, Ethiopia and other African countries and sees no possibility of reestablishing full diplomatic relations with Havana under these circumstances, highranking Administration officials said today.

title: Nonprofit Corporation Is Set Up To Draw Businesses to New York
description: Mayor Beanie and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch joined yesterday in officially opening a new venture with city and private financing to attract businesses and jobs to New York City and to keep and expand those already here.

title: People and Business
description: Ralph E. Bailey, 53 years old, has been elected president and a member of the executive committee of the board of directors of the Continental Oil Company, Howard W. Blauvelt, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: Symphonic Trainees Master Difficult Mirage
description: THE NATIONAL Orchestral Association, a training organization for symphonic musicians that is in its 48th season, undertook a program Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall that might have intimidated many a more experienced group. The most imposing piece was Jacob Druckman's Mirage, which the Pulitzer Prizewinning composer wrote last year for the St. Louis Symphony on commission from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: URBAN TRANSIT BILL IS SIGNED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 16 (UPI) President Carter signed today a bill authorizing $80 million for urban mass transit despite his serious reservations that some cities had not lived within their oriainal Federal navments.

title: Tempers Flare as the First Soviet Advisers Start Leaving Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 16The first of several thousand Soviet advisers and technicians began leaving today as the Somali Government, which had ordered their expulsion, awaited a visit by a United States Congressional delegation.

title: Board Members of Nonprofit Corporation
description: The cochairmen for the newly organized Business Marketing Corporation for New York City are Osborn Elliott, deputy Mayor, of the Mayor's Office Economic Development: Oscar Dunn, chairman of the board of the New York Chamber of Commerce and industry, and Donald Smiley, chairman of the board, R.H. Macv's & Co. The other members of the organization's hoard are:

title: The Wall Lamp You Hardly Notice
description: THERE'S AN apocryphal quote by the late designer T.H. Robsjohn Gibbings that goes: If someone says, What gorgeous lamp'get rid of it. Mr. Gibbings practiced what he preached and nearly 30 years ago was one of the first designers to order unobtrusive Hansen lamps for his clients.

title: Bridge:
description: The complicated tale of the ten of hearts, which caused a furore in the semifinal stage of the NassauSuffolk double knowckout team championships recently, has now been concluded.

title: Sant'Angelo Imitates Life in a Living Room
description: T0 SEE live models living in model rooms today is as startling as it was in the 1930's to see a couple dancing mechanically on a Queens Boulevard billboard. But we saw it Monday and can thank Giorgio Sant Angelo, the fashion designer, for putting living back in our living room furniture settings.

title: Meteosat Launching Rescheduled
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP) United States space agency officials have rescheduled the launching of Meteosat, the European Space Agency's first weather satellite, for Sunday at 8:35 P.M. The launching was postponed from Nov. 17 when a leaking propellant valve was found in the second stage of the rocket. The satellite will provide Europe with weather photos and information every 30 minutes, and perhaps more accurate longrange weather forecasts.

title: Panel to Examine The Way U.S. Deals With Dying People
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 16 (Reuters)The head of the White House Office of Drug Abuse Policy, Dr. Peter Bourne, announced today that a committee to examine the way the United States deals with its dying is to be set up by the National Institutes of Health.

title: Carter Wins the Approval of 54%, And 30% in Gallup Poll DisapprovE
description: Fiftyfour percent of a sampling of Americans approve of President Carter's performance in office, according to the latest Gallup poll. Thirty percent disapproved and 16 percent were undecided.

title: Polities Is Master at Chess Drawing
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15Two, grandmasters who used to live in the Soviet Union met here today in a brief ceremony to decide which one will make the first move in a match to determine who will challenge the world chess champonwho still lives in the Soviet Union next year. The ceremony was rife with politics.

title: Richard Addinsell, Writer Of Scores in Hollywood; Did Warsaw Concerto!
description: Richard Addinsell, the British composer of film, theater and television scores, whose Warsaw Concerto achieved popularity during World War II, died Tuesday at his London home. He was 73 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
EDWIN A. BOSS
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 16 (AP)Edwin A. Boss, a Des Moines resident who turned a $3,500 loan into a major chain of hotels in Iowa and other states, died yesterday n6 canevrlie was 86 years old.

title: National Distillers Plan a Swap Of Its Stock for Emery Industries
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation yesterday announced it was planning to acquire Emery Industries Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at $223 million.

title: Hers
description: IT IS NOT easy coming out the other side marriage. Though divorce is as common these days as subway breakdowns, nonetheless, the uncoupling process takes its toll on the participants. I am surrounded by the walking wounded, friends who have been married for years or a moment, friends with children and friends without, rich ones and poor ones, all of whom are floundering in the tidal rip of their marital lives. And most of them are puzzled as to why. It is as if some uncontrollable force were loose in the marriage market, and all the investors had been sold short.

title: Personal Beauty
description: HERE WE GO again. A flock of new hairdressing salons has opened recently, some have changed names or locations, others have split up like amoebas and multiplied, and hairdressers are playing musical chairs. If you've lost your favorite hairstylist lately, chances are he or she's busy at one or another new shop.

title: State Treasurer Expects a Surplus H Income Tax Continues in Force
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16  State Treasurer Clifford A. Goldman said today that the state income tax, if permitted to continue at its current 2 to 2 12 percent levy on gross income, will produce annual surpluses within a few years and could be cut or used to reduce property taxec further.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16An influential committee of Roman Catholic bishops sharply criticized today a popular book on sexuality that conflicts with much of the church's traditional teaching on morality.

title: Knicks to Meet Bullets Without Ailing Monroe
description: Earl Monroe will miss tomorrow night's game against the Washington Bullets at Landover, Md. The Knick captain and second best scorer came out of Tuesday night's victory over the New Orleans Jazz with a left ankle sprain and tendinitis in the left knee cap. The loss of Monroe leaves the Knicks with only three guards, although Willis Reed, the coach, has used a rookie, Glen Gondrezick, in the backcourt.

title: 4th Seabrook Protest Planned
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Nov. 16 (AP)Opponents of the Seabrook nuclear power plant said today that they would stage a fourth demonstration with thousands of people occupying the plant's construction site next June 24. We hope construction is halted before June 24. If is not we will attempt to stop it then. And if not then we will return again and again, said Cathy W. Wolff, a leader of the Clamshell Alliance. The alliance has organized three earlier demonstrations at the site.

title: An Encounter That's Out of This World Stage: Squat Abuses
description: IN THE 1950'S, the decade in which we fought the Korean War, witnessed the rise and fall of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and fretted (along with Mort Sahl) about the atomic bomb's falling into the hands of Princess Grace, and Prince Rainier, sciencefiction films enjoyed a new, lively popularity largely by feeding on our wildest nightmares. We watched movies in which planets fought wars with each other, worlds threatened to collide and a huge malignant carrot, a vegetable with a higher form of intelligence, landed at the North Pole.

We urge attention, therefore, to a speech the Ambassador gave in Rome this week to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. It contained a modest but promising proposal for coping with one of the era's most vexing problemsthe failure of many developing countries to grow enough food feed their people.

Soviet Wages Increased
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 (Reuters)Almost nine million Soviet workers employed in education, the health system, catering and other jobs will receive pay increases averaging 18 percent beginning of next month, the Soviet press agency Tass has reported. The report did not say how much these workers now earn.

title: City Ballet Opens With a Gala
description: TO STAGE a gala performance for the return of New York City Ballet to New York is practically an exercise in agreeable redundancy. Any return of the company to its home is almost by definition a gala occasion, a reason for rejoicing, and a time for New York to become little more New York. Every town has institutions that live on it, some that live in itand a few, a very precious few, that are of its essence.

title: System Relieving Judges of Duties May Not Be Legal, Justice Says
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 16A State Supreme Court justice, acting in the case of 41 town and village justices who are targets of an investigation of alleged ticketfixing, said today he had serious doubt about the constitutionality of procedure that automatically relieves i judge of his duties once he has been formally charged with a disciplinary infraction by a court on the iudiciarv.

title: At World's Busiest Bus Terminal, New Space and Old Ills
description: Undaunted by a tenant's rent strike and lawsuit, by recent uncertainties over transit financing and by a busload of other concerns, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is proceeding on schedule with the $160 million expansion and modernization of its midtown bus terminal.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Aug. 25, about a house in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., referred to plates made by the Saturday Evening Girls, a group of young immigrant prostitutes . . . in Boston. The Saturday Evening Girls were not prostitutes. The grotkP, founded in 1899, met on Saturday nights to discuss the social, ethical and economic problems of the day, to share books and to practice dance and theater. They are best known for the Paul Revere Pottery, which they operated from 19081942. The organization's members included children of new Americans. Their supporters were Boston socialites. The Times regrets the error.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: GENOA, Italy, Nov. 16 (AP)A judge in Genoa today ordered the nationwide seizure of all bottled CocaCola on the ground that its ingredients were not properly labeled. The magistrate, Mario Sossi, also banned any further distribution or production of bottled CocaCola, a $120 millionayear business in Italy.

But there is no mystery as to why it was once popular for Sunday outings  Green  Wood is as lush a landscape as exists anywhere in the builtup boroughs of New York.

title: Notes on People
description: AUNANIMOUS vote of confidence was given to Anita Bryant yesterday when the Florida Citrus Commission extended her cnotract to advertise orange juice through August 1979. The 12member commission also adopted a resolution supporting the right of the singer to give her views on any subject without fear of reprisal. This included. it said, her controversial stand against equal rights for homosexuals. She's doing a great job for us, said Dan Richardson, the commission chairman. He added that Miss Bryant's positions against homosexuality, as well as those in favor of prayer in public schools, have nothing to do with our decision. Our decision is on whether she still is effective, and she is. The commission picked up Miss Bryant's option to appear in orange juice commercials for a fee of $100,000 a year.

title: Initiate Is SoHo Theatricality

title: Film: 'Thunder' From King of Bees
description: THUNDER and Lightning," which opened yesterday at the Victoria and neighborhood theaters, is a buoyantly slapdash comedy about bootleggers in the Everglades. Although the movie appears to have been photographed almost entirely on Florida location and although its cast includes some good actors, David Carradine, Kate Jackson, and Sterling Holloway. "Thunder and Lightning" is less like a live-action movie than a 95-minute Bugs Bunny cartoonwhich is one of the nicest things about it.Mr. Carradine plays an independent-minded young bootlegger, a fellow who wears an earring in his left ear and who swaggers with just a little more self-assurance than his charm allows. Miss Jackson, one of the better comedians to come out of television, is his friend, the daughter of the syndicate-backed bootlegger who is Mr. Carradine's nemesis.The movie begins with a chase involving swamp buggies, and later shifts in various makes and models of automobiles. There's hardly a moment in the movie when someone's not being pursued by, or in pursuit of someone else. It's painless, sometimes funny, good-natured, as well as extremely prolife. As in a Bugs Bunny work, no one is permanently damaged by the non-stop mayhem. This is no big deal, I suppose, though as soon as one realizes this is its method, watching the movie becomes a benignly peaceful experience.Roger Corman, sometimes known as the King of the BeesB-pictureswho has given early employment to such directors as Francis Ford Coppola, Peter Bogdanovich and Jonathan Demme, produced "Thunder and Lightning." It was directed by Corey Allen and written by William Hjortsberg; we may well be hearing from them again. "Thunder and Lightning," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vulgar language and a lot of action but no real violence.

title: Interlocking the U.S. and Israel
description: PHILADELPHIAIt's time for the United States to bite a real bullet in the Middle East. A 636,000kilowatt generator, one of two installed in the power plant, will generate 120,000 kilowatts of power, 20 percent of its capacity, in its initial stage. Its full capacity could be reached next March or April.

Charles (Bud) Baker, the owner of the 4yearold colt, made the announcement today, saying there would be 36 shares at $25,000 each and that Norcliffe's stud fee would be $6,000. Norcliffe was Canada's horseoftheyear in 1976, and, as a 3yearold, won the Queen's Plate and the Prince of Wales Stakes, the first two gems of Canada's triple crown.

title: Black Nominee Under Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee will send staff aides to New Orleans to investigate allegations against Robert F. Collins, nominated by President Carter to be the first black Federal judge in the Deep South. Mr. Collins, a 46yearold magis trate in New Orleans, was interviewed here yesterday by the committee staff. I have categorically denied all the allegations, he said later. He declined to say what the allegations were, but they reportedly include charges of conflict of interest and favoritism while serving as a magistrate.

title: City Ballet: Prodigal Acting
description: IN DANCE, acting is the shortest gesture between two points. It is quite different from acting in a play. Its message is telegraphed across with visual signals in which facial expression may play only a comparatively small part, and the message delivered is rarely as explicit as that normally conveyed by words, which are generally less ambiguous. Acting in dance is, at its best, a gestural echo chamber of poetic resonances; it needs to be interpreted, and that very interpretation offers all the range of moody evocations and suggestions of songs without words.

title: Minuteman Missiles Ordered
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 17 (UPI)The Defense Department has decided to order $105 million worth of Minuteman III strategic missiles and will keep the production line, scheduled to shut down, open after all. The Pentagon announced in July that it was ending production of the landbased strategic missile but it now has notified Congress that contract action was taken earlier this week to keep the assembly line at Hill Air Force Bas, Utah, open to turn out 30 more Minutemen.

Mr. Humphrey's sister, Frances Humphrey Howard, told a news conference at which the drive was announced, I guess he's as excited about this as about anything that has happened to him, because he's a visionary. Mrs. Howard said that her brother, now undergoing chemotherapy treatment for an inoperable pelvic cancer, was responding beautifully.

It seemed that there was trouble with the delivery of the orchestral parts, and the New York Philharmonic could not get them in time. So Erich Leinsdorf, at the last moment, substituted Wagner's Siegfried Idyll, and he conducted it sweetly and songfully.

title: The Big Japanese Trade Surplus
description: No solution has emerged in the campaign to deflate Japan's ballooning trade surplus. There has been much dialogue in the last few years about the incendiary nature of the problem. Strong exhortations have been made on both sides of the Pacific to allow the yen to appreciate sharply to try to eliminate the competitive advantage of some Japanese goods. And through the influence of socalled tradefacilitation committees in Tokyo and Washington, some curbs have been arranged on shipments of electronic products here, especially color television sets.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: CHARLES LUDLAM opened a small, shabby cardboard suit case and took out Walter. Walter is a ventriloquist's wooden dummy with bright eyes that goggle (or ogle), a perpetual grin and a trick neck that can bob up and down over the collar of his pullover. Mr. Ludlam is larger than lifea playwright, actor, founder and director of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company. His latest work is Aphrodisiamania, a new Paul Taylor dance for which he supplied the story. The dance has its premiere Nov. 29 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: The Inimitable, Expendable Dr. Burns

For them, it follows that President Carter must reappoint the outspoken economist to another fouryear term as head of the Fedthe nation's secondmostpowerful economic post.
