title: Screen: A Romance Of Medieval Spain
description: "THE CONFESSIONS OF AMANS," a story of tragic love set in medieval Spain, is a most unusual movieso rigorously disciplined and composed it looks as if it were the work of someone who is nearing the end of a career and has long since abandoned the tricks of a trivial trade.Instead, it is the first feature of 28-year-old Gregory Nava, an American of Basque-Mexican parentage who studied at the film school of the University of California at Los Angeles. Using professional actors, costumes that once appeared in "El Cid" and a lot of the castles of ancient Segovia. Mr. Nava made "The Confessions of Amans" in Spain on a budget of about $20,000, including a grant from the American Film Institute. Like all successful film makers, Mr. Nava apparently has an artistic sensibility matched by an ability to promote himself and get things done."The Confessions of Amans" is a beautiful, muted film of the kind that takes some getting used to. People seldom raise their voices or lose control of themselves. Passion is expressed discreetly in glances or in the holding of hands.I've no idea whether this is the way life was in medieval Spain, but this is the way it seems to have been to us today. We're so far removed that we can't quite make out the feelings, only the looks on the faces, the gestures, the etiquette. Interiors are almost as barren as the lovely, lonely landscapes, as if the people who once inhabited them had died long ago or moved to the city. The movie has the manner of something slowly freezing in time, which is as chilly as death.This, I assume, is exactly the manner Mr. Nava sought. It also explains the curious neo-Bressonian distance from which we observe the story of Amans, a poor young philosophy scholar, and Anne, the young wife of the lord of the castle where Amans is employed as the tutor. Amans and Anne, whose love has no happy end, are parts of the medieval landscape.It's difficult to judge actors in this sort of film, in which every performance appears to be as much the composition of the director as his choice of the color for a costume. The actors are English stage performers who speak the mostly jargon-free dialogue in accents that have no immediate association to any particular time or place.Mr. Nava produced, directed, photographed and edited the movie, and wrote the screenplay in collaboration with Anna Thomas, another U.C.L.A. graduate.

title: Concert: Joseph Smith
description: jOSEPH SMITH'S piano recital Wednesday night did not shoot or the moon. No late Beethoven sonatas, no Liszt in B minor, no Symphonic Etudes, no Diabelli in fact, the most significant item on his program at Carnegie Hall was Schubert's Moments Musicaux. Mr. Smith seemed to be out to charm with the sort of potpourri that used to be commonly encountered at recitals in a less serious, perhaps less competitive, time in musical history.

Over the years I picked up that a neighbor of ours had had something called a nervous breakdown, that another friend was not quite right, and that a distant cousin was locked up in a state institution where, I assumed, everyone was crazy.

title: SomaliaWatching From the Sidelines
description: Unaccustomed as they are to watching international drama from the sidelines, Americans can be pleased with their recent role as onlookers at events in the African Horn. The events are rooted in longstanding local rivalries, but they have been made worse by extensive Soviet meddling and kept from becoming still worse by American restraint. As a result, the United States may now have an opportunity to play the constructive role of peacemaker.

title: Pop: Return of the James Gang
description: ASIDE from an occasional night at Roseland, there has been no place in New York in recent years where one could go to hear the old, swingera type of big band that played for dancing as well as listening. However, the Playboy Club, 5 East 59th Street, is taking a plunge into using big bands in its Cabaret Room, starting this week with Harry James, whose band played there Wednesday and last night.

title: EXC,I,A. MAN ASSAILS SAIGON EVACUATION
description: A former senior analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency in Vietnam has charged that the agency's 1975 evacuation from South Vietnam was an institutional disgrace that abandoned thousands of Vietnamese employees and collaborators and exposed them to North Vietnamese retaliation.

title: A New Role for Eddie Belmonte
description: He used to be a peacock, a $250,000ayear jockey swaggering through life with a wardrobe of $1,000 velvet suits and a steady hand that could pick up a $500 restaurant tab without flinching. He drove fancy cars, lived in a fancy house, had a lion cub for a pet and thrived on the adulation of $2 horseplayers whose pleas of c'mon, Eddie were consistently rewarded by winners. From 1966 through 1974, the horses he rode earned $14 million. But the money is gone now and Eddie Belmonte, no longer a peacock, scratching for a living like a barnyard rooster. Too heavy at 135 pounds to try Sports another riding comeback, the Puerto RicanOf bred Belmonte has become a jockey agent. The Times It's a tough game, he was saying yesterday in the horsemen's room at Belmont Park, where scratches for the day's programs Aqueduct were announced shortly before 9 A.M. The trainers know what my jockey can do. But it's not an easy game. You have to keep talking, keep selling the product. Belmonte's product is Bernie Gonzalez, a pleasant, 21yearold jockey who was one of the hotter riders on the New York circuit until he lost his bug (i.e., the weight allow ance all apprentices get) last July 24. From September of 1976, with the bug, Gonzalez had ridden 215 winners. Without it, there has been very little demand for his services.

description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP)Bob Lanier's ailnig left knee was declared much improved after an examination today, but the big center will miss the Detroit Pistons next three games, a spokesman for the National Basketball Association team said. Lanier injured the knee in practice Nov. 7 and has not played in three of Detroit's last four games.

It was rechristened the Iridium Room.

This approach has gained prominence as it has come to mesh easily with environmentalists fear of conventional energy (such as oil, natural gas, coal and nuclear) and with the goals of the faction opposed to growth as a neneral concept.

title: Murder Ruling Wrongly Reported
description: Over a period of nearly 12 hours, a number of newspapers and broadcasters erroneously reported Wednesday night and yesterday morning that New Jersey's Supreme Court was expected to rule that a statute of limitations would bar prosecutions for murders that had occurred more than five years before.

title: Blacks Electoral Gains? Sizable. But, Still..
description: The black urban lower class is slowly being destroyed. Large forces are at work, not the least being catastrophic unemployment. Very little withstands the corrosive force of worklessnessnot the sense of individual selfworth, nor the stability of the family, nor the fabric of community life. A large proportion of each succeeding generation in the ghettos responds by selfdestructionschool failure, addiction, criminality. The paths to social suicide are many, and crowded.

title: MACY PROFIT IS UP 23.9% FOR QUARTER
description: R. H. Macy & Company, reported yesterday a 23.9 percent rise in earnings for the quarter ended Oct. 29.

title: ARMENIAN CHURCH RECEIVES SCULPTURE: Archbishop Torkom Manoogian with sculptor, Reuben Nakian, left, in light coat, in plaza of St. Vartan Cathedral

title: Cabarets Are Thriving Again With a Host of Favorites
description: The nightclub, that intimate medium of the arts, is cozily thriving this season after what had seemed to be several years of slack. Acts that make splashes on network television, in the concert hall, on the Broadway stage, flourish in excerpt or in full in the shadowy, smoky closeness of the nightclub, the small room where space cannot intervene between performer and audience. It is a personal experience for both, something not quite matched in the same way anyplace else.

description: BONN, Nov. 17Klaus Croissant, the radical lawyer extradited by France to his native West Germany early this morning, was taken later today to a maximumsecurity prison in Stuttgart where until recently several of his terrorist clients were held.

title: SCREENING OF JUDGES AGREED TO BY BEANIE
description: Mayor Beame, bowing to criticism from lawyers organizations and others, said last night that he would submit the names of any judges he planned to appoint before leaving office for screening by the City Bar Association.

title: Music: A Gretchen Wyler Hour
description: BETWEEN HER matinee and evening performances of Sly Fox on Wednesday, Gretchen Wyler rushed over to Town Hall to give what she described as a lecture as part of the Hall's late afternoon interludes series. In a sense it was a lecture, in that she talked, but because her subject was Broadway Greats and the Songs That Made Them Famous, she also sang and even danced a little.

title: Carter Urges Measures, to Simplify and Improve Federal Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  President Carter took steps today to permit a harassed public to have a greater voice in bureaucratic regulations and to increase career opportuities for women in the Civil Service.

title: A Convicted Rapist Is Linked by Police To 2 Murder Cases
description: A Convicted Rapist Is Linked by Police To 2 Murder Cases

title: New Bond issues
description: Thursday, Nov. 17, 1977

title: Manning W. Heard, 81, a Leader In the Hartford Insurance Industry
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 17Manning W. Heard, a retired chairman of the Hartford Insurance Group, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Police Are Sought by Suspects
description: What better place to hide from an outraged robbery victim than in a police station.

title: Dr. X to Stand Trial in Curare Case
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 17Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich was ordered to stand trial next Jan. 30 on charges of murdering five hospital patients, as the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 0, that there is no time, limit to the indictment of an alleeed murderer.

title: A Tentative Schedule Of Sadat Trip to Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17 (AP)Here is a tentative schedule of some of the events in the 36hour visit to Israel by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt:

title: SAVINGS BANK PROPOSES HOME MORTGAGE TARGET
description: Responding to pressures from community groups, the Greater New York Savings Bank proposed yesterday to set an annual target of $25 million in new residential mortgage loans in New York City.

title: Black Politicians Assess Sutton's Defeat in Mayoral Primary Race
description: Back in August, City Clerk David N. Dinkins indicated that although it was not a prospect he favored, he thought he and Percy E. Sutton could win their races for Borough President of Manhattan and Mayor just with black votes. At the time, he said, . . . this race is doable with black votes Urban alone, and we have got to Affairs send forth that message. But on Sept. 8, Mr. Dinkins ran third in the fourman race and Mr. Sutton ran fifth in a pack of seven. Only onethird of the enrolled black Democrats voted in that primary, against a citywide average of 45 percent. As a result, for the first time in 24 years there will be no black on the Board of Estimate, and Mr. Sutton, who has ruled unchallenged in the last decade as Harlem's political strongman, will hold no political office.

title: Gospel Disk Jockey Aids Carter In Bid for Panama Canal Treaties
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 17In his campaign to gain support for the ratification of the Panama Canal treaties, President Carter has enlisted the efforts of one of  the country's top gospel disk jockeys.

title: MAJOR CONCESSIONS ON CRUISE MISSILES BY SOVIET REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Soviet Union has made important concessions on the question of the testing and deployment of cruise missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: Taiwan Opens Nuclear Plant
description: TAIPEI. Taiwan. Nov. 17 (Reuters)Taiwans first nuclear power plant started) generating electricity at midnight last nigh'. Two more nuclear plants are under construction in Taiwan. When completed, the three will produce a total of 5,144,000 kilowatts of power.

title: Networks Preparing Coverage of Sadat
description: ABC, CBS and NBC all are making plans to provide live satellite coverage on Sunday morning of Egyptian President Anwar elSadat's address before the Israeli Parliament, although there was no certainty yesterday that cameras would be admitted. The speech is scheduled for 9 A.M. New York time, but the networks expect to begin their coverage about an hour earlier.

title: The Pop Life
description: ANGLOAMERICAN rock and pop are hardly all there is to the world of popular music. Admittedly, Englishlanguage. electronically amplified music has a greater impact worldwide than any other kind, But there are also the fluffier, folkinspired sounds of Europop to consider, and at least sometimes that, music lapses over into the AngloAmerican marketAbba from Sweden, for instance. And sometimes a particu

title: Money Supply Rose $2.4 Billion For the Week
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $2.4 billion in the week ended Nov. 9, a substantial increase but one that was fully anticipated in the securities markets. The broader money supply climbed $3.6 billion, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Up 1.3 To 205.4 From 204.1 Last Week
Treasures for Morgan Library
description: The Heineman Collection, one of the greatest troves of books and manuscripts in private hands, was given today to the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: SADAT GOES TO ISRAEL TOMORROW; HIS FOREIGN MINISTER RESIGNS; SYRIA, IRAQ AND P. L. 0. ASSAIL TRIP
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, disregarding sharp criticism in the Arab world and in his own Government, formally accepted yesterday Prime Minister Menahem Begin's invitation and will make a historic 36hour visit to Israel. The Egyptian leader will arrive in Jerusalem tomorrow night and will address the Israel Parliament Sunday afternoon.

title: Excerpts From New National Catechetical Directory Adopted by Bishops for Roman Catholics in the
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  Following are excerpts from an unedited version of Sharing the Light of Faith, the newly approved National Catechetical Directory for Roman Catholics of the United States.

title: Reserve Report
PRINCESS CHARLOTTE, 79; MONACO RULER'S
description: PARIS, Nov. 17 (UP!)Princess Charlotte of Monaco, the mother of Prince Rainier, died late yesterday at her home here after a long illness, the royal family of Monaco announced today. She was 79 years old.

title: The Now York Times/Carl T. Gossett OLDEST NURSERY SCHOOL PARTY: Georgette Hauser, director, celebrating yesterday the 90th continuous year operation of Memorial Day Nursery School in Paterson. School is reportedly the oldest nursery school in state.
Notes on People
description: Senator Robert J. Dole and Elizabeth Taylor yesterday announced a bipartisan fundraising drive to make possible a $20 million Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the Senator's alma mater, the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. They said that more than 1,500 persons had already pledged $1,000 each to assure the success of a fundraising dinner to be held in Washington Dec. 2. Mr. Humphrey's sister, Frances Humphrey Howard, told a news conference at which the drive was announced, I guess he's as excited about this as about anything that has happened to him, because he's visionary. Mrs. Howard said that her brother, now undergoing chemotherapy treatment for an inoperable pelvic cancer, was responding beautifully.

title: Art: Projects of W.P.A. Revisited
description: THE KIND of art that American artists produced, or were alleged to have produced, under the Federal art programs of the 1930's was for many years a subject that inspired a good deal of hypocrisy, mytholoav and comedy. At the timein the fiepressionhatnted days when so many artists found it so difficult to make even a su.)s sLen, Federal art programs were embraced with enthusiasm. They enabled artists first of all to survive, and they enabled them to work. Whether what was produced on the projects met a high artistic standard was not then the most important issue.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT BOSTON

title: A Convicted Rapist Is Linked by Police To 2 Murder Cases
description: A 23yearold man who was accused of forcing a 17yearold girl to the roof of a fivestory building at knifepoint last February, then raping her and pushing her off, was convicted yesterday of attempted murder, rape and sodomy.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: yOU winced at the beginning of Pete Hamill's new novel, Flesh and Blood. You winced when the tough Irish hero, Bobby Fallon, insisted on dragging his black sidekick, Kirk, into a Brooklyn bar called the Shamrock and then started a brawl because the bartender refused to serve them. You thought such swashbuckling liberalism got worn out in the 1940's. You winced when a turnkey in the prison that Bobby and Kirk get sent to comes up to Bobby while he is doing pushups and says, I hear you're a fighter . . . I run the boxing program here. You thought that routine went out with From Here to Eternity. Most of all, you winced at the rhetorical use of you that Mr. Hamill employs in alternate sections throughout the novel It was you, babe ... You lay there, alone in the desert, the taste of pennies in your mouthwhen you is really I. You'd hoped this locution had died with Jimmy Cannon. I winced.

title: Pro Football Statistics
Japanese Goods Swamp U.S. And Create Trade Tensions
description: Five hundred million Japanese zippers, 30 million feet of Japanese chain and 3 million gallons of Japanese soy sauce are contributing to a record Japanese trade surplus with the United States this year. The Japanese surplus or, to put it another way, the United States deficit is expected to reach $8 billion this year. As a result, the dollar is falling, the yen is soaring, American manufacturers are complaining and Government officials of both nations are wrestling with a disruptive international problem.

title: Meadowlands Results
Arabs in the U.S. Stunned, Puzzled By Sadat's Action
description: The scheduled visit of PresiciPnt Anwar elSadat to Israel and the dramatic succession of events that led to it have left the ArabAmerican community numb and puzzled.

title: About Real Estate
description: BALTIMOREOutside the downtown commerci3I center of Baltimore, row houses stretch out for mile upon mile. They are usually of solid masonry construction, built in the 19th century and ranging in width from S feet to 25 feet. In a city of 900.000 people and 300,000 housing units, fewer than 10,000 of the units are in apartment buildings. _

title: Foreign. Minister Quits in Egypt;. Successor Resigns Hours Later
description: CAIRO, Nov. 17 (AP)President Anwar elSadat lost two Foreign Ministers in the space of a few hours today, with the resignations indicating that there was opposition to the President's decision to visit Jerusalem.

description: A Holiday Festival

title: Brazil Beats U.S. Spikers
description: TOKYO, Nov. 17 (AP)Brazil, spearheaded by Amauri Riheiro and Capt. Antonio Carlos Moreno, easily beat the United States, 158, 158, 157, today in the first preliminary match of the third men's World Cup volleyball championship at Fukuoka. Paul Sunderland led the American scoring with 4 points.

title: Boeing Machinists Accept Contract
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 17 (UPI)Striking machinists of the Boeing Company voted today to accept a threerear contract and end their sevenweek walkout, which idled some 24,000 workers in Washington, Oregon and Kansas, and at several missile bases across the nation.

title: Two Senators Help Form Group to Aid Shcharansky
description: New York's two Senators romed yesterday with other prominent citizens to form a committee that will seek the release of Anatoly Shcharansky, a Soviet Jewish dissident awaiting trial.

title: Pentagon Reorganization Plannec
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)Defense Secretary Harold Brown named three for mer Pentagon officials today to head studies ordered by President. Carter designed to improve the command structure and management of the Pentagon. Appointed were Richard C. Steadman, who served in the foreign policy branch of the Defense Department in the Johnson Administration: Paul R. Ignatius, who served as Secretary of the Navy and in a variety of other posts in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, and Donald P. Rice, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Collapse of Hot Water Tank Kills 3 At Monsanto Plant in Texas City
description: TEXAS CITY, TEX., Nov. 17 (UPI)Three workmen searching for a water leak died yesterday in the collapse of a giant hot water tank at the Monsanto Company's chemical plant. Two others were critically injured.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 0.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railorads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.3 billion tonmiles, up 0.6 percent from the eyarearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 461,373 cars, off 3.1 percent from last year. Both weeks included the Veterans Day holiday in some states. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5.1 percent from a year ago.

title: Murder Ruling Wrongly Reported
description: Over a period of nearly 12 hours, a number of newspapers and broadcasters erroneously reported Wednesday night and yesterday morning that New Jersey's Supreme Court was expected to rule that a statute of limitations would bar prosecutions for murders that had occurred more than five years before.

title: Broadway
description: AMEETING BY THE RIVER, which was nicely received novel by Christopher Isherwood 10 years ago and since then has been a play in search of a Broadway production, is now supposed to come to the stage late this season. Albert Marre will direct it, and Keith Baxter will star in it, and it will be produced by Terry Allen Kramer and Harry Rigby. They want to put it in rehearsal in January, open it at the university or tennessee and then perhaps do it Washington before they do it on Broadway. When A Meeting by the River was given a single perform ance here by the Phoenix Repertory Company in 1972, Richard F. Shepard, reviewing it for The New York Times, said it was a play worth more work and refinement. Mr. Isherwood and Don Bachardy, his collaborator, say they now have worked and refined it.

title: Japan Society Holds Ichikawa Film Series
description: An Actor's Revenge, a film about an actor who avenges the death of his parents, will be shown today at 2 and 7:30 P.M. at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street, as part of a 21film retrospective of the Japanese director Kon Ichikawa that will run until Feb. 2. The films will be shown Wednesdays at 7:30 P.M. and Fridays at 2 and 7:30 P.M. at Japan House.

title: Film: Fassbinder Sneers at German Affluence
description: IN THAT BODY of grisly-comic literature devoted to worms-that-turn, to Mr. Milquetoasts who suddenly sour, to nice family men who quietly take axes to their innocent families, "Why does Herr R. Run Amok?" is one of the scariest as well as one of the funniest works of all.The film, which was made in 1969, is an almost perfect example of the early cinema of Rainer Werner Fassbinderthough I suppose the reason it wasn't included in the New Yorker Theater's Fassbinder retrospective last spring and summer is that it's not technically a Fassbinder film. That is, it was codirected by Mr. Fassbinder and Michael Fengler in the days when the members of the Fassbinder theater and film company thought of their work as communal endeavors. This was the first and last time Mr. Fassbinder let that happen. Such communism, fine for ants, is difficult in the arts.In terms of the chronology of the Fassbinder films we've seen here this year, "Why Does Herr R. Run Amok?" comes immediately after "Katzelmacher" and "Gods of The Plague" and just before "Beware the Holy Whore" (1970), which was all about the difficulties of making a film on which no one had any real authority. Mr. Fassbinder is not a film maker to let an unhappy experience go to waste.If the making of "Why Does Herr R. Run Amok?" with Mr. Fengler was an unhappy experience, it doesn't show in the completed movie, which is as spare, blunt and sardonic as anything that Mr. Fassbinder has ever done by himself. It's also a revealing demonstration of how the style of a Fassbinder film becomes its ubject.The story is simply told: Herr R. (Kurt Raab), a paunchy, mild-mannered fellow, works by day as a draftsman in a small architectural firm. He functions as the master of T-squares, straight-edges and nonleaky pens. At night he is the proper husband to his wife (Lilith Ungerer) and the proper father to young Amadeus (Amadeus Fengler). Together they watch television, plan for the promotion Herr R. hopes to get, and say all the proper things to his boring parents, with whom they talk about television, eating and money.One night while Herr R.'s wife and a neighbor are discussing to the point of exhaustion the subject of ski clothes as Herr R. is trying to watch television, he gets up from his chair and methodically sets about expressing his irritation, using a large blunt instrument.Why does Herr R. run amok? He is bored, but because he has no safety valve of impatience, he explodes. Similarly bored is the camera that observes Herr R.'s life and times.The camera has a habit of more or less settling downas if it were someone vastly overweight filling up a chair. It watches what goes on with no special interest, but it hasn't the strength to move. The camera often can't be bothered to turn to focus on a person who's talking off-screen, knowing that if it waits long enough someone within its range will talk.As Herr R.'s work is completely absorbed by petty details that seem to have no importance in themselves, so is the film composed of a series of small scenes of crushing banality. Much of the dialogue sounds improvised, and like a lot of improvisation, it sometimes is unexpectedly funny and sometimes goes on too long, which is also an aspect of Herr R.'s existence.In addition to Mr. Raab, who is grossly appealing in the title role, the cast includes such other Fassbinder regulars as Hanna Schygulla (in a tiny but funny role), and Lilo Pempeit (the mother of Effi Briest) as one of Herr R.'s office associates, a gray, spinsterish-looking woman who giggles a lot."Why Does Herr R. Run Amok?" is short, bitter film. It's full of sneers for the same German affluence that has made Mr. Fassbinder's extraordinary film career possible, but that's the way with many artists these days. They must bite the hands as long as they feed them.

title: Soviet Asserts West Is Waging Propaganda War
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Pravda today accused the North Atlantic coon= tries of waging a propaganda war over human rights at the Belgrade conference on EastWest cooperation.

title: Biack Nominee Under Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee will send staff aides to New Orleans to investigate allegations against Robert F. Collins, nominated by President Carter to be the first black Federal judge in the Deep South. Mr. Collins, a 46yearold magistrate in New Orleans, was interviewed here yesterday by the committee staff. I have categorically denied all the allegations, he said later. He declined to say what the allegations were, but they reportedly include charges of conflict of interest and favoritism while serving as a magistrate.

title: SCIENTISTS CRITICIZE U.S. ON NUCLEAR SAFETY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)A group of scientists opposing nuclear power plants said today that the Government's basic safety estimates were far too optimistic and that reactor accidents might kill thousands of people by the year 2000.

title: SADAT'S ISRAEL TRIP CRITICIZED BY ASSAD
description: DAMASCUS. Syria, Nov. 17President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, ending his talks here today before preparing to go to Jerusalem to speak to the Israeli Parliament, had a public clash of views with President Hafez alAssad of Syria amid signs of deteriorating relations between their countries.

title: Retail Store Sales Off 1% in Week
description: Retail store sales declined I percent last week to a seasonally adjusted $13.49 billion, compared to the preceding week, but were about 9 percent higher the yearearlier level, according to the United States Department of Commerce. For the year to date, sales are up an adjusted 10 percent over the year earlier level.

title: Silvia F. Silbert, 67, Was Active In Division of Cancer Society
description: Mrs. Silvia F. Silbert, former chairman of the American Cancer Society's women's advisory committee, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of cancer. She was 67 years old and lived at 936 Fifth Avenue.

title: Carey Doubts Need For Pollution Study On Westway Plan
description: Governor Carey, returning from Israel and quickly shifting his focus to state affairs, said yesterday that I don't see how we can find differently than Federal air pollution studies allowing the Westway highway project.

title: Michigan Reactor Is Ordered Shut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered the shutting down of Michigan reactor for replacement of electrical connectors used in safety systems that mieht fail in case of an accident.

title: Kennecott's $66 Carborundum Bid Tied to a Big Offer by Continental
description: The Continental Group, formerly known rs the Continental Can Company was the suitor that lost out to the Kennecott Copper Corporation in a hectic bidding contest for the Carborundum Company, wellplaced Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: DOCK WORKERS VOTE ON PACT IS DELAYED
description: The sevenweekold dock strike, which earlier this week had seemed close to Conclusion, now is likely to continue into next week because of a delay in the voting on ratification of a new master contract.

title: About New York
description: The recognition that was so hardbought on television followed Mario Cuomo like an electronic tsunami into retreat in the Poconos, small mountains that offered small comfort.

title: Issues in the ArabIsraeli Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18  With President Anwar elSadat of Egypt about to fly to Israel, attention has again focused on the issues that have blocked an ArabIsraeli peace agreement. Following is a brief summary of the problems.

title: 'Summerdog,' a Movie Without Bark or Bite
description: Don't bring your children to see "Summerdog" unless you either own a hound or are prepared to pick one up on the way home. This is yet another shaggy-dog movie with a plot that hinges on the physical, moral and intellectual superiority of the family pet. Hobo, the dog of the title, isn't Lassie by a long shot, nor is he even Benji. But he is so much smarter and more appealing than either his owners or their enemies that the film amounts to one long advertisement for canine companionship.Mom (Elizabeth Eisenman), Dad (James Congdon) and their two perfect blond children (Oliver and Tavia Zabriskie) live in an unspecified city that incorporates both a small-town air and large chunks of Central Park, but they have decided to spend their summer vacation in the country. They rent a sweet little cottage, and Dad tries to write there, "I'm afraid the words aren't flowing too well today," he complains at one point.Mom grows radishes. Dad: "It's hard to believe they were just little tiny dried-up seeds a couple of weeks ago." Mom: "It's kind of magical, isn't it?"And the kids find Hobo, whose paw has gotten caught in a bear trap set by Old Caleb, a grizzled neighbor. "Do you think Caleb Grimes is really a bad person or just someone who can't cope with today's world?" Mom inquires.Everyone falls in love with Hobo, but the family can't bring him home: The landlord won't allow pets, and they simply can't afford to move. After a lot of fuss and intrigue, the problem is solved, and a song praising Hobo is sung. Needless to say, he gets to stay."Summerdog" is so unimaginatively made, and so full of noisily exaggerated acting of the "More Parks Sausages, Mom!" school, that it should be of only slight interest to older children and of no interest to adultsunless they can keep busy with puzzling out the plot's fine points, like the matter of how a family too strapped to move can magically rent a summer house without subletting their treasured apartment.However, there are a few isolated scenes here that a preview audience of small children found screamingly funny. One such episode involved a dozen people chasing madly down a circular staircase, with Hobo at the fore. Another featured a mouse, who appeared in the summer house and gave Mom a good scare.

title: Rate Tensions Ease And Dow Rises 3.90
description: Stock prices pushed slightly higher yesterday as tensions over shortterm interest rates eased somewhat on Wall Street. Advancing issues outnumbered declines on the New York Stock Exchange by more than a 4to3 ratio.

title: Koch Starts His Studies as Mayor Major at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18Mayorelect Edward I. Koch of New York City came to Harvard University today to join a seminar with other new mayors and he did some politicking in Boston along he way.

title: 2 Share Lead in Japan Open
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18 (AP)Norio Suzuki of Japan shot a 71 today, one stroke better than the firstround leader, Severiano Ballesteros of Spain, and tied for the lead at 141, halfway through the $265,000 Japan Open. Kosalcu Shimada, with a 71, was a stroke off the pace at 142. Larry Nelson had a 74 for 148 and Johnny Miller had a 77 for 152 and missed the cut.

title: Saudi Criticism Is Ominous
description: CAIRO, Nov. 18The Saudi criticism was seen here as adding greatly to the already enormous political risks involved in President Sadat's trio to Israel.

title: GOING PRIVATE CODE IS PROPOSED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed rules that would require companies that repurchase their own stock to assure that the interests of minority stockholders are protected.

title: Cape Man Case Jury Is Still Deadlocked
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 18After nearly two days of deliberation, the jury remained deadlocked today in the trial of Salvador Agron, the murderer who was known in the 1950s as the Cape Man, on charges of absconding from an inmate educational release nroeram.

title: Two Brothers Slain In Broorlyn Office Of Their Company
description: Two brothers who owned a clothing export company were shot and killed in their Brooklyn office yesterday afternoon, apparently the victims of a robbery attempt.

title: New York Riders Holding Talks on Union Affiliation
description: New York's thoroughbred racing industry received another jolt yesterday when jockeys, currently riding at Aqueduct, disclosed that they have been holding discussions about the advantages of becoming unionized.

title: Reagan, Connally and Baker Open A Broad Attack on Administration
description: ORLANDO, Fla. Nov. 18Sensing the political potential in President Carter's recent slippage in the public opinion polls, three top Republicans have launched a broadside attack on the Carter Administration's domestic and foreign policies.

title: Howe Shut Out Again
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 18 (AP)  Thirdperiod goals by John McKenzie, Alan Bangsleben and Mike Antonovich carried New England to a World Hockey Associationrecord 12th consecutive victory tonight with a 32 decision over the Winnipeg Jets. But the Whalers veteran, Gordie Howe, again failed to collect the 1,000th goal of his career.

title: Brandt and Schmidt Reelected
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 18Germany's ruling Social Democrats today reelected Willy Brandt as party chairman and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt as deputy chairman for the next two years.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in The Times reported incorrectly yesterday the projected levels of hydrocarbon pollution related to the Westway. Original predictions were that with the Westway, traffic in Manhattan would produce 15.4 tons of hydrocarbons a day and with its alternative 15.9 tons; the revised estimate was that both would product about 15.9 ikt tons.

title: At Houston Meeting, A Kaleidoscope of American Womanhood
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 18A torch, the flaming symbol of the womens rights movement, carried 2,610 miles from Seneca Falls, N.Y., reached Houston today to open the National Women's Conference. A cross section of American women were here to greet it. Among them were the 2,000 conference deleEates.

title: Silky Sullivan, Race Horse, Dies
description: PLEASANTON, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI)  Silky Sullivan, who two decades ago was a star stretchrunning thoroughbred race horse, died today at the age of 22. A spokesman at the Green Oaks Stables said Silky Sullivan had died in his sleep of apparent natural causes.

title: Personal Investing
description: Is there some way to make money by trading against the grain of taxselling in the stock market? An associate professor of finance at the University of Massachusetts suggests in a study that there are situations in which some might find it profitable to trade against a taxselling market. Page 29.

title: What Can the Equal Rights Amendment Do and What Can't It Do?; The likely. effects are not as farreaching as some say
description: The equal rights amendment, one of the central issues at the National Women's Conference in Houston, has the potential for changing the lives of countless women and men in myriad, major waysmany, but not all, of which can be forecast now. The likely effects if the E.R.A. passesand it is currently three states short of the 38 needed for ratificationare not all as farreaching as some of its most vocal opponents have predicted; there is no realistic possibility, for instance, that the amendement will be construed by courts or legislatures to forbid separate bathrooms for men and women, one of the specters that has been raised.

title: Jet Run Wins Jumper Class In Toronto
description: TORONTO. Nov. 18Show horses are often shuffled from owner to owner in the United States. But it's a rare mount that makes a round trip between the United States and Mexico.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Aid CutOff Is Barred

title: Mauch Must Stay With Twins
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 18 (UPI)The Minnesota Twins board of directors has declined to release Manager Gene Mauch from his 1978 contract. The board met yesterday and released a statement today that said: It was decided by the hoard that Gene Mauch is the manager of the Twins in 1978. Gene Autry, principal owner of the California Angels, had sought Mauch to manage his team.

title: Nicklaus Shoots Record 67, But Trails by 3 in Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. IS (AP)Jack Nicklaus moved into contention in the $200,000 Australian Open today with a record fiveunderpar 67 at the Australian Club, a course he recently helped redesign. The 67 left Nicklaus three strokes behind the leaders, John Lister and Don January both tied at 141, at the end of the second round.

title: Business Inventories Show Lag
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)Businesses accumulated inventories at slower rate in September during a sluggish month for sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS GAIN TENTATIVE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Nov. 19United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, reached a tentative contract agreement late last night with 8,000 flight attendants, avoiding a strike threatened for midnight that could have disrupted heavy holiday traffic next week.

title: Campbell Soup Expects Rise In Profits for 1977 Fiscal Year
description: The Campbell Soup Company expects that profits in the fiscal year ending next July 31 will be better than the $107.1 million, or $3.28 a share, reported for fiscal 1977, H. A. Shaub, president, said after the annual meeting in Camden, N.J.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
Memphis Seeks to Restore Its Status
description: MEMPHIS  Almost alone among the major cities of the South, this battered htit resilient cotton capital at the northern tip of the Mississippi Delta struggled through the late 1960 s and early 70's without visibly sharing in the boom that was transforming the Sunbelt.

title: DAVEY O'BRIEN, 60, A STAR QUARTERBACK
description: Davey O'Brien, who as a 5foot7inch, 150pound quarterback won the Heisman Trophy in 1938 after leading Texas Christian University to 11 straight victories, died yesterday of cancer in Fort Worth. He was 60 years old.

title: Bangladesh to Whip Hoarders
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Men found guilty of hoarding and involvement in the black market will be whipped, according to a new martiallaw regulation. Observers said the regulation was promulgated last night after prices of essential commodities soared as a result of largescale hoarding and trading.

title: Women May Skip U.S. Open for Own Tournament
description: The West Side Tennis Club and the Women's Tennis Association are considering the possibility of staging a $400,000 tournament next year that could conflict with the United States Open championship at Flushing Meadow Park.

title: Sale to China Lifts Soybean Prices
description: Despite reports that the Soviet Union and China had bought grains and soybeans here, futures prices of those commodities on the Chicago Board of Trade remained steady until about midsession, when speculative buying rapidly pushed prices up.

title: T.V.A. Sues Gulf and 12 Others, Charging a Uranium Conspiracy
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 (UPI)The Tennessee Valley Authority filed suit today charging that 10 foreign and three domestic companies joined a conspiracy in 1972 to fix world uranium prices, milking the agency of as much as $200 million through control of nuclear fuel supplies.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Leon Jaworski, the special counsel to the House ethics committee, warned President Park Chung Hee of South Korea tonight not to make the mistake of obstructing an investigation, as he said President Nixon did in the Watergate affair.

title: Networks Question Drop in TV Viewing Indicated by Ratings
description: People are watching television somewhat less this year than last. At least, that is what the Nielsen monthly ratings data have been showing. The television industry, however, has doubts that it is true.

title: I.P.S./Fronk Pa?arp A SEVERE HAILSTORM, accompanied by winds of 60.90 miles an hour, tore part of the roof off this houseln, Mercer County's Ewing Township yesterday and spread it all over the yard. The storm lasted only an hotin
Profit in 4th Quarter At American Motors Totaled $3 Million
description: The American Motors Corporation today reported a fourthquarter profit of $3 million, or 9 cents a share, on revenues of $565 million, announced a series of promotions and the resignation Of its vice chairman. R. W. McNealy.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in The Times reported incorrectly yesterday the projected levels of hydrocarbon pollution related to the Westway. Original predictions were that with the Westway, traffic in Manhattan would produce 15.4 tons of hydrocarbons a day and with its alternative; 15.9 tons; the revised estimate was that both would produce about 15.9 tons.

title: Earthquake Jolts Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 (AP)A moderately strong earthquake struck 60 miles southeast of Belgrade this morning, causing minor damage to buildings in the towns of Velingrad and Jakoruda but no casualties, officials said.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1977

title: CAIRO FACES A CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18The Arab world faced a potential crisis today as opposition intensified to the decision of President Anwar elSadat to fly to Israel tomorrow.

title: Teddi King, 48, a Noted Jazz Singer
description: Teddi King, a singer who had followings in both jazz clubs and sophisticated supper clubs, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. Miss King, who had been in poor health for several years, was admitted to the hospital on Thursday, suffering from what was diagnosed as meningitis. She lived at 825 West End Avenue and was 48 years old.

title: PORT AGENCY PLANS TO BAR SST'S IN 1985
description: With the Concorde due to start passenger service at Kennedy International Airport Tuesday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that a majority of its commissioners had decided to adopt a new noise rule that, starting in 1985, would have the effect of barring the supersonic airliner.

title: In Indonesia, A Writer's Plight
description: Pramoedya Ananta Toer, generally regarded as the finest contemporary writer in Indonesia, has not written a word in 12 years. His writer's block can be readily explained: Since his arrest in 1965 he has been denied any access to pencil, pen or paver.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLAN TO CUT IMPORT FLOOD BACKED BY U.S. STEEL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The nation's biggest steel company today tentatively endorsed a referenceprice formula of the Carter Administration to protect the industry against excessive imports and suggested that if it was implemented fairly the company might withdraw multibillion dollar antidumoine suits.

title: Buttock Pinch Without Consent Is Ruled a Crime in New York
description: Pinching or touching the buttocks of a person without that person's consent is a crime in New York and punishable by a jail term, a Manhattan Criminal Cour judge has ruled.

title: A Few Small Gifts for New Yorkers
description: The installation of a new Mayor of New York City inevitably creates a yearning for dramatic gestures to lift the spirits of the community. Unfortunately, such gestures are expensive and New Yorkers cannot expect grand pianos for Christmas this year. Nevertheless, change is always a chance to provide at least a few municipal stocking stuffers that raise morale and hint that better days may be ahead.

title: Visit Marks a New Direction After a Long History of ArabJewish Antagonism
description: When Israeli architects were planning the nation's new Parliament building in the early 1960's they decided at the last moment to turn the structure around so that its main entrance would not face enemy guns less than a mile away.

title: The Theory of the A&F Class
description: For 85 years, Abercrombie & Fitch, now in the throes of its final sale, nas stood as a citadel of The Leisure Class. In its inviting halls stylish sportsmen could count on finding the highestgrade rods and guns at the highest prices. It was immensely gratifying for a group that, as Thorstein Veblen instructed us, distinguished itself by making leisure a way of life.

title: Teenagers Seized in Crypt Thefts
description: Five teenagers have been charged with breaking into crypts in two Queens cemeteries and removing skulls, apparently to sell them to cult worshipers, the office of the Queens District Attorney, John Santucci, announced yesterday.

title: Municipal Aides Examine New JobInsurance Law
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18Municipal officials expressed concern today about the cost of unemployment insurance for their employees in a federally mandated program that will begin Jan. 1.

title: APPLAUSE AT AIRPORT
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18For the first time in Israel's 29year history, an Arab airliner touched down today at an Israeli airport. Israelis applauded as 60 Egyptian officials and technicians emerged to join in the feverish preparations already under way for the historic visit of President Anwar elSadat beginning tomorrow.

title: Regents Let Girls Join Boys Teams
description: The New York State Board of Regents ruled yesterday that secondary schools must let girls play baseball and soccer on boys teams, but it continued to forbid mixed competition in some of the more rigorous contact sports such as basketball, football and wrestling.

title: Musto Denies Gambling Conspiracy And Says He Won't Quit His Posts
description: UNION CITY, Nov. 18State Senator William V. Musto angrily denied today Federal charges that he conspired to protect illegal gambling operations in Union City in late 1974 and asserted he would not resign either from the Legislature or from his position as Mayor of this aging Hudson County community.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS AND BANK ACCUSED BY S.E.C. IN FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Securities and Exchange Commisison today charged Goldman, Sachs & Company, major investment banking and brokerage firm, and the First National Bank of Chicago with aiding and abetting a now defunct Wisconsin bank in a securities fraud. Also named in the agency's action, which orders administrative proceedings, is Glenn Caan, a Wisconsinbased broker.

title: Experts Debate The Prediction Of Disasters
description: An increasingly bitter debate is spreading among experts in many fields of science over catastrophe theorya mathematical concept intended to explain and predict events as disparate as chemical reactions, dog bites, stock market crashes and the outbreak of war.

title: PALESTINIANS STORM EMBASSY IN ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Nov. 18About 30 Palestinian students stormed the Egyptian Embassy here tonight, setting off a wave of panic during a rally of nearly 100,000 Greeks gathered to hear Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis give his final speech in the Greek election campaign.

title: Itinerary for Visit Is Issued by Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Following is a tentative schedule for President Anwar elSadat's visit. It was issued by Israeli authorities:

title: Dancers Lives Up to Its Name In Both Skill, Choreography
description: Dennis Wayne's new company, Dancers made its official New York debut at its metropolitan home, the Roundabout Theater, on Thursday night, at an invitational gala. The very name Dancers almost tells it allfor the emphasis is determinedly on the dancers rather than the dance.

title: Reserve Panel Voted in October to Keep Rates High
description: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, the 12man group that meets monthly to set monetary policy and then publishes a record of its decisions with a month's lag, voted again in midOctober to push shortterm interest rates higher.

title: Barge Raised Under Cargo Afloat at Dock
description: NEWARK, Nov. 18Even for the nation's biggest port, it was an unusual loid to be sending off. A total of 12 barges, one 225ton floating derrick, a dieiel tug 50 sets of aircraft landing gear, severiil trucks and 775 bales of blankets were among the items being loaded on board here today for passage to Nigeria.

title: The Dollar's Slide From Boom to Bargain
description: The decline in the dollar's value is having repercussions from Tokyo to Blomingdale's.

title: Criminal Counts Loom In. Ringer Case
description: Despite a courtordered lifting of his suspension, criminal charges against Dr. Mark Gerard appeared imminent yesterday.

title: Deatha
description: APPLBAUMDavid Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Gerald and Bernard. Loving grandfather of Meryl, Seth, Robin and Gary. Dear brother. Services Sunday, 11:30AM, Gutte man's. 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Live Classical Music Soothes Bellevue Prison Ward Inmates
description: The cello seemed somewhat out o place, and, for that matter, so did the piano, even though it was a battered old upright that had been banged in the psychiatric prison wards long enough to become slightly out of tune.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONAn anchor assembly system that has interchangeable flukes was patented this week. Willam Steiling??a New York actor, received Patent 4,058,078 for the system.

title: U.S. LAW ON FAST TRIALS RULED UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP)A Federal district judge ruled unconstitutional today a 1974 Federal law mandating speedy trials for criminal defendants, calling the act a legislative encroachment on the iudiciarvy.

title: Hunters Find Two Fetuses
description: CHESTER, N.J., Nov. 18 (UPI)Two rabbit hunters found two sevenmonthold fetuses wrapped in a blanket in a discarded typewnter case the police reported oday. The fetuses were found yesterday in a wooded area of Chester near dumping ground used by contractors. Sgt. Wandell Cox said authorities believed the fetuses had been in the typewriter case since Nov. 12.

title: Dance: City Ballet and Stravinsky
description: It was an allStravinsky program by the New York City Ballet Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Actually, one of the scheduled ballets, Stravinsky Violin Concerto, was replaced by the Rubies section of Diamonds because of an illness in the first ballet's cast.

title: Getting the Word From Grandmother
description: There is more felicity on the far side of baldness than young men can possibly imagine. Logan Pearsall Smith

Israelis applauded as 60 Egyptian officials and technicians emoted to join in the feverish preparations already under way for the historic visit of President Anwar elSadat beginning tomorrow.

title: Meadowlands Results
Visit Is Dominant Topic in Israel and Occupied Areas
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18Israel and the Arab territories it occupies were linked by common excitement today over tomorrow's arrival of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt. For once, most of the Jews and many of the Arabs were saying, and perhaps believing, the same thing and sharing the came hone.

title: Sadat to Publish Memoirs in 1978
description: The memoirs of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, which include hitherto secret details about the 1973 ArabIsraeli war and Egypt's subsequent rearmament, are to be published in the United States and in other countries next May or June, publishing executives disclosed yesterday.

title: Battle for Pasadena: Ohio State and Michigan Clash Today
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov 18Amid the panoply of a grand American tradition, Ohio State and Michigan will stage their annual football game tomorrow to decide the Big Ten championship and the team to go on to the Rose Bowl.

title: In a Whirl of Festivities, Movie Stars Enliven the Washington Scene
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The whole world must be here, proclaimed a wideeyed guest. Well, not unite.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18The Arab world faced a potential crisis today as opposition intensified to the decision of President Anwar elSadat to fly to Israel tomorrow.

title: Charles C. Loehmann Is Dead at 83
description: Charles C. Loehmann, a founder and the chairman of Loehmann's Inc., the women's fashion discount chain, died late Thursday evening in his apartment in the Drake Hotel here. He was 83 years old.

title: FTC. HEAD TO PRESS ANTITRUST ACTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Michael Pertschuk, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that the agency would pursue a policy of boldness in enforcement of the antitrust laws and would make more use of its authority to enjoin mergers before they Occur

title: `Semi-Tough' Film Winson Field Goals
description: "Semi-Tough," Dan Jenkins's best-selling comic novel about big-league professional football, has been slimmed down, beefed up and reworked to make a funny film that is as much satire as parody, as much about our time as it is about some of our more bizarre culture heroes.The movie, which opened yesterday at the Criterion and Baronet Theaters, takes us on a sort of "Through the Looking Glass" journey into the Sunday afternoon television screen and beyond, into the lives of Billy Clyde Puckett (Burt Reynolds) and Shake Tiller (Kris Kristofferson), prostars whose names are part of the film's comic method, and Barbara Jane Book-man (Jill Clayburgh), the pretty but failure-prone daughter of the owner of their ball club. Barbara Jane shares a platonic friendship with the two players as well as their Miami Beach penthouse apartment, a gaudy nest that looks as if it had been decorated by the people who did our Ziegfeld Theater.Other "characters" who move in and out of the film are Big Ed Bookman (Robert Preston). Barbara Jane's father, a hot-tempered tycoon with a fondness for patriotic songs (Gene Autry records); Friedrich Bismark (Bert Convy), the hustling head of a terrifically successful "energy training" course called BEAT, and Clara Pelf (Lotte Lenya), a ferocious chiropractor who calls what she does "pelfing."Walter Bernstein, who wrote the screenplay, and Michael Ritchie, the director, haven't been successful in giving dramatic structure to the episodic novel, but they do succeed in restraining a terrible tendency toward cuteness, not an easy thing to do in a comedy in which all men are recognized as just over-grown boys.With this film Mr. Ritchie ("The Bad News Bears," "Smile," "Downhill Racer") reinforces his reputation as one of those rare directors who is able to look at Middle America critically without being especially outraged or even surprised.Mostly he is amused, not as someone who sets himself apart from the scene, but as a man who recognizes his own place in it. He may wish it were other than it is, but he doesn't rage that it isn't. He's a humanist fascinated by the manners and mores of a society in which everything, from food to mental health, has been merchandized for the take-out trade."Semi-Tough" is not a movie that forces a lot of plot on you. It's under way for some time before you begin to grasp what is meant to be the storythe thing that is supposed to pull you along. This is about the rivalry that suddenly springs up between the self-assured Billy Clyde, a role that effectively uses Mr. Reynolds's television talk show personality, and Shake Tiller, a fellow who is a pared-down, very hesitant version of Mr. Kristofferson's identity as a musician-singer. At the center of the quarrel is Barbara Jane.If the film's various sketch-pieces were not so funny, "Semi-Tough" would not have any story at all. As it is, we go along with it for the three leading players, who are good company, and for the wit that, though random, is consistent. For a film about football, "Semi-Tough" spends comparatively little time on the field and makes no serious attempt to trap our interest in questions about winning or losing.Winning or losing is not the concern of the film, which knows that there are always new seasons to improve old records. The film isn't even too concerned about whether Barbara Jane marries Billy Joe or Shake Tiller. Its interest is in the overall scenein the shambles of her wedding ceremonies, a very nice sequence that begins as we overhear the minister and Friedrich Bismark, the mental-health tycoon, standing at the altar solemnly discussing tax shelters.Miss Clayburgh, who's been asked to play zany heroines in "Gable and Lombard" and "The Silver Streak" by people who failed to provide her with material, has much better luck this time. She's charming."Semi-Tough" pokes fun in rambling fashion, but it is vulgar in intelligent ways and almost always amusing in its perceptions of befuddled people who are perfectly healthy but often convinced they're not.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Rangeritis: Loser Syndrome
description: There's a new outbreak of an old disease in town. Rangeritisas predictable as the flu in winteris infecting another roster of Rangers.

title: Torsney, on Stand, Insists He Thought Slain Boy, 15, Had Reached for a Pistol
description: Police Officer Robert Torsney, accused of killing a Brooklyn youth last Nov. 25, maintained under crossexamination yesterday what he had said under direct examinationthat he had acted in selfdefense and did not feel he had committed a crime.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Nov. 18 (UPI)Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi said today that Iran was ready to place new industrial orders in France worth billions of dollars.

title: ALABAMIAN GUILTY IN 63 CHURCH BLAST THAT KILLED 4 GIRLS
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 18Fourteen years after a dynamite bomb exploded here at the 16th Street Baptist Church and killed four young black girls in one of the worst racial incidents in Southern history, a jury of three blacks and nine whites delivered a murder conviction in the case today.

title: Benitez, Floored 3 Times, Gains A Split Decision
description: Wilfredo Benitez, knocked down three times in all and almost out on his feet at the end of the fourth round, survived Bruce Curry's heavy hitting to earn a split decision in their 10round welterweight fight at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Begin Thanks Ceausescu for Help
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel thanked President Nicholae Ceausescu today for helping to arrange the visit by President Anwar elSadat to Israel, according to diplomatic reports reaching Belgrade.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Firmly Against Taking S. A.T.'s
description: BOSTON  What would happen if they held the Scholastic Aptitude Tests and nobody came? If high school students refused to take the S.A.T.'s?

title: MANUEL ARTIME DIES; LED INVASION OF CUBA
description: MIAMI, Nov. 18Manuel Artime Buesa, a Cuban physician who became the leader of the illfated United Statessupported Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in 1961 and who was later ransomed from Cuban jail for $500,000, died here last night of cancer. He was 45 years old.

title: Experts Debate The Prediction Of Disasters
description: An increasingly bitter debate is spread ing among experts in many fields of science over catastrophe theorya mathematical concept intended to explain and predict events as disparate as chemical reactions, dog bites, stock market crashes and the outbreak of war.

title: PALESTINIANS STORM EMBASSY IN ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Nov. 18About 30 Palestinian students stormed the Egyptian Embassy here tonight, setting off a wave of panic during a rally of nearly 100,000 Greeks gathered to hear Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis give his final speech in the Greek election campaign.

title: C.I.A. Says Agent Violated Oath By Publishing Book About Saigon
description: The Central Intelligence Agency yesterday accused Frank Snepp, a former agent, of violating his security oath and his word by publishing an extensive analysis of the agency's role in South Vietnam without obtaining prior approval.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. The acceptance by Egyptian President Anwar elSadat of an invitation to visit Israel evoked strong opposition in various countries of the Arab world. The Palestine Liberation Organization made no comment, but was also reported to be critical of the move. Apart from emotions, why is the Palestinian leadership, in particular, opposed to the move?

title: Bullets Trounce Knicks
description: LANDOVER Md., Nov. 18For almost two weeks, Elvin Hayes of the Washington Bullets, one of the best shooting forwards in the Natioral Basketball Association, had been in the worst scoring slump of his 10season career. He had failed to score a field goal against the Houston Rockets, and in eight games had totaled only 103 points. Since Hayes was nearing his 32d birthday, rumors had started that he might be traded.

title: Sadat Spends Day in Canal City and Attends Prayers
description: CAIRO, Nov. 18President Anwar elSadat spent today in the Suez Canal city of Ismailia where he attended prayers at the local mosque as part of a fiveday celebration of the Moslem feast of Bairam, commemorating Abraham's sacrifice of the lamb.

title: A Primer for Challenging a Bar Association
description: WASHINGTONLawyers and bar associations must feel as if they are in a state of siege. For decades, unchallenged, they wrote the rules that defined their power, prerogatives and income. Why? Because professionals, of course, were only subject to selfregulation. Outside scrutiny by legislatures, courts and citizens was for meat producers and utility executives, not lawyers.

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP)The Soviet Union has bought an additional 250,000 metric tons of American wheat, raising to more than 1.6 million tons of wheat and corn it has purchased this week, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Public Advocate to Study Pinelands
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, Nov. 18The New Jersey Public Advocate has agreed to study possible administrative actions to protect the states Pine Barrens as result of allegations that land speculators are attempting to move into, the vast semiwilderness area before planning legislation is enacted.

title: Teachers in Jersey Facing Layoffs
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18School districts may have to dismiss teachers to balance their budgets, school officials said today.

title: Sadat's Visit Threatens Arab Aid to Egypt
description: The economic risks to Egypt may be at least as great as the political ones in President Anwar eladat's visit to Israel today.

title: Earthquake Jolts Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 (AP)A moderately strong earthquake struck 60 miles southeast of Belgrade this morning, causing minor damage to buildings in the towns of Velingrad and Jakoruda but no casualties, officials said.

title: Modern Technology Blurs Distinctions in HealthCare Delivery
description: The indictment last month of Smithtown General Hospital on Long Island and four of its staff members for allowing a medicalsupply salesman to help perform hip surgery has focused attention on the interrelationship between medicine and technology.

title: TV Plans Coverage Of Visit by Egyptian
description: The three major television networks say they plan live satellite coverage of President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel this weekend.

title: Davey O'Brien Dies
description: Davey O'Brien, the winner of the 1938 Heisman Trophy and a former quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, cEed yesterday at the age of 60. Page 24.

title: Torsney, on Stand, Insists He Thought Slain Boy, 15, Had Reached for a Pistol
description: Police Officer, Robert Torsney, accused of killing a Brooklyn youth last Nov. 25, maintained under crossexamination yesterday what he had said under direct examination that he had acted in selfdefense and did not feel he had committed a crime.

title: U. of Michigan's Proud Old Blues Brace for Ohio State Blitz
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18As Bob Ufer might tell it on radio station WJR, Field Marshal Woody Hayes's Panzer divisions are rolling north from Columbus across the prairies of Ohio, murder in their eyes and destruction in their hearts as they bear down on civilized, sophisticated, cosmopolitan Ann Arbor. But General Bo (George Patton) Schembechler is waiting with equally hardeyed troops, ready to match the invaders tuchdown for touchdown. If Coach Schembechler succeeds, Bob Ufer will scream with joy into his playbyplay microphone while he honks horn that once was attached to the real General Patton's jeep. Students listening on their transistor radios will break up in gleeful appreciation.

title: Notes on People
description: Because of union troubles, Lillian Carter's return flight to the United States from Ireland was delayed indefinitely yesterday. President Carter's 79yearold mother rejected suggestions that she leave her fellow Americans who had traveled to Ireland on a charter flight and instead take a commercial flight home. I came with an American party and I will return with them, no other way, said Mrs. Carter. Irish trade unionists refused to give service to the American group's aircraft, chartered from Trans International Airlines, at the request of the United States teamsters union, which is involved in a labor dispute with the airline.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Brewers Pay Hisle $3 Million
description: While the Mets made history by signing their first postrevolution free agentat Met pricesthe Milwaukee Brewers hired Larry }lisle yesterday and gave him one of the most lucrative baseball contracts ever written, a sixyear deal worth more than $3 million.

title: Coal Output Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)The National Coal Association today estimated bituminous coal production in the United States for the week ended Nov. 12 at 15,290 million tons. Production for the corresponding period in 1976 was 13,820 million tons. Production Jan. 1 through Nov. 12 was estimated at 602,585,000 tons.

title: Debra P. Dickson Married to Edward Spering
description: The Church in Brielle, N.J. (Reformed Church in America) was the setting last night for the marriage of Debra Prizer Dickson, daughter of Mary Prizer Dickson of Brielle and Charles Hugh Dickson of Asbury Park, N.J., to Edward Samuel Spering, son of Margaret Smith Spering of Glenside, Pa., and Stone Harbor, N. J., and the late Edward Samuel Spering. The Rev. William H. Jewett performed the ceremony.

title: Union Authorizes Greyhound Strike
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 18 (AP)Members of the Amalgamated Transit Union have voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike against Greyhound Lines, threatening to disrupt Thanksgiving holiday travel.

title: Official Need Not Testify on Biko
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 18A South African court ruling today effectively barred the lawyer for the family of Stephen Biko from summoning the Justice Minister to testify on how he came to issue an announcement suggesting that a hunger strike instead of brain injuries caused the black leader's death.

title: Koch Faces Demand For 1978 Pay Rises, 3 Union Chiefs Say
description: Three municipal labor leaders, who are preparing for contract negotiations with the city, made it clear yesterday that their members would seek wage increases next year despite the city's ??? plight.

title: CENTER FOR HUMANITIES TO BE BUILT BY COLUMBIA
description: Columbia University yesterday announced plans for a new center for the humanities to be built over the next few years as part of a $16.5 million student residence complex on the eastern edge of the Morningside Heights campus.

title: Money
description: Friday, November 18, 1977

title: The HumphreyHawkins Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18It started off as legislation that would have made the Government the employer of last resort for the unemployed. The question now is whether the HumphreyHawkins fullemployment bill, after all the compromises. ended up as a political symbol of last resort for President Carter, Congressional liberals and the Congressional Black Caucus. The question arises in light of the many concessions made to Mr. Carter in months of negotiations with the sponsors, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Representative Augustus F. Hawkins of California, both Democrats.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Policeman Arrested on Charge Of Stealing a Dollar From Decoy
description: An offduty 30yearold New York City policeman was arrested yesterday for allegedly stealing money from a decoy Transit Authority policeman staked out in a midtown subway station.

title: Nativity Scene Suit Dismissed
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a complaint seeking to bar the construction of Christmas nativity scenes on public land in the Westchester County communities of Mamaroneck, Larchmont and Scarsdale. Three individuals filed the suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claiming that construction of the creches on public land represented an unconstitutional establishment of religion. In dismissing the complaint for lack of jurisdic. lion, Judge Robert Ward did not rule on the merits of the case.

title: Guinea's Halting of Soviet Flights Leaves U.S. in a Quandary on Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Guinea has quietly terminated Soviet reconnaissance flights from its territory, placing the Carter Administration, with its concern about human rights, in a quandary over whether to extend modest military and economic aid to the repressive Marxist Government there.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MEN OF MUSIC The prolific Ned Rorem, the Pulitzer Prizewinning composer, will be present tomorrow to introduce his new work, Serenade on Five English Poems. and to answer questions from the audience in the first of three Sunday performances by the Cantilena Chamber Players at 3 P.M. at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. Admission $6. and $3 for students.

title: Police Press Hunt for Youth Suspected of Two Dozen Flatbush Rapes
description: A special task force of as many as 40 police officers has begun a nightly stakeout of a neighborhood in the Flathush section of Brooklyn in an effort to capture a youth suspected of raping two dozen women there since June 1976.

title: Scores on WOXR
description: Scores of leading I0Otball games Will be given over WQXR on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and on other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

title: Sinks Wins And Looks For All Bout
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 18 Presumably earning a shot at Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight champion, who sat at ringside after again having publicly declared his intention to fight the winner in February, Leon Spinks of St. Louis took a decision from Alfio Righetti of Italy tonight. All three judges scored the freeswinging but not terribly damaging fight 4644.

title: Germans Fear a New Terror Attack
description: BONN, Nov. 18Extraordinary security precautions were in force throughout West Germany today, in reaction to rumors that radicals were preparing to stage a terrorist attack in memory of the deaths of three of their leaders in a Stuttgart orison a month ago.

title: Buttock Pinch Without Consent Is Ruled a Crime in New York
description: Pinching or touching the buttocks of a person without that person's consent is a crime in New York and punishable by a jail term, a Manhattan Criminal Court judge has ruled.

title: Profit and Poison in Guatemala
description: A few moments of extra thought are in order about detailed report to The Times last week by Alan Riding on the destructive use of insecticides by Guatemalan cotton growers. More insecticide means more cotton; fewer insects mean higher profits, ran one grower's catechism. He did not add that the pesticides also exact a fearful toll from Indian cotton pickers, who earn $1.25 for 12hour day in the fields. Many die. Many more become seriously ill. And the runoff from all the pesticide pollutes rivers and grasslands, infesting meat, fish, milkand people.

title: Memphis Seeks to Restore Its Status
description: MEMPHIS  Almost alone among the major cities of the South, this battered but resilient cotton capital at the northern tip of the Mississippi Delta struggled through the late 1960's and early 70's without visibly sharing in the boom that was transforming the Sunbelt.

title: Control of Landenburg Is Sold

title: Sports Should Be Fun, At Least for the Amateur
description: At age 30, many of us are suddenly faced by the horrible fact that we are not what we once were physically. Following the Sunday afternoon softball game, the Wednesday afternoon racquetball match or the weekly jog around the park, we retire to the cooler or refrigerator to grab a beer and reminisce about the good old days when muscles were less tender and our bodies could absorb more punishment. We come home from the courts, the paths and fields not necessarily feeling invigorated, but wondering if we have won another battle against getting older. Instead of enjoying the psychological benefits of sports, we are running for our lives.

title: DANCE VIEW

You could focus on any number of passing features and Miss de Mille attempted, surprisingly successfully, to present a diagramatic and synergistic view of the world theatrical dance. It was history and esthetics, and, by the way but above all, it was entertainment. What I want to focus on for the minute are the glimpses she gave us of lsadora Duncan and Martha Graham.

Ludwig has written a procedural involving the Los Angeles Police Department. He has tried for a realistic approachone neither sadistic nor, on the other hand, representing the cops as Boy Scouts. Trying to show his men whole, he takes us into their private lives and emotional tensions. Brenner, for instance, is middleaged, divorced, still on good terms with his exwife, still seeing his son at frequent intervals, but faced with the possibility of losing both.

He or she may be happy to put a small class together, and the instructor who's assigned to it will be rapturous. You need a mountain with a vertical drop of at least 2,000 feet, or some unusually expansive and challenging terrain to compensate for lesser height.

title: ART VIEW
description: Oh, look, here are some paintings by artists who are still alive! Such was the astonished and unmistakably happy exclamation overheard by this writer the other day when he wandered into the galleries of 20thcentury art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. One could readily appreciate the astonishment of the visitorwho made this remark. The Met, after all, despite its periodic exertions in this realm, is still not a museum we normally go to in order to see the work of living artists or even the work of artists recently deceased. We go there to see the work of the unquestioned masters of former times and distant places. Elsewhere on the New York museum scene, and in more commercial galleries than anyone can quite keep track of, we are regularly treated to the richest display of 20thcentury art to be seen anywhere in the world. The special mission of the Metropolitan has traditionally been seen as necessarily keeping a certain distance from this hurlyburly where reputations remain unsettled and values still in flux.

title: South Africa Still Holds The Vital Purse Strings

South Africa is also Zambia's premier trading partner. And Botswana's President, Sir Seretse Khama, has observed that no one can expect his country to commit suicide in any antiapartheid campaign.
