title: A Word for, and from, the Matchmaker
description: A word, on this Sunday morning of hope in Jerusalem, for the true broker of the SadatBegin encounter. For all we know, Henry Kissinger was as surprised as the rest us by the overture from the Egyptian President that produced his sudden visit to the Israeli Prime Minister. No matter. The former Secretary of State recognized the irrepressible yearning for peace on both sides of the Suez Canal in the dark and frantic hours of the 1973 war. Daringly, to the extent possible, he maneuvered the battle itself so that each side would emerge with enough pride and incentive to move toward negotiation. He then demonstrated with his celebrated shuttle the opportunities for a series of deals. And generously, even out of office, he has lent his support and counsel to all parties to preserve the momentum.

My son and I were two or three miles back in the woods, skiing a trail that rolled and curved across a gentle Berkshire landscape. We crossed an unplowed road and came out in a high open meadow, slanting away to the north. Giving in to the temptation of that tilted expanse, we took several swooping runs down, our boots and light, skinny skis disappearing beneath the snow. Later we followed our own halffilled tracks back to the unplowed road. It was flat but we didn't push for speed or try for fancy form. A steady crosscountry rhythmkick and glide, kick and glidewas the right pace to enjoy the hush of the woods deep in winter.

title: Odyssey: Redefining. The Strength of Nations

title: Headliners
description: A Federal banking official, Donald L. Tarleton, who is being investigated for his role in covering up the banking practices of former budget director Bert Lance, has resigned his post. Mr. Tarleton was head of the regional office of the Comptroller of the Currency in Atlanta. That office had reached formal agreement last year with Mr. Lance's bank on monitoring an order for the bank to cease and desist from certain unsafe and, unsound banking practices. Mr. Tarleton unilaterally rescinded the potentially embarrassing agreement only hours before Mr. Lance was appointed budget director. Mr. Tarleton testified that his action was based on the bank's reformed practices, but other evidence indicated he and Mr. Lance had discussed lifting the agreement for political reasons. Justice Department officials say they will decide on future action against both Mr. Lance and Mr. Tarleton by the end of the month.

Police Offers entered his apartment at 11540 166 Street after a woman on the sidewalk outside had complained that he had taken from her a wallet and taken it up to his apartment, the police reported. title: Where New Playwrights Try Their Wings

title: Mr. Carter Is Now Challenging That Impregnability, but He, Like His Predecessors, Will Walk Cautiously
description: WASHINGTONNow that the Central Intelligence Agency is conducting selected public tours, probably no Washington institution is so impregnable, so wrapped in mystery and mystique and, some would say, so anachronistic in its operations as the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that lordly body of generals and admirals that operate from a protected sanctuary within the Pentagon. From its woodpaneled meeting room, known as the tank, it issues top secret recommendations on the defense budget and force structures. In its National Military Command Center, it can, with the touch of a button, talk to a military commander anywhere in the world. It operates like a separate world within the Pentagon. When he was assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, Joseph Laitin used to lament that even though he presumably was the representative of the Secretary Defense, he could never find out what was going on.

title: Talk With Stephen Jay Gould
description: NABOKOV studied butterflies here. Marianne Moore visited the famous glass (lowers; then wrote a poem. And so, when Stephen Jay Gould looks happily around his vast, cluttered office ill the 1859 wing of Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology, he has good local precedents for say. ing, Science is always culturally embedded. Gould has a right to his metanhor. He is a naleontoloeist trained to study fossils, remnants of life embedded in stone. And metaphor is no frill in the speech al this articulate, young (36) professor of geology. His mind works that way, sees connections between, say, the lingo of Darwinian evolution and the plastic cups the airlines use for coffee.

title: Equity for Wives
description: Women of every social class are learning that the marriage contract is no guarantee of lifelong security. Laws that make the husband responsible for support tend to benefit, not wives, but creditors. A wife can't use these laws to compel a husband to support her. She can only sue for separation or divorce. And despite cries of rage from exhusbands, only 14 percent are or dered to pay alimony and 44 percent directed to pay child support, and less than half of them remit payments regularly. So the fulltime homemaker risks all on her marriage, which makes her the most vulnerable of all women; she is only one man from welfare.

title: Labor Dept. Sets Up Frauds Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI)The Labor Department announced today that it had set up a new division to investigate suspect claims for workers compensation claims in the Federal Employees Compensations Program, the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers Compensation Program and the Black Lung Benefits Program. Repartment officials said the unit would investigate whether any persons receiving disability compensation are employed and have not notified the Department of Labor of their employment.

title: G.&
description: The Bohack Corporation has alleged that Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman of Gulf and Western Industries Inc., falsely testified under oath on four separate occasions during a 1973 deposition, and that Mr. Bluhdorn directed Bohaek's former president to give similar false testimony.

title: Sale of Mansion a Symbol of Decline of G.O.P. in Suffolk
description: BLUE PQINT, L.I.The mansion that has housed the Republican Party of Suffolk County for the last 20 years is for sale, and in many ways the decision to sell it symbolizes the mixed fortunes of the party since its decline from a position of complete dominance in the county.

title: Family at Pyramids Feasts and Then Watches Speeches
description: NAZLET ElSIMAN, Egypt, Nov. 20In this once rural village in the shadow of the pyramids, at the edge of the desert on the western outskirts of Cairo, it was a day, as in the rest of Egypt, to celebrate the Feast of the Sacrifice, to remember deceased relatives and to listen to President Anwar elSadat deliver his dramatic speech to the Israeli Parliament.

title: Brewers Hire Dalton
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20 (AP)The Milwaukee Brewers, after a weekend purge in which their general manager resigned and their field manager and player development chief were dismissed, confirmed tonight that they have hired Harry I. Dalton of the California Angels as general manager.

title: Rioting Mars an Election in Taiwan
description: CHUNGLI, Taiwan, Nov. 20Local elections were marred last night in this northern Taiwanese city by rioters who set fire to six police cars and army trucks and burned down a fire station. It was believed to have been the first instance of mass violence in Taiwan in 20 years.

title: Cities and People in Distress
description: Senator Moynihan once observed that the day city planners became known as urbanists was the day they realized that everything is connected to everything else. In Washington, this realization, of how interconnected the problems of cities are, has flagged sadly in recent years. But now there is welcome news. The Carter Administration is well on the way to developing what may be the Federal Government's first coherent policy for addressing the urban problem.

title: Sign Appears That Soviet Supply of Oil Is Tightening

title: Stabler Hurt in Loss
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 20 (AP)With Ken Stabler on the sidelines after the first quarter because of a knee injury, the Oakland Raiders could not generate an offense today, and they lost to the San Diego Chargers, 127. With the defeat, Oakland dropped out of a tie with Denver for the lead in the American Football Conference's Western Division. Stabler, the latest of a number of di'sabled quarterbacks, twisted a knee when hit by Louie Kelcher and was replaced by Mike Rae, who completed only one of six passes, for 16 yards. It was not known whether Stabler would miss any further games. Cliff Olander, a rookie, handled the quarterbacking for San Diego, with James Harris and Bill Munson injured.

title: Books of The Times
description: Michael Harrington tells his jotirnal (and us): I am tired of my conscience. It is a wheedling, jesuitical conscience; a sloppy, sentimental, pathetic conscience; it is a hypocritical conscience. I am tired of it, or, rather, of all of them. And perhaps that is a psychological secret of why we Northerners can be as callous as we are. We can't really contemplate these things, or else we would be driven to some wild kind of holiness, or else we would go crazy  I don't want to be a saint. title: 'Iphigenia' Too Unspartan as a Film
description: Because Euripides (480-406 B.C.) was Greek and Michael Cacoyannis (1922- ) is Greek, there is a tendency to applaud Mr. Cacoyannis's thoroughly ponderous attempts to make the ancient Euripidean tragedies comprehensible to contemporary movie audiences. We are asked to believe that the playwright and the film maker share some sort of deep cultural bond, as if they'd been in the same class at Athens High. Good old Mike and Rip  the Mutt and Jeff of the Acropolis.The bond may well be there, but it isn't apparent in the films Mr. Cacoyannis has made to date  "Electra" (1962), "The Trojan Women" (1971), which was a big-budget production with an international cast that spoke various kinds of English, and now "Iphigenia," a Greek-language version of the last Euripides tragedy, "Iphigenia in Aulis."Like "The Trojan Women," "Iphigenia in Aulis" is a bitter reflection on the war that Athens had been waging against Sparta since 431 B.C., and that Athens would lose in 404 B.C. with the complete destruction of her defenses. When it was written in 407 B.C., "Iphigenia" was a topical play in which the playwright substituted Troy for Sparta. Even though Euripides was then in exile, he wasn't foolish enough to believe that such an attack on state policy would get very far if staged frontally."Iphigenia" is not a conventional tragedy. There are no easily recognized heroes in the way Euripides dramatized the story of the Trojan War. As Euripides tells it, Agamemnon, the leader of the Greek forces waiting to sail against Troy, agrees to sacrifice his eldest daughter, Iphigenia, to please the gods and insure victory. To this end, he has Iphigenia come to the camp in Aulis on the pretext that she's going to marry Achilles. Instead, she is to die, a bit of flimflammery that outrages Clytemnestra, not because she cares about her daughter that much but because she fears how much she will suffer the loss of a daughter.There's not a truly noble person in the entire play, not even the doomed Iphigenia who, though she goes bravely to her death, goes as a deluded child for all the wrong reasons.Euripides's method in "Iphigenia" is oblique  nobody ever means everything that is said. This undercurrent of furious irony is something that is completely lost in Mr. Cacoyannis's "Iphigenia," whose characters have been so simplified as to become tragic stereotypes. It's not that the text has been tampered with but the manner in which it's played and set.Irene Papas, with her magnificent profile intact and her eyebrows in full bloom, plays Clytemnestra as if she were Mother Earth and not the complicated, selfish, conniving bitch she should be. Miss Papas's Clytemnestra asks for sympathy, as does the Agamemnon of Costa Kazakos, though he also manages to convince us of the contradictory desires that have been his undoing. Iphigenia is played by Tatiana Papamoskou, a tall, skinny, doe-eyed 12-year-old who looks as if she might grow up to be a terrific Dior model, which has nothing to do with ancient Greece or Euripides.In "Iphigenia," as in "The Trojan Women," Mr. Cacoyannis employs all sorts of comparatively snappy film techniquesthe handheld camera, the zoom lens, and the subjective camera by which we look out through the eyes of the characterto make us believe that we are there. It never works and can't work. We're not meant to get inside these characters, but to stand aside and observe the spectacle as a single, headlong ritual.Mr. Cacoyannis's fondness for photographing these densely packed, poetic melodramas in scenic, real-life landscapes distracts from the text and demolishes the actors, whose grandly theatrical mannerisms look silly in sets as big as all outdoors. People in the movie tend to run in a half-crouch, the way a stage actor runs when he wants to indicate a sprint even though he's covering no more than 10 feet of stage space.The film is not without its own paradox: The best thing in it is all wrong. This is a pre-credit sequence in which we are shown the state and condition of the Greek forces in Aulis as they await orders to sail to Troy. We see their boredom as they lie about the beaches, their ships idle, their rations low, their anger accumulating. The sequence has a lazy, eerie kind of beauty, but it should be the preface for a big, overblown historical pageant like "The Fall of the Roman Empire," not "Iphigenia," which has no need of anything more than its action and the extraordinary text.

description: In the first telecast by satellite of a complete opera from Europe, Metromedia Television will present on New Year's Eve a new production of Johann Strauss's Die Flederrnaus by the Royal Opera at Covent Garden in London. Metromedia owns WNEWTV, Channel 5, in New York, and stations in Los Angeles, Washington, Minneapolis, Kansas City and Cincinnati.

title: Ballet: Dancers Puts On AllNorman Walker Bill
description: Although the new ballet company Dancers, now giving its first full New York season at the Roundabout Theater, does not have a principal choreographer, Norman Walker comes closest to filling that bill. Of the 36 works listed in the repertory, representing 22 choreographers, Mr. Walker was responsible for seven of them. Some are revivals, a few have been specially created for the Dancers company.

Billy's Beer Is Banned in Virginia
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20 (Uk)Billy Carter's new brand of beer has been banned in Virginia under a state regulation that prohibits the sale of alcoholic beverages bearing the endorsement of any wellknown living person on the label.

Koch Advisers Say First Deputy Will Lose Power in New System
description: The first deputy mayorthe second most powerful official in city govenment under Mayor John V. Lindsay and Mayor Beamewill be reducedin authority to one among equals under Edward Koch, advisers1 to the Mayorelect said Yesterday.

description: Richard A. Tompkins, who covered education news and was a generalassignment reporter for The New York Times and later served in London for The Associated Press, died Friday at Flushing Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens, but had been confined to nursing homes for several years.

title: if New York City Is Lagging on School Integration Now, What About the Future?
description: If the dream of racially integrated public schools is slipping away now in much of New York City, what will have become of it five years from now, or ten years?

title: Graham Takes Australian Open
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20 (AP)David Graham of Australia shot a 71 to win the $200,000 Australian open golf tournament today by three strokes after a tense struggle with Don January.

title: Heckling of Begin Surprises Sadat
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt looked startled today by shouted interruptions from the floor during Prime Minister Menahem Begin's reply to his address in Parliament.

description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20 (Reuters)Following is a transcript of the address by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to the Israeli Parliament today. The simultaneous interpretation from the Arabic was done by a parliamentary internreter.

title: DEWEY D. STONE, AIDED IN JEWISH IMMIGRATION
description: BROCKTON, Mass.. Nov. 20 (AP)A funeral will be held Tuesday for Dewey D. Stone, a businessman who helped organize the illegal immigration of Jews to Palestine after World War II. Mr. Stone, who was 77 years old, died yesterday.

title: Iran Emerging as Major Alternative In Eastern Europe's Search for Oil
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Nov. 19Iran has begun to emerge as a potential major supplier of oil and gas to Eastern Europe.

title: Doctors for Military Are in Short Supply Since Draft Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)Since the draft ended in 1972, relieving the pressure on medical students to enlist, the military has been short of doctors, and a spokesman says the situation may get worse.

title: Shah's Visit Underscored Large Number of Iranian Students in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20  Dissident Iranian students were highly visible and audible here last week, but their noisy, occasionally violent demonstrations outside the White House did little to tell who they were or wnat they wanted, save that they opposed the visiting Shah of Iran.

title: The Holiday Abroad
description: PARIS

title: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr. TAKING THE BUGS OUT: Gloria Gaynor sat on top as Mrs. Claus climbed aboard Macy's Doodlebug in Central Park for trial run yesterday before annual Thanksgiving Day Parade. Santa's elves and clowns gave assistance:
Andrea L. Harnett Bride of Walter Fisherow
description: Andrea Lois Harnett, an assistant United States attorney for the District of Columbia, was married yesterday in New York City to Walter Benjamin Fisherow, a staff lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington. The ceremony was performed at Hampshire House by Rabbi Carl Wolkin of Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Pumpkin: Memories. Are Made of This
description: John Greenleaf Whittier's hymnic invocation to that unlikely vegetable, the pumpkin, both confirmed and anticipated its role in American folklore. The ancient Chinese had honored it as a token of lontgeVity, but it gradually has come to be a specifically American symbol. Whether or not the Pilgrims actually dined on pumpkin pie that first Thanksgiving Day is problematic, and its earliest American reviews were inauspicious.

title: Herzog Calls Speeches Badly Translated
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20Chaim Herzog, the chief Israeli delegate here, said today that the shortcomings of inexpert translation, as carried by the television networks, eliminated or distorted significant points in the speech of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel to Parliament,

title: Shortening the Distance
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20Prime Minister Menahem Begin declared emotionally today that the distance between Cairo and Jerusalem is short, but until President Anwar elSadat arrived here, that dis Lance was almost infinite. Although the two leaders have now met face to face, it is clear that the political distance separating them remains enormous.

title: Cyclone Death Toll at 670 in India
description: HYDERABAD, India, Nov. 20 (Reuters) At least 670 people died in a cyclone that swept the coast of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh yesterday, it was announced tonight.

title: Texas Wins Claim On Gold and Silver From Sunken Ships
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 19The state's claims to gold, silver and artifacts from galleons wrecked off Padre Island 423 years ago have been upheld in Federal District Court here.

title: Assocleled Preis Israeli soldiers ringing arches surrounding Jerusalems Al Aksa Mosque, beyond, as part of heavy security measuras
Physical Therapists
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)The American Physical Therapy Association announced today that it has lifted its ban against physical therapists advertising their services.

title: Louise Langdon, 70, Director Of Publicity for Bloomingdale's
description: Louise Langdon, who had been successively advertising director of Bonwit Tel, ler and Bergdorf Goodman and director of publicity of Bloomingdale's died Saturday in a nursing home in Green Brook, N. J., where she lived on Greenway Lane. She was 70 years old and the wife of Charles Langdon, a former mayor of Green Brook.

title: Is This Csonka's Last Season?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20As they walked off the field at Giants Stadium today, players from each team drifted together in twos or threes. Some had been teammates in college or with anothm National Football League team and now, after the Cleveland Browns 217 victory over the Giants, they were socializing in the moments before their locker rooms would separate them again. In the procession Larry Csonka was talking to Paul Warfield, Once they had been together on the Miami Dolphins two Super Bowl championship teams and they, along with Jim Kiick, had gone to thelate World Football League in a $3 million deal. But now Larry Csonka is the Giants fullback, although he's more of a blocking back. Only four carries today for 4 yards. And now Paul Warfield is a Browns wide receiver, still as sleek as ever, if not quite as swift. Two receptions today for 33 yards, including an 18yard touchdown with a leaping catch in the end zone. Their numbers are the same as they were with the Dolphins39 and 42, respectively. But their bodies aren't.

title: Network W ill Cover The Return of Sadat
description: NBC will expand its weekday Today show to provide coverage of the return to Cairo from Israel this morning by President Anwar elSadat of Eavnt.

title: Toll  Is Placed at 130 In Crash of Jetliner At Madeira Airport
description: FUNCHAL, Madeira, Nov. 20 (Reuters) The death toll in the crash of a TAP Portuguese airliner last night was 130, rescue workers said today.

title: CONCORDE PROTEST ATTRACTS 250 CARS
description: Turnout Is Small at Demonstration to Slow Kennedy Airport Traffic

title: Volunteers Bridging a Fiscal Gap For Dumont Mental Health Center
description: DUMONTVolunteers are conducting holding action at the Community Center for Mental Health in this Bergen County Community to assure the continuance of its successful program despite financial cutbacks.

title: 5Set Victory And $100,000 For Connors
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 20Playing. for a $100,000 prize, Jimmy Cnnors. and Roscoe Tanner battled more than. three hours before Connors won a fifth set tiebreaker for the victory today in the Challenge Cup final, 62, 56, 36,. 62, 65.

title: Biko Inquest Appears Unlikely to Fix Blame for His Death
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 20After the first week of the Stephen Bike inquest the chances of the court clearly assigning responsibility for the b'ack leader's death appear to be slim despite the success of counsel for the Biko family in demonstrating major discrepancies in the police testimony.

title: Leonard Silk
description: What the Dollar Will Buy  Vs. What It Will Bring

title: 5,000 CONVICTS ARE JAILED IN FEDERAL CRIME PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)Nearly 5,000 convicted criminals have been jailed for an average of 14 years as a result of federally financed programs to crack down on career criminals, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration said today.

title: Sadat in Jerusalem,Day of Challenges
description: JERUSALEM, Nov, 20  Moving through a day in Jerusalem of physical, emotional and intellectual challenges, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt maintained an appearance of iron stolidity, but his face occasionally registered feeling.

title: Giants Open Offense, Still Lose to Browns
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20The Giants opened up their offense today and passed for three touchdowns. But one was called back because of a holding penalty, another was scored by Gerald Irons, a Cleveland linebacker, and the one scored by Emery Moorehead was not enough in a 217 loss to the Browns.

title: ExAnalyst Says C.I.A. in Saigon Gave False Reports to Newsmen
description: Frank Snepp, the former analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency in Saigon, said last night that the C.I.A. and the United States Embassy there had deliberately provided American newsmen with false information about a possible brood bath in Saigon in the closing days of the Vietnam War.

title: Payton Breaks Record, Scoring and Statistics in N.F.L. Yesterday
description: Having suffered all week from influenza, Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears said, he felt weak and had hot and cold flashes before a game against the Minnesota Vikings at Soldier Field in Chicago yesterday. I didn't think could put on a Walter Payton performance when I left the dressing room, he said.

title: Fed's Target for Money Growth May Camouflage an Easier Policy
description: The credit markets have moved quite decisively toward lower interest rates in November, largely on the conviction that the Federal Reserve has decided to pause for a while and not raise shortterm rates any more just yet.

title: Franco's Death Is Commemorated
description: MADRID, Nov. 20 (Reuters)Tens of thousands of Francoists gathered in a Madrid square today with bullettorn banners and Spanish flags to mark the second anniversary of the generalissimo's death.

title: Thanksgiving1977
description: Can't we have something different for Thanksgiving? Do we always have to have the same main course of turkey with dressing, cranberry sauce and sweet potatoes, creamed onions and green peas? And the holy trinity of dessertspumpkin, mince and apple pies? Must it always be the same old thing?

title: United Press International ROBERT KENNEDY REMEMBERED: Ethel Kennedy, wife of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, comforting her 8yearold daughter, Rory, at Mr. Kennedy's grave at Arlington National Cemetery yesterday. At left is her son, Doug, 11. The Senator would have been 52 years old yesterday.
Vance Starts Latin Trip, Stressing Nucle'ar Dangers
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance began athreeday trip to three South American countries here today with an agenda dominated by the desire of the United States to halt the spread of nuclear arms.

title: HUGHES TO ADDRESS LEGISLATURE TODAY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 20Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the New Jersey Supreme Court will make an unusual appearance before a joint session of the State Legislature tomorrow, adding a load of judicial woes to the burden of legislators already troubled by the state income tax, an auto mobile insurance crisis and teacher strikes.

title: Houston Voters Show Little Enthusiasm for Mayoral Runoff Election
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 20On a local radio talk show last week, a caller suggested putting the names of all the drunks at the downtown Salvation Army mission into a hat, pulling one out and naming him Mayor of Houston. Compared with the candidates for the job, said the caller, even a derelict would be an improvement.

title: Central Park Boathouse Rescued
description: The Central Park Boathouse, which was closed for the winter early this month for the first time in more than 20 years, will reopen at the end of the week thanks to the efforts of birdwatchers, poets, joggers, bicyclists and children with large appetities.

title: Ending the Feast: Cold Turkey
description: ALONG TIME AGO I wrote an article with wholly ser ous intent stating that there rre some main courses in this world worth cooking for the s'mple pleasure of dining on them secondtime around. Leftovers, to put it more bluntly.

title: 16 Hurt as Amtrak Train Derails After Hitting Truck in Colorado
description: DELHI, Colo., Nov. 20 (AP)Four engenes and six cars of an eastbound Amtrak passenger train derailed after the train struck a pickup truck near this southeastern Colorado farm town, officials said.

title: CARAMANLIS'S PARTY WINS GREEK ELECTION
description: ATHENS, Nov. 20Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis won a mandate to continue running the country in elections held today, but the majority that he received three years ago was sharply reduced.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Symbolic Attire
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 20The politics of dressing at the historic National Women's Conference seems to boil down to this: You are what you wear.

title: In Jerusalem, Most Feel Gains Hinge on Private Meetings
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20A majority of the politicians, analysts and other Israelis interviewed here today after the speeches of President Anwur elSadat of Egypt and Prime MinisterMenahem Begin said that those who had expected a major breakthrough in the Middle East impasse to come in the speeches were unrealistic.

title: Network of Airport Bomb Dog
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)On March 9, 1972. a Trans World Airlines jet left Kennedy International Airport in New York for Los Angeles. Minutes later the airline received an anonymous phone call warning that a bomb was aboard.

title: Music: The National Symphony
description: it was all arranged, no doubt, by Isaac Stern. Thruogh some sore of secret diplomacy, the eminent violinist, who is chairman of the board of the AmericaIsrael Cultural Foundation, managed to have the organization's annual gala concert take place on the day that Egypt's president Anwar elSadat went to Jerusalem. It was also arranged that Mstislav Rostropovich should conduct his National Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, of which Mr. Stern is prsident, and that the violinist's longtime associates Eugene Istomin and Leonard Rose should join them for Beethoven's Triple Concerot.

title: CARBORUNDUM DEAL CREATED SUSPENSE
description: The secret bidding war for the Carborasidum Company, in which the Kennecott Copper Corporation finally won the support of Carborundum's management, appears to have been a cliffhanger for bath sides, with no one certain who would prevail until the final hour.

title: Most.New Yorkers Feel Buoyant After Watching Televised Session
description: Hope for peace in the Middle East swept ethnically diverse New York yesterday after thousands of residents of different religions watched the televised addresses of President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menahem Begin.

title: Father of Bride Is Killed by Car While Loading Gifts at Reception
description: YONKERS, Nov. 20 (AP)  A 50year old Mount Kisco man was killed early today when he was struck by a car as he loaded gifts from his daughter's wedding into the trunk of his car outside the Lincoin Park Jewish Center.

description: Better Ways

description: The Rangers, playing very poorly, were beaten by the Vancouver Canucks at the Garden, 30. Jere Gillis scored twice for the visitors. Page 56.

title: The Music of Renaissance Italy
description: The Waverly Consort lays claim these days to being this country's leading oldmusic ensemble. That may or may not be true, but it is probably the most ambitious, and its opening concert its 197778 subscription season at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night was amply attended and most attractive.

title: Amin Becoming SecurityConacious
description: KAMPALA, Uganda (UPI)Idi Amin, who has survived at least 13 assassination and coup attempts, until recent months scorned bodyguards for the most part. But now he has severely curtailed his highly visible visits to Kampala, spending more of his time in wellguarded compounds around the capital.

description: bNet loss after $5,294,000 loss from cumulative effect of accounting change. For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stork Exchange, (a) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

description: The luncheon yesterday for 300 businessmen from topdrawer New York City concerns opened with a slide show filled with fiscal horror stories:

title: Democracy Lays an Egg
description: The American Film Institute has just polled 17,000 people to elect the ten greatest American movies and came up with strange results. It shows how gravely you can err when you submit art to democracy. The leading votegetter, for example, was Gone With the Wind, a leadenfooted, overblown romance, which was powerful stuff in 1939 but now seems merely endless whenever Clark Gable is not on screen.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Documents Show F.B.I. Harassed Puerto Rican Separatist Parties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Starting in 1960, the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted an 11year campaign in New York City and Puerto Rico to disrupt and demoralize political parties advocating Puerto Rican independence, according to documents made public by the bureau today.

title: ASPIN ASKS ARMY BENEFITS FOR A CONVICTED P.O.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he wants restoration of military benefits for a former Army officer who was courtmartialed after the Korean War.

title: A.M.A. Warns on Yeast Tablets
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UPI)  People should refrain from taking yeast tablets that contain selenium, the Journal of the American Medical Association reported in today's issue. An overdose of selenium can be harmful to people and can be fatal to animals, the article said. Yeast tablets containing selenium are sold as a cure for dandruff in health food stores, the Journal said.

title: East Germans Beginning Work On Older Section of Berlin Wall
description: WEST BERLIN, Nov. 21 (Reuters)East Germans began tearing down one of the oldest stretches of the Berlin wall today, apparently to replace it with 200 yards of freshlypainted white concrete slabs.

title: Adeline T. Muhlenberg, Pioneer Swimmer Who Fought for the OnePiece Bathing Suit
description: Adeline Trapp Muhlenberg, who was called Queen of Heligate in 1909 for being the first woman to swim that swirling East River channel, died in Brooklyn Methodist Hospital yesterday. She was 89 years old and lived at 386 Parkside Avenue. Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Nov. 13 reported incorrectly that the Modern Language Association had voted against meeting in states that have not ratified the equal rights amendment. The association has adopted a resolution regretting that Illinoiswhere the group will hold its annual convention next monthhas not approved the amendment, but it has not called for a boycott.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. SAY TREATY ON A.B.M. IS WORKING WELL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)Five years after signing a treaty restricting antiballistic missile systems, the United States and the Soviet Union reported today that the pact was operating effectively and needed no revision.

title: McDonald & Little Chosen by Simmons
description: The Simmons Company, Atlanta, having checked out over 60 ad agencies and visiting 28 of them, has selected McDonald & Little, a hometown shop, to handle advertising for its sleep products, which include Beautyrest mattressess.

title: Comment on Palestinians
description: After Prime Minister Begin suggested in his speech to the Israeli Parliament on Sunday that representatives of all of Israel's foes visit Jerusalem in turn for discussions, he was pressed In broadcast interviews for more explicit comment about the Palestinians.

title: Quake Strikes Northwest Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 21 (Reuters)An earthquake that struck northwestern Mexico last night apparently was centered under the Gulf of California, the Tacubays Seismological Institute said here today. The institute, which measured the quake at 5.5 points on the openended Richter scale, said there had been no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

title: AT LEAST 3,000 DEAD IN CYCLONE IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 21The death toll In a cyclone over the weekend in southeastern India rose to about 3,000 tonight, according to official reports from the scene, and some estimates of the number dead were considerably higher.

title: Plans Set In Event Nets Fold
description: The National Basketball Association has a 21team schedule ready to put into operation in the event that the New Jersey Nets fold.

title: I.M.F. DISCUSSING MEANS OF AIDING BRITISH ECONOMY
description: LONDON, Nov. 21A team from the International Monetary Fund began discussions with Government officials here today on ways to chart a more hopeful economis future for Britain.

title: Market Place
description: There is little question but that the big profits in the stock market these days arise out of takeover talk and action.

title: Le Duan of Vietnam Meets With Peking's Leader
description: PEKING, Nov. 21 (Reuters)Hua Kuofeng, the Chinese leader, met today with Le Dual), the Vietnamese Communist Party chief, for a round of discussions described by the Hsinhua press agency as cordial and friendly.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest power utility, asked the State Board of Public Utilities yesterday for rate increases totaling almost $395 million.

title: Carter Aides May Scrap Proposal For Standard Secrecy Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)President Carter's aides say that they probably scrap a proposal to develop a standard secrecy agreement that agencies could use to require employees to promise never to disclose classified information.

title: U.S Is Glad. Israel and Egypt Still Stress Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Carter Administration said today that it was encouraged that both, President Anwar elSadat and Prime Minister Menahem Begin had given priority in their remarks to an early reconvening of a Middle East peace conference in Geneva and to relying on American mediation efforts.

title: The U.N. Today
GOING OUT Guide
description: TWO FOR THE HOLIDAYS Two years ago when Barbara Cook broke attendance records at Reno Sweeney, the Greenwich Village club, John S. Wilson of The New York Times wrote, There is currently no other voice of such magnificence in popular music. A veteran of Broadway in such hits as The Music Man, She Loves Me and Candide, Miss Cook returns to the club tonight for two weeks, with shows at 9 P.M. and midnight (no Monday).

title: Israel's Time of Decision
description: JERUSALEMThe time has come for sharp transitionfrom rhetoric to diplomacy; from the public exchange of arguments to the private exchange of proposals; from the useless question, Whose fault is it? to the essential question, How do we find remedy?

title: Women End Parley With Plan for Rights
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21The National Women's Conference ended here today with a platform for national action to bring women's equality. The only point on a 25part prepared agenda that failed to win the approval of the 2,000 delegates was one that proposed a Cabinetlevel women's department.

title: Beyond Jerusalem
description: Where to now in the Middle East? To begin with, off camera. We must not expect a daily extravaganza of emotions or a weekly recurrence of diplomatic breakthroughs. Peace does not break out, like war; it is a process of accommodation. President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin understood as much when they agreed to disagree about the issues before them and to begin to negotiate directly. A world sympathetic to their warweary peoples will give them time to absorb the gestures they have exchanged. A helpful diplomacy by the United States would let them define the pace and shape of the negotiating process without presuming that Americans have a better understanding of their national, or individual, security,

title: EFFORTS ON RHODESIA ARE SAID TO INTENSIFY
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 21Despite the general expressions of pessimism that greeted Field Marshal Lord Carver, the British commissionerdesignate for Rhodesia, on his recently completed visit to southern Africa, efforts toward a Rhodesian settlement have accelerated.

title: Fire in Atlantic City That Killed Two Infants Is Ruled Accidental
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 (UPI)Fire authorities said today that a fire in an apartment that killed two infants and seriously injured a third young child was caused by an accident.

title: Jane White Sings on New Stage
description: In more than 30 years in the theater, Jane White had been called upon to sing only two or three times before she made her debut last year as a cabaret singer. Bobby Short, who has bee singing in cabarets for a long time himself, was so impressed with what he heard that, taking his first plunge as an impresario, he presented Miss White in her first concert appearance Sunday evening at Town Hall.

title: Transit Police Chief Says Agency Saved City $140 Million
description: The chief of the New York City Transit Police, Sanford D. Garelik, has reported that the first 27 months of reorganized operations saved the city an estimated $140 million in direct cash and increased productivity.

title: HispanicAmericans Live With Diversity of Cultures
description: New York City, historically the most powerful magnet for immigrants to this country, has over the last two decades been attracting a huge migration of HispanicAmericans. Contrary to the popular notion that they are a monolithic.people, these new immigrants are, bringing with them a wide diversity of cultures and customs.

title: Rhodesia's Oil Suppliers Assailed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21After months of deliberations, a committee of the Security Council issued an interim report today recommending legal action against oil companies whose subsidiaries in South Africa continued to defy United Nations sanctions by providing oil to Rhodesia.

title: As the Temperature in New York City Begins to Fall, Tenants' Complaints of a Lack of Heat Begin to Rise
description: As wintry weather nips around with an occasional sharp bite into the low 30's to remind of what's ahead, protests against too little heator no heat at allare beginning to rise among New York City's apartment dwellers.

title: Local Issues Delay Vote on Pact to End Dock Strike
description: Striking longshoremen reported yesterday that continuing delays in completing local port agreements would probably put off ratification votes on a new master agreement for a few more days.

title: Durable Goods Orders Up 5.4% in October, Chiefly Because of Gain in Defense Items
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)New factory orders for durable goods climbed 5.4 percent in October, the largest increase in eight months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Paving the Way for Accidents
description: Traffic safety groups are on a collision course with state highway officials over an issue that could affect virtually every motorist: the design standards to be required when highways (other than freeways) are rehabilitated or resurfaced with Federal aid. The safety groups fear that the proposals of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials could allow some weakening of highway safety features, thus adding to the carnage on the nation's roads. Their concerns are justified.

title: 33 Yale Students and 26 Strikers Arrested
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21Thirtythree students and 26 striking bluecollar workers were arrested today as they tried to block two trucks delivering oil to a Yale University power plant. They were carried or led in waves to police vans and detained for about two hours while being charged with disorderly conduct.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board has a legislative fight on its hands that it concedes it should have headed off. At issue is the board's controversial proposal to require oil and gas producers to use a uniform method of accounting for exploration and develpoment costs. Page 55.

title: Carol E. Kramer, Editor, Bride of David M. Alpern
description: The marriage of Carol E. Kramer, editor of the Now section of The New York Daily News, to David M. Alpern, a general editor at Newsweek magazine, took place yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: Hotel in New Hampshire Burns
description: CARROLL, N.H., Nov. 21 (AP)The Crawford House Hotel at the northern gateway to Crawford Notch in New Hampshire's White Mountains has burned to the ground. Fire officials said that the hotel, owned by the state civil defense director, George McAvoy, was razed yes by a fire that apparently started in the third floor of the unoccupied and closed fourstory woodframe building.

title: Vernon Jordan And the Issues Vital to Blacks
description: When the National Urban League Equal Opportunity Day Dinner was convened at the New York Hilton the other night, Dr. Charles D. Cobb delivered an invocation in which, among other things, he invoked divine protection for the league's president, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., from William F. Buckley Jr. Urban Even the most devout in the gatherling lifted their eyes and exchanged knowing nods and smiles with their dinner companions. Mr. Buckley just a few days before had written a column asking who Mr. Jordan led and spoke for. After indicating that he believed the league official to be the preeminent black spokesman, Mr. Buckley went on to list the kinds of issues Mr. Jordan has been addressing lately: jobs, poverty, housing, health and welfare.

title: Spanish Communist Takes Tolerant View of Washington's Coolness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21  Santlago Carrillo, leader of Spain's Communist Party, was considerably more tolerant today of the Carter Administration over the absence of an official American welcome than he was of the Soviet Government earlier this month for what he says was its refusal to let him speak at the 60th anniversary in Moscow of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
Empire State Changes Lights
description: The banks of lights on the 72d, 82d and top floors of the Empire State Building have been changed from white to amber, to marke the arrival of the Thanksgiving season. But a spokesman for the building management said last night that, in about 10 days, they would be changed back white. Shortly thereafter the colors will be changed to green and white to symbolyze the Christmas observance.

title: Ringer Horse Is Traced to Saratoga
description: The mystery horse in the Belmont Park ringer case spent time at Saratogar last summer under an apparent alias investigators have learned.

title: 1979 Olympics for the Retarded To Be at State U. at Brockport
description: Governor Carey alternated in kicking and tossing a soccer ball to six boys and girls wearing Special Olympics Tshirts at a news conference yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel.

title: ANTONE GERHARDT SINGSEN, BLUE CROSS EXECUTIVE, 62
description: Antone Gerhardt Singsen, who was senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York until he went on leave last June, died Saturday in White Plains Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived at 2 Brayton Road. Scarsdale.

title: Men at the Women's Conference: Few in Number, but Hard to Miss
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21Yes, there were men at the National Women's Conference, which ended here today. They were small in number, but they made their presence felt, as delegates, commissioners and behindthescenes officials.

title: Relics of Maccabees Among Sadat's Gifts
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 (AP)Gifts presented to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today included nine candlesticks from the time of the Maccabees uprising against Greek rule of Palestine in the second century B.C. and ancient pottery from the time of Abraham, considered the forefather of Jews and Arabs.

title: Music: Rebroff, Bass at the Bijou
description: Ivan Rebroff, Who began a one week, run at the Bijou Theater last night, is still being billed as the possessor of the richest, darkest, highest, lowest bass in the world.

title: Chief Justice Hughes Asks Raise Of $12,500 for Judges in the State
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21Richard J. Hughes, the Chief Justice of New Jersey, told a joint session of the State Legislature today that it must increase judicial salaries substantially in this session or invite deterioration of the state's court system.

title: Getty Museum Bronze Sets Record
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has bought a bronze sculpture of a Greek athlete dating from the fourth century B.C. at a price thought to be the highest ever paid for a work of sculpturebetween $3.5 million and $5 million.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: FactoryExplosion Suit

title: Notes on People
description: France's most coveted literary award, the Prix Goncourt, was presented yesterday to Didier Decoin, the 32yearold author of John L'Enfer, or John in Hell, a novel that deals with the collapse of civilization in a futuristic New York. The Goncourt's prize money is modest, but since it is the most prestigious French literary award, its recipient is practically issued handsome sales of the work that captured the prize. John in Hell is Mr. Decoin's 10th novel since he began writing at the age of 20.

title: West German Chancellor Arrives in Poland
description: WARSAW, Nov. 21 (Reuters) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany arrived here today for a fiveday official visit, during which he will confer with Edward Gierek, the Polish leader.

title: Italian Survey Finds Rise In the Literacy Rate
description: ROME, Nov. 21More than 10.5 million Italians, or onefifth of the population, are illiterate or semiliterate, according to statistics recently released by the Ministry of Education.

title: Books of The Times
description: DELMORE SCHWARTZ. The Life of an American Poet. By James Atlas. 417 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Strauss & Giroux. $15.

title: Business Records
description: Monday, Nov. 21, 1977

title: U.S. WARNS JAPAN AGAINST CONTINUING BIG TRADE SURPLUS
description: Tokyo, Nov. 21American officials have warned the Japanese Government that its continuing substantial trade surpluses with the United States as well as other nations, seriously threaten relations between Washington and Tokyo.

title: Survivors of Madeira Air Crash Say Plane Overshot the Airport
description: FUNCHAL, Madeira, Nov. 21 (AP)Survivors of a crash that killed 130 of 164 persons aboard a Portuguese airliner say the pilot apparently realized that he had landed too far down the runway and tried to take off, but the plane plunged 200 feet down an embankment and burst into flames.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21Governor Byrne received a minutelong standing ovation from the Legislature today when he entered the Assembly chamber shortly before Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Transcripts of the News Conference and Communique
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 (AP)Following are transcripts of the news conference of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, closing statements by the two leaders and an agreedupon communique read by the Israeli Prime Minister.

title: About New York
description: We have lost in the mist of centuries the folk events underlying such invitingly titled Scottish dances as The Sow's Tail, The Rock and the Wee Pickle Tow and Old Jim's Lumber Room. It is imperative, then, to set down the truelife tale of the newest Scottish country dance, MacDougall's Fancy.

title: Article 2  No Title
STRAY RADIO SIGNALS POSTPONE LAUNCHING
description: Something strange happened at Cape Canaveral, Fla., last Wednesday. A rocket standing on its launching pad picked up song stray radio signals, source and frequency unknown, and this has now caused the indefinite postponement of plans to launch a West European weather satellite.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: In good part because of its admitted political naivete, the Financial Accounting Standards Board finds itself in a fight to maintain its unquestioned position as the private sector's top authority on accounting rules.

title: New Vaccine Approved by F.D.A. For a Potentially Fatal Pneumonia
description: A new vaccine to protect against a common, potentially fatal type of pneumonia was approved yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration. It is intended primarily for use among older people and those with chronic illnesses.

title: A Busy Volcano Has Unsettled Japanese City
description: TOYAKO ONSEN, Japan  In this city, the pictures on the walls hang crooked. Every few minutes all conversations halt while residents look up at their ceilings and the buildings shake.

title: London Newspaper, in Pay Dispute, Suspends Publication Indefinitely
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (Reuters)The management of The. Daily Mirror gave notice of dismissal today to all journalists on its London editions and ceased publication in the capital indefinitely.

title: HUEY NEWTON DENIES MURDER AND ASSAULT
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 21Huey P. Newton seemed to be conveying the image of the new Black Panther Party today when he came to court to plead not guilty to charges of murder and assault.

title: Tony Kornheiser
description: Every so often he sees her at the gym on East 64th Street. He works on his left leg, where the heel bone was shaved and tendinitis set in like an unwanted house guest. She works on her right leg, on the rebuilt knee with its zipper scars. They exchange smiles, watching each other straining to lift the weights, trying to get that old feeling again. They even use the same expression to describe the effort. They call it, gutsing it out.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Sets High of 33.3 Million Shares in Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 245,391 shares in the month ended Nov. 15 to 33,322,411 shares, a new high. The short interest for the year earlier level totaled 24,777,197 shares.

title: Women End Parley With Plan for Rights
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21The National Women's Conference ended here today with a platform for national action to bring women's equality. The only point on a 25part prepared agenda that failed to win the approval of the 2,000 delegates was one that proposed a Cabinetlevel women's department.

title: Gold Price Declines In Europe as Dollar Hits a Low in Japan
description: The price of gold tumbled in Europe yesterday while the dollar closed lower against most major European currencies and hit a new low against the Japanese yen, The Associated Press reported.

title: Some Arabs Fear Sadat Has Provoked New Rifts
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21As angry, officially inspired comments continue to fill the air, concern is rising among Arab political and diplomatic sources here that President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel may have provoked the beginnings of another sharp division in the Arab camp that could unsettle the search for an overall Middle East peace settlement.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Rate Up to Pay for Nuclear Plant
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 21 (AP)The Public service Company, New Hampshire's largest electric utility, told the Sage Public Utilities Commission today that it would begin charging higher rates on Dec. 3 to help finance the Seabrook nuclear power plant. The utility filed for the 17 percent rate rise in April, By law, it can begin charging customers at the higher rate if the commission fails to make a decision within six months. Public Service estimates the now rate will add almost $4 a month to the average residential bill.

title: Delaware River Protection Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Department of the Interior has recommended that a 75mile section of the upper Delaware River in New York and Pennsylvania be included in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. A department report has proposed that the river, between Hancock, N.Y., and Matamoros, Pa., be managed by the National Park Service. Land protection for the adjacent area would be the responsibility of the governors of New York and Pennsylvania along with local governments and the Delaware River Basin Commission.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: State Checks New $1 Million Game
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ordered an investigation yesterday of a new milliondollar Las Vegas backgammon tournament said by its sponsors to be designed to avoid the legal and financial flaws that had killed a similar venture.

title: Dancers: James Dunne Sparkles
description: Since Dennis Wayne calls his new company Dancers and his slogan is Dancersthat's what we're about, it is only fair that cast changes assume. a large proportion of the interest, in this dance troupe.

title: New York Schools Are Offered $3 Million of Unneeded Supplies
description: Three million dollars' worth of balloons and bongo drums, castinets and coffee pots, turtle tanks and tuning forks that have been gathering dust in the Board of Education's Bureau of School Supplies warehouse in Long Island City have been offered to the city's public schools.

title: U.S. VOICES CONCERN ON FURTHER SLOWING OF WORLD ECONOMY
description: PARIS, Nov. 21The Carter Administration expressed its concern today at the danger of a further slowdown in the world economy next year, which would threaten internationally agreed upon plans for pulling the industrialized nations out of the doldrums.

title: SCHLESINGER EXPECTS ENERGY COMPROMISE WITH GAS PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21In his most conciliatory statement to date, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger suggested today that the Administration expects the energy legislation Congress is working on to contain higher prices for natural gas, more tax credits for businesses converting to coal and more revenues for the oil industry than were originally proposed.

title: Money
description: Monday, November 21, 1977

title: Game Warden Hunts Violent Quarry
description: ERROL, N.H.Like most men here in the big woods along the Canadian border, Warren Jenkins is out hunting all day and much of the night, now that the leaves are down and the first light dusting of snow is on the ground.

title: Not Much Of A Lobby
description: Federal Judge Morris E. Lasker recently ordered New York State to return 140 prisoners to a temporary release program from which they had been removed without a hearing. He was acting on a suit brought on behalf of all 140 by Prisoners Legal Services of New York.

title: Records of College Football Teams and the Schedules of Their Remaining Games
description: Nov 26Auburn. at Birmingham

title: Samoa Is Electing A Governor Today For the First Time
description: PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Nov. 21 (AP)Residents of this South Pacific territory take a major step toward selfdetermination tomorrow when they choose their first elected chief executive.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Refuses to Appear at Inquiry on Her Rule
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 21Former Prime Minister Indira Ganfhi today refused to appear before a judicial commission that is investigating her Government, maintaining that the inquiry is little more than a platform for malicious political propaganda against her.

title: SCHLESINGER EXPECTS ENERGY COMPROMISE WITH GAS PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21In his most conciliatory statement to date, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger suggested today that the Administration expects the energy legislation Congress is working on to contain higher prices for natural gas, more tax credits for businesses converting to coal and more revenues for the oil industry than were originally proposed.

title: Vance Wins Argentine Pledge on Nuclear Arms
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21Secretary of State. Cyrus R. Vance obtained a commitment from Argentina today to ratify the. Treaty of Tlatelolco, which bars the presence of nuclear weapons in Latin America.

title: The Sadat Trip: Psychology and Substance
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21All available evidence since President Anwar elSadat returned to Cairo today is that the results of his extraordinary journey to Israel came entirely in what he called the psychological 70 percent of the Middle East problem and not in the 30 percent that is substance.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: AT LEAST 3,000 DEAD IN CYCLONE IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 21The death toll in a cyclone over the weekend in southeastern India rose to about 3,000 tonight, according to official reports from the scene, and some estimates of the number dead were considerably higher.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Advertising
description: David Ogilvy, who admits that his Confessions of an Advertising Man was one of the best books ever written on advertising, has, at the request of his publisher, turned his hand to an autobiography.

title: Arthur Ebinger,88, Helped to Establish A Baking Company
description: Arthur D. Ebinger, former president of the Ebinger Baking Company, died last Thursday at the age of 88. He lived at 1 Prospect Place West in Brooklyn.

title: People and Business
description: In designing reforms to reduce or eliminate unjustified tax preferences, the Administration will take into account the importance of tax incentives for capital formation, both for corporations and for individuals, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal promised yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
Prices of Precious Metals Decline on Reports From the Middle East
description: The flow of dovish news from Jerusalem over the weekend eroded prices of precious metals yesterday on both sides of the Atlantic. Precious metals have long been a security blanket for those nervous about political, economic or social developments.

title: Begin, on the Spot
description: With his spectacular visit to Jerusalem last weekend, President Anwa?? elSadat of Egypt risked his personal and political life not only to achieve a breakthrough in the peace negotiations but, in a move that was as shrewd as it was bold, to put Prime Minister Menahem Begin's Government on the spot.

title: City Ballet Offers a Fine Bournonville Bill
description: One of the most curious aspects of the New York City Ballet is that one of the works that shows it off to best advantage is not by George Balanchine. Another almost equally curious aspect is that it is not by Jerome Robbins, either.

title: N.F.L. Playoff Picture Remains Blurred
description: After the Los Angeles Rams, a plodding team with a runoriented offense that wears opponents down, had defeated the San Francisco 49ers by 2310 on Sunday, Pat Haden said: We're definitely in the driver's seat now. We're going to be tough to beat. That was the Rams' seventh victory in 10 games, and it left them with a twogame lead in their division, Western of the National Conference, which offers little competition.

title: Sears Profit Rises 41%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported earnings for the quarter ended with October rose 41 percent on a sales gain of 19 percent. Most of the profit increase came from the Allstate insurance group. Page 53.

title: Cantilena Players Honor Rorern
description: The Cantilena Chamber Players, a group, of New York musicians formed in 1970, offered the first of three Helena Rubinstein Concerts Sunday afternoon at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: The Sadat Trip: Psychology and Substance
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21All available evidence since President Anwar elSadat returned to Cairo today is that the results of his extraordinary journey to Israel came entirely in what he Called the psychological 70 percent of the Middle East problem and not in the 30 percent that is substance.

title: Administration Fumbling And Business Uncertainty
description: One of the Carter Administration's major failings in its first year has been the inability to construct a welldefined economic game plan that it could convey clearly to everyone. The lack of coherence and consistency in economic strategies has created unnecessary confusion and strained relationships with various sectors of society, as well as provoking the erratic behavior of the financial markets throughout 1977.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article In The Times Nov. 13 reported Incorrectly that the Modern Language Association had voted against meeting in states that have not ratified the equal rights amendment. The association has adopted a resolution regretting that Illinoiswhere the group will hold its annual convention next monthhas not approved the amendment, but it has not called for a boycott.

title: Waldwick Rifleman, 17, Holds Off Police 5 Hours Before Giving Up
description: WALDWICK, Nov. 21A troubled 17yearold youthreportedly angry that his mother had taken his car keys from him sprayed a quiet suburban neighborhood here with .22caliber rifle fire today and held 30 police officers at bay before surrendering to a county police sergeant who talked facetoface with him for about an hour and 40 minutes.

title: AntiAbortion Activist Charged
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Criminal charges were filed in Boston Municipal Court today against a Lynn man accused of gluing an antiabortion banner to the golden dome of the Massachusetts Statehouse in August. William Baird, an advocats of choice in abortions, was among those who filed charges against the antiabortion activist, Charles Swain.

title: Citibank Is Planning to Commit $10 Million to Mortgage Program
description: Citibank said yesterday it planned to commit $10 million in a pilot program to provide moreliberal mortgage loans in three areas of Broklyn, which were described as neighborhoods whcih once were prideful examples of city living (that) now ar but a shell of what they were.

title: Columbia Hails a Boyhood Friend
description: The inscription read, To George Edward Jonas for a life of selfless dedication to others, but to the more than 2,000 boys whose lives he has touched, he will always be Freddie, although no one remembers for sure just how he got the nickname.

title: Stolen Police Pistol Wounds Bronx Girl
description: A 13yearold boy who ran errands and shined shoes at the 42d Precinct station in the East Bronx stole a sergeant's pistol from a locker room there Sunday, the police said, and the gun was later discovered by the boy's 14yearold brother. The brother picked it up and discharged it, wounding Their 17yearold sister in the arm, according to the police.

title: TV: Symbolic Event Is Highlighted by Sheer Drama of Pictures
description: The extraordinary event was largely symbolic, and therefore the function of television could clearly be seen in its most powerful aspects. President Anwar elSadat's historic trip to Israel apparently offered little in the way of concrete political resolutions, but it left the world with a new collection of unforgrettable images, most of them transmitted live to the tens of millions of people in 32 countries watching small screens in the giant community of the global village.

title: MORE TALKS PLEDGED
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ended his epic mission to Israel today by joining with Prime Minister Menahem Begin in repeated pledges of no more war.

title: Ten Days in November
description: There are times, like today, when events in Washington remind us of the story about the boy who bragged to his father that he saved 50 cents by walking home instead of taking the bus. But, the father replied, unimpressed, if you'd walked home instead of taking a cab, you would have saved $3.

title: Princeton Drops Casciola, Football Coach Five Years
description: Princeton University dismissed its head football coach yesterday, nine days after the conclusion of the Tigers' fifth straight nonwinning season under his direction.

title: Greek Vote Result Shows Trend Toward Polarization
description: ATHENS, Nov. 21Although the Greek voters gave Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis a majority in Parliament yesterday, the results of the election show a drift toward political polarization.

title: Head of Jersey Bar Association Urges Lawyers to Reduce Fees
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21 (AP)The president of the New Jersey State Bar Association has called on lawyers to reduce their fees before they price themselves out of business.

title: Bridge:
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 21Two New York experts, Kathie Wei and Judi Radin led into the final session of the life master women's pair championship at the American. Contract Bridge League's fall nationals here tonight.

title: ONE OFFICER PER CAR A SUCCESS, CODD SAYS
description: Oneofficer patrol cars are working out well in the seven New York City precincts where they began operations a week ago, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Benefits Rise for Miners' Disease
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)The 490,000 coal miners and their families who get payments because of black lung disease received A, 7.05 percent increase in benefits this month, the Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, James B. Cardwell, said today. The monthly payment to a coal miner disabled by the disease or to his widow is now $219.90, up from $205.40. The maximum to families with three or more dependents is $439.70, a $29 increase.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Court Affirms Robbery Conviction, But 3 of the Judges Assail Police
description: The conviction of a man who had been charged with shooting a policeman in an East Side restaurant nearly five years ago was upheld yesterday by the State Court of Appeals, but three of the seven judges sharply criticized the police and strongly suggested that the wrong man may have been arrested and convicted.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: CAREY HAILS SADAT TRIP AS EXERCISE IN PEACE
description: Governor Carey yesterday called the visit to Israel by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt the greatest exercise in my memory in bringing peace to the entire world. But he warned of the threat of increasing terrorism.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: In a major step in the restructuring of Champion International, Andrew C. Sigler, president and chief executive officer of the building and paper products company, announced yesterday plans for the completion of the company's disposition of its furnishing operations.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The fact that I pay dues to P.E.N. American Center, this country's branch of the International writers' organization, testifies to my regard for its efforts on behalf of writers' freedom. That is why its new Freedom to Write Global Report is especially irksome. P.E.N. lists 606 cases of repression in 55 countries. Among the Argentinians who have disappeared, the South Africans condemned to obscurity, the TinsMans committed to psychiatric institutions and the hundreds of other writers jailed, tortured and banned, the report carries the names of six Americans. What are they doing here?

title: 2 Aides Questioned In Rome Bank Case Are Seeking Leaves
description: ROME, Nov. 21 (AP)Two top officials of a major statecontrolled bank asked for leaves of absence today pending the outcome of an investigation into their possible role into the bankruptcy of financier Michele Sindona.

title: MAYOR HAS LIE TEST, THEN OUSTS ACCUSER
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21Mayor Michael E. Bilandic, embroiled in a running controversy over charges by an aide that be had conspired with taxi companies to get their fares increased, announced today that he had taken a polygraph, test, had passed it and had then discharged his accuser.

title: HORACE H. CLEVELAND
description: Horace H. Cleveland, long a civic leader in Queens, died Thursday in Interboro Hospital in Brooklyn. He had lived in the family home at 8719 164th Street in the Jamaica section of Queens for 88 of his 89 years.

title: Around the Nation
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Nov. 21 (AP)Negotiator for the Amalgamated Transit Union rejected today a new contract offer from Greyhound Lines but said that the union would make a new proposal shortly in an effort to prevent a nationwide strike during the Thanksgiving holidays.

title: New York's Tourist Boom Bringing $4.5 Billion a Year
description: Shows will be running in all 16 Shubert theaters in New York City this week and their marquees will remain lighted up at least into next year, the first time there has been such sustained prosperity on Broadway in more than 20 years.

title: Sears Profits Up 41% in Quarter, With Bulk of Gain in Allstate Unit
description: Seara, Roepuck & Company, the world's largest retailer of general merchandise, reported, yesterday a 41 percent jump in earnings for the quarter ended with October on a sales gain of 19 percent.

title: Spring Collections at a Leisurely Pace
description: The fashion action has moved from Seventh Avenue, where spring collections were unveiled earlier this month every hour on the hour, to the hotels on the Upper East Side, where the pace is far more leisurely.

title: Psychiatrist Terms Officer Insane At Time He Killed Brooklyn Youth
description: Robert Torsney, the police officer accused of killing a Brooklyn youth last Nov. 25, was described yesterday by a psychiatrist for the defense as having been legally insane at the time of the shooting.

title: Pope Receives Califano
description: ROME, Nov. 21 (AP)Pope Paul VI received Joseph A. Califano, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, in private audience today. Details of their discussion were not disclosed. Mr. Califano is here on an official visit as guest of his Italian counterpart, Luciano del Falco, to discuss cooperation In the field of health,

title: BIG BANKS PROPOSE A FREE TRADE ZONE TO HELP NEW YORK
description: A group of the nation's largest banks have drawn up a plan that would establish a free trade zone for banking in New York to strengthen the city's position as a world financial center.

title: Mutual Radio Applies to F.C.C. To Be First AllSatellite Network
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 21The Mutual Broadcasting System, the country's largest radio network, has asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to become the first network connected by satellite rather than land links, the company announced today.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: White Hospital Head Regains Job; Bias Charged on Ouster for Black
description: In what was described by state officials yesterday as the first successful case of its kind, a white, Jewish administrator at a city hospital was reinstated after allegedly having been dismissed because of his race and creed. He had been replaced by a black man, the State Division of Human Rights said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 21 (AP)Henry Rono of Kenya, a student at Washington State University, captured his second straight National Collegiate crosscountry championship today. Rono, among 253 runners, led all the way for a time of 28 minutes 33.5 seconds on the 10,000meter track at Hangman Valley Golf Course south of Spokane.

title: Cairo Crowds Cheer The Man of Peace
description: CAIRO, Nov. 21President Anwar elSadat was welcomed home from Israel tonight and acclaimed as the man of peace by tens of thousands of Egyptians standing shoulder to shoulder for most of the 20mile route from the airport to his home beside the Nile.

title: Policeman in Connecticut Slain By Gunman Fleeing After Breakin
description: PLAINVILLE, Conn., Nov. 21 (AP)A local policeman was fatally wounded today while chasing a burglary suspect through a wooded area near a house he allegedly had broken into.

title: Koch to Retain His Own Life Style Despite Burden and Duty as Mayor
description: Perhaps, Edward I. Koch said yesterday, he will let a neighbor, who has already volunteered fer the task, carry his shirts to the laundry when he is too busy being Mayor of the City of New York.

title: News Media Oppose Court Order to Ban CrossOwnerships
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) The Supreme Court is getting briefs from newspapers and broadcasters in opposition to an order threatening the breakup of 150 media combinations in 44 states.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1977

title: Senator Chases Pair To Aid Robbed Woman
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21 (AP)Senator Joseph R. Eiden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, spent part of his 35th birthday chasing two youths who had robbed a woman on a Wilmington street. Mr. Eiden did not catch the pair In the chase yesterday afternoon,, but he did recover Mary B. Barnett's nurse.

title: Arabs at U.N. Appear to Be Trying to Close Ranks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21Arab members of the United Nations, in political disarray over President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel, appeared today to be trying to close ranks as they sat down together for their first private group meeeting since the events in Jerusalem.

title: Suspect Killed, 3 Wounded in Shootout And Chase After a Bronx Bank Robbery
description: A bank robbery suspect was fatally wounded and two alleged accomplices were captured yesterday in a wild threemile automobile chase that reportedly began with a noontime shootout at a Bronx bank. The chase ended when a pursuing police car rammed the suspects' vehicle at a busy Bronx intersection.

title: John Byram, 76, Dies in Florida; Was Theater Critic and Producer
description: John Byram, who spent more than 30 years in the Broadway theater as a critic, property scout and producer, died Sunday in a Naples, Fla., hospital at the age of 76. He had been living in Naples since his retirement in 1958.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL FOOTWEAR USE OF FALSE DATA ADMITTED
description: The National Footwear Corporation of Epping, N.H., its president and its sales manager pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to using false affidavits in importing leather from Haiti in order to evade customs duties.

title: Deaths
description: Balchunas, Jean

title: YIELD ON U.S. NOTES ESTIMATED AT 7.15%
description: The Treasury's twoyear notes scheduled for sale this afternoon will likely yield about 7.15 percent, dealers estimated late yesterday as fixedincome securities drifted lower in price.

title: Last Groups of Russian Advisers Are Reported to Have Left Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 21 (AP)The last Soviet advisers are reported to have left Somalia, ending an eightyear period during which the country was the Soviet Union's closest ally in East Africa.

title: THOMAS B. SWANN
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP)Thomas B. Swann, a former chairman of the Florida Citrus Commission, died Saturday. He was 80 years old. He was appointed to the first citrus commission in 1935 and served for 17 years under seven governors.

title: Vocal Arts Ensemble Is a Delight
description: Vocal quartetscontrapuntal and/or harmonized pieces for four singers, with or without piano accompaniment, are generally thought of as 19thcentury German HausmusiR when they are thought of at all. But there is more to this music than superficial bourgeois pieties, as the New York Vocal Arts Ensemble proved in an absolutely delightful concert Sunday evening at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association.

title: HUTCHINS SUCCESSOR SELECTED BY CENTER
