A fire department spokesmansaid the case of the fire was not yet determined.

title: Lance Is Reported Holding Discussions On Repciying Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24A key factor in whether Bert Lance can avoid a Federal regulatory action that could keep him out of the banking business is whether he will repay two Georgia banks for certain uncollected loans and disallowed business expenses, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: RikersIsland No LessGrim 2 Years After Its Rebellion
description: Conditions on Rikers Island have changed little in the two years since inmates at the House of Detention for Men seized five guards and barricaded themselves for 17 hours.

title: Solar Light Overcomes Blackout
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP)When the switch was flipped to open a Federal display on energy problems, only one exhibit worked. There was no current .because of a generator blowout. But in the corner of a trailer housing the display, a light shone from one exhibit chugging along. It was powered by solar energy.

title: A Goulash of Folk Dancing
description: Dancing is more than just the hustle, Michael Herman believes. It is the bregovska, the hambo, the polka, the Boston twostep, the karapiet and many, many, more.

title: Farmers Prepare A Tractor Convoy For Rally in Plains
description: PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 24 (AP)Farmers say thousands of tractors will roll into President Carter's home town tomorrow, while cropdusters planes buzz overhead, to hold a rally to protest low farm prices.

title: Ranking Republican On Panel Criticizes Postal Service Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The ranking Republican on the House Post Office Committee has lashed out against the postal bill pending before the House, callling the measure an outlandish Rube Goldberg schematic.

title: Publishing: Once an Australian
description: THERE is nothing I want, Patrick White, the Australian novelist, said when he won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1973. Acting on his word, Mr. White (The Tree of Man, Voss, The Aunt's Story) used the money to set up an annual $10,000 award for an Australian writer.

title: Metal Workers in Peru Strike
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Peruvian metal industry workers went on strike today to press for the reinstatement of 600 workers who were dismissed following a general strike last July. A spokesman for the 10,000member Federation of Metalworkers would not predict the duration of the strike.

title: Classroom in California Is Silent All the Time, But Learning Goes On
description: CARLSBAD, Calif. (AP)The classroom at Magnolia Elementary school is silent. There are no measured tones of instruction, no pupils whispers. But learning goes on, the deaf teacher communicating easily with her seven deaf students.

title: Western Union Ordered to Pay For PregnancyRelated Disability
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company has been found guilty of discriminating against its female employees by refusing to provide disability benefits for pregnancyrelated disabilities.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 24Steve Lubar led a field of 570 runners to win the Port Washington fivemile road race today. Lubar, 24yearold manager of the Shore Tennis Club, finished in 24 minutes 44.9 seconds.

title: JAPANESE YEN SOARS TO NEW HIGH OF 240 AGAINST U.S DOLLAR
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24The yen rose sharply against the dollar to a new postwar high of 240 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today. Reflecting an overnight upward surge in overseas money markets, the Japanese currency began the day at 240 yen, a steep jump of 1.30 point from Tuesday's finish of 240.30. (The market was closed yesterday for a holiday.)

title: U.S.SOVIET TALKS SET ON ARMS SALE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The Soviet Union, after prodding by the Carter Administration, has agreed to begin formal talks here in midDecember on limiting Soviet and American sales of conventional arms, officials said today.

title: Police Chief Faces Suspension On Drug Charges in Florida
description: SOUTH BAY, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP)Offidials say the City Council will meet tomorrow to formally suspend the Police Chief, Willie D. Wrisper Jr., who was arrested Wednesday night on drug and prostitution charges.

title: BilingualEducation Program Stirs Controversy for New York Board
description: Three years after a courtmandated bilingual education program began in New York City's schools, the Board of Education, parents and leaders in the Hispanic community are embroiled in a controversy over what the program should entail and how it should be run.

title: Anne Katherine Gartrell Wed To David Samuel Herscher
description: Anne Katherine Gartrell and David Samuel Herscher, both of New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the apartment of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Herscher of New York.

title: Art: Masters Of Collage
description: TWELVE AMERICAN MASTERS OF COLLAGE at the Andrew Crispo Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is one of the most inventive and illuminating group shows that we shall have seen this whole. year.

title: Perisylvania Hospital Files Suit Against Coroner in Gas Mixup
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI)Suburban General Hospital, where at least six people are believed to have died because of a mixup in gas lines in the efnercy room, has filed suit against the acting Montgomery County coroner.

title: White Sox Sign Moore, ExBrave
description: Junior Moore, a free agent irk whom the Yankees had displayed some intefa est, has joined the mushrooming mumber of free agents who are flocking to the Chicago White Sox.

title: Markets Open Today
description: Banks, stock exchanges and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday for the Thanksgiving holiday, but will be open today. The weekly report on the money supply, normally issued each Thursday afternoon by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will be issued this afternoon.

title: Rhodesian Offers Majority Rule In a Bid to Local BIack Leaders
description: BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Nov. 24Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that he was prepared to concede the principle of majority rule based on one man, one vote as a starting point for negotiations with black nationalist leaders living in Rhodesia.

title: B1LINGUA EDUCATION AN ISSUE IN NEW YORK
description: Three years after a courtmandated bilingual education program began in New York City's schools, the Board of. Education, parents and leaders in the Hispanic community are embroiled in a controversy over what the program should entail and how it should be run,

title: TaxSaving Curb on Budget Rises Under Growing Assault in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Nov. 24Although they have been in effect only a year, New Jersey's budget cap laws, or limits on municipal, county and school spending, are under increasing attack by critics who believe they are hampering new programs and in some cases threatening existing ones.

title: Seeger'sSingalongIs BackIn Town
description: Fifty years ago this fall, a skinny thirdgrader by the name of Pete Seeger gave his first concert. My roommate and I put on a program of sea chanteys at a little school in Connecticut, he recalls today. The concert culminated in a rousing singalong versionof Whisky Johnny, and people have been singing along ever since.

title: Probation Officers Elect
description: WOODBURY, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP)The New York State Probation Officers Association has elected Anthony J. Carnecki of New Rochelle as its sixth president. At 29, he is the youngest person to head the 2,000member association.

title: RUMANIAN DISSIDENT MAKES PLEA IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Nov. 24The Rumanian writer Paul Goma called on the world's press today to give maximum exposure to dissidents in his country so that Government authorities would cease their persecution.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Books: Dipping Into a Mixed Bag of Words
description: OUR AIM, Mr. and Mrs. Morris say of their curious book, is to trace the histories of several thousands of the more interesting words and phrases, some borrowed from other tongues, some the product of quickwitted invention. Though the tone of many entries is casual, even lighthearted, rest assured that careful scholarship buttresses every entry.

title: Film: Not the Homosexual
description: IT'S NOT THE HOMOSEXUAL Who Is Perverse, but the Situation in Which He Lives, is a militantly Marxist call for a end to homosexual oppression, made by a Young German film maker who has taken the nom de cinema of Rosa Von Praunheim. The 65minute movie, which was shown in the Museum of Modem Art's Cineprobe series in 1972, opened yesterday at the Film Forum on a bill with a 30minute film, Audience Response to It's Not the Homosexual ..., which is just what the title says, a record of (mostly angry) viewers responses to the Von Praunheim film after screenings in New York.

title: He Waited to Be a Playwright
description: For Gus Edwards, the fruit of 18 years of sacrifice will be harvested tomorrow, when the Negro Ensemble Company opens its 11th season with previews of The Offering, the first of two plays by Mr. Edwards that the company will produce this season.

title: Discipline Hayes, Group Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)F.A.N.S., the sports consumer group endorsed by Ralph Nader, today called on the N.C.A.A. to discipline Ohio State's coach, Woody Hayes, for swinging at an ABC cameraman during the MichiganOhio State game. Mike Freedman of Los Angeles, the cameraman, deflected Hayes punch and sustained only a bruised left elbow.

title: BritishSpanish Talks on Gibraltar Produce No Visible Path for Future
description: STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Britain and Spain today ended talks on the future of the British colony of Gibraltar with expressions of good will but no visible results.

title: Invocations by Metuchen Council Opposed by Atheists and a Pastor
description: METUCHEN, Nov. 24Paul Marsa, gasstation owner in this Middlesex County community who is also the state director of American Atheists Inc., has opened a campaign to end the Borough Council's tradition of opening each monthly meeting with a prayer, contending that the practice is a violation of the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: Pontiff Attends a Funeral Mass For Luigi Cardinal Traglia, 82
description: ROME, Nov. 24 (AP)Pope Paul VI attended a funeral mass today at St. Peter's Basilica for Italianborn Luigi Cardinal Traglia, dean of the College of Cardinals, who died Tuesday at the age of 82.

title: Woman Stabbed in Luxury Building Where Tenant Was Slain Nov. 12
description: A woman who was apparently removing garbage from her 45thfloor apartment was stabbed in the arm yesterday in the same luxury building where a 68year old resident was stabbed to death on Nov. 12.

title: Black Panthers Set Back as a Leader Leaves Oakland and a Contributor Loses Post
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 24The Black Panther Party suffered two setbacks here this week when Elaine Brown, the former chairman, resigned to move to Los Angeles, and Mary Ireland Dougherty, a financial contributor, was dismissed from her county job.

title: Few Stones Left Unturned at This Show
description: Ghostly hundreds of men, women and children gather in a Jersey dump field, blankets over their heads, and with batteryrun ultraviolet lights peer at chunks of debris,

title: The U.N. Today
Arabs Investments In U.S. Slackening
description: A slightly smaller share of the dollar surplus from Middle East oil producers is flowing into the United States this year than at any time since the huge oil price increase in 1973, an analysis of official figures shows.

title: 32Man Force Is Set Up On Coast After 10 Women Are Killed in Last Month
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP)Ten young females have been killed, most of them strangled and raped, in less than four weeks. Their bodies have been tossed onto lawns and into ravines and bushes.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$10,000, mdns., 2YO, 6f.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Department Store Locks Its Doors, and Purses Open to Aid Two Schools
description: Shopping in Bloomingdale's with the store closed to the public, wandering through the aisles with drink in hand, watching models slither around in designer lingerie, dining with friends on the store's furniture: The guests agreed that it was certainly a novel way to raise money for private schools,

title: Around the Nation
description: A combination of rain, freezing rain, sleet, snow and howling winds covered much of the upper United States yesterday, making Thanksgiving travel hazardous.

title: Dolphins Rout Cardinals, 5514; Bears 3114 Victors Over Lions
Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Mayo Smith, Managed the Tigers To a World Championship in 1968
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) Edward Mayo Smith, who managed the Detroit Tigers to their 1968 world championship, died today. He was 62 years old.

title: Management
description: Fourteenhour days and few weekends off are about par for one of the toughest and most unusual graduate school programs in this country. At the end of the 10month program, 56 students will receive Master of Science degrees from the Arthur D. Little Management Education Institute in Cambridge, Mass.

title: MOUNTIES OF CANADA ARE LINKED WITH C.I.A.
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 24Reports of close links between the Central Intelligence Agency and the security unit of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have emerged in the public examination of alleged spying activities by the Mounties.

title: Statue of Minerva Found in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 24 (Reuters)A lifesize terracotta statue of Minerva, the Roman goddess of wisdom, has been unearthed in one of the most important archeological finds in recent years, Italian archeologists said today.

title: Article 4  No Title
Ice Rinks in KuwaitWill Separate Sexes
description: KUWAITA French company has won a contract to build the first iceskating complex here, with separate rinks for men and women.

title: Ban on Billy Beer Protested in Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE. Va., Nov. 24 (UPI)The. Charlottesville Distributing Company says that Billy Beer, endorsed by President Carter's brother Billy, is hot item and that it will go to court next week to seek reversal of a ban on sa?e of the beer in Virginia.

title: AN INTERRELIGIOUS GROUP INVITED TO VISIT HUNGARY
description: ROME, Nov. 24A delegation of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders announced here today that they had met with senior Hungarian officials and had been invited to visit religious groups in Hungary.

title: Nora M. Ophuls Married To John Anthony Nevin
description: Nora Macfarlane Ophuls of Branford, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Macfarlane of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday afternoon to John Anthony Nevin of Durham. N.J., son of Mrs. Walter S. Nevin of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Mr. Nevin.

title: White House May Let Cities Decide on Transit Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The Carter Administration is considering a new transportation policy that for the first time would give cities the right to integrate their highway and mass transit funds and spend them according to local priorities.

title: Newark's Plans to Relocate 200 People Protested by Architects' Group
description: NEWARK, Nov. 24This city's plans to relocate 200 people from a downtown area to provide space for parking and other uses by the Essex County Community College are being protested by a group known as the Architects Community Design Center.

title: Rumania Hails Sadat's Israel Trip As Opening Way Out of Deadlock
description: VIENNA, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Rumani breaking ranks with Moscow, expresses approval today of President Anwar el Sadat's visit to Israel and called it major step toward peace in the Middle East.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE subject for today is louts. A lout for the purposes of this discussion is somebody who is loud and obnoxious at a concert. Sometimes this is no problem at al., there are some concerts that positively demand a loutish responsethere's no place for genteel concert manners at an appearance of Black Sabbath, and anyone who would insist on such a thing would be guilty of reverse loutism.

title: Sheepskin, Though Chic, Should Still Be an AllWeather Friend
description: Sheepskin coats and jackets have always been about the warmest garments around, but today in the hands of designers like Oscar de la Rents, Geoffrey Beene and Ralph Lauren they have become fashionable as well.

title: Barnard Is Giving Up Transplants Of Animal Hearts Into Humans
description: CAPE TOWN, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard said today that he was giving up transplants of animal hearts into humans for the time being.

title: WILLIAM J. NOVEMBER, 71; EXECUTIVE WITH EQUITABLE
description: William J. November, a retired vice president and actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died yesterday at the Glen Cove, L.I., Community Hospital after suffering a stroke while playing golf. He was 71 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., where he had been a civic leader for many years.

title: Stewart Ends Borg's Streak In 31st Match
description: OVIEDO, Spain, Nov. 24 (UPI) Sherwood Stewart of the United States snapped Bjorn Borg's 30match winning streak today, ousting the Swede by 61, 76. The upset came in the third round of a $100,000 Grand Prix tournament.

title: Fahey Gets Four Scores In Stamford Catholic Rout
description: Kevin Fahey scored four touchdowns and ran for 229 yards on 16 carries to lead Stamford Catholic to a 548 romp over Notre Dame of Bridgeport. Catholic will face Ansonia, which stopped unbeaten Naugatuck yesterday, 180, in the Class S championship.

title: Burglar Alarms Vary in Design; All Should Be Approved by Agency
description: WASHINGTON (AP)Burglar alarms cost anywhere from several hundred dollars to more than a thousand dollars, but all should be approved by Underwriters Laboratories or another major testing agency, the National Bureau says.

title: Inmates at Rikers Tell of Assaults, Rats and Screaming in the Night
description: There's no stability of mind here, said Charley Guida, who has been a Rikers Island inmate longer than anyone else now there. You're better off taking a plea and going upstate. Upstate is like a resurrection.

title: A Different Kind of Larceny
description: My problem, says the indignant harness driver, grateful for the chance to be heard, is not that I've been accused of doing anything dishonest. I've been in the business 25 years, and I've always driven to win. That's my problem. Lou Puntolillo's husky, almost hoarse voice rises to the urgent tone of a patient on a psychiatrist's couch. My problem, he says, is that I won't go along with fixed races. And if you won't steal, they don't want you to work. Harness racing's most unwanted driver, still fit and capable at the age of 64, nods his head as if to punctuate the accusation. Sports Do the track owners know about this? of his visitor asks. Do the racing officials The Times and state commissioners know about it? Know about? Puntolillo says, shaking with laughter. They're part of it.

title: Toys and Games of Yesteryear Shown at Yale
description: Lititia Littlebrain, a stern matron with her nose in the air, wants to know why a drunk man is like a Quaker.

title: Dance: Pilobolus Climbs High
description: PILOBOLUS Dance Theater, that fabulously innovative group of young people who have developed hanging upside down from one another's necks into a fine art, arrived last night at the St. James Theater for its first Broadway season.

title: Tomb of Philip II of Macedon Is Found in Northern Greece
description: SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 24A tomb uncovered near here a month ago is without reservation that of King Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, the archaeologist who discovered it announced today.

title: Auctions
description: TRADITIONALLY, there are about five major auctions of toys and model trains between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Ana this year is no exception. The action starts today in Lionville, Pa., where Ted Maurer, Pottstown auctioneer and schoolteacher, will dispose of the McKeon collection of early tin toys by the late Edward R. Ives, the 19thcentury toy manufacturer, and others, castiron designs and comic tin toys. The collection covers an abundance of ingenious devices that charmed children from around the Civil War through World War II, playthings that are sought today mostly by adultsand affluent ones at that.

title: New Face: Joseph Carberry
description: One October night four years ago, 25yearold aspiring actor who had been making ends meet by working as a cabbie drew his taxi to a halt outside Riverside Church.

title: Notre Dame Picking Up Right Where It Left Off
description: In this year's preseason girls' basketball scrimmages, they beat the defending Staten Island public school champions, Tottenville, and the defending Brooklyn Diocese Catholic champions, St. Xavier.

title: North Beats South in Middletown
description: Dan Kelleher passed twice to Dennis Jaques for touchdowns and reeled off a 13yard touchdown run as Middletown North (91) trimmed Middletown South, 2712. North will meet North Edison on Dec. 3 for the Central Jersey Grnun 4 championship.

title: Postcards Become Instant Art
description: THE epoch of the picture postcard is, apparently, upon us. No longer just somethingeither splendid, silly or commonplaceon which to scribble a sentiment or send a message, this lowly medium is on its way to higher things. Like some waif suddenly rescued from obscurity in a 19thcentury melodrama, the postcard has been elevated to a new status. It has now been claimed as heir to the art of the present age.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Bloomfield Easy Victor Over Clifton
description: Bloomfield raced to a 190 halftime lead and posted its ninth victory in 10 starts, 3220, over Clifton (82). Tom O'Connell and Paul Martino scored two touchdowns each for Bloomfield, which, like Clifton, was eliminated from the state playoffs last Saturday.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: On Saving Energyand Face
description: For months we've watched Congress turn the Administration's energy program into the moral equivalent of a pillow fight. First the House dumped the President's tax on gasoline. Next, the Senate wasted weeks on an emotional debate over natural gas before passing an energy bill that was little more than a cynical agreement to disagree. And last week the HouseSenate conference committee threw in the towel on mandatory Federal guidelines for electricity rates; one of the few tough, issues it had faced. Some of the President's supporters had begun to talk about dropping critical portions of the energy package entirely and trying again next year.

title: Alternative Center Offers India and Delta Music
description: Music from India and the Mississippi Delta will be offered this weekend at the Alternative Center for International Arts, 28 East Fourth Street (between the Bowery and Lafayette Street).

title: Escalators Being Replaced on New York Subways
description: A program to replace and recondition Cay of the escalators at New York City subway stations has been started by the Transit Authority, the agency said yesterday.

title: Mother and 2 Children Die in Fire
description: MANCHESTER, Mo., Nov. 24 (AP)A woman and her two children died early today in a fire in their home in the St. Louis suburb of Manchester, the police said. The victims were identified as Winfred Brooks, 53 years old; her daughter, Bethann, 13, and her son, Glen, 8.

title: military Regimes in South America Looking Less Harshly on a Return to Some Form of. Civilian Rule
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 19In the 1960's, the political pendulum of South America swung from democracy toward authoritarianism as civilian regimes were deposed by the military.

title: Cleveland's Schools, Failing to Meet Payroll, Enter Deeper Crisis
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 23The financial crisis in Cleveland's public schools, which had simmered quietly since a Federal judge turned down the heat a month ago, is approaching a new boiling point.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Britain has undertaken a new initiative aimed at restoring local rule to Northern Ireland.

title: Favored Cox's Ridge, With Maple Up, Rallies for Queens County Victory
description: There were some in yesterday's crowd of 18,565 who thought Aqueduct's mud would ruin the favored Cox's Ridge's victory chances as seven starters appeared for the $54,450 Queens County Handicap.

title: 40,000 Are Reported Convicted Of Trying to Flee East Germany
description: WEST BERLIN, Nov, 24 (Reuters)A group that anonitors events in East Germany said today that about 40,000 people there had been convicted of attempting to flee to the West since the Communist authorities erected the Berlin wall in 1961.

title: Unusual Is Usual for Gregg Smith Singers
description: I don't mean to be patting ourselves on the back, Gregg Smith was saying, but my singers don't do the usual sort of choral program. We do special music, chamber operas, theater pieces, folk songs and everything else that can serve to expand the whole range of vocal music. I don't even call us a chorus anymore: We're a vocal ensemble.

title: Officer Shoots Another in Accident on a Police Bus
description: A police officer was shot in the stomach by a fellow officer in an apparent accident as they sat in a bus that was taking them for patrol duty at the Thanksgiving Day parade in Manhattan yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: WHAT does Ingmar Bergman have that Bernardo Bertolucci doesn't have? If you answer Liv Ullmann, you'll only be right for a few more months. The stunning Norwegian actress is now acting for her Swedish mentor in Autumn Sonataa tense drama in which she plays Ingrid Bergman's anguished daughterbut, come spring, she will team with the Italian director of Last Tango in Paris and 1900. This intriguing artistic collaboration will take place on neither Italian nor Scandinavian soil, however. La Lunaas Mr. Bertolucci has titled his contemporary screenplay will be shot in the exotic borough of Brooklyn.

title: Ballet: Dancers Surpass Dances
description: The entire company or Dancers performs suavely, energetically, poetically and elegantly. So much so that the mediocre repertory hangs like an albatross around the performers cleanly trained bodies. The ballets are not only inferior, but also virtually identical stylistically. For so young a company, it has more than its fair share of disposable ballets, several of which received their first performances locally at the Roundabout on Wednesday evening.

title: Clowns and Other Favorites Evoke Thrills at Macy Parade
description: By the thousands, the children sat on the damp curbs along Central Park West and Broadway. They clustered atop news. stands and telephone booths. They rode their fathers shoulders and clung to the tops of police call boxes. They sat in the street on tiny folding chairs or on the window ledges of apartments houses.

title: Rikers Island No LessGrim 2 Years After Its Rebellion
description: Conditions on Rikers Island have changed little in the two years since inmates at the House of Detention for Men seized five guards and barricaded themselves for 17 hours.

title: Arabs Investments In U.S. Slackening
description: A slightly smaller share of the dollar surplus from Middle East oil producers is flowing into the United States this year than at any time since the huge oil pries Increase in 1973, an analysis of official figures shows.

title: BONN PLANNING TRANSFERS OF IMPRISONED TERRORISTS
description: BONN, Nov. 24The justice ministers of the federal and state governments apparently agreed today to transfer the 90 terrorists held in West German prisons and to rotate their guards.

title: JOHN WHARTON DIES THEATER AFICIONADO
description: John Franklin Wharton, a lawyer who founded the wellknown firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison, and a theater aficionado who was one of the founders of the eminent Playwrights Producing Company, died early yesterday at his home at 141 East 72d Street of complications brought on by emphysema. He was 83 years old.

title: VINCENT GILROY, 88, OPPOSED TAMMANY
description: Vincent Gilroy, a former New York State' Assemblyman and a lawyer with a special interest in mass transit, died in Coney Island Hospital Nov. 16, three days short of his 89th birthday.

title: Steak and Ale Now On Menu at Burnett
description: The Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, which officially lost the Kentucky Fried Chicken account only recently, has just picked up a replacement, the Steak and Ale Restaurants of America, with about 150 outlets.

title: Art: Blithe Spirit With a Sharp Chisel
description: AS a sculptor of human nture, William King has often been likened to Daumier. But he might better be compared to Nol Coward, the sharpness of whose insights were scarcely noticed for the witty packages they came in.

title: In Defense of Virgins
description: LONDON'Do not, said Bernard Shaw, do unto others as you would they should do unto you. Their tastes may be different.

title: Article 6  No Title
A RESTAURATEUR SHOT, OFFDUTY OFFICER HELD
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (UPI)An offduty New York City police officer was arrested early today and charged with assault for allegedly shooting a Westchester County restaurant owner in the stomach.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two reindeer from Finland are biding their quarantine at the Animal Import Center in Clifton until Monday, when they will be shipped to Washington as Christmas presents for Amy Carter.

title: Sadat Trip Protested in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 24 (AP)About 300 students shouting slogans against President Anwar elSadat of Egypt demonstrated outside the physics and chemistry faculty of Aryamehr University today, the Iranian Government said. Joining the protest were Palestinian sympathizers who apparently opposed Mr. Sadat's trip to Israel last weekend, the Government said. It also reported that two other student demonstrations had been staged in recent days.

title: PALESTINIANS INVITED TO CAIRO TO REVIEW SADAT'S ISRAEIA TRIP
description: CAIRO, Nov. 24Egypt's ruling Arab Socialist Union decided today to invite Palestinian leaders from Israel and from the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan to come to Cairo to discuss President Anwar elSadat's visit to Jerusalem last weekend. It marked the first effort by Cairo to brief Palestinians on the trip, which the Palestine Liberation Organiz tion vehemently opposed.

title: Japan's Economic Invasion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The critical problems between nations usually don't appear suddenly or dramatically as in the SadatBegin confrontation in Jerusalembut develop slowly from small misunderstandings or large misjudgments while their peoples are not paying much attention.

title: In Gratitude, Dinner for All
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24They came in gym shoes, tattered coats and blue jeans, old people carrying canes and young ones carrying babies. By 11 A.M., more than 100 were lined up four abreast from the door of the restaurant and into the street.

title: Dollar Falls to New Lows
description: LONDON Nov 24 (AP)The troubled dollar slid to new lows today against three West European currencies in nervous trading on European money markets.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets for the Sine Nomine Singers concert Sunday at 8:30 P.M. in the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A. on Lexington Avenue, are $5. They may be purchased at the box office or through Chargit, 2397177. Information: 4276000, extension 722.

title: Westfield Adds to Its Long Streaks
description: Westfield continued to dominate its opponents as it shut out Plainfield, 380, for sits 23d straight decision without a, defeat, its 20th consecutive victory and its 10th this season.

title: Music: Lou Rawls on Broadway
description: IN THE 20ODD YEARS since Lou Rawls began to cut his teeth as performer on the Chitlin Circuit, he has, as he points out, been identified as a jazz singer, a pop singer, a folk singer, a blues singer, a rock singer and a soul singer. Now he can add Broadway singer to the list, not just because he opened a 10day engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theater in a concert performance called Lou Rawls on Broadway on Wednesday evening, but also because he has expanded his repertory to include at least one show tune, Send in the Clowns.

title: Officer Pushed Out of the Air Force Feels Vindicated by Court
description: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 20John H. VanderMolen says that he has never refused to push the button nor does he want to ban the bomb or eliminate nuclear energy plants.

title: H.E.W. Names Antifraud Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)The appointment of Marjorie Fine Knowles, a University of Alabama law professor, to a government antifraud post was announced today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. A former New York Assistant District Attorney, she was named assistant general counsel for the H.E.W. Office of Inspector General, which is charged with preventing and detecting fraud and abuse in the department's programs.

title: Hospital Deaths Being Cut by Use Of Intravenous Feeding Technique
description: HOUSTONThe operations were technically successful, but despite the best available hospital care all three patients died, and a very discouraged young intern, Dr. Stanley J. Dudrick, began to question his desire to become a surgeon.

title: PRESIDENT, AT CAMP DAVID, GETS REPORT FROM VANCE
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Nov. 24 (AP)President Carter summoned Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance for a report on his trip to Latin America, including his unsuccessful efforts to win Venezuelan support for a freeze on oil prices.

title: For Its Guards, Job in Prison Is Punishment
description: For a person whose consciousness about prisons was formed in the turbulent reform era of the late 60's and early 70's, it is hard to feel empathy for people who work at keeping other people in jail.

title: Henry Heinemann, Noted Physiologist, Killed in Accident
description: Dr. Henry Heinemann, a physiologist known for his research into kidney and pulmonary diseases, was fatally injured early Wednesday evening as he crossed York Avenue in front of New York Hospital at 70th Street. He was 57 years old.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: A Facilitating Policy
description: Former Secretary of State Kis singer probably is right that the Carter Administration, in the wake of President Sadat's visit to Jerusalem, should not tie itself too closely to its desire for a Geneva conference to negotiate an overall Middle East settlement.

title: What Price Bases in the Philippines
description: President Marcos evidently wants to give a positive cast to his negotiations with the Carter Administration over the future of American bases in the Philippines, and that is all to the good. But contrary to reports from Manila, the talks are not near an end. They are just beginning. And on the most important questions, the Carter Administration is showing a wise reserve.

title: 3DQUARTER NET OFF 66% AT N.Y.S.E. MEMBER FIRMS
description: Aggregate earnings of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange fell 66 percent to $30.8 million in the third quarter of 1977 from $90.4 million in the third quarter of 1976, the exchange announced. During the same period, average trading volume on the Big Board rose 11.4 percent.

title: Somalia Calls U.S. Indifferent to Red Takeover Threat
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Nov. 24(Reuters)President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia has bemoaned the apparent unwillingness of the United States to become involved in the Horn of Africa.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1977

title: 900 Pieces of Sunken Treasure Are Put to Auction in England
description: PENZANCE, England, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Spanish cannon, pieces of eight and Ming cups were among 900 items of sunken treasure auctioned here today. They came mostly from ships wrecked off the English coast in the 16th through 19th centuries The item that brought the highest price, $12,600, was a Spanish Armada Cannon found by a Schoolboy while spear fishing about 50 miles from this southwest England port.

title: JERSEY BUDGET CURB UNDER RISING ATTACK
description: TRENTON, Nov. 24Although they have been in effect only a year, New Jersey's budget cap laws, or limits on municipal, county and school spending, are under increasing attack by critics who believe they are hampering new programs and in some cases threatening existing ones.

title: Yugoslavia to Release Mihajlov and 722 Others
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Yugoslavia will free the dissident author Mihajlo Mihajlov this weekend in an amnesty affecting 723 prisoners, Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Yesterday's Results in Scholastic Sports
description: Football

title: CATHERINE II LETTERS FOUND IN NEW ORLEANS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24Ordinarily, the thirdyear Russian class at Benjamin Franklin High School in New Orleans is an orderly affair, like other classes in the school's college preparatory courses for high achievers. But one day earlier this month, there was an unusual buzz in the air.

title: Chemical Concerns Face High Cost In Setting Up Toxic Data Systems
description: Anticipating the Environmental Protection Agency's request for extensive record keeping under the Toxic Subotancee Control Act, companies using or producing chemicals face the costly task of building computerized medical and exposurehistory data systems.

title: Hides Into Coats: An Ancient Craft
description: NAPA, CalifThe rich smell of new leather and fresh soap pervades the balmy air here in the tanning barn of Sawyer Tanning Company next to the Napa River, about an hour's drive north of San Francisco.

title: Israelis Say Sadat Opened Way to Settle Key Issues Before. Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Nov 24Israel's past position that all matters of substance in the conflict with the Arabs must be directly negotiated has been altered by the historic visit of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Natl Basketball Assn
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: Venezuela, Rich From Its Oil but With Agricultural Problems, Imports Cows FirstClass, Flying In 74,000
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 24Venejuela now has so much money that even cattle can afford to fly. some 74,000 highquality breeding cows have been flown here from Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Panama to improve local herds. The program was begun 14 months ego and completed last week.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1977

title: Blasts Damage New Paper Mill
description: SKOWHEGAN, Maine, Nov. 24 (AP)A new $230 million Scott Paper Company ?? mill was closed today after two minor explosions damaged a complex systen designed to collect odorous gases generated in the pulp making process. No one was injured in the blasts.

title: Town Imposes Curfew and Recalls Quieter Times
description: CEDAR GROVE, Nov. 21To combat a rash of vandalism in this small Essex County community, a 1 A.M. curfew for boys and girls 16 years of age and under has been unanimously adopted by the Town Council.

title: Search Is Pressed in the Adirondacks for Two Lost Practice Bombs
description: The New York state police and an Air Force team searched the Crest BurnHobble Hill area of the Adirondack Mountain wilderness yesterday for two practice bombs that were ripped from an Air National Guard fighter plane flying too close to the treetops during a practice mission last Saturday.

title: ALCOHOLICS IN ENGLAND AND WALES PUT AT 500,000
description: NEWCASTLE, England (Reuter)Social Services Minister David Ennals says that half a million people in England and Wales suffer from alcoholism.

title: Hospital Deaths Being Cut by Use Of Intravenous Feeding Technique
description: HOUSTONThe operations were technically successful, but despite the best available hospital care all three patients died, and a very discouraged young intern, Dr. Stanley J. Dudrick, began to question his desire to become a surgeon.

title: Scientists Turn to Molten Rock as Vast Source of Energy
description: Hotand sometimes moltenrock beneath the Western states holds from 500 to 1,000 times more energy than Americans consume each year, according to one estimate. A bold effort is under way to extract at least a small fraction of it.

title: President of DaytonHudson Unit in Minneapolis Resigns His Post
description: Carl T. Erickson resigned yesterday is president of Dayton's, the largest department store in Minneapolis and a major division of the DaytonHudson Corporation.

title: Soviet Visitors To Jersey Find. Common Foe
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., Nov. 25Five Soviet agricultural specialists completing a 12day visit to the United States in South Jersey learned today that they and Deald Johnson, a potato farmer near here and a State Agriculture Board member who served as their host, had at least one common enemythe Colorado beetle.

title: U.S. Safety Agency Cites Ford in 2d Plant Fatality Ignored by Michigan Unit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP)For the second time in 15 months, the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration has cited the Ford Motor Company in a fatal accident that was not investiaatod by Michigan's own safety agency.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: P.L.U. Is Said to Urge Palestinians On West Bank to Rebuff Cairo Bid
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25The Palestine Liberation Organization is contacting mayors and other leaders in the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan, urging them not to accept an invitation to Cairo to discuss the Middle East situation after President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel, Palestinians said today.

title: Television
Surfers Seeking a New Imageand Maney, Too
description: SUNSET BEACH, HawaiiThe big waves are rising again on the north shore of Oahu. And so are the hopes of an itinerant fraternity of young men who are trying to polish the image of surfing and make a living by riding the waves.

title: Retail Sales Up 1.2% in Week
description: Retail sales rose 1.2 percent last week to a seasonally adjusted $13.65 billion the Commerce Department reported yes terday in Washington. Sales last week were 9 percent higher than the 1976 week, matching the yeartoyear gain .in the four most recent weeks but dropping below the 10. percent advance in the year so far.

title: State U. Acts to Curb Students Who Default on Their U.S. Loans
description: The State University of New York announced yesterday that it would begin withholding transcripts and preventing the reenrollment of students who default on Federal student loans.

title: Bank of England's Base Rate to 7%
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (UPI)The Bank of England raised its minimum lending rate by 2 percentage points to 7 percent today, the first time in more than a year the rate has been increased.

title: William. Doescher Weds Linda Blair
description: Linda Blair of New York and Weston, Conn., an interior designer and marketing consultant to the Copper Development Association, was married in Darien, Conn., yesterday to William F. Doescher of Hickory, N.C., vice president for advertising and public relations of Drexel (N.C.) Heritage Furnishings Inc. Justice of the Peace Robert A. Fearon of New Canaan, Conn., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. A. Richard Scala.

title: Ways of Curbing Press at Trials Pose Tricky Questions
description: In Florida, a United States Senator goes on trial on charges of misusing his office. He is the first Senator in history to be indicted while in office. During the trial, the judge does not allow the names of the jurors to be released, refuses to let reporters see a number of exhibits and repeatedly holds bench conferences to which the press is not privy.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: ACTIONS BY STATES BLAMED FOR RISE IN AUTO SPEEDING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)Some state legislatures are deliberately underutting the national 55 mileanhour speed limit by rendering penalties virtually meaningless, says a new report to President Carter.

title: College Results
description: FOOTBALL

title: Arab Banks Alive and Well in Paris
description: PARISThe unsmiling features of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia stare down from the waiting room wall. On the coffee table are scattered copies of the annual report, printed in French and Arabic. This is the lushly carpeted headquarters of the Al Saudi Banque, which opened its doors last year in an expensive part of. Paris off the Champs Elyses.

title: Koch's Appointments
description: Edward N. Costikyan, who lost his job as First Deputy Mayor even before he got it, says that Mayorelect Edward I. Koch did not change the definition of the post he eliminated it. Mr. Koch does not disagree. But in declining to do without

title: Lawyerish Legislature
description: A study released by the Insurance Information Institute said lawyers account for the largest single group of lawmakers in the New Jersey Legislature.

title: The Loose Look Is Easing Into Spring
description: I've never has such fun, said a woman trying on clothes in a New York department store. Everything is so comfortable. If she found the fall clothes so great, she'll be delirious when she gets around to the spring styles.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In explaining why the New York Rangers dropped the guillotine on Rod Gilbert, who was perhaps the most popular player in the team's history, John Ferguson talked about how the right wing had scored only two goals this season. He's 36, the general manager said, arid that was basically the whole decision. We were concerned about his play. But the Rangers also were concerned about his pay: $200,000 for the final season of his threeyear contract, Two goals in 20 games come to about $25,000 a goal. Too expensive. Two 33yearold right wings also had become too expensive. Ken Hodge, who makes $135,000, had scored two goals. Bill Goldsworthy, who makes $165,000, had scored The Times none. That's a total of four goals for $500,000 in salariesabout $30,000 a goal over the first quarter of the season. Much too expensive.

title: family/style
description: AMHERST, Mass.Adele Smith Simmons regards herself as a member of a rare species. She is a woman president of a coeducational college and the best estimate is that no more than a dozen women in the country hold such jobs.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: 61 Harvest Girl Takes Dark Mirage
description: 61 Harvest Girl Takes Dark Mirage; Alydar Heads Remsen Field Today

title: Sports News Briefs
description: St. John's scored a 6660 triumph overLafayette last night in the opening round of the. Lapchiok Memorial basketball tournament. The tournament, which is named for Joe Lapchick, St. John's coach for 20 years, was being held at the St. John's court in Queens.

title: SYRIA CHARGES SADAT DAMAGED PROSPECTS FOR GENEVA PARLEY
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 25Syria tonight ruled out participation in a Geneva conference on the Middle East under the present circumstances, but it left the door open to a negotiated settlement with Israel, saying that it was not ready to join a rejectionist camp.

title: Stocks Move Ahead With Modest Gains; Dow Advances 1.12
description: Stock prices moved ahead with modest gains yesterday as a semiholiday air prevailed on Wall Street in the session following Thanksgiving Day.

title: Dollar Continues to Slide Against Major Currencies In Europe and Japan's Yen
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP)The dollar slid fractionally against some of West Europe's major currencies today, continuing a weeklong decline that pushed the American currency to new lows on world markets.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT S GAMES

title: U.S. FUNDS AVAILABLE TO REOPEN PLANTS, STEEL GROUP IS TOLD
description: The head of the Carter Administration's task force on steel told local officials from the Youngstown area in a meeting this week that Federal money was available under existing programs to reopen closed steel plants such as the Campbell Works.

title: Books of The Times
description: Americans have fallen prey to the sin of gluttony of the spirit, obsessed with soaking up experiences rather than things, driven to various exotic cures; among then the lure of Eastern religion. But alas, concludes Harvey Cox in his analysis of the spiritual aspects of the spectacle, the seekers after Oriental panaceas are doomed to return unfulfilled.

title: Dissident Charged With Treason
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 (AP)Soviet officials said today that Anatoly Shcharansky, an imprisoned dissident, is in good health, and confirmed that he has been charged with treason, close friends reported.

title: 3 Chileans Ask Return, Not Asylum
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 25We Want to go back, Chile is our homethat's where we were born, that's where we want to live, and that's where we will die, Anna Gonzalez said this afternoon. Her eyes were bloodshot, her voice quivered and she frequently stumbled over her words.

title: Money Supply Up Modestly; Stable Interest Rates Seen
description: The nation's basic money supply, which consists of currency and checking. accounts, rose modestly in the latestbanking week, Federal Reserve statistics. showed yesterday.

title: World News Briefs
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 25South Africa's highest court today upheld the appeal of Donald J. Woods, a banned newspaper editor, against a sixmonth jail term imposed when he refused to identify the sources of a complaint he lodged against the country's security police.

title: Let Someone Else In the Game
description: PARISInternationally speaking, the big external loser in this week's Greek elections was the United States. Prime Minister Caramanlis retained his parliamentary majority but by a decidedly smaller edge and the emotionally antiAmerican Andreas Papandreou won enough votes to become leader of the opposition.

title: UPSTATE NEW YORK EXPECTING BLJZZARD
description: A blizzard with four to eight inches of snow was forecast for today for western New York State, and a prediction of heavy rain in the New York metropolitan area prompted a flash watch for North Jersey and warnings of basement and street flooding in New York City.

title: Chagall at 90 Is a Growing Artist
description: PARISWhen one is 90 and the world's most famous living painter, every day tends to become one's birthday, and every birthday an official celebration. The climax the bombardment of tributes to which Marc Chagall has been submitted since his birthday on July 7 was reached on Oct. 17, when President Valry Giscard d'Estaing opened an exhibition of 62 canvases by the Russianborn master, painted since 1967, on the top floor of the Louvre's Pavillon de Flore. The exhibition will run through Jan. 7.

title: Exchange Seat Sold at $45,000
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $45,000, unchanged from the preceding sale on Nov. 18. Big Board seats currently are priced at $42,000 bid, $50,000 asked.

title: Russians Visiting a Potato Farmer Find They Have Common Enemy
description: BRIDGETON, Nov. 25Five Soviet agricultural specialists completing a 12da visit to the United States in South Jersey learned today that they and Donald Johnson, a potato farmer near here and a State Agriculture Board member who served as their host, had at least one common enemythe Colorado beetle.

title: College Football
description: AT LOS ANGELES

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1977

title: The Label on the Liquor Bottle
description: Last April, Dr. Ernest Noble, the director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, suggested that pregnant women be warned that more than two drinks a day might harm their unborn children. He cited evidence from animal experiments and epidemiological studies on humans that excessive alcohol consumption in pregnancy can lead to physical and behavioral abnormalities in children. The danger is greatest for chronic alcoholics, but even a normally abstemious woman might damage the fetus she bears on a single binge.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Duck Blinds and Books
description: For more than a century, waterfowlers have been experimenting with various types of blindshiding places from which they can observe, decoy and shoot birds without being spotted by their quarry.

title: MINE UNION'S LEADER HALTS TALKS, CALLING A STRIKE INEVITABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 25Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers of America, walked out of negotiations with the Bituminous Coal Operators Association today and said that a national strike of coal miners on Dec. 6 was inevitable.

title: Morgan T. Murray, a Partner In New York Brokerage Firm
description: Morgan T. Murray, a partner in the New York City brokerage firm of Chauncey & Company, died Thursday at his home on Breezy Way in Lawrence, L.I. He was 45 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING Highlights of the Los Angeles 500 NASCAR race, at Ontario Motor Speedway. A preview of Super Bowl XII, at the Superdome in New Orleans, and the eighth event in the series of the world's strongmen will also be shown as segments of this telecast. (TelevisionChannel 2, 4:30 P.M.)

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$10,000, mdn., 2YO, 6f.

title: RISE IN WORKERS' OUTPUT IN QUARTER REVISED DOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)The Labor Department reported revised figures today showing that productivity of American workers rose at a slightly slower pace in the third quarter than previously reported.

title: Notes on People
description: The comedian Dick Gregory, his wife, Lillian, and a Massachusetts State Senator, William Owens, were released from a Washington jail yesterday after pleading not guilty to charges that they illegally picketed the South African Embassy on Thursday. They were ordered to stand trial on Dec. 21. The three spent Thursday night in jail after refusing to post bond of $100. They were charged with violating a law prohibiting demonstrations within 500 feet of a foreign embassy in Washington. Othello Malone, an aide to Mr. Owens, said Mr. Gregory had led 50 demonstrators in a protest in front of the White House against South African racial policies. Later, they moved to the embassy, about two miles way. Most of the group dispersed on police orders, but Mr. Gregory, his wife, and Senator Owen returned and refused to obey an order to leave. They then were

title: TEACHING HOSPITAL SEEKS $39 MILLION
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 25Offsctals of Middlesex General Hospital said today that they were hopeful of early approval of their application for a special $27 million state bond issue to finance the hospital's new affiliation as the primary teaching hospital for the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Rutgers Medical School at Piscataway. One informant sal dthe approval might come tvithin a couple of Weeks.

title: SYRIA CHARGES SADAT DAMAGED PROSPECTS FOR GENEVA PARLEY
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov, 25Syria tonight ruled out participation in a Geneva conference on the Middle East under the present circumstances, but it left the door open. to a negotiated settlement with Israel, saying that it was not ready to join a rejectionist camp.

title: CLASS INTEGRATION IS STUDIED BY U.S.
description: The regional director of the Federal Office for Civil Rights began an evaluation yesterday of the New York City Board of Education's denial that it maintained several thousand illegally segregated classes during the 197576 school year.

title: Vance Meets With Rumanian
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Manea Macovescu of Rumania discussed Middle East developments today with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. Rumania, which is in close touch with both Israel and Egypt, has been credited with playing a behindthescenes role in arranging President Anwar elSadat's visit to Israel last weekend.

title: Around the Nation
description: Judge Grants Injunction Sought By Alaska Paper

title: FLORENCE KIMBALL, TEACHER, DIES AT 87
description: Florence Page Kimball, the teacher of Leontyne Price and many other singers of achievement during a teaching career of 46 years at the Juilliard School, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 87 years old and had been living in a nursing home before entering the hospital last week.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Nov. 25, 1977

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation released yesterday a list of 56 rail lines, or 854 miles of trackage, as possible candidates for abandonment. The lish was called from a group of 260 lines that Conrail had told the Interstate Commerce Commission it was studying last June.

title: C.I.A. Papers, Released to Nader, Tell of 2 Soviet Nuclear Accidents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The Central Intelligence Agency has made public 14 documents that describe two apparently separate nuclear accidents in the Soviet Union, one of which reportedly took the lives of hundreds of people.

title: Sales Prospects Giving Furriers Warm Feeling
description: With a bitter winter behind them and who knows what kind just ahead, more and more New York clothing retailers are making the trip downtown to a cluster of aging warehouses on Seventh Avenue.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONAnne W. Story of Cambridge, Mass., an engineering psychologist for the United States Department of Transportation, has invented an apparatus to test motorists for intoxication.

title: Article 1  No Title
Biko Inquest Witness Rebuts Police
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 25An expert who studied the brain of Stephen Biko testified today that the late black leader must have become unconscious immediately after incurring the head injuries that ultimately proved fatal.

title: LEIGH M. BATTSON
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25Leigh M. Battson, a past president of the Santa Anita Race Track and a former petroleum executive, died yesterday in Palm Desert, Calif., after a series of illnesses. He was 86 years old.

title: The Callousness of the Well Fed
description: A human economy that ends up discouraging the production of food in a world of hungry people just isn't worth the paper it's written on. We understand all the technicalities and practicalities that led the Department of Agriculture to call for a 10 percent reduction in next year's American plantings of corn, barley and sorghum. Like President Carter's request last August for a 20 percent cut in wheat production, the purpose is to maintain the market price and thus the incomes of farmers. Whatever the value in one small farming corner of the world, this can appear elsewhere only as the callousness of the well fed. And that is what it is.

title: The Rivals at Pasadena
description: Michigan reached Orange Bowl two years ago and Rose Bowl last season with Rick Leach directing effective Wolverine running attack. This season, Leach perfected passing enough to make it major factor in drive to Big Ten championship and another Rose Bowl... Junior needed to throw well since Michigan's running attack out of option I was hampered by injury to Harlan Huckleby, tailback. Russell Davis, fullback, was leading ground gainer with 1,013 yards and eight touchdowns.... Leach threw for 1,109 yards with 76 completions and 13 touchdowns....Leach, Davis and Huckleby worked behind big offensive line led by Mark Donahue, and Walt Downing....Coach Bo Schembechler's offense made 333 points, winning 10 of 11 games. Michigan defense, small but quick, gave up 97. The 52 defense operates out of slant angles with outside linebackers brought up to end spots.

title: Surfers Seeking a New Imageand Money, Too
description: SUNSET BEACH, HawaiiThe big waves are rising again on the north shore of Oahu. And so are the hopes of an itinerant fraternity of young men who are trying to polish the image of surfing and make a living by riding the waves.

title: 3 Chileans Ask Return, Not Asylum
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 25We want to go back, Chile is our homethat's where we were born, that's where we want to live, and that's where we will die, Anna Gonzlez said this afternoon. Her eyes were bloodshot, her voice quivered and she frequently stumbled over her words.

title: Retiring Social Security Chief Sees Faults in System
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)James B. Cardwell, the retiring Commissioner of Social Security, says that the Federal retirement and Social Security systems have some inequities, including the one that is leading to his retirement.

title: OCTOBER SALES UP 14.7% AT MAJOR RETAIL CHAINS
description: October business among 33 of the nation's largest retail chains rose 14.7 percent over the year before in continuation. of a strong trend that has been prevalent during much of 1977.

title: Women, Talking About Themselves
description: To me, one of the special delights in listening to women talk about themselves is their sense of irreverence. Nothing is sacred; the masks are pelted off, the myths debunked. Their words seem couched in a sense of physical self that is brave, optimistic, pragmatic and comically honest.

title: Britain and U.S. Wait to See the Small Print in New odesian Offer
description: LONDON, Nov. 25The British Government reacted cautiously today to the Rhodesian Prime Minister's endorsement yesterday of the principle of full voting rights for the black majority as a basis for negotiations with black nationalist leaders living inside Rhodesia.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
For Affirmative Action for Some Whites
description: DULUTH, Minn.A misconception about the Bakke case is that whites are against blacks on the issue of affirmative action.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: BACHE GROUP (N)

title: Letter Describes Lincoln Death
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP)A faint, yellowed letter written by a mail who helped to carry the wounded Abraham Lincoln from Ford's Theater is the most complete account ever discovered of the President's assassination, according to a historian.

title: Article 2  No Title
Penn State and Pittsburgh Will Keep a Late Date
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25Pittsburgh or Penn State could be sitting back tomorrow and anticipating the prospect of playing Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl on. Jan. 2, had these two Eastern independent powers met in their annual season finale list Saturday.as originally scheduled.

title: In Field of Taste and Smell, International Flavors Leads
description: A doctor recently asked International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. to reproduce the odor on a patient's breath before he slipped into a hepatic coma.. The doctor thought it would be helpful to make the odor available to other doctors for diagnostic purposes. I.F.F. perfumers listened to what the doctor said, had him sniff their attempts and, sure enough, produced a bottled hepatic coma victim.

title: Theater: From Texas, With Love
description: Although set in Israel, Aharon Megged's comedy A Visitor From Texas, which the Folksbiene is presenting on weekends through March at the Central Synagogue auditorium, is an amiable excursion into familiar territory: The effort of the parents of a marriageable daughter to arrange the best match for her.

title: In Search of the Galaxy's Debris
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 25A reward posted by the Field Museum of Natural History has stirred the rock hounds. Hundreds of them are hoping that the heavy, oddlooking rocks they have collected are meteoriteswhich will bring $100 apiece and possibly more, if the museum determines that they are authentic, new specimens.

title: Dock Pact Vote Is Set Tuesday
description: The International Longshoremen's Association said last night that a ratification vote on a new master contract would be held next Tuesday and could end by that evening the eightweekold limited strike that has affected ports from Maine to Texas.

title: Tragic Farce in the Philippines
description: The military court that hurriedly decreed death yesterday for President Marcos main political rival, Senator Benigno Aquino, undoubtedly acted on instructions from the Philippine dictator himself. Its hasteafter Senator Aquino's fouryear detention without trial and on mostly suspect chargescould be a prelude to tragedy or farce.

title: HousingCourt Aides in New York Accused of Illegally Practicing Law
description: New York City officials and legal groups are investigating coniplaints that city marshals and process servers are practicing law illegally, cluttering the already troubled Housing Court with defectiVe legal papers and often victimizing 'smallscale landlords.

title: Koch Rejects Proposal On How to Treat Poor
description: Mayorelect Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he disagreed with a proposal submitted for his consideration by a professor at Columbia University that allegedly urges that the poor be discouraged from living in New York City.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: IMPORT THREAT SEEN IN COMMUNICATIONS
description: The American market for telecommunications equipment is the new target of foreign manufacturers, the Communications Workers of America has warned.

title: Personal Investing
description: A new municipal bond unit trust provides another sign that Wall Street is trying to wring maximum advantage out of investor's enthusiasm for taxexempt securities. MI the securities in the portfolio were issued by municipalitos, agencies or governmental arms of wie state of Massachusetts. Page 28.

title: Santa's Helpers Starting Work To Spread the Holiday Cheer
description: When not otherwise engaged, Santa. Claus may be a night watchman, an icecreams vendor, a summerresort worker, a carpenter, a house painter, an actor. Or he may be unemployed or on welfare, or have a drinking problem.

title: 5YEAROLD S.I. GIRL DIES IN A SUSPICIOUS BLAZE
description: A 5yearold Staten Island girl visiting her father in the Port Richmond section died in a onealarm blaze of suspicious origin late last night that was confined to the secondfloor bedroom in which the girl was sleeping.

title: Victoria de los Angeles States Carmen Being Misinterpreted
description: Victoria de los Angeles, the only woman in recent memory who has been equally fascinating as Bizet's Carmen and Debussy's Mlisande, sat there on the sofa looking simultaneously seductive and demure and tried to explain what had kept her away from New York for five years. It was something about taxes, the Spanish soprano said with a small gesture that implied she knew little about such practical matters.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Letter: On Westway
description: To the Editor: After one has digested all the data and tables, the substance of your Nov. 14 editorial Westway, Still the Best Way is that the $1.156 billion Federal handout's only tangible benefit to New York City is that it would be free. As Adam learned when he took another Big Apple, not all gifts are blessings.

description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: Thursday's Fight
description: PORTLAND, MaineWilson Bell, 149 pounds, Porttand, knocked out Joey HousTon, 155, Lowell, Mass. 4 rounds.

title: Vladimir Slepak, a Russian Dissident Like His Father an.d Sons, Now Isolated From Both
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25Vladimir S. Slepak lives in a suspended generation, isolated from his father and his sons.

title: The Bilingual Goal, in Plain English
description: Much of the continuing controversy over the city's bilingual education seems either irrelevant or contradictory. For example, Aspira of New York, the Hispanic tights organization whose court challenge led to a ruling in 1974 that mandated bilingual instruction, presses for greeter numbers of the special classes now offered in 500 of the city's 900 schools. At the same time the Federal Government complains that the school system is maintaining some 3,800 racially segregated classrooms. The Board of Education is obliged to point out that nearly half of those classes are precisely the courtmandated bilingual ones.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERJames Hoban 53, of Watermlll NY, died Wednesday, November 23 at South Hampton Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Alexander, son of the late Edward R. Alexander & the late Elise Piquette Hoban Alexander, was a greatgreat grandson of James Hoban, the architect & builder of the White House & close friend of George Washington. Mr. Alexander donated an exhibit of Hoben's personal effects to the Museum of American History of the Smithsonian Institution & several House of native offurnitured Ohio Mr. Alexander attended Columbia College in NY & was a long time resident of Washington, D.C. & Phoenix, Arizona. Survivors include his sister Sylvia Alexander Conklin of Larchmont NY, a brother Edward R. Alexander Jr. of New York city, nephews & 2 nieces. Predeceased were 2 sisters, Elise Alexander Carter of Villenove, Pa. & Louise P. Alexander of Washington, D.C. Funeral services will be held Saturday at 11:30am at Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the Osteogenesis Imperfecto Foundation Inc, 102 Harold Dr.

The demonstrators, most of whom wore masks to conceal their identities, contended that the workers were actually Iranian secret policemen.

title: Shortages Are a Matter Of Perspective

The American Indians saw timber as so infinitely bountiful that hunters thought nothing of regularly setting uncontrolled fire to hundreds of thousands of acres of hardwood to drive game or to open land for the taking of game. title: Design
description: Kenzo Takada is at the forefront of French fashion today. Though Japanese, he is regarded as a French designer. He has lived there for 12 years now but it was only six months ago that he really settled into an apartment. Essential to his way of life are space and light and in the duplex shown here, overlooking the Luxembourg Gardens, he finally found both, The furniture is purposely limited: a sofa, an armchair, a chest, a bed, an antique writing desk surrounded by plants, and a dining table with a hot plate in its center for cooking meals on the tabletop, Japanese style. This table, designed by Kenzo, Is the focus of the apartment. Here he cooks shabu shabu and tempura for friends and colleagues. Space is defined by plants and ceramic jars filled with flowers bought by Kenzo on frequent forays to Rungis, the new Les Hallos. Kenzo doesn't try to imitate formal Japanese floral compositions, he bunches real flowers the same way he does those he designs for his fabrics. These fabric designs cover the oversize pillows that are everywhere in the apartment  after each collection he makes new covers using that season's dress, skirt or shirt fabrics. Kenzo's dream would he to live in a real Japanese house on top of a tall building with a huge terrace. He would, he says, sleep on a tatami mat and bathe Japaneseinstyle in a huge wooden tub. In the meantime, he is content to adopt the European way of life, adding, in his own way, nostalgic touches of Japan. Hence the pillows. Kenzo doesn't like to sit In his armchair. Life on the ground, he says, suits him better.

But folklore is also a magnet for picture book authors and illustrators who are challenged to try their creative mettle against its timeintested plots and diverse cultural backgrounds.

title: Enormous Life Wish
description: ENZO SERENI was physically tiny, a peanut with spectacles. Born in 1905 into a cultivated, wealthy Italian Jewish family, he steeped himself as a youth in traditional Italian culture. Burning with visions of Eden, he became one of the little band of Italian Zionistsmore precisely, the still littler band of Italian Socialist Zionists, dreamers of a new life for Jews as a people and as people. At 22, he went off with his wife to Palestine, the two of them the first Italians to work as pioneers. He became a founder of kibbutz Givat Brenner, working on and off as laborer in the fields and then racing away to beg/borrow money for the kibbutz from Jewish agencies and Italian relatives. man border. During the war he served with British intelligence in Cairo, and then worked as a secret agent in Iraq, helping endangered Jews to flee. Finally, 39, he parachuted behind the Nazi lines in northern Italy, hoping to save a few of the remaining Jews stranded there. Caught by the Nazis, he was shipped to Dachau. The few surviving witnesses record that he behaved with notable courage. In 1944 the Nazis killed him.

title: TRUCKERS
description: court for lawless behavior, and the total fines resulting from these court encounters usually amount to considerably less than $1 millionhardly enough to frighten an industry whose regulated part alone takes in well over $20 billion a year. It is more profitable, some companies feel, to keep rolling and pay the petty fines than it is to take trucks out of operation for safety repairs. Interstate companies can have their licenses revoked by the I.C.C. but only twice in the last 10 years has it taken such action against firms that operate dangerous clunkers. Although Federal law says that no driver can be forced to take out unsafe equipment, drivers have been fired for refusing a clunker, and the Teamsters Union, which has a cozy relationship with management, does not always fight for their reinemployment. Nor have Federal officials always responded to drivers safety complaints with much sympathy. Some drivers claim that when they specifically requested bureau investigators to inspect a dangerous defect they were told to move along and stop holding up traffic.

title: A Long Goodbye
description: SOMEONE once said to Yeats that only a fool spent a lot of time thinking about sex and death, to which Yeats retorted that only a fool spent lot of time thinking about much else. Yeats's priorities have certainly swept the novelistic field since the great days of 19thincentury tripleindeckers, with their broad social and historical perspective: a Victorian would probably be as puzzled by the narrow concerns of our novels as we would be by comparable limitations in their lovemaking techniques. What?a contemporary of Dickens or Trollope might well say Gus in Bronze'a whole novel about a woman dying of cancer? You mean, that's it? Well, one would reply with a lordly Yeatsian glare, yes and no.

title: In Balanchine's Dancesteps
description: DANCE criticism is still a primitive and most craven enterprise. Were it not for a few exceptions, like Edwin Denby's Looking at the Dance in 1949 and B. H. Haggin's Ballet Chronicle in 1970, one might think that Arlene Croce had by herselPinvented the passionately alert, exciting and usefully learned kind of dance observation collected in this book of pieces dating back to 1966 fr.om The New Yorker and other magazines. In fact, she doesn't owe much to either of her worthy predecessors. For while she lacks Denby's sensitivity to the mythological elements in dance movement or ballet libretto, she is far more willing that he to clear away the junk that keeps good things from taking root; and while she doesn't know as much about music as Haggin does, she isn't as inflexible as he in her estimations of dancers or as euphorically vague and repetitious about those she adThe reason she could have gotten along without these other critics is that she learned, as did they, from studying the greatest of choreographerincritics, George Balanchine of the New York City Ballet. From watching him she learned how much could get expressed through his dynamic adaptations of classical style, its capacities to comment on rather than merely mimic the music, its intricate crossinreferences and visual punnings that nonetheless support the large onward thrust of the whole work. I can't be sure that somewhere in the world there isn't a critic as good as Croce, but I would be willing to guess that there isn't, if only because her degree of critical intelligence can only have been developed and sharpened where a choreographer of genius like Balanchine is himself actively exercising the critical function. Everything he creates is in some sense a reinterpretation of the vocabulary of classical dance, its potentialities with respect to a piece of music and to the endowments of a particular dancer.

title: To Put Beside Boswell
description: THE celebrity author is not now a creature we can feel very comfortable with. His writing too seldom accords with his personal habitshis politics, say, or marital difficulties, his behavior on talk shows. To call Samuel Johnson a celebrity would be an appalling vulgarity, but in his time he was both a writer and a public figure. The (for us) shaming difference is that, although everyone recognized the magnificent oddity of his personality, he was admired and cherished for qualities of mind and character that were evident in both his work and his life. For all his complexity, there was only one Johnson.
