title: IN AMERICA
description: DETROIT. He's wearing a dark suit with a pearlcolored tie on a white shirt and there's a suggestion of silver in his hair, which always appeared to bristle in news photographs. The background is burgundy and Jimmy Hoffa's left arm is laid across his knee, with a bit of French cuff flashing. This must be Hoffa as he wanted to be seen: not the union despot or buddy of racketeers, but the labor statesman straight out of the old whisky ads for the man of distinction. Only when Bob Lins, the incumbent president of Local 299 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, strolls across the platform to switch on the light above the painting do you notice the mockery in Hoffa's smile. In that great union hall in the sky, he must be enjoying himself as he peers down on his old local, which in the year A.D. 2after his presumed death at the hands of his old Mafia alliesnow teeters on the brink of rankinandinfile rebellion. It could never have happened when Hot fa was in power, for he would have snuffed it out. And it could never have gone very far had he lived, for the restoration that he restlessly plotted after his release from a Federal prison was to have started with the recapture of 299. But now, with Hoffa's elimination, the local faces the first real election it has known in the four decades since he established his dominance and started to reach for control over the nation's largest union. The strangest part of his ambiguous legacy is that Hoffa is now more obviously the patron saint of the rebellion than of the union hierarchy it challenges, for the first stirrings in Local 299 came only after he'd broken with his successor, Frank Fitzsimmonsthe disloyal vassal whom he'd lifted from 299 to leadership in Washington.

title: Saving Social Security
description: When Congress returns for the final phase of its 1977 session, opportunity still will existinbut just barelyinfor drastic action to improve the pending Social Security legislation. As they stand now, bills passed by both houses to keep Social Security solvent for the rest of this century will also force sharp periodic tax increases through the next decade, exert upward pressure on the price level and dampen buying power during the same period, possibly worsen the unemployment situation and still not solve the system's basic longinterm problem.

title: Maximizing Mortgages, Minimizing Risks
description: Redliningina banking practice that marks out large sections of cities as unsuitable for mortgage loans on any terms whateverinhas generated a national controversy. On one side are urban residents, community groups and local government officials, who blame alleged redlining for the decline of neighborhoods, particularly those where minority groups live. On the other side are the bankers, who argue that geographical location is never the only factor in judging a mortgage, but that a longterm mortgage corrunitment to a distressed area is the kind of risk they must avoid unless the borrower unusually sound.

title: Galbraith's Choice: The Seven Wonders of the Modern World
description: I must begin this piece with more than the allowed number of disclaimers. The most important is that I have never been to Egypt, the Cairo airport apart. My list also excludes natural flora, fauna and waterfalls, the economics of Milton Friedman and the last rites of Elvis Presley. It is confined, in other words, to architectural wonders. It also occurred to me as an economist that I might combine my wonderswhich can easily be doneand thus save on travel costs. Finally, I am excluding the things that nowadays one sees anyway.

title: A Rash of Revivals
description: No wonder the nation's exhibitors are gnashing their teeth and crying huge, heartfelt tears. When their theaters are not pitchindark, they are frequently halfempty or playing nervous host to shoddy pornographers, thanks to an alarming paucity of fresh fare from the major studios. Yet, not every theater manager has been crippiea ny tnis snortage of product. In New York, for example, there is a handful of enterprising buffs who have managed to turn a passion for old movies to a thriving new business. Uptown, the Regency, one of the younger revival houses, has been jamming its aisles with the fans of early Hepburn, Crawford and Davis andstarting Dec. 4the theater will reverberate with the golden sounds of Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy. Meanwhile, down  the Village, the Bleecker Street will serve its public painterly view of life, today and tomorrow, with a double bill of John Huston's Moul Rougestarring Jose Ferrer as ToulouseLautrecand Vcente Mnelli's Lust for Life, with Kirk Douglas giving his ear for his art as Vcent van Gogh. On Tuesday, when the Bleecker Street's feature attraction will be John Ford's Stagecoach, there will be a bonusinfor serial freaksthree chapters of Dick Tracy and two of Buck Rogers. Other reminders of Hollywood's heyday which will be on view during the coming week are shown on this.

description: COLONI A, Yap. title: The Museum Director's Dilemma
description: PURCHASE THE image of the museum director has dramatically changed in the last few decades. He is no longer an individual solely with an. expertise in the art of the past. He must also be aware of contemporary artistic activities. He is no longer como mitted to an elite few who come to his ino stitation to contemplate beauty. He now has.an allegiance to educate the public at large in the arts. Beyond that, the director must be a show organizer, an acquisition specialist, a fund raiser, a staff arbitrator and an administrator who can juggle finances, bureaucracy and personalities.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26Last July, homeowner  Birmingham, Ala., went to his attic to examine some new sulation, taking with him a mechanic's extension light. While he was looking at the sulation, which had been sold to him as fireresistant, the extension light set it on fire.

title: A Prorlamation
description: Time out of mind at this turn of the seasons when the ardy oak leaves rustle in the wind and the frost gives tang to the air and the dusk falls early and the friendly evenings lengthen under the heel of Orion, it has seemed good to our people to join together in praising the Creator and Preserver, who has brought us by a way that we did not know to the end of another year. In observance 1 this custom, I appoint Thursday, the 26th of November, as day of Public Thanksgiving for the blessings that have been our common lot and have placed our beloved State with the favored regions of earth4or all the creature comforts : the yield of the soil that has fed us and the richer yield from labor of every kind that has sustained our livesinand for all those things, as dear as breath to the body, that quicken man's faith in his manhood, that nourish and strengthen his word and act; for honor held above price; for steadfast courage and zeal in the long, long search after truth; for liberty and for justice freely granted by each to his fellow and so as freely enjoyed; and for the crowning glory and mercy of peace upon our land ;that we may humbly take heart of these blessings as we gather once again with solemn and festive rites to our Harvest Home.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS,
description: Modern biology consists of two great enterprises. One, molecular and cellular biology, is concerned with the machinery of life. Its goal is to explain the ways in which cells, tissues, and organs are constructed out of molecular building blocks and run by chemical energy. This is the increasingly familiar biology of viruses, genes, cancer research, and recombinant DNA.

title: Joseph Durso
description: Tls the season, so why beat around the bush? Our nomination for athlete of the year is the 17yearinold secretaryintreasurer of the Kentucky conglomerate called Steve Cauthen Associates.

description: Chris Smith's recent letter on abortions is typical of the compulsory pregnancy groups that insist on calling fetus an infant and that refuse to admit that their beliefs are religious ones that they try to impose on all of us.

title: I. JACK MESSINGER
description: I. Jack Messinger, a lawyer, died of cancer Monday at the Baptist Hospital Miami. He was 68 years old and lived Miami and New York.

title: WHY LAETRILE WON'T GO AWAY
description: The Senate Health and Scientific Research Subcommittee, chaired by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, seemed to generate an unusual air of excitement when it gathered last summer. For one thing, more than the usual number of reporters and TV crews were on hand, more than the usual number of uniformed guards were at the door, and, indeed, more than the usual number of spectators filled the small meeting room. The subject under discussion was the now wellinpublicized illicit anticancer chemical Laetrile (pronounced LAYuhintrill), an extract of the lowly apricot pit. The event could have been called the Great Confrontation  the Cancer EstablishHealers.

title: Evangelista Stops Coopman in First Round
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 26 (AP)The European heavyweight boxing champion, Alfredo Evangelista of Spain, retained his title tonight, knocking out JeanPierre Coopman of Belgium in the first round.

description: IS THAT woods or marsh part of corporation's headquarters, or is a nature preserve? That depends on ones point of view, because in New Jersey it is often both at once.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 (UPI) Mihajlo Mihajlov, a Yeugoslav dissident freed from prison under a national amnesty, says he is ready to return to jail rather than stop criticizing the regime of President Tito. Mihajlov, Yugoslavia's bestinknown political prisoner, was released yesterday  the amnesty marking the country's national day next Tuesday.

title: SELECTION
description: BY around seveninthirty the party is usually in full swing, surging back and forth between the long black, beige and brown dining room and the large black, beige, brown and gold living room, between the bar and the buffet and the author and his idolizers, a crowd of a hundred or more, gathered this winter night in the publisher's elegant fourinstory East Side townhouse to celebrate the appearance of yet another volume bearing the imprint Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

description: Medical care of higher quality and lower cost could be achieved through the use of computers to store and retrieve patient records, but such gains are not likely to be achieved unless the Government adopts new policies to control the development of such systems, a report by the Office of Technology Assessment has concluded.

description: To guide readers of this column who are terested buying a new color enlarger  the near future, this writer spent a few weeks recently testing and evaluat ing the most widely available models.

description: Striking iron ore workers at the Eveleth Taconite Company  northern Mnesota rejected last night a proposal that would have ended a 17week strike. It was the first such rejection after a string of acceptances by other locals of the United Steelworkers of America.

title: Talk With John McPhee
description: JOHN McPHEE and I are sitting in his office above the main street of Princeton, N.J. Maps of Alaska line the walls, and his handwritten notebooks, containing 5060,000 words on Alaska, are wrapped in twine on the bookshelves. McPhee, who is handsome, lean, muscular and bearded, has been writing all day. His intensity, generally noticeable, seems nearer the surface this evening. He fidgets as he talks.

title: KOCH HOLDING TALKS ON STAFF SELECTION
description: Mayorinelect Edward I. Koch yesterday began a series of weekend meetings with prospective appointees for the halfindozen posts as deputy mayor  his coming administration, and aides said he would announce some of his selections by midweelc.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Let me confess at the outset that I am a fan of Ian Watson's. His previous novels, The Embedding and The Jonah Kit, were distinguished by an irresistible blend of narrative energy and intellectual interest. It is not often that books dealing seriously with the nature of language and consciousness also offer suspenseful, fastinmoving plots and a cast of eccentric yet affecting characters. If these earlier novels had a common flaw, it was that Watson did not know when to stop: too many concepts, too many characters, too much plot. Before the reader had a chance to assimilate one scene he was being hustled on to the next.

title: HE SAYS HE'S ONEZERO, BUT COURT IS UNCONVINCED
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 26 (AP)At time when many people compla of losing their identities to a long string of numbers, Michael Herbert Dengler is waging a legal fight to be called 1069.

title: East Hampton Issue: Guns for Auxiliaries
description: EAST HAMPTON THE 16man police force that regularly provides law and order in this resort village, which has a yearinround population of 3,000, will soon be augmented by a corps of auxiliary police officers, and the question of whether to arm them has divided the community.

description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH FOR the first time in nearly 10 years, the 45 families living along Peters Lane here will soon be drinking from an unpolluted water supply.

title: Queen Victoria's Angel
description: THE tragedy of Prince Albert was one that he shared with many famous men. He was not fully appreciated until after his death. The point was well put in December 1861 by a young lordling known as Hartyintarty (Lord Hartington) to his mistress, Skittles, residing in Paris: Everybody here is very sorry about poor Prince Albert, though they did not seem to be very fond of him when he was alive; but he is a great loss now.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP)Ken Rosewall of Australia and Billie Jean King of the United States won semifinal matches today in the $125,000 Gunze tennis tournament at the Aoyama Gakuen University gymnasium.

title: Vertical Takeoff Jet For Marines Faces A Denial of Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)The Marine Corps is  danger of losing budget funds for a crashinplagued vertical takeoff jet it considers the battlefield bomber of the future, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Phoebe Montgomery to Wed
description: The engagement of Phoebe Sands Montgomery to Dr. Mark Bolton Moeller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Dade W. Moeller of Bedford, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Rodman B. Montgomery Jr, and Mrs. Reese Evans Howard, both of New York. A winter wedding is planned.

title: Informers for I.R.S. Paid Average of $744
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service says that during the last three years 114,667 people have volunteered formation about Income tax cheats and $1,052,550 was paid out fnr the tips, an average of $744.38 to each former.

title: Polish Coloring Book Aims to Help Children Understand Their Culture
description: [DETROIT, Nov. 26 (UPI)If someone asks if you've heard about the Polish coloring book, don't wait for the punch line. It's not a joke.

title: Sailorg Have New Game on L.I. Sound
description: In an attempt to stem the decline in yacht racing on Long Island Sound and also to lure the weekend sailor, a new dimension will be added to racing on the Sound next springinperformance handicapping. And it will be a newNews of Boating ball game, for the owner of an older boat. There were a large number of cruising boats on the Sound, boats three to five years old whose designs no longer made them competitive under the International Offshore.Rule and the Midget Ocean Racing Club's rule, said Pete Jackson, a member of the distance and rules committee of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

title: TV: Token Coverage of the Election?
description: IN THE aftermath of the New Jersey gubernatorial primary last June, the New York television stations were severely criticized for keeping voters in the dark and failing to cover the election. A monitoring of Manhattan TV stations for the week prior to the primary election disclosed that most of them provided token coverage or none at all.

title: The Music And the Man
description: MANY musicians feel about Paul Hindemith's music as he felt about the model railway that occupied three rooms in his prewar Berlin apartment: We had a timetable, and trains had to run on schedule, otherwise we would have collisions. In othgr words, they feel that his music is a wellinorganized universe with prescribed, mechanical rules, all tonal, which kept the system functioning in immaculate order. No sudden departures, no collisions, no original tracks.

title: Commentary: A former staff member examines restructuring and asks, Why hurry?
description: Calls for the restructuring of the securities markets have become commonplace; hardly a week passes without some Congressional leader, academic or securities dustry spokesman endorsing some form of electronic communications system for executing trades  listed securities, The subject will be Topic A at the meeting of the Securities Industry Association starting Tuesday  Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Cooking For the Seamstress
description: In Esperanza, in northern Ecuador4 there is only one place to stay. At Cis4 Aida a tourist pays 75 cents to sleep in a single bed in a room with four other beck; and four other tourists. The sign ot41front says, Casa Aida, Vegetariaij Meals. Aida's clientele is mostly American backpackers with vegetarian preferences, and since vegetables are less expensive than meat, Aida is happy to oblige.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Aldous Huxley described man as an intelligence in servitude to his organs. Dr. Elisabeth KublerRoss, a medical pioneer in the field of the way human beings die, is attempting to bring under standing and faith to the process so that the mind dominates to the very end.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The sale this month to a Saudi Arabian millionaire of the Wildenste's spectacular collection of 18thincentury French furniture, has refocused attention on such palaceinquality antiques, designs that many mistakenly thought had declined so dramatically  popularity, they would never recover.

title: GARDENING
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y. DOES a catalpa tree with exquisite large clusters of pink flowers appeal to you? What about a cherry tree bearing fruits in 20 colors, ranging from yellow through shades of orange and red to deep black?

title: Where Life Begins Over
description: ALASKA is touted as our last frontier, and actually is that. Fewer people live in it than in Denver. A boy born there can grow to be a man in the old trueinblue fashion. A man coming into the country as a settler can lose his life almost instantly through the ice, or get lost in the summer woods, or otherwise meet with quick grief. His fate is mostly determined by the qualities of sense and stamina and character that he brought with him to the state, which is why so many of its best residents did not arrive in their first youth. They had been seasoned in World War II or during the Great Depression. They had experienced some weathering in Minnesota, Texas or Korea, perhaps had fallen painfully on their noses in a marriage that failed or, after making a fool of themselves in some previous career, had determined not to fall into a pattern of doing that.

title: A Calling to Help
description: WILL CAMPBELL'S memoir is really two books in one, and what is so remarkable that both of them are so good. The first is the story of the intense, rewarding and ultimately heartbreaking friendship between Campbell and his older brother, Joe. The second is the story of how Campbell, a poor white boy from Mississippi who at an early age was called to the Southern Baptist ministry, later was called to the cause of civil rights and has been fighting for it ever since, often in chilling circumstances.

title: Thanksgiving Thieves Get Gems and Turkey
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 26 (AP)As if haying $5,000  jewelry stolen wasn't enough to ru an Amherst couple's Thanksgiving Day, the couple discovered when they walked to their kitchen yesterday thieves had also made off with their turkey.

title: Martinelli Gets His Second Chance
description: YONKERS ALTHOUGH Angelo R. Martinelli has been Mayor of Yonkers since y973, there has never really been what one might call a Martinelli administration in the state's fourth largest city.

title: Caucuses: A Trend Born  Politics, Spreads to Special Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)Not so long ago, when a member of the House said that he was going to the caucus, you knew he meant the general meeting of his Democratic colleagues. Republicans call their equivalent meeting a conference.

title: County Planners Chart an Enigmatic Future
description: TODAY, Westchester County is changing, building, abandoning, paving, preserving, moving in, and leaving behind, and each one of these tiny currents of activity trails through the offices of the County Department Planning, leaving numbers and momentary clues about the enigma that is unraveling outside. The lifetimes of almost a million peopleapartment dwellers, homeowners, commuters, students and the elderlyare flickering. within the boundaries this enigma, a 450squareinmile funnel with roughly 9,000 acres working farmland, 53 square miles of cities, vast reaches smallintown quiet and 80 miles of coastline.

title: Hartford Opens Office Abroad for Business
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 26 (UPI)A fulltime office  Brussels has been opened by the State of Connecticut to attract foreign vestors, according to Gov. Ella T. Grasso.

title: Poll Fds More Liberal Beliefs on Marriage and Sex Roles, Especially Amonointhe Young
description: Americans are more likely to believe that marriages  which the partners share the tasks of breadwinner and homemaker are a more sat'sfying way of life than they are to prefer the traditional marriage  which the husband is exclusively a provider and the wife exclusively a homemaker and mother, according to a New York TimesCBS News nail.

title: Tough Decisions Facing the. S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Roberta Karmel, the newest and first woman member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, weighs her words carefully. Judiciously. Somewhat circumspect by nature, she is particularly hesitant to express a personal opinion that might divulge the secret deliberations of the commission.

title: Helane Levine Wed To Michael Keating
description: Michael F. Keating, an associate professor of English at the City College of New York, and Helane Caryl Levine, a college structor, were married yesterday evening  the Promenade Cafe at Rockefeller Center by Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz of Temple Beth Or  Washaton Township. N.J.

description: Bill Koenig showing children how to make applesauce the Pelham Art Center. On Saturday the center will offer makeinainpresent workshops.

title: Associated Press
description: THE BEST LAM SCHEMES  Chicago's oldest house, the Henry B. Clarke house, built  1836, is being transported to a new site where it will be stored. But first the twoinstory structure will have to be moved past a bridge of the city's elevated transit system. The mover tends to jack the house up, hoist it across and lower it to the other side.

title: GARDENING
description: IF you are under 25, you may never have experienced the majesty that once was the American elm. To be certain, there are a few still around. But this isn't the leafy canopy that once covered village and thoroughfare in the East and Midwest and provided natural airinconditioning against the heat of summer.

title: BLACKS' RIFT HELPED G.O.P. IN CHARLOTTE
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 26Next Friday Kenneth Rhyne Harris is to become the first Republican  memory to serve as the Mayor of Charlotte, a city of 300,000 people that calls itself a little Atlanta and takes pride  its status as the banking and textile capital of the Carolinas.

title: NUCLEAR HARDWARE IN MICRONESIA
description: When the United States gained control of Micronesia after World War II, we were obliged  consistent with our assertion that we had fought the war for no territorial gain to put the islands under United Nations trusteeship. But under pressure from the Pentagon, we insisted on having the islands designated a Strategic Area, which gave the United States the right to build military bases in Micronesia. Moreover, because it was a strategic trust, we became responsible not to the General Assembly, as with other trust territories (of the 11 that were set up after World War II, Micronesia is the only remaining one), but to the Security Council, where we have a veto.

title: Rising Water Table Poses A New Woe for Homeowners
description: WHEN he went houseinhunting on the South Shore recently, Irwin H. Kantrowitz had an unusual requirement. Most Long Islanders would find a basement a desirable feature, but he was looking for house without one. Since Mr. Kantrowitz is a hydrologist in charge of the Water Resources Division of the United States Geological Survey on the Island, he knew then what homeowners on the South Shore are now discovering with alarminthat anyone living there faces the likelihood a flooded basement when it rains, and at other times, too.

title: Education or Entertainment?
description: NEVER have I had difficulties. accepting money, even on the rare occasions when I have been overpaid. But the $275 (before taxes) that came in the mail from my employers, Hofstra University, a couple of weeks ago stuck in my metaphorical craw. Spending it will be difficult, so I have decided on something both symbolic and useless: a bisque porcelain dormouse. Doctor's bills and insurance premiums can wait.

title: Max Neuhaus Music Made Especially for Times Square
description: just south of the statue of Father Duffy at 96th Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue is a large subway grating on a pedestrian island. If you walk over it, you will hear a steady sound, not unlike that of conch shell held up to the ear. If you stand still for a long enough time, you will notice that the sound changes gradually and subtly.

title: Deaths
description: ADLMANRuth M. Beloved wife of the late William C. Loving mother of Edward, Arthur. and Beverly. Dearest grandmother of William. Fred, and Robert. Darling greatingrandmother of Cara. Jill, and Even. Private services were held Friday, November 25, 1977. Interment Mount Ararat Cemetery.

description: Only lie SOphiSticated are naive enough to believe that George Balanchine is not. waving the nag  Stara and Stripes,. a Bicentennial ballet he Composed 18.years ahead of time.

title: Teacher Returns Safely to Ohio After Reported 12Day Abduction
description: MIDDLEBURG HEIGHTS, Ohio, Nov. 26 (AP)  A Middleburg Heights school teacher returned home today after being rescued from a man, now accused as kidnapper, who took her to Florida a sack and held her captive for 12 days, apparently planning to set up housekeeping with her, the police said.

title: More Momentum
description: Surprise, surprise. AfterAnwar elSadat's sensational visit to Jerusalem, the next move toward achieving peace in the Middle East seemed to be up to the Israelis. But, with his usual flair for the unexpected, yesterday the Egyptian President announced a second, equally daring initiative. He invited the Middle East belligerents and their greatinpower patrons to go to Cairo as of next Saturday to discuss preparations for a Geneva conference.

title: South Americans In U. S. Said to Run Shoplifting Gangs
description: Every morning at about 9 o'clock as many as 50 Chilean nationals gather  a 24hour restaurant  Manhattan's Washington Heights and, over coffee, talk about business. Their business takes them on the road and they notify each other of where they will be working so they won't cover the same territory.

title: Engineers brief High Court on the Hazards of Bidding
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 26 (UPI)The Supreme Court, having entered another battle volving feeinsetting by the learned professions, is getting a crash course  engineering.

title: FILM VIEW
description: For weeks before the first public showings of Steven Spielberg's new scienceinfiction spectacle, Close Encounters of the Third Kd, the common stock of Columbia Pictures Industries, the company that has vested more than $18,000,000  the movie, was climbing  a lunatic way that would give serious market vestor. From a year's low 73/8, the value of the stock climbed to a high of 193/8 a aay before the film's premiere. On the day the film opened, my office telephone was ringing  a way it hadn't since the circulation of the last rumor about James Dean that he was alive and well selling postcards at the Miami Seaquarium. Only one the callers was a movieinnutina hysterical young man who wanted to make sure that  my review of Close Encounters, which was to run the next day, I didn't tell him everything that happens  the last 30 minutes of the movie. He'd already seen the movie, he said, and the experience had been seriously damaged because someone on another publication had given him a minute description of the film's climax. He told me firmly that he didn't want that to happen when went back to see the film aga (because, I assume, he has the gift of total forgetfulness).

title: State Workers Seek The Right to Strike
description: FOR the last 10 years, the 375,000 employees of state and local governments in New Jersey have had the right to organize and have their unions negotiate contracts for them. But they have not had the right to strike, and many of them, especia Ily teachers, are getting restless.

title: New Mideast Strategy
description: PARISAlthough President Sadat changed the entire Middle Eastern mood by his bold visit to Jerusalem, he made it clear to Prime Minister Begin and Foreign Minister Dayan that the Arabs retain the option to resume war so long as Israel occupies territory they claim.

title: The World
description: Pater montns of promising an internal solution to Rhodesia's racial troubles, Ian D. Smith has offered one which sounds plausibleelections on the basis of one man, one vote. The concession has long been sought by Rhodesia's black majority, but, as usual with Mr. Smith, there was catch. He said that he was willing to negotiate a settlement only with black leaders who have renounced terrorism, thus effectively precluding negotiations with the leaders of guerrillas fighting his regime.

title: 3 Cities Given Grants for Centers For Mediation of Mor Disputes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has announced grants to three cities for neighborhood centers designed to provide an avenue to justice for many persons now shut out of the legal system.

title: ExNominee Facing Charges  Election Gets Federal Post
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)A formerSan Francisco Supervisor whose nomination to a key Interior Department post was withdrawn by the Carter Administration is biding his time  another. Government job while fighting charges of election irregularities.

title: To Ierusalem
description: Hoteliers in the Holy City expect President Anwar elSadat's sensational visit to spark another tourist boom. They recalled that Secretary of State Henry Kissinger's much publicized shuttle between Cairo and Jerusalem ended the tourist slump that followed the sixinday war of 1973.

title: Going Straight
description: Revelationin his skin magazines, Hustler and Chichas brought a certain notoriety to publisher Larry Flynt. Goodbye to all that, Mr. Flynt said last week. After several talks with Ruth Stapleton Carter, the President's evangelist sister, Mr. Flynt has decided he has been convicted sin by the Lord and that he's going to clean up his magazines. Sex, he says, will be dealt with only in a healthy manner. Because the magazines are printed well in advance, it may be several months before readers notice the difference, however.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THERE are times when a section of a plaster ceiling or wall is rotten and crumbly, possibly because of water damage, and a sizable patch is needed. Often even the fairly skilled doinitinyourselfer is afraid to tackle the job. To reinplaster he would have to nail up lath, then apply several coats of plaster, and finally smooth out the last coat.

description: Georgian Gems

title: Panthers' Conversion in Waning Seconds a HalfYard Short
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26Penn State won the right today to say, We told you so, and We should be in the Orange Bowl, when the Nittany Lions held on by the margins of 12 seconds and a halfinyard to beat Pittsburgh, 1513, in one of the most thrilling of the 77 games between these Keystone State rivals.

title: STORMSBATTER AREAS OF EAST AND MIDWEST
description: High winds blew windows out of office towers yesterday  Denver and Boulder, Colo., and Thanksgiving holiday travelers In the East and Midwest faced slippery roadways and hazardous driving conditions as a pair of storms brought frigid weather to much of the nation.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The modern wanderyear is a cutinandindried affair, with student hostels waiting to receive the upintoindate Wilhelm Meister, with paperback guides advising him, in unromantic terms, on how to see Europe on five, sorry, ten aollars a day, and with cheap rail passes speeding this cosseted youth from one patented threeinstar site to another. In his day, which was the mid1930's, Patrick Leigh Fermor ordered his rambles differently. He walked from the Dutch coast to the Balkans, without precise itinerary, and, when he confronted newinfledged Nazi Germany or a vanishingly faint country lane in Hungary, his only guide was Horace in the Loeb edition. Innately (perhaps excessively) literate, Leigh Fermor kept assiduous notebooks, which he offers here, converted into a prose of preening but often magnificent richness. Visiting the great baroque German shrines in winter, he effused: Sunlight flared in the lintels and the broken pediments, and streamed in over the snowy sill. so close to the ceilings that they gave a last lift to the trompel'oeil Ascensions and Transfigurations as they poured across them and quickened the white and cream wreaths of stucco that held them aloft: garlands doubly etherealized by the reverberated radiance of the snowflakes and composed of all that reed and palminleaf and tendril and scallop and conch and the spines of murex can in

description: Black Timman

The Rev. James A. Gay performed the ceremony.

title: Cortland State in Final
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 26 (AP)Cortland State beat the host team Babson, 10, on penalty kicks today and gained the N.C.A.A. Division III soccer final against Lock Haven (Pa.) State tomorrow.

title: ES. ABORTION PANEL DISBANDED BY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The head of the Carter Administration's study group an alternatives to abortion has disbanded the group after concluding that the only real alternatives are suicide, motherhood and, some would add, madness.

title: MAYORELECT SEEKS FOUNDATION MONEY
description: Edward I. Koch's transklct team seeking money from taxinexempt foundations to pay its expenses during the weeks before it can use city funds.

title: Alouettes Are Grey Cup Favorites
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (AP)The Montreal Alouettes are 3point favorites over the Edmonton Eskimos in tomorrow's Grey Cup game. But that means the betting fraternity regards the Canadian Football League final as little more than a tossup, since a field goal is the advantage usually awarded for home field.

title: Last King of France
description: MONARCHS rarely write memoirs. The recent British kings have kept diaries, but they are so banal and so grittily formal that no one has ever suggested that they should be given the dignity of print. The publication of these memoirs of LouisPhilippe, who was King of France from 183048, is, therefore, something of an event. He lived an extremely adventurous life. He was son of the Duc d'Orleans, Philippe EgalitO, who threw in his lot with the Revolution and ended under the guillotine. LouisPhilippe got out of Franc'e in time to save his own life and traveled extensively in Europe and America, trying to live as anonymously as possible, waiting for Time to do its work with the Revolution. He was know exile many times and, indeed, to die in it after being toppled from his throne by the Revolution 1848. But he had his successes and his fame. He was the last king of France, the citizen King who tried reconcile the bourgeois, great and small, to the idea constitutional monarchy, and he nearly succeeded.

title: DOOM ENDS
description: After 17 years in publishing during which he worked for houses large and small, ending up as editor in chief of Dial Press, Richard Marek had a hankering for autonomy, so when the opportunity arose to have his own imprint within the G.P.PutnamBerkleyCoward, McCann Geoghegan complex (which is owned by MCA, an entertainment conglomerate), he took it. He was risking the security of his job with Dial, but in exchange he was enabled, in efThct; to set up his own publishing house without financial risk to himselfan offer a number upperinechelon editors are finding it hard to refuse these days. The idea of being his own boss was so important to Mr. Marek that the negotiations over salary and percentages of profit's took about 30 seconds, he said, speaking hyperbolically, but working out the contractual limits of his autonomy took a couple of months of haggling (the main limitation is ceiling on the amount he can bid for a book). Anyhow, now he's Richard Marek Books, with a list of 30 titles scheduled next year (one of which has already been sold to a paperback house for $300,000), including novels by Robert Ludlum and Richard Condon, whom he edited at Dial.

title: STAGE VIEW

Not an outline of the dramatic structure, mind you; I'm not using the word metaphorically. mean the kind of map that would get you where you were going if something vital was at stake and the whole world hurry.

title: ART VIEW
description: NEW HAVEN Hazlitt,  his Lectures on The English Comic Writers, distinguishes three categories or degrees of the laughable. The first and most obvious cause of laughter, he writes, is to be found  the simple succession of events, as  the sudden shifting of a disguise, or some unlookedfor accident, without any absurdity of charactet or situation. Of the second category he observes: The ludicrous where there is the same contradiction between tne object ana our expectations, heightened by some deformity or convenience, that is, by its being contrary to what is customary desirable. And of the third categoryThe ridiculous, which is the highest form of the laughablehe writes that is that which is contrary not only to custom but to sense and reason, or is a voluntary departure from what we have a right to expect from those who are conscious of absurdity and propriety  words, looks and actions.

title: Roman Comedy
description: YOU can find the beginning of this delightful and preposterous love story, if that's what it is, Niccolo Tucci's first Englishinlanguage novel, Before My Time (1962). It says there that Leonardo Claudi and Mary von Randen met and fell in love the museum in Naples in I893spying each other through the glass of a display case containing an ancient Greek vase. Leonardo was a poor medical student from southern Italy, who had given up his literary studies to support his family. Mary was a 15yearinold blond and pale apparition from the fabulous North, daughter of a wealthy Russian widow. They saw each other only three times after the first meeting, but did manage to tell each other: You are my sun and without you I am nothing.  Then they were found out by Mary's tyrantinmother, the grande dame Sophie, who whisked her daughter away from Naples forever. But, the story went, the lovers remained true to each other in their hearts.

title: Fashion
description: The word Paris still means Fashion to women everywhere. What happens there at collection times, such as last month's pret a porter showings for spring and summer 78, sends tremors and telegrams of news to the rest of the interested world. Actually, there are groups of equally creative designers in New York, Milan and, sometimes, in London, and most of them are on the same wavelength. But that magic name of Paris cryStallizes the fashion of the moment and gives it the stamp of approval. What Paris designers are now advocating with their usual panache and unique flair is what designers in Milan and New York are also saying: The clothes for 1 978 should celebrate the body that's underneath them. The fabrics are light, semiinopaque or sheer  even if they're wool or knit; the silhouettes are loose, caught in somewhere with a sash or belt, but moving on the body in an unfettered way. Last month, as one Paris collection after another rolled by, the sight, or sense, of breasts beneath these clothes became so commonplace it ceased to be the sensation it might have been a season ago. In fact, it was often obvious that the models had nothing on under these new clothes and, while this did stir some special appreciation, it did not seem offensive or vulgar  just natural and in the character of today's fashion which is attractive and wholesomely sexy. What is significant is that this freed body fashion is evident in the clothes of all designers  from the avantingardists to the established, worldinknown design names such as Dior, Givenchy and Ungaro. Each does it in his own way, but there is no question about the direction they are all taking. But what does this mean to us  the real women of the world who are not endowed with the gorgeous bodies of fashion models, and who have occasional lumps and bumps in the wrong places? What the new fashion is saying is Take a whole new look at yourself. Celebrate your body and do away with anything that stiffly confines it. Here are highlights from the collections of some of Paris's most important designers, each of whom took an individual approach toward celebrating and enhancing  the freedom of the body.

title: Alice Franklin Married to H. James Caulkins
description: Alice Abell Frankl of New Vernon, N.J., and H. James Caulkins of Somerville, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's home by Mayor W. Thomas Margetts of Harding Township. N.J.

title: LETTERS
description: A Letter to Brezhnev (by Boris Rabbot, Nov. 6) could have been addressed to almost any Russian head of state Soviet leader or czar  over the past 900 years. The conditions Rabbot cites have been part of the Russian political landscape for centuries: constant intrigue within the ruling hierarchy, censorship, antiSemitism, abuses by the secret police, an excessive military budget, promotion of unworthy individuals to high posts, dependence on Western technology and suspicion of Western ideas. Why is this so? The tragic but unavoidable conclusion is that the Russian people, as a whole, prefer a dictatorship, with all of its abuses, to the anarchy they fear would follow the establishment of democratic institutions. Unfortunately, this preference for an authoritarian form of government is so deeply embedded in the Russian psyche that it probably will not disappear during our.

Alone among painters now active on the mainland of Europe, he can take the classic modes of Euro pean painting and excel  every one of.them. He can paint landscape. He can paint still life. He can paint the nude. He can paint portraits. He can paint teriors with figures. His paintings, once seen, are rarely forgotten.

title: U.S. Steel Reports E.P.A. Accord On Plans for a $3.5 Billion Mill
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (AP)  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Steel Corporation have settled their environmental differences over a proposed $3.5 billion steel mill, according to a company spokesman. Disagreements between the Federal agency and the company had stalled completion of an environmental impact study on the plant proposed for 3,000 acres of land spanning the OhioPennsylvania border near Conneaut, Ohio.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The island republic of Trinidad and Tobago, a few miles off the coast of Venezuela, has aga issued an 8piece proof set of their legal tender coins. This has been an annual event since the first set of this size was released  1972 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of their dependence. Once aga their national bird, the scarlet ibis, will grace the $5 sterling silver piece. (This bird weighs only two pounds but has a wingspread of 40 ches. It is slightly smaller than the blackinandinwhite sacred ibis of Egypt.) The high value  the set, the $10 co, also  sterling, has a less exciting design: a map of the area with tiny depictions of a porpoise, a marl, and a sailing vessel on a field of ripples meant to represent the trade winds.

title: The Medical Examiner Examined
description: As an anecdotalist the late Dr. Milton Helpern could be both amusing and instructive. I interviewed him a number of times when I was doing research, some years ago, for a book about Bellevue Hospital. Dr. Helpern, who died last April, was a tenacious medical examiner (20 years the Chief M.E. of New York), a respected pathologist and an expert witness sometimes for the prosecution, sometimes for the defensein many celebrated murder trials here and abroad. The identification by his publisher on the book jacket as The World's Greatest Medical Detective, while perhaps not subtle, is probably accurate.

title: U.S.A.F. IN EUROPE TESTS SOCIAL VISITS IN BARRACKS
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany Nov. 26 (AP)The United States Air Force  Europe has agreed to a 90day trial period for a plan under which men and women enlisted personnel will be allowed to visit each other  their dormitories. It said the trial period would give personnel the opportunity to prove they are mature enough to enjoy the privilege.

title: L.I.R.R. Riders Get A Holiday Reprieve
description: DESPITE the usual delays, the 150,000 daily riders of the Long Island Rail Road can expect relatively uninterrupted service and good will, if not peace, between labor and management during the holiday season, and no fare increase in the new year.

title: How the Smithtown Democrats Did
description: THE defeat of the powerful Smithtown Republican organization by a political newcomer, Patrick J. Vecchio, the new Supervisorinelect of Smithtown, provided a classic example of a candidate, an issue and an organization converging at the right time and the right place.

title: !Behind China's Quiet Facade Are Squabbles, New Purges
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 26Behind a facade of unity and economic recovery, some Chinese leaders seem to be engaged once aga  a practice that has bedeviled Communist politics over much of the past decadesettling accounts. For WestNotes ern analysts confined to the diplomatic enclave On Peking or to this listening China post on China's coast, it isnot easy to gauge the magnitude of the latest round of purges, as signs of squabbles among ranking leaders, over personal if not policy differences, keep surfacing.

title: LEGISLATOR DENIES PLANS TO CLOSE SOME HOSPITALS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI)4Ilaying fears among communities with small hospitals, Representative Paul G. Rogers says new Government health planning guidelines will not force the closinginof any hospital.

title: What's Needed Is More Water Policy, Not More Water
description: Next to energy no dwindling resource is attracting more attention in the United States than water: droughts, floods, dams breaking, controversies over new dams, flood control, farm acreage limitation. The headlines go on and on.

title: DANCE VIEW

About the economic circumstances underlying their existencethe gritty subtext to the guiltedge vitationsand why people gave them and, best of all, why people went to them. What delicious mixing God and mammon these festivities provide. Enough  this is not the time, place or room for even the smallest book. Galas, and their expos, must wait.

title: Low Asks Doubling Of Plan to Replace A gedW ater Mains
description: Because of an crease  the number of breaks  water mains that are more than 100 years old and a subsequent rise  damage claims, New York City should double its waterinma replacement program, Robert A. Low, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday.

title: The Nation
description: From the start, it has been evident that if there is to be a national energy program the President and Congress must employ that familiar midwife of legislation, the compromise. Last week, Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger made that obvious point and for the first time suggested possible areas of Administration tradeinoffs. For his trouble, he got only more trouble.

description: CAIRO, Nov. 26 (AP)Following are excerpts from President Anwar elSadat's address to the Egyptian Parliament on the Middle East situation as translated from the Arabic by the Egyptian state radio.

title: Goya Painting to Be Sold
description: MADRID, Nov. 26 (Reuters)For the first time  Spa, a. painting by the 18thcentury Spanish master Goya has been put up for auction. The Duran Gallery  Madrid said today it would auction tho work, St. Anthony of Padua, on Dec. 20

title: Roving Beat
description: SIDNEY BERNARDthe Bronx kid, El Sid, gray longlocks of a roving editor, and just plain roving are names he gives himself in his writingsis the freeinest lance in New York journalism. El Sid broke into the business in the late 1940's in a conventional way, as a rewrite man and reporter on the lobster shift (the lateinnight beat), covering Drooklyn police news out of a shack opposite Brooklyn Police Headquarters for the Standard News Association, a wire service that covered neighborhood and borounh news for local and Westchester papers. When the S.N.A. folded, Bernard, still conventional, began writing for Sunday supplements and assumed the role, as he says, of pastmaster (and partintime) flackcopy writer for Restaurant Associates and others, contributor to raunch mags like Dude, Gent, Nugget and Rogue. But about a dozen years ago Bernard began declining all assignments from editors, and now he covers only whatever happens to appeal to him. His beat is the New York literary scene, for the most parta press conference for a Nobel laureate, the founding convention of Cosmep (The Committee of Small Magazines, Editors and Publishers), National Book Award bashes, poetry readings at St. Mark'sinintheBouweriemixed with some coverage of local politics, pulse readings in bars like the Lion's Head Sheridan Square or Phebe's on the Bowery, serious browsing in serious bookstores like the New Yorker, the Eighth Street and the Gotham, and occasional forays to London, California, New Orleans and Madison, Wis. Bernard will spend months shaping an account of one of the events on his beat and then mail his essay, unsolicited, to a number of smaller and larger magazines. If an editor likes the piece he buys it, and Bernard always finds enough buyers to make a living. O.K.!

title: Iran Gains World Cup
description: Iran win represent Asia in tne final round of the World Cup in Argentina next June. The Iranians reached soccer's premier event for the first time by edging Australia, 10, Friday in Teheran's Aryamehr Stadium, packed News of Soccer by 95,000 fans who Mebrated the country's qualification with singing and dancing.

title: Passage to India
description: In the year 627, during the reign of the great Tang emperor Taiintsung, a learned monk named Hsuanintsang (596664) undertook a hazardous journey to India in quest of Buddhist scriptures. He did not return to Changinan until 645, and spent the remainder of his life translating a great many of the Buddhist texts he had brought back.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER

title: Foolproof Plaster Patchwork
description: THERE are times when a section of a plaster ceiling or wall is rotten and crumbly, possibly because of water damage, and a sizable patch is needed. Often even the fairly skilled doinitinyourselfer is afraid to tackle the job. To reinplaster he would haie to nail up lath, then apply several coats of plaster, and finally smooth out the last coat.

title: Out But Not Silent
description: Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav author and dissident, has been released from prison, the beneficiary of an amnesty declared by Belgrade to mark Yugoslavia's national day, Nov. 29. Mr. Mihajlov said upon his release that he would continue to comment on Yugoslavian affairs even at the risk of new imprisonment. He credited the current EastWest conference on human rights in Belgrade for winning his freedom after serving two years of a seveninyear term imposed 1975 when he was convicted of propagating antigovernment material. The amnesty affects 723 prisoners, some of whom have been released and some of whom have had their sentences reduced. About 30 percent were defined by the Government as political prisoners.

title: TV VIEW

Indeed, when searching for their most damaging terms of contempt, stage and film critics automatically voke unflattering comparisons to television oroeramming.

title: A Friendly Rivalry Within the U.S.E.T.
description: International riders concentrate on finishing ahead of members of rival teams. That is the name of the game, but sometimes, they derive pleasure at the thought of beating their own teammates.

This is Wickecheoke Cteek, complete with a treed island and which flows toward the Delaware River five miles farther west.

Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tener of Plandome and Bellport, L. I. financier, civic leader and philanthropist.

description: WESTFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26 (4P).1State Representative Garreth J.. title: Sunday Observer
description: I have a doodad tree in the living room. In New York you have to put up with things like that. All the vital people of New York go in heavily for parlor greenery, which is natural, considering that when they step outside, the landscape is mostly cement and high blood pressure.

title: Death Penalty in Manila
description: Benigno S. Aquino, a former Senator and once the chief political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos the Philippines, has been sentenced to death by a military court on charges of subversion, murder, and illegal possession of firearms. Few, however, expect Mr. Aquino to be executed, since only one person, a narcotics dealer, has been executed since martial law was imposed by Mr. Marcos five years ago. Moreover, there are serious doubts over the merits of the case, since much of the testimony against Mr. Aquino came from two former guerrillas who turned state's witness to avoid their own prosecution, and, after testifying, met violeni deaths. If Marcos believes I'm guilty, said Mr. Aquino. after the sentencing, then I want to be shot tomorrow.

title: A Second Mate at 11,  Oceanside High Senior Becomes PartyBoat Owner at 18 After Death of Capta
description: OCEANSIDE, L I.  When Michael Danon, an 18yearinold at Oceanside High School, became the youngest partyinboat owner on the Freeport water front last month, no one along the Wooddeft Canal was surprised. The 5foot7ch, 118pound youth has been fishing on the Capt. Lou II, a 45footer powered by a singleinscrew diesel engine, since he was 5.

title: The Arms Race:
description: Thirty years after the start of the cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union still live in a state of uncertainty and insecurity. In America, this condition has been attributed from the start to the aggressiveness of Soviet Communism, which is seen as striving for world hegemony and bent on the destruction of its principal obstacle, the United States. In Moscow, just as consistently, the guilt has been assigned to the evil designs of American militarism and imperialism.

Analysis and travel diary are part of the author's determination to rescue Americans from their willful ignorance of the many ways which our national policy contributes to the continuing destitution of most of the world's Population.

title: ZAIRE PLANS INDUCEMENTS FOR FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Nov. 26 (AFP) President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has announced a national economic recovery nlan to attract foreign vestment.

title: Mary E. Tucker And John Grim To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Duane Tucker Jr. of Pelham, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Evelyn Tucker, to John Alan Grim, son of Mrs. de Forrest Grim of Fargo, N.D., and the late Mr. Grim. The wedding is planned for the summer.

title: A Sailor's Dream Becomes Reality
description: GROTON DAVID HAYS is a salty dog from way back. He has spent most of his life on and around boats and still holds a sailing record for a 1963 transAtlantic voyage. When he decided to build a home in eastern Connecticut to be near the Waterfordbased National Theater of the Deaf, where he is company director, he told the realty agent he was interested only in shore property.

title: BRIDGE
description: Until a decade ago the admistrative headquarters of the American Contract Bridge League were  midtown Manhattan, a legacy of the days when most of the topinranked players and most of the major tournaments were located  or near New York and Philadelphia. After a oriet sojourn  Greenwich, Conn., the headquarters were moved  1972 to Memphis, Tenn., where a substantial staff handles such matters as membership, supplies, publicity, and tournament organization.

title: Cold Spring Harbor Estate Gives 50 Blind Residents a Sense of Beauty
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.There is a postcard view of Cold Spring Harbor from the veranda of the majestic Georgian mansion at the top of the bluff. And  this season there is a carpet of red and gold leaves that covers the garden where azaleas grow  warmer weather.

title: Article 3  No Title
that's Doing in LONDON
description: POST JUBILEEYou can still buy a Jubilee ballinpoint pen, complete with a leather thong to hang it around your neck, or a pocket notebook with the Queen's portrait on the cover. But they have pulled down the bunting on the Mall and in Trafalgar Square, and it is once again possible to drive through central london for two or three minutes without seeing a tour bus. The great celebration of Queen Elizabeth's 25 years on the throne is over, and London is recovering its normal aspect. Normal, meaning that the streets are still full of Continental nonBritons, Arab nonBritons, North American nonBritons and East Asian nonBritons, here for a week, a month, a year or a lifetime. Oldintimers complain that the bloody place is full of foreigners, but it always has been, and the economy would be in far worse shape if it were not.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The specter of breast cancer haunts most women. Fears of mutilation, lost attractiveness and death make the issue highly emotional, and the continuing medical controversy over methods of detection and treatment only heightens anxiety. Last week, dispute centered on whether or not a nationwide screening program to find small tumors by mammography has led to unnecessary breast removals.

title: Putting Federal Money Where It's Needed Is Hard as Ever
description: WASHINGTONLong ago, back in the Nixon and Ford years, the favorite verbs of the bureaucratic wordincoiners were prioritize and impact. They used to say, for example, that they wanted to prioritize the way block grants impact on the cities.

title: INVESTING
description: This has been a rocky year for Old King Coal, the country's acetheinhole hydrocarbon that is expected to bear an creasing share of the energy burden.

title: A Very Personal House of Worship
description: BRIDGEPORT IHAVE been a freshman of sorts for the last four or five years. I was struck by my unique spot recently as I stepped down to go to mass. Usually one walks up a lot of stairs to go to church, and somehow even that gesture is intimidating. But this particular place is more like a cellar or grotto, with dimly lit candles and plain white walls. It is a place conducive to intimacy.

title: Francis Gorman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank. T. Gorman Jr. of PrincetoO, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Thorpe Gorman, to Samuel Ray Whitby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ray Whitby of Brodnax, Va. The wedding is planned for May.

title: The Japanese Presence Inobtrusively Makes Itself Felt
description: Hideo Kitayama has been in this country since 1923, when he was 20 years old. He has lived in New York since he was released from a Japanese relocation camp after World War H. One of his fondest memories is of West 65th Street. He remembers it as a place where, in the days before Lincoln Center, many of his countrymen lived and worked, giving the area the makings of a very little Little Japan.

title: Unbeaten Texas Storms Into Cotton Bowl, 5728
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 26Hook Em Horns was the message on the orange and white buttons and bumper stickers of Longhorn football fans. And the members of the splendid nilversity of Texas team not only hooked the Texas Aggies, but also ground them into the Astroturf of Kyle Field today and won the Southwest Conference's decisive game decisively, 5728.FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 26 (AP) A freshman halfback, Larry Jones, rushed for 177 yards on a schoolinrecord 41 carries as Colorado State, staying on the ground because of strong winds, beat Utah State, 1310, today in the season finale for both teams.

title: A New Art: Cooling Off Conflict
description: Something there is that doesn't love a wall, and often enough, it's the neigbors. But that kind of neighborhood dispute, along with community controversies, prison uprisings, property battles, boycotts and an assortment of bfiliwicks that until now led to long legal actions and unsatisfactory outcomes, may soon be settled in a more simple, civilized and satisfactory fashion. The technique: conflict resolution.

title: Broker Weds Mimi Clarkson
description: Marie Covington Clarkson, daugbter of Loraine Stockstrom He Clarkaor of St. Louis and George W. Clarkson a New York terior designer, war married  St. Louis yesterday tc Charles Frederick Bates 3d, son of Mr and Mrs. Bates 2d, also of St. Louis, Msgr. James Hartnett performed the ceremony . the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunziata.

title: New Orleans Cattle Venture Described as a Hoax
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26A socially prominent New Orleans lawyer, a member of this city's most exclusive clubs, has touched off an vestigation to what his former law partners describe as a bogus vestment venture, allegedly Involving a nonexistent herd of cattle and the disappearance of more than a million dollars.

title: An AllRutgers Exhibition
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE 12 From Rutgers, a display of the works of 12 contemporary artists graduated from the university, may turn out to be one of the most controversial shows held in New Jersey this year.

title: Status Maker
description: IT has taken a New York man to make New Jersey conscious of the fact that it has an identity. The man, Bernard Bush, executive director of the New Jersey Historical Commission, feels that most residents of the state are not aware of its accomplishments, and he is doing much through the written word, symposiums and exhibitions to awaken the natives.

title: Damascus Says It Will Take Part In a Refusal Summit  Libya
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 26Syria rejected Egypt's proposal tonight for a preliminary meeting to prepare for a Geneva conference. Foreign Mister Abdel Halim Khaddam said: We will not go to Geneva and we are all going to a refusal summit  Tripoli on Thursday.

title: AXEL GROSSER
description: Axel Grosser, a specialist  architectural photography who had his own laboratory  Manhattan during the 1960's and early 1970's, died Friday at the Pascack Valley Hosiptal  Westwood, N.J., following a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived  Washington Township, N.J.

title: Constance Smith Bride Of Robert Joseph Doris
description: Constance Bagley Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Porter Smith of Tucson, Ariz., and Robert Joseph Doris, son of Associate Justice John F. Doris of the Supreme Court of Rhode Island, and Mrs. Doris of Woonsocket, were married yesterday  Tucson.

title: Psychiatrist Sued on a Sex Charge
description: Three wcmen have each filed su:t for $4 million against a.Manhattan psychiatrist whom they charge with willfully ducing them to engage  various sexual activities with him during therapy.

title: MINISTER SPONSORS HOMOSEXUAL RITUALS
description: During the Vietnam War the Weihington Square United Methodist Church acquired the nickname The Peace Church for its ministry to the antiwar movement. Now the current pastor of the church  Greenwich Village is extending its mistry to homosexual couples who seek an annroved Christian relationship.

title: RAISING HELL ON THE HIGHWAYS
description: I got 10 forward gears

title: Advertising
description: Money magazine, one of the new entries from Time Inc., will soon be announcing plans for its first special advertising insert. Everyone stems to be doing it.

title: News Summary
description: Washington is perplexedover how to react to the proposal Saturday by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt for a preliminary Middle East conference to convene in Cairo next Saturday, Administration officials said. As the Unites States weighed a reply, the Soviet Union, the other cochairman of the Geneva conference on the Middle East. remained silent. Moscow, like Washington, was apparently caught off guard and was seemingly concerned that plans for a Geneva meeting this year might fail because of Mr. Sadat's overtures. On American TV, Mr. Sadat said he was ready to negotiate in Cairo on procedures for a Geneva conference with Israel alone. [Page 1, Column 6.J

title: There Is a Season
description: WASHINGTONFor all things, the folk singers tell us, there is a season. A time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing; a time to criticize and a time to praise. This is a time to do both.

title: Denver Rolls to 10th Triumph. 2713
description: DENVER, Nov. 27When it comes to choosing Pro Bowl squads or allpro teams, young Bert Jones, the Baltimore quarterback, wins the votes and Craig Morton, the older Denver counterpart, does not. But in today's game the accolades went to the 33yardold Morton and the adversity centered on the 26yearold Jones who threw one too many passes to the shallow weakside zone.

title: JEROME F. HEALY JR., 73, WAS PARTNER IN LAW FIRM
description: Jerome F. Healy Jr., a lawyer and past president of the New York Athletic Club, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 468 King Avenue on City Island in the Bronx.

title: Leading Scientists, Including Four Nobel Laureates, Attracted to Conference Sponsored by Sun Myung Moon
description: Nobel laureates in particular, to make himself known in every corner of the world through his sponsorship of such conferences.

title: Music. Soprano
description: Mary Judd's reeital Alice Tully Hall Saturday night was a very correct, slightly formal occasion that traced the, prescribed song recital format. For openers there were the customary arie antiche (Handel, Pergolesi, Paisiello and Bononcini), followed by German lieder (Brahma, Strauss and Mahler), a couple of more dramatic  and (Beethoven and DVorik), and to wind things up four Italian songs with whiff of contemporary flavor by Cimara, Buzzi Pecciit and CastelnuovoTedesco.

title: 4 Military Officers in California Found Dead in Private Plane Crast
description: KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP)Rescue workers found the wreckage of a singleengine aircraft and the bodies of four military officers today in a remote area of Kings Canyon National Park. The plane, a private aircraft leased to a flying club at the Navy air station at Moffett Field, had been missing since yesterday.

title: Musical Risks Taken in Stride
description: Tom Johnson's Risks for Unrehearsed Performers, presented at the Kitchen on Saturday night, was a risky enterprise indeed. The four performersRichard Stoltzman on clarinet, David Reck on the Indian veena, Lukas Foss on piano and Emily Derr singing sopranohad no idea what they would be asked to do until they opened the white boxes that were sitting in the middle of the performing space. Had they known, one wonders whether they would all have taken the risk.

title: Marijuana Smoking in Public Increases As Penalties Drop
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27Thousands of marijuana smokers lit up handrolled cigarettes at A Day on the Grass here this month, and there was not a single arrest. Crowds of Cleveland youths recently enjoyed a public smokein with equal impunity.

title: Commodities
description: The coffee futures trade is divided over whether there was an attempt recently to corner the market in green beans. Fears of a corner provoked severe Federal and New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange restrictions on the expiring futures contract. Page 52.

title: CARL LATHAM
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif., Nov. 26 (UPI) Carl Latham, who retired as day city editor of The San Francisco Chronicle in 1972, died at John Muir Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Carter at Services in Hangar
description: THURMONT, Md., Nov. 27 (UPI)President Carter attended worship services in a helicopter hangar at Camp David with 300 military personnel and their families today. A pulpit was set up on a platform in the hangar with two candles, an open Bible and a cross. Lieut. Col. Cecil D. Reed, the chaplain from nearby Fort Ritchie, conducted the service.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP)In defiance of their international officers, striking members of a machinists union local voted todaY,to accept a threeyear contract proposal and return to work at Lockheed Missiles and Space Company's Sunnyvale plant.

title: Wrong Neighborhoods Got Funds On Poverty, Goldin Audit Charges
description: Nearly $20 million in poverty funds has been spent in the wrong neighborhoods during the last four years because of a failure to use uptodate data on where New York City's poor are living, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: Labor Dispute Raises the Issue: Can the U.N. Be Sued?
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.. Nov. 26  A decision by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has started a debate in the Secretariat over whether the United Nations must honor its collectivebargaining agreements and whether it can be taken to court if it does not.

title: This Day the Jets Were Any Team
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers, who needed 40 years to reach the National Football League playoffs for the first time, showed up in Shea Stadium yesterday with their sixth consecutive division championship dead in their sights. We're hurting defensively, said Ed Kiely, their director of public relations, but it's a strong team. We can beat any team in the league, and we can also lose to any team.

title: Shopping Rush Gets Down to Business
description: For retailers, Sunday was a busy day. Pedestrians were five deep at Macy's as entertainers performed, above, and one shopper just had to rest after adding to purchases at Korvettes. Even pretzel vendors, right, were doing brisk business on a wintry day; page 35. Merchants around the nation are expecting banner season in sales. Page 49.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 27 (AP)George Johnson blocked three shots in the last three minutes and scored a key free throw to lead the New Jersey Nets to a 9996 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics in a National Basketball Associationgame tonight.

title: Lisbon Government Near Collapse As Talks on Fiscal Problems Fail
description: LISBON, Nov. 28 (UPI)  A breakdown in talks with Portugal's opposition over fiscal policy has pushed the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares to the brink of collapse after 16 months of minority rule.

title: AfghansAct to Halt Opium ProductionbutProblemsRemain
description: JALALABAD, AfghanistanIn an initiative financed largely by the United States, the Afghan Government has strengthened its efforts to halt the illegal cultivation of opium poppies.

title: Commodities An Effort to Corner Coffee?
description: Was there an attempt to corner or manipulate the expiring December coffee futures delivery? If so, could it have succeeded?
